description:
We were craving burritos after a hike and came here for a quick lunch! Around 2PM on a Saturday afternoon, the restaurant was pretty empty. There's not that many high top tables but we were able to snag two to combine together for our group of five.  

The menu is comprehensive with tacos, rice bowls, burritos, etc. In addition to the normal stuff (carne asada, pollo, etc.), they also have a TON of veggie options for your vegetarian friends and some specials (shrimp). 

I wasn't super adventurous, so I went with the chicken burrito with whole black beans, spanish rice, and the spinach tortilla wrap. Everyone's orders came with a small bowl of tortilla chips and a BOMBBBBB sauce/salsa(?). The sauce was sooooo good I couldn't help but finish my entire bowl of chips. Then I continued to pour the sauce over my burrito until it was all gone. The burrito itself was also very well done. In particular, I like that they toast the tortilla so that it has a nice crispy exterior and soft interior. They also do not skimp on any of the filling. The chicken in particular was super tender and super juicy. I wouldn't have minded just a plate of the chicken and rice on their own!

Bus your own trays after you finish your meal! There is a box of foil on the counter for your to pack up your monstrous burrito if you don't happen to finish it! 

Pro tip: the sauce/salsa is supposedly available for purchase at Whole Foods for all of you fans!!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Ordered Shrimp Quesadillas here with extra Sour Cream and Guacamole here however the extras were never served. 

They charged me and then refuse to make the right one. Avoid this Mexican place at all cost, the don't do honest business here.
author: S J.

description:
I *love* their salsa so we decided to come try it in-person. I was somewhat disappointed they don't have a free salsa bar so you can try all their salsas. 

We split a carne asada super burrito - all burritos come with a side of chips and salsa which was nice. We also ordered an extra side of chips & salsa so we didn't have to share and overall that was plenty of food for two people. 

The burrito was average so I would recommend going to El Farolito or El Castillito in the Mission for more flavorful burritos and free salsa bars.  I'll stick to buying Papalote's salsa from the grocery store which is truly delicious ($6.99 per bottle)
author: Stephanie L.

description: came here so that E could try the Triple Threat Burrito.  He ordered light rice.  As you can see, it's massive so I can only imagine if rice was included.  The thing would be the size of his arm!  He said it was really good.  He actually was only able to eat half and took the rest back to the room.  I guess I would recommend.  In my opinion, kinda of pricey.  $9 for 2 carne asada tacos is a bit much in my opinion so I didn't eat anything!  He said he would get again!
author: Lynette C.

description:
Papalote on Fulton is pretty fantastic. They offer several great options for vegans with completely vegan beans - whole black beans, whole pinto and black refried! That's outstanding! Their rice is vegan too which is nice (if you're vegan, don't assume your rice is vegan). They also have two other great vegan protein options - marinated tofu and vegan soyrize (both are nice savory). The fact that they actually use the word "vegan" on the menu means that they take this type of dietary lifestyle seriously. I can't thank them enough for doing this.

Their food is very good. Each time I've been here either by myself or with a group of friends, the experience has been excellent. They really know how to make great Mexican food. From great tortillas to spicy tasty salsa, this places has something for everyone. The interior is a bit of a mess but their consistently excellent food more than makes up for it.
author: Theart P.

description:
Came here yesterday after running at Kezar.  Found parking right I front of the store-- which is a plus! Overall experience was great!  The line wasn't very long.  

The employees were friendly.  

We ordered:

Chicken burrito - which was just ok for my taste.  Nothing special about it.  But I guess you add the papalote sauce and it suppose to make it taste better. 

Carne asada  burrito - my husband loved it.  He said it was tasty.  He doesn't really order carne asada burrito anywhere but he enjoyed it this one.  

1 Beer (modelo)

Total bill was $34 - which is a lot for 2 burritos and beer- so I took off one star for their price.  I think it's too pricey. 

Would I come back?  Prolly not.  There are much tastier and fairly priced burritos in the city.
author: Junaline G.

description:
The food is 2-3 stars, nothing special. It's quite overpriced, even for San Francisco.

Customer service is a different story....

One of the employees dropped their famous salsa all over my backpack. The dish clattered to the floor. Sprayed salsa on my jacket, shirt, and head. 

Not even an apology was given. Dude literally gave me a rag and walked away. Had to go to the counter and ask for a PLASTIC BAG to put my jacket in because it was covered in salsa. 

Also asked for a refund and they still charged me for a coke.

Sorry, if my friend has to help me clean SALSA FROM MY HAIR, you should give me a full refund. It's basic customer service.
author: Sheila G.

description: I'm confused why it's only 3 stars....I honestly think Papalote is one of the best FRESH burritos in the city. They have a location in the Mission as well. I usually get the super burrito with carne asada. BOM DOT COM.
author: Jenn L.

description: The burrito was great!!!! But waaaay overpriced! I paid $15 for carbe asada burrito...i can get 2 burritos in the Mission for d same price.
author: Shena L.

description:
I'll start by saying I'm impressed with the vegan options at such an authentic Mexican spot. We ordered the soyrizo tacos, and a burrito with tofu as the meat. 
The soyrizo tacos were a major hit, there was so much flavor in them & I would definitely recommend them. The tofu burrito was not my favorite. I added refried beans, Spanish rice, with a whole wheat tortilla. (Almost all the burrito options are vegan) Everything in the burrito tasted fine except the tofu. I've had my fair share of tofu tacos and burritos and this was not the best. The tofu isn't cut small enough so it ends up being quite chewy with no flavor inside. The refried beans, however, were great & I still ate a good amount of the burrito. Next time I would switch the tofu for soyrizo and call it a day.

Also their "famous" salsa was really nothing special. The flavor and spice really weren't there at all. Which, we were pretty disappointed about because we love salsa.

I'd still recommend this restaurant though, as it is hard to find good vegan Mexican food.
author: Brittany W.

description: I ordered here because I was close by and I love the 24th st location, but i found the chicken mole burrito to be very dry and not as good as the other location.  Ok, just not great.
author: Vivian W.

description: It's good but the prices are too high for what it is. Ordered a burrito while the place was empty and I watched them dick around for almost 10 min before finally starting it. This with a staff of 4.
author: Greg S.

description:
Still the BEST FISH BURRITO in town! Good to know the food quality here never changes.

I used to live down the street from here and ate here all the time. My go to was the fish burrito, super with cheese guac sour cream, and rice and beans on the side. You absolutely have to get the rice and beans on the side because the white fish cooked in white wine and butter is so delicate that the competing textures and flavor just take too much away from the fish itself. Trust me on this. You can change up the tortilla by getting a whole wheat, spinach or tomato tortilla but don't screw around by adding rice and beans.

Their house salsa is still the best salsa I have ever had and I grew up in SoCal which is the Mecca of Mexican food. I can honestly drink this salsa by the bucketful. It's a great compliment to their thin, crispy, and warm tortilla chips which come free with your food order whether you dine in or order for take out. Extra container of salsa will cost you $0.50 but it goes great in that fish burrito. 

I was passing through the neighborhood today so had to stop by for my usual burrito and chips. I sat for a bit to enjoy my chips and salsa, then asked to get my burrito to go. 

Service is always quick and friendly whether you dine in or order to go. Seating can be tricky since tables are limited but that's never stopped me from coming in. The guys who cook the food are super cool. I always make sure to pop my head over the counter to say "thank you" before I leave.
author: Betty R.

description: Papalote is quick, convenient, reliable, tasty, and has options for everyone. While I wouldn't consider their food to be one of the best Mexican in the city, their food is consistently delicious. Complimentary chips and salsa? Amazeballs. I can honestly just drink their salsa, so I always order extra on the side.  Even when I order them for delivery, the burritos and chips would arrive nice and hot. They have a good variety of vegetarian options as well and all are super yummy. Definitely one of my go to neighborhood Mexican joints.
author: Nana L.

description:
A horrid burrito only made worse by the $14 price tag. I regularly pay $16 for my burritos, but at papito's and papi's - it's worth every penny. 
College dorm food at it's worst here. On a college campus, makes sense I suppose. 
I would've resisted the urge to write a review if the food wasn't insanely overpriced and as bad as it is.

Sorry, guys. It needed doing.
author: Dan B.

description:
My friend Justin took me to Papalote last week for dinner for the first time. Let's just say I was extremely pleased with the entire experience. 

I ordered the eggs and chorizo burrito, a classic breakfast for me. Every bite of it was extremely delicious. It was one of the best egg and chorizo burritos I think I've ever had, and that's quite a lot. 

The burrito is slightly overpriced in my opinion. While it is large and very good, paying over $10 for a burrito is excessive in my mind. But it's not going to stop me from going back. 

On top of the burrito itself, the salsa was delicious. I know how proud they are of their salsa for beating Bobby Flay, but even just knowing that didn't prepare me for it. It's literally the perfect salsa. And I went and got 2 jars from Whole Foods the day after trying it. 

I'll be back to try the Chile Verde burrito very very soon.
author: Nick D.

description:
Bobby Flay was rightfully beaten by Papalote, have you tried their salsa? Jarred it loses something but if you get in in-person, wow, it is one of the top salsas I've ever had. Although they are pretty stingy with it...

Burrito-wise (you come here for burritos, FYI), there are really only three choices to consider. If you like steak, get carne asada. If you are on a diet, get pollo asado. If you are on whatever the opposite of a diet is, get a "triple threat", which I think is beef, chicken, and shrimp.

I don't know how anything else tastes at Papalote, because all I've ever ordered is burritos. Make sure you get refried black beans! I cannot stand whole beans in burritos, it's so gross, and of course Spanish rice, not brown rice.

The quality at Papalote is high, but there are a few downsides. Of course, they are super stingy with their salsa. Charging $0.50 for extra salsa is ridiculous, salsas should be free and unlimited. It's not like it's got truffles in it, it's like 90% tomatoes!

Another downside is the wait, they take ages to make a burrito, even when you're the only one there. I don't know why, since a lot of the ingredients are sitting around, but that's what it is. Finally, with tax you are looking at about $14 for a super burrito. That is... too much. Even for SF. At $9.99 it's a steal, but at that price they are getting into sit down territory.
author: Sm L.

description:
First and last time i do to this place. 
$13  shrimp for a regular size burrito
(expected it to be at lest a bit bigger for the price) 
-the refried beans were super watery 
-burrito itself consisted of mainly rice and beans with a total of 5 shrimps 

As a fist time shopper here the service was horrible employees seem more concentrated on having chats with one another and the person taking orders seems to not understand the words "would u like to add in.." instead he just said sour-cream, cheese, and guacamole. Which i had asked him if it came with it or not.

Overall i ended up spending almost $18 on a very soggy burrito and a bag of crushed chips (yes they just though the burrito on top of a bag that had chips
author: Kelly C.

description:
Best Vegan Nachos in SF! 

Papalote does an amazing job at grilling tofu! Add it to your nachos or burritos! Not to mention their salsa is da bomb! It's so good they even sell jars of it at their shop and in Whole Foods.

Vegans and veg heads enjoy
author: Maude B.

description: Best salsa in town! That smoked tomato flavor is divine. Plus some of the best fish tacos north of the border
author: Amir M.

description:
TLDR; Fresh ingredients and good side items at inflated prices

----

"Hello darkness my old friend," you whisper to yourself as you kiss the rusted cylinder of your '55 Model 29 revolver and hot load a .44 special cartridge into the weathered chamber, giving it a quick flick of the thumb to watch it spin and let chaos sort out the facts. 

You snuggle the cold nozzle to your temple. 

"I heard there was a secret chord," you murmur, as your arthritic finger pulls back on the ancient trigger. 

It squeezes through the point of mechanic tension. 

Click.

"Not today," you surmise. "Not today."

You gather your supplies and start to set about on your way but then you hear it. 

"Ehhhh...!...Papalote...EeeEhhh..."

"PapeeEEhhh...papapaEhhehh..."

"perpa...perpalordie...!...?...peralolaeeeee..."

You see a pod of Echo-Force 1, the elite spec-ops unit of the Ukrainian militarized dolphins that came through The Chasm and partied on spring break and enslaved the vast majority of humankind through advanced interstellar-technology and military strategy, get in line to order Papalote. 

Being dolphins from outer space, they don't understand how overpriced and terribly bland the food is. As an advanced species that has figured out how to surpass the speed of light and make left turns between the hours of 1-5pm, they should be aware of the food situation.   

There's something different about this pod though. This pod is on high guard. 

That's when you see him. 

The Supreme Leader, Rick. 

Rick the Dolphin. 

https://www.yelp.com/biz/7-eleven-san-francisco-16?hrid=iusTS9azVdjaaEiNOkVTvQ

You stand in acceptance, perhaps in defiance, of your pre-destined journey, and take a step forward. A step forward to Rick and The Chasm...the shimmering tear in the dimension that brought the Others. 

You lock eyes with Rick and both of you acknowledge your shared past. A breath of memories.

Rick raises.

You draw....

Bang.

The air barks and a lump of lead jumps out of rest, composing itself long enough to slide peacefully through the salt-watered skull of a fish that tried to live and rule on land.  

"It goes like this, the pork the fish..." you pray to the forgotten gods, holstering your iron. You walk off.
author: Dave G.

description: My favorite burrito. In the world. When I first moved to SF, I found this little place on one of my first days in the city, walked over and got a burrito. I've been obsessed ever since (and have gotten my three roommates obsessed as well!!). All the food is super delicious and really fresh. And don't get me started on their salsa - it's a huge reason to go there!! I've moved back to LA and out of all the incredible food I tried in SF, Papalote will always be my fave (and the first thing I go get when I visit!!)
author: Riley L.

description:
Good location, good salsa. Mediocre and soggy everywhere else. The 2 stars are solely for the salsa; at least they got one thing right. Papalote has potential, but after several visits Papalote has been consistently overpriced and underwhelming.

For $10+ you get (2) soggy tacos and are asked to pay extra for salsa, guacamole, cheese, and sour cream. This was what I received for $10.44 after tax; 2 tortillas, over cook/over seasoned chicken, lettuce, tomato. Do yourself a favor and go to Taco Bell.
author: Ryan D.

description: Great place for a burrito! If there was one thing recommend, it's the salsa. Whether it's with the burrito or chips, the salsa really was the clincher. Chips seemed fresh and with some salt they were perfection.
author: Robert J.

description: Not sure how I felt about this place at first until I tasted their papalote sauce. The food is GOOD. It is tasteful, fresh, and of good quality, but the sauce makes it stand out from other taquerias. I've only had their burrito and burrito bowl, but both have continuously kept me coming back for more. Make sure to get a side of chips and papalote sauce, you won't regret!
author: Kassie E.

description: This place was nasty. I shouldve turned around the moment I walked in when all the tables were disorganized and there was garbage everywhere. I made the mistake of ordering and was disappointed with soggy tacos smothered in lettuce. No redeeming qualities to this place. How are they even passing health inspections? Nasty.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I've been a loyal papalote customer for years and just ended up with the saddest burrito and I'm really hoping it's a one-off. But seriously, the burrito was half its usual size and the amount of chips that came with it about a quarter of the usual amount. And I ordered it super, but I'm halfway through it now and haven't seen anything but black beans. 

There are so few things I can still afford in this city, so for the love of all that is holy on earth, please don't let this be what papalote becomes.
author: Nicki L.

description: I love this place the dip or sauce that comes with the chips is unique not sure what is it called but definitely worth a try . I tried the   Asada burrito and a side of Spanish rice and beans no complaints excellent will come again for sure
author: Hashem K.

description:
What happened to their special house sauce?
Been coming here sporadically since it's beginning and have now experienced what old San Franciscans have complained about for years- another victim of high cost operations, labor, etc.
and it shows now with watered down or diluted house salsa (see photo ) that used to be one of the best in the City.  How this locale rates as a "$ out of $$$$" astounds me- $14.01 for a super carne asada burrito- comes with that extra penny for your thoughts and good luck making those USF students think twice for putting $1.99 to add sour cream and guacamole.  To be fair this burrito is still delicious & quite the belly bomb but damn now it's more like a wallet bomb.  Seriously what happened to this spot?  Just because this place got featured on an old bobby flay food network spot, Papalote can't ride that high horse no more.  The sauce here is no longer boss, adios.
author: vince r.

description: Love coming here every Monday And Wednesday as I have class those days and I walk to school from the FIDI all the way to the John Adams campus.  The papalote sauce is absolutely to di3 for and love getting the burrito bowl without the wrap. I like the pescado (fish). Soooo yummy.  Miguel, the co-owner and executive chef, is nice and treats everyone well and keeps his customers coming back.  I love papalote's!!!
author: Jill P.

description:
The only shrimp burrito I eat. 

I finally figured out my perfect burrito recipe:

Buttered shrimp with peppers but no mushrooms 
Rice
Refried beans 
Cheese
No pico

Was pipping hot by the time I got it home to the sunset. Consistently delicious last three times I ordered it. Buttered shrimp are so memorable and fill my belly with warm fuzzies. :)

But the size and price components don't compute for me. $15 for a 1/2 inch diameter burrito? :(

I mean, it is a terrific shrimp burrito but the prices are despicable. Especially when it's hella little and contains only four shrimp total. Whaaaaaaaa
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Love the food here but the customer service tonight was terrible. I picked up a to-go order around dinnertime that I had already called in, and twice the cashier stepped away from the register while I was trying to purchase my food to help a courier who was also picking up food for a food-delivery app/service. If no other customers are at the register and I walk up, I expect for them to help me before helping other customers who have walked in the door after me. 

I've been coming here since 1999 (I live in the neighborhood) and with the increased prevalence of food delivery services it seems like customer service for in-person customers has gone downhill.
author: Lindsay E.

description: I just had a terrible experience here tonight. We ordered two veggie burritos, one naked veggie burrito and a side of guacamole. As soon as I opened the guacamole it looked like the top of turned all brown so I investigated and it was all that weird brownish green color all the way through ... Same on my naked burrito a big glob of brown horrible guacamole and same in the burrito... It ruined the food and was disgusting. I can't believe a restaurant would allow that type of guacamole out the door.  Also, the carrots tasted rotten and I'm a little worried I'm going to get food poisoning from eating a few bites of what I just ate tonight.  We composted everything after those few bites.  When I called they did refund my money for anything that had guacamole but did not refund my daughters cheese quesadilla or a side of black beans. This is fine, though I live very far away so the other three of us in my family were left without any food. I won't be going back here anytime soon. And would not recommend that you do either.
author: Bridget J.

description: Pretty much paid $12 for a carne asada burrito that is essentially a rice burrito with hardly any meat [regular burrito with no sour cream or guac]. Still love the orange sauce and the fresh sauce is still better than the jarred one you can get at the market. They'll fill up a mason jar of the fresh stuff for you for $8ish.
author: Mimi L.

description:
Re-posting since this was removed for promotional content. If someone knows what's promotional in this, please let me know as I would love to know and adjust my reviews accordingly. Thanks!

-----

The last time I had Papalote was years ago when I grabbed a couple burritos on the way home. When the roommate mentioned he wanted Mexican for lunch, we found Papalote on DoorDash. Placed an order for delivery Sunday, January 10th around 1:25pm. The food arrived around 2pm.

Prices below are what we paid using DoorDash. Comparing these to Papalote's online menu, some dishes were priced more and some less. We payed more for: the Burrito and Chile verde (+$0.55 each), making the burrito Super (+$0.51), and the Carne asada (+$0.20). The dishes priced less were: Chorizo con queso (-$0.25) and Chorizo con huevo (-$0.45). So depending on what you order, you may pay less for some items.

*Pollo asada burrito ($10.50): grilled chicken, Flour tortilla, Black refried, Make it super (+$2.50), No sour cream
*Chile verde ($17.50): tender chunks of pork cooked slowly in a tangy tomatillo and serrano pepper sauce
*Chorizo con queso ($9.50): melted jack cheese and chorizo
*Chorizo/soyrizo con huevo ($12.50): scrambled eggs with your choice, Chorizo, Rice and Beans on side
*Carne asada ($8.95): grilled steak, Tacos (2)

My favorite was the con queso. Super cheesy and delicious. I also got the chorizo egg burrito. Unfortunately, they gave me the soyrizo one. Disappointing as I really wanted the chorizo. Soyrizo is just not the same! Not sure who's fault this was, but we complained to DoorDash and got a $5.99 credit. Considering we didn't want the soyrizo, I think this should have been a full refund, but I guess that's not Paplote's fault. The carne asada tacos were okay. I wish I could have ordered just one as I didn't really want two tacos. The roommate got the chile verde and pollo asada burrito. He said they were alright. He's more of a carnitas guy.

The salsa IS as good as everyone says it is! I just wish they gave us more given the amount of food we ordered. They only gave us two containers. If I could have covered the soyrizo in that salsa, it might have been better.

I find it weird they don't have carnitas, but Paplote is a good option if you want the standard Mexican fare such as carne asada, pollo asada, etc. I, however, like meats such as cabeza, lengua and tripitas. But their salsa is to die for. Can I come by just for that?!
author: Elena N.

description: Wish I could give this place NO STARS! I went in the girl at the register named "Claudia" was rude! I ordered a chicken burrito and my daughter ordered a shrimp burrito. We sit down and start eating and my daughter says her shrimp taste weird. She gives me one, I smell it and it smells spoiled! My daughter spits hers out and I go to the register to tell the employees. (I noticed the whole time all the workers watched me and my daughter eat) I went up to tell this woman Claudia that the shrimp are spoiled. She says the shrimp they serve are not fresh and they keep them in a bucket in the fridge. I said okay why are you serving spoiled shrimp? She tastes it and says it's good. I told her I want my money back! She got an attitude and refunded the money for just the shrimp burrito. If my daughter is sick I'll have to report this place.
author: Teanna S.

description:
If you want a $12.30 subpar carne asada burrito with whole black beans, guacamole (I don't do cheese or rice) on a spinach tortilla, then eat here.  They didn't even have the decency to add lettuce and pico de gallo.   Super disappointing all the way around.

Bland flavor + the missing, standard burrito condiments x the exorbitant price = Thumbs down.  Waaaay down.
author: Ally C.

description: For the subpar food and above average prices, I expected decent customer service, at the very least. Dude made me feel guilty for asking for a fork to eat my burrito BOWL. I asked for another cup of salsa and they said .50 cents. Asked if they would take a card since that's all I had and they said no and gave me another cup, which I appreciated. What I didn't appreciate was the girl chuckling about it. Had I known it was extra and you were going to ridicule me for it, I would've paid for it earlier instead of tipping you. Also, their "famous" salsa has lost its touch and not even worth the .50 cents but the food was dry and I needed it.
author: Julia C.

description: I would not recommend this place. I've had way better Mexican food than this. We got the triple threat burrito which was priced way too much for the taste and quality. Paid $25 but it was worth $8.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I ate at Papalote for a second time yesterday with my cousin.
My first visit was great- carne asada.
Yesterday, I went for their soyrizo burrito.
It was good, but I think Papalote is not an authentic mexican food.
But overall, I give this place 4 stars; 3 stars for the food and 1 more star for the friendly service!
author: Candice L.

description:
Used to love this place, till I got the bill for a $13 vegetarian burrito. Top that off with being shady on getting more chips and salsa! 

Sorry Mr E, I have been coming here since before the TV apparences, now it seems like only the rich folks can afford it.
author: Wes W.

description: I'm a big fan and I believe I have given it a 5 star review in the past. My wife picked up 2 burritos and it was 26 dollars. 13 per burrito? Prices have gone up and it already was on the pricier side. I guess they are responding to basic supply and demand principles...
author: Marty J.

description:
The salsa is to die for!!! They sell them in jars if you're addicted like me and want some for home. I am always satisfied whenever I come here. The burritos are a decent size and I love that they roll it properly so you don't have to worry about everything falling apart. I recommend the carne asada or shrimp marinated in lime burrito. Your oder always comes with tortilla chips and a side of their chipotle salsa. I am taking one star off because every time I get a soft taco the tortilla ends up getting soggy way too fast from the tomatoes. 

Cashiers and cooks are always really friendly. The other day my friend wanted queso dip and they made it for her even though that's not something they needed to do since that's not a normal menu item.
author: Andrea R.

description:
I stopped purchasing food here a while ago due to dramatic price increases, but would still go in to get salsa.  Now they want well over $4 for 8 oz of salsa.  I'm finished with this place.

I do not understand how people can pay over $14 for a freaking burrito.  Even the employees are apologetic though I don't blame them.  Whoever sets the prices is just gouging people at this point.  While I don't mean to wish anyone misfortune, I do hope these price increases catch up with them and we get something else in its place.
author: Brian D.

description: Gave them another chance and just as terrible as before. This place used to be great, no idea what happened. Rude staff, overpriced bland food, and even the salsa isn't great like it used to be.
author: J P.

description:
Papalote is my guilty pleasure that I eat at more often than I should. I have tried a few things here but there are basically 2 that I consistently order and recommend-

Chicken mole: I usually get this in a burrito but the "naked burrito"/burrito bowl is good as well. The mole sauce is not the best but it is pretty good and while I haven't had a lot of mole in SF, this has been the best I've tried in San Francisco. The burrito normally comes with rice and beans but I just get it with guacamole, cheese, and sour cream. The quality varies but it is generally a pretty solid option and a good thing to order if hungry. I strongly recommend getting the burrito with the papalote hot sauce (it's not that spicy) and not pico de gallo.

Nachos: The nachos are simple yet good. I also get them with Papalote hot sauce instead of pico and usually with refried beans and sometimes carnitas. They use shredded cheese and not nacho sauce and quite a lot of it. These are a great option if you've been drinking; when I have had them at other times, they are kind of overwhelming. 

They do have a dining room but I usually either order on the phone and pick it up to go or order through Postmates (the fact that you can get delivery is a little too convenient). The food at this location is definitely not as great as the location in the Mission but it's still a pretty good (though probably slightly overpriced) Mexican option.
author: Seema U.

description: Good.  We stopped by on the way to nearby USF and had a couple of chicken tacos, chicken burrito, and a carne asada burrito.  Everything was good, and chips and salsa came with it as well.  Loved the salsa.  Service was efficient.  Place is small but we were able to find a table for 4.  Portions were generous as well.
author: Ronny T.

description:
So a shrimp, a chicken, and a cow walk into a bar.

Aaaand that's it - that's the whole story.

There's no punchline.

Because the Triple Threat Burrito is no joke.

+ Also a Chicken Adobo x Garlic Rice Burrito #señeezysiseezy
- Don't sit by the smelly trash cans
author: Dan B.

description: Gross. IDKW people like this spot. I've lived in the 'hood for a long time and occasionally drop in or quesadillas, nachos or a burrito and it's never been good, except for the salsa, but even that seems to now be bad. The past 2x I've gotten food here it tastes like cleaning chemicals. Gross. Gross. Gross. Save your money and eat elsewhere.
author: Stacey K.

description:
I like Papalote but there are a few things to note. 

- it's more expensive then many taquerias. Which isn't to say it's overpriced but I always feel like the total is more than I expect

-Food is generally tasty, but I don't really crave anything there. 

- Salsa is SUPER delicious. I buy it at the store nearby all the time. 

- Restaurant space isn't anything special 

Basically I go there from time to time but just do t ever feel wowed by my food
author: John-Mark I.

description: Good food, amazing salsa, but overpriced for what you get. Chicken fajitas were $18.95 and the amount of chicken included was way too little. Burritos are solid but again, not enough meat for what you pay.
author: David N.

description:
Worst place ever!!!!! 
I got into the place and ask for a carne Asada the girl  in the cashier was rude to me didn't take my order correctly even though I told her exactly what I want and requested with no dairy I got a burrito instead and when I came to replace it she accused me for not mentioning it 
I am allergic to dairy and don't want to think what would've happened if I've had this dish
All in all bad customer service  !!!!!?
author: Shay T.

description: After living in SF for the past 2 years, I've decided that this is the best burrito in the area. I've lived in San Diego and LA so I like to think that I have high standards when it comes to Mexican food. Their chorizo is BOMB and they have the best salsa. The prices are a little high but the burritos are so big that they are like 2 separate meals. Also, this location is waaaaay better than the other one on 24th street.
author: Jordanne G.

description: Best burrito I've ever had and love the salsa. I am so glad the salsa is sold at Safeways now because I don't live in the city. No other place compares!
author: Miley B.

description: I keep coming back for the salsa. The food is good, but overpriced in my opinion. The salsa, however, is out of this world. It's a roasted tomato based salsa that I could eat by the jar. You can also get brown rice and whole wheat tortillas, which I like.
author: Emily F.

description:
This review is about the salsa and the establishment
You know... the life changing salsa?
Pedestrian at best. 
Watered down, tomato soup with flat seasoning.
Very dissatisfied.
Nice establishment but very evocative of gimmicky at it's best. I would have delighted in a simple burrito joint, hole in the wall, that just lived up to the hype.
author: Jamie T.

description: Over-rated and over priced. I just waited for 35 minutes for a quesadilla - not anywhere near a lunch or dinner hour. Had to get back in line after waiting because they made the wrong thing. Wayyy better Mexican food nearby for the same cost or less.
author: Matt B.

description: The food was ok but not worth the price. My husband and I got 2 bean and rice burrito with cheese (although I never saw any cheese) and it was $17. WHAT!!! Way too pricey for literally bean rice tortilla and salsa. Plus what I never tasted or saw cheese. Oh they do give you a small bowl of chips and orange dip sauce.
author: Paras B.

description:
Papalote all day!!!

My favorite burrito spot in SF. Fresh meat and veg, ample chips with a wide array of sauce, quick turnaround and usually plenty of seating.

Never a bad decision at Papalote.
author: Tara N.

description: I'm not sure what's happening at Papalote but the food is not the same. Maybe recipes have been modified? I don't remember how long it's been since I last came but the tacos used to be good; more meat, not watery, the salsa tastes different too. Today after having three orders of tacos I walked away feeling disappointed, can't justify the price. I think the tacos (now) are better if you don't get cheese, sour cream and guacamole as they take away a lot of the flavor. The lettuce and tomato also made the taco too watery and since there's barely any meat in there I was left trying to figure out exactly what I was eating, ended up scraping away everything and eating with a fork...taco blasphemy. Maybe it was just an off day, or maybe it was just a Monday. Will return on a taco Tuesday many full moons from now and try my luck again!
author: Uriel G.

description: The cashier here is so super unprofessional the cashier keeps exonerating all the time the cashier needs to shape it up the cashier needs to behave professionally or the cashier needs to be reprimanded due to unprofessional
author: GQ G.

description: Came here for a side of chicken, was charged 7 bucks for half a cup of cold meat, felt ripped off
author: Brian S.

description:
What happened to the days when you could get a burrito for $6!? 
The food here is good but way overpriced. I like that the meat is grilled to order and the veggies always fresh. But $12 for a super burrito!? 
I wish there were more Mexican options in the neighborhood but until then I'm going to keep paying $12 and keep on complaining :)
author: Sam A.

description: I ate here about five years ago and it was pretty good. I was there a couple of days ago and ordered a chicken mole plate with rice and beans.  The mole was very salty (and I like salt), but I had to take breaks to finish, and drink lots of water afterwards.  The chips had a funny taste, like they were sprayed with some kind of chemical.  Maybe it was lime, but it left a very strange taste in my mouth.  The salsa is not as good as I remembered, but still pretty tasty.
author: Liz L.

description:
Salsa alone is a million stars! I don't know why it's so good but I could eat it all day every day. Wish they weren't so stingy with it (you only get one small salsa with a burrito and chips).

The carne asada burrito is dabombdotcom! I always ask for them to char the outside on the griddle after making it-takes it to another level. 

One star off for not having sweet plantains like TLC. I also don't really like the tortilla chips...wish they were freshly fried taqueria-style chips.

Overall, solid burrito option in the City. Both locations are good and I've always had good service.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Decided to give this spot a try last night for dinner and i gotta say, it was pretty expensive for a burrito. It was $9.95 for the burrito with rice and beans which seems reasonable but obviously you gotta add cheese, guac and sour cream (which are each .99 extra!). So it ends up being a $14 burrito...the burrito itself was good, definitely not the best I've had but it was good. Not $14 good though. I did like how they grilled the tortilla, but not too sure I'd come back here.
author: Ilana B.

description: Simply the best! We order in from popalote all the time, the staff is nice, hard working and fast. You're order is always correct (and mine is admittedly complicated) but they always deliver delicious, fresh hot food that keeps us coming back... and that salsa tho!
author: Matt S.

description: It's a good spot with good food. I mostly order the chicken adobo burrito! My favorite.
author: Stewart M.

description:
Way overpriced Mexican food

I should have opt to get my hubby dinner somewhere else. I got a super carne asada quesadilla and at $10.51 with tax was not worth it! They wrapped the quesadilla in foil and it was so flat! :( isn't it suppose to be stuffed with uber goodness? Plus it was very salty. Below average Mexican food. I don't think I will go back here again. I should have went to Underdogs or even Chiptole.
author: Carol Y.

description: I've been here twice and have finished my burrito both times, it's so good! The salsa is amazing, I can't wait to go back!
author: K M.

description:
Papalote has good flavors, and a unique salsa. The foods is a little pricey, and they only offer you one salsa option with the complimentary chips.  

The salsa has a light orange color that I believe they get by olive garden emulsion.   They sell jars of their salsa at the ordering counter.

On this visit I ordered the salad w chicken.  The jicama and black beans w salsa bandera (pico) was good.  I appreciate they not over dressing the salad, I would not restrain myself from dousing it w the tasty chipotle ranch.
author: Marlon T.

description: Horrible customer service, dirty tables with rude employees. Paid $20 for burritos with no meat and just beans & rice, which was bland and watery and eating here caused my co-worker and I to have diarrhea for hours afterwards. The owner is aware of the situation and did nothing. Very unprofessional & unacceptable.
author: Crystal N.

description:
The best burritos and most amazing salsa! I've also tried the tacos here, which are good but nothing like the burritos. 

Tip: You can buy a jar of their homemade salsa and take it to go... which you totally should!
author: Jaching H.

description: This restaurant really deserves 2.5 stars. The only redeeming quality about the restaurant is it's cleanliness. The food is below average when it comes to mexican foods. You will have better luck finding better quality and more authentic Mexican eats in the mission district. The tortillas and salsa tasted a bit cold. The chicken in my tacos tasted like chicken you'd find in a fast food chicken salad. And no complimentary limes to drizzle over your tacos!! What's up with that?! If only this restaurant put as much effort in giving you great Mexican food as they give in keeping the restaurant looking nice, then there'd be a reason to come back here. I understand based on the location of this restaurant they may want to cater more to the American palatte, but I feel sorry for those who think this is an authentic take/experience on Latin American cuisine. Please look elsewhere for that.
author: Richard M.

description: The mission branch is my favorite burrito in town; just tried this location's chile verde for the first time, and it didn't live up to the high standards. I found the ingredient mix to be lacking (bites full of rice, then meat, then beans), and didn't seem to be grilled at all after being rolled. I'll give them another shot soon; maybe just an off night.
author: Derek M.

description:
Overpriced, tasteless Mexican food. 

Being that this place is less than a block away from my school, I had been dying to try it. Man was I let down. 

First of all, the burritos only come with your choice of beans, rice, meat and salsa for $9-11. Adding cheese, guacamole or sour cream is 99¢ each (or $1.99 for all three). Like, if I'm gonna pay that much, I might as well go to Chipotle. 

The shop is quite tiny. There's three tables and a bar. I'm learning that that's pretty average for SF though. 

The staff was really friendly though. Just disappointed with the quality and cost of food.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I can't believe it's been almost 9 years since my last review of Papalote. 

I still appreciate Papalote's Fish Burrito and I like that they don't batter their buttery wine marinated fish  - but I if I have to go another 9 years without another one of their burritos- I'd be totally fine.

I used to adore coating my burrito in Papalote's flavorful salsa. This evening I didn't. The salsa didn't have the same sass that it used to and after having learned recently that one of the main ingredients in their famous sauce is canola oil - I just didn't really want to. 

I also paid over three dollars for a side of their lack-luster guacamole. The portion size was disappointing.

There are far too many affordable and quality burrito spots in the city - to overpay for just an OK burrito.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: For advertising as the best burrito in SF this place truly let my expectations fall flat. Just go to a real Mexican taqueria for good authentic food and not this place. Doesn't live up to the hype.
author: Rosy C.

description: I frequent this place at least a few times a month. The burritos are always fresh and the service quick. Slightly pricey, but worth it as it's one of the best burrito places on this side of the city!
author: Kelcey P.

description:
I live right near Papalote and used to love this place. The salsa is still great, but that is about it. There has definitely been a steady decline, both in service and food quality.
Someone else said this below, and I'm just gonna quote it because it is right on: "The staff is rude, they don't care about the customers, and it's not a pleasant experience..."

I just paid $14.80 (!!!!) for a prawn burrito. The prawns were tiny and there were 2 (TWO) in the whole burrito. The prices are absurd and this is the second time I have gotten a shrimp or prawn burrito and been ripped off. 

Papalote - please take a look at yourself, think about how you would feel if you were the customer, and fix your problems. You used to be great. Be great again.
author: Josh B.

description: The burritos were tasty and fast. I really like that they use vegan beans and rice. It is nice to know that not everything has to be cooked in pork fat! Service is so-so. We came in at 6:30 on New Year's Eve (they closed at 7) and it seemed like the person behind the counter was a little irritated with us coming in at that time.
author: Sebrina D.

description:
I had maybe the best breakfast burrito of my life here once. In fact, I went back the very next day to get the same exact one; it wasn't AS over-the-top spectacular but still pretty awesome the 2nd time.

To be specific, I get the chorizo breakfast burrito (posted a picture of it as well). Every bite was a super well-balanced bite. The chorizo itself is bomb - I get it with my non-breakfast burritos that I get at Papalote as well.

As other reviewers point out, Papalote is also great because they give you massive portions as well as free chips and their delicious homemade salsa as part of your meal! No extra charges! :)

Downside is that there is limited seating here so you won't be able to eat there with a group larger than 4 total, 2 is ideal. They do takeout though (you still get chips/salsa).

Definitely try the chorizo, it will change your view on this place as it is my favorite meat to get there. They have soyrizo as well if your vegetarian!
author: Peter M.

description:
You're not gonna find many Mexican places living around the USF area. This place, like many others have said, is OK. It's convenient, but extremely mediocre. It would be more worth it if the prices were $2 cheaper. Otherwise the quality:cost ratio is off. The burritos and tacos are decent, but just overpriced what what it is. The sauce and chips are good, though.

Solid place to fulfill a craving if you're in the area.
author: Jacquelyn T.

description: I'm done with this place after the price increase.  Just paid 14 for a highly craptastic chicken burrito.  They charged extra dollar just for sour cream.  First bite was salt over load.  Chicken was rubbery.  Oh want some water?  There's a dirty looking water tank that probably hasn't been cleaned since i first set foot in this place two years ago.  No thanks.  I'm done with this place.  Advise you to spend your money elsewhere.
author: Bike R.

description: Great food, lousy service! Some of the cashiers don't even speak English very well, and are plain rude to the customers at times. If only they would treat their clientele better... Why does management not do anything about this? Are they totally f*#%ing clueless, or what? I will never eat here again!!! Besides, their menu is way overpriced anyway...
author: Torfin S.

description: SO sad to write this post, but Papalote has just gone downhill the past 4 years. I have always loved the burritos, chips and salsa, but lately the service has been awful. It's incredibly expensive as it is, $11 for a basic burrito, however today I went in and asked for extra chips... $1.00 (OK) and then you have to pay for extra salsa ($.57)... fine... then I got my food, a little cold and looked in my bag of chips. I asked if they had given me extra and it became this big production of everyone looking inside and confirming, yes, this was 'extra'. Ridiculous. Just a big money making industry that's lost touch with the customer and the food! Disappointing, as I won't be back again.
author: Abigail M.

description:
Walked in right before it was closing to grab a quick burrito. I usually get a burrito with their refried beans, but I went with whole pinto instead. First mistake. Beans didn't have too much taste to them whereas their refried beans are one of a kind. Chips came along with my burrito order, but they were pretty stale. Thankfully, I could just drown those out with their amazing salsa.

This location is about as spacious as the one on 24th Street except it doesn't have a picnic bench setup like the other branch does. Despite the bathroom being graffiti'd all over, it's pretty clean. Adds a unique touch to the place.

As it sits, I probably won't be coming back any time soon. There are just way more places in SF to try Mexican food and for a cheaper price.
author: George Z.

description: Gave this place a shot 4 years ago and wasn't impressed. Just had it again bc everyone raves about the salsa. Yes, the salsa is good and staff is nice. That's pretty much it. Quesadillas were so tiny and like $14 and not that good.
author: Alyssa M.

description: I wanted to like this place because it's so close, but I've given it two chances and it has not delivered. The first time I went, the steak was rancid and they seemed annoyed when we asked for a replacement. The second time I went, the chicken was a strange texture, like maybe it was old? The order of guac and chips was expensive, given that the guacamole was brown and hardly mixed! The only reason I gave this place a second star was for the salsa, which is pretty good.
author: Jaclyn G.

description: I've eaten at Papalote over 20 times and this place is absolutely delicious. My menu favorite is the carne asada super burrito - a must-have. The staff is kind and there never seems to be a long wait, no matter the time. Again, this place is a MUST and can't be beat in terms of a solid burrito for its price. I've brought 10 friends and all gave a thumbs up for bringing them.
author: Jose V.

description: The prawn burrito which was once delicious was inedible! The prawn had not been deveined and there was a flavor of disinfectant. It was the worst burrito I have ever had. I returned the burrito and they offered to re[place it with another which was gracious but that one was almost as unpalatable ..the chips tasted of disinfectant...if this is the best burrito in SF, I will never eat another.
author: Lauren A.

description: Fantastico!! deliciouso!! Food here is awesome. Best to try in here nice ambiance as well.
author: Randy A.

description: This place is service is very bad . I order grilled veggies fajitas 14.95 add chicken or steak $3 extra 17.95 . She is asking me $6 extra add chicken . But there is sign on display add chicken $3 &  $17.95 . She don't wanna listen me . Bad experience on this place . Never wanna go back there .
author: Carlo S.

description:
One of my favorite burrito places in the city. they're home made salsa is tops you can buy a second helping of salsa for something like 50 cents and a jar to take home for a few bucks more. They also have some awesome green habenero sauce bottles on the tables that kick up the heat on their home made salsa several notches. The refried black beans for their burritos are a nice touch they offer that you don;t see everywhere.
The seating is limited, getting your food to go and eating it in golden gate park is awesome one a nice day.
author: Robert H.

description:
I love having this in my neighborhood. Really good burritos and really good salsa also. 

Some go-to burritos: 
- Carne Asasa
- Chicken Mole
- Vegetables (not the grilled vegetables one)

Make sure to make your burrito "super" for 99 cents. Also, you can ask for them to put the Papalote salsa into your burrito, which is a must-do, if you like spicy-ish salsa.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I actually really like this place. The burritos are all really good. Id recommend the mexi-pino burrito its has a sisg style rice and carnitas. 

Menu is pretty standard but all of the burritos Ive had have been excellent, always consistent. The chips and salsa are awesome. Only one flavor of salsa (as far as i can tell) and its kinda like an orange sauce. 

Really no complaints, for the NoPa area I would say its one of the best burrito options.
author: Adam M.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and I'm never disappointed. Everything is the bomb.com. 

The salsa is amazing. Had to take home a jar. I always get a chicken quesadilla. The chicken is absolutely amazing and has so much flavor. 

Really good Mexican food.
author: Yasuko R.

description: One of the best mexican places I've ever been to. I had the carne Asada plate and everything about it was awesome. The horchata is different from chicago but I like the San Fran better. This place is pretty small and can get packed really quick. The service was really fast and the food was awesome.
author: Seleen T.

description:
Burritos are okay and not cheap. Not my favorite in the bay area. Also, not my favorite mole.

However,  their salsa is awsome! It comes in a jar for $7 and is totally worth it.
author: Teresa S.

description: As other reviewers have said, the salsa here is amazing!  I also love the naked burrito. I have them omit the rice and it's a quick, delicious, affordable, semi-healthy(?) dinner. Also the burritos include chips and salsa so the price is reasonable - on par with Chipotle.
author: A C.

description: This place is delicious. I find the wait to be a little longer but if you're eating there they give you tortilla chips and salsa to munch on while you wait.
author: Jess E.

description:
I called in to order a super carne asada burrito. When I picked up the order (after paying a whopping $11.52) I got in the car and started eating. It wasn't until I got three bites into the burrito that I noticed they gave me the wrong order. It was chicken and it wasn't super, but I was already too far away by the time I noticed. 

All good and I wasn't super upset about that, but during eating I already started to feel a stomach ache. After finishing (maybe a bad call) I immediately had to go to the bathroom. No fun. I'll leave it there and spare you the details. 

So, I paid $11+ for a burrito that was the wrong order and made me immediately feel like shit. 

Only thing good is the salsa these days. Bummer.
author: Darius T.

description:
Had a great burrito here a few weeks ago.
We were having a challenge, and five of us pitted Papalote against Chihuahua and Papalote won unanimously.

Chile verde was done well.  At some other places, it can be dry and smothered in sauce.  This was juicy even under the sauce.  Of course the salsas were great, no argument there!

Funky decor (that giant kite, right?) a few tall pub tables in front, and bar seating along the wall going towards the back.  

Definitely on the list for a return visit!
author: Ken B.

description: Great neighborhood Mexican Grill. But what's up with the STRONG oder of Pin Sol?   Past few times I noticed the smell.  Very strong. Not sure that I will revisit without nose plugs!  Ugh.
author: Pamela K.

description:
It never fails, but on the date of our yearly lunch gatheringI am handed the wrong order.

So here's the deal. I ordered the chorizo con huevos. But when I was handed my order I was given a burrito. Rather than cause a commotion and send it back, I elected to not say anything (which is what I usually do) and just decided to eat it. I mean it had to be mine as we were the only patrons in the restaurant. I also figured, it's a burrito how bad can this be?

Turned out my instincts were right. My adopted orphan burrito was delicious. I'm not sure what was inside the thing, but it looked meaty (god I hope it wasn't seafood). There was a layer of refried black beans and melted cheese that added to the goodness. If I ever find out what kind of burrito it was, I would get it again in a heartbeat. 

Seating is tight, here and can see this might be a problem at peak meal times. But given that we here between breakfast and lunch we breezed right in and found a nice vacant table for three. But the taqueria did quickly fill and plenty of hungry diners were forced out on the street.

I loved my lunch, but cannot grant you that fifth star. Maybe next year..
author: Rene C.

description:
Ok so first off when I walked in all of the staff were just hanging around behind the counter showing each other things on their phones and talking to each other. Not a good start. After a minute or so of standing there (and after they finished their personal conversation) they took my order. So after 15 minutes of waiting in an empty restaurant with no phones ringing for orders and no customers coming in I was getting irritated. It took another 5 customers coming in and another 5 minutes before I actually got my order. All of the staff seemed to just stand around socializing not really caring. The food was ok but not great. 

I could have driven over to the new Chipotle and driven back in the time it took them to make my order. I'm just find this kind of service inexcusable, especially at these prices. 

I have two comments 
1. Get better staff
2. Stop nickel and diming your customers

Chipotle here I come!
author: Rose S.

description:
What sucks is that the food is great, but the hosts are incompetent. Every time I eat here my order gets screwed up, something doesn't make it in the bag, the hosts don't check to-go orders, etc. I've had my order skipped and waited 30+ minutes for my food. I have gone back in and told them that something is missing and they want me to bring the food back so they can check the order themselves... Because it's REALLY that difficult to just remake my chorizo con queso without me walking to and from my car a million times. It's just disappointing and a hassle. 

Two stars are for the food, it is tasty, but it's becoming so frustrating that I don't know if I'll eat here anymore.
author: Caitlin G.

description:
The salsa is so good I could eat it by itself.   Prawn  burrito is fresh and prawns are big, cleaned/deveined.  
Feels slightly healthier than your avg Mexi joint. 
Annoying lines and no parking but  hits the spot.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I use to go here all of the time but I just refuse to support this place anymore. I went there today and bought two burritos, one steak burrito and the other rice and bean. The total came out to be 28.00. I'm sorry, what?!!! They had a sign a while back saying the price in meat and dairy has gone up. Yes I agree, but beans and rice has been the same price since I was a kid. Plus, a fresh bag of pinto beans are always buy one get one free at luckys. So come on!!!! But seriously it's absolutely ridiculous. I will definitely be taking my money and business elsewhere.
author: LaNiesha P.

description:
Papalote was once one of my favorite local spots to grab a burrito.  Everything was fresh, the meat seemed to be fairly high quality, but those times have changed.  The last few times I have picked up dinner from Papalote I grabbed burritos to go only to be extremely disappointed when I would get home and take a few bites. The burrito I ordered last Friday night was inedible due to the chicken being extremely tough/chewy and the overall burrito being ridiculously salty (maybe the beans).  My boyfriends burrito was also inedible for the same reasons though we both had different beans.  We literally threw away more than half of the burritos, and this was after putting them on a plate to salvage some of the meat, rice and beans. Each piece of chicken was absolutely disgusting/inedible and the beans, rice and pico were too salty to be enjoyed by scooping up with what seemed like store bought bulk tortilla chips.  Ive had fresher burritos from the drive-thru of fast food joints.

The above is not a fluke.  The exact same situation has happened the last 3 times I have been there, which of course, decreases the frequency of me grabbing dinner from Papalote.  2 chicken burritos (one with guac, one with cheese) comes out to a little over 25 dollars and you can guarantee I will not be wasting my money on RIDICULOUSLY EXPENSIVE, literally inedible, burritos.
author: Jen S.

description:
I always pass this place when I take the bus to work and have been meaning to try it. Not wanting to cook dinner, I decide to to finally try this place out on my way home. I order the carne aside burrito super to go. After I get my food, I look in the bag and see no salsa. I asked one of the ladies at the cashier  if I could get one and as she was handing it to me, the cashier next to her say "uuuuuh essssscccuu me, there's already one in your bag." I say oh I didn't see it, could I grab an extra then? And she rudely says I have to pay extra 50 cents. Unwilling to argue about salsa I pay her pennies and head out.

After a 30 min ride back home, I was so excited to bite into my burrito. I take a couple bites and was not impressed. The so called infamous salsa was so meh, there was really nothing to it. Yeah, it had a unique taste but there was nothing wow about it. The lady cashier fought me like it was liquid gold. The burrito in fairness had a good amount of meat, but that's all it was, just meat and rice. The extra $1 I paid for to get it "super" was a total rip off. I saw one little speck of guac and that was it.

The burrito was tiny and expensive, the salsa so-so, the cashier was a meanie.


Such a disappointment. I wouldn't come back.
author: Marie N.

description:
I am sitting here wishing I did not drunkly eat all of my food last night and had leftovers... *sigh*
two words, VEGAN MOLE. 
This place was recommended by a friend where my meat eating boyfriend and I could both enjoy some great quality mexican food and it never disappoints. The service is great, food comes out quick, and they give you complementary chips and the most delicious salsa EVER (I have a back up stash at home that I purchased at Whole Foods when cravings occur). 
I typically go for the "naked" burrito, tofu drowning in a delicious mole sauce with black beans, rice, pico de gallo, and added guacamole. SO MUCH FOOD. 
My boyfriend typically gets the chicken burrito (super status) and says its tasty, fresh ingredients, and just enough food. 
took one star away because one time I came here and asked for just guacamole on my burrito to go - only to come home and realize it came with cheese and sour cream so this little vegan couldn't enjoy it :(
Otherwise, this is a great go to place for delicious mexican and to die for salsa.
author: Kelsey B.

description: My boyfriend and I have been going here for years and won't be stopping any time soon. They food is AMAZING. Best quick mexican food you can get in NOPA and the surrounding area. I wouldn't consider it the best mexican food in the city (the mission takes the cake on that), but it is pretty darn close. Their salsa is to die for and so fresh. It is a go to for SF foodies.
author: Jenna G.

description: Tacos were bleh. Overpriced for such an average mostly lettuce taco. Lacking flavor and character. My husband loves the burrito though - we are a house divided. I've given the place a few tries and am always underwhelmed  chips also tasted stale :/.
author: Madison H.

description:
Not sure if people are eating while drunk or eating "Mexican" food 
for the first time from the mid-west
but this place does not pass this native's burrito test.

Over and over I have tried still confused.
The carne asada is tough, the pork chile verde is too tangy 
and the shrimp is just not right.
All of the above had no flavor, I kept searching with every bite.

The only reason to go here is to grab some salsa and chips.
It's the one thing on the menu that won't feel like a mistake on your lips.

Two tacos and one burrito cost 20 bucks.
If you're looking for pseudo Mexican food and prefer disappointment you're in luck.

To get your burrito fix, head to the Mission 
otherwise you'll be sorry you didn't listen.
author: Kristi G.

description: Good burritos, great salsa, but everything is a bit over-priced. Also, the food takes around 15 minutes to prepare -- too long. They're usually showing the Giants or Niners game on the TV, so that's cool if you're able to grab one of the limited seats inside.
author: Philip T.

description:
Best FISH QUESADILLA EVER! (also good in the burrito)
I go back there just for that! It is my favorite I can never get enough of it!
There homemade salsa is also really good... but very spicy!
author: Manon E.

description: Love this place.  Can sum it up in two words:  Mole tofu burrito.  Wait, that's three words.  Oops.  Let me try this again.  Two words: amazing salsa.  Boom.
author: Stevan D.

description:
Two burritos make this place sing. One, the mexipino burrito. Chicken adobo with garlic rice. A classic Filipino dish presented in a Mexican staple. It's a beautiful combination showcasing the best of Mexican and Filipino fusion.

The signature item is their triple threat burrito. Named in honor of one of the best DJ crews in the world, you will find this burrito a tasty, unique concoction. Though it lost on Throwdown it's still worthy.
author: Patrick Gabriel L.

description: I was disappointed by the amount of guacamole I got for the price of $10. (See picture) overall I would not go back, the food is just okay. Not super flavorful.
author: June O.

description: I used to love going to Papalote when I lived in the city.... Now that I'm back working in the city and found the one over on Fulton I was stoked. Ordered my usual prawn burrito... took a bite and was like mmmmm still the same, first bite was a big fat juicy prawn. next few bites was pretty salty and no shrimp insite. Got to the bottom and got two more shrimp. It was a little salty but still was good. But there prices are a little outrageous. Prawn burrito with sour cream = $13.50 (for 3 shrimp) .. don't think I'll be getting another. Tacos were loaded with lettuce. And their triple threat burrito for $19.95 ... that's kind of much. 2 burritos and 1 order of tacos... +$40...think next time i'll take that extra drive across the city to La Mission.
author: Keeks P.

description: Papalote used to be great, but they've steadily raised their prices and maybe moved to a new supplier - their meat has been noticeably worse quality the past few times i've ordered the prawn super burrito. It's also one of the most expensive Super Burritos in SF - I think I'm done paying 15 bucks and staving off my cravings until I can get Cancun or El Farolito instead.
author: Israel S.

description:
Really more like 3.5, but I'll round up for their soyrizo. 

Lately I've been cutting out meat from my diet. I'm not really going strict vegetarian; if someone offers me food at their home or if I'm at a family style dinner, I'll eat it. But for the most part, when I cook at home and eat alone, it's meatless. So I was glad to learn Papalote serves up soyrizo, since it's right by USF! 

I also appreciate they have a "naked" burrito (which is really a burrito bowl). Not for diet reasons... I just like eating with a fork. I know, I'm weird. The soyrizo is pretty good, and their chips and salsa are as good as everyone says they are. 

A few minor dislikes: 
I know it's the city, but $10+ some change for one soyrizo burrito with guac!? Jeeeeeeeez. 

This place always seems to smell like they just mopped up with a shit ton of pine sol. I'm glad the place is clean, but it's kind of gross when you wanna eat there. 

And on that note, the most uncomfortable chairs. But, you can always opt to take your food to-go.
author: Angela L.

description:
We ordered the Chile Verde burrito and pollo (chicken) both with "super" which is supposed to have avocado, sour cream and cheese "in" the burrito. We both had cheese, but nothing else. Beans galore... To replace the lacking meat. The meat that was in there didn't meet expectations... Didn't feel or taste like it had been cooked down for hours. Extra charge for bad pico de Gallo. Also super confusing... Ordered chips n salsa to start because it was on the menu, but it appears to come with your meal, which I wish the girl would've mentioned... 

Overall, I don't see it winning any throwdowns with Bobby or any of the other amazing Mexican joints we have in the bay area.
author: Sau y.

description:
Not your typical burrito joint, not by a long shot... 

Armed with a BBE coupon just in time for my trip up to the city, I couldn't resist the urge to try one of their burritos. Once referred to as Cheech Marin-squared, co-owners Miguel and Victor Escobedo vanquished Bobby Flay in the burrito challenge on Throwdown with Bobby Flay; kind of a Mexican-lite vs West Side Story. The Triple Threat Burrito is a $19.95 monster famous for beating out Flay's "lame" all-green burrito... 

The Triple Threat Burrito consisted of grilled prawns, carne asada steak, and chicken, with rice, black beans, guacamole, and tomato salsa, wrapped in a large flour tortilla. It was a gargantuan dry-style burrito, made with quality ingredients -- Bomb! It's a good thing that I don't live in the city any more, else I would be dropping these down all the time... 

I mentioned that this is dry-style burrito, but you can take their famous roasted tomato salsa and smother the burrito yourself on their colorful Fiestaware-style plates and you would be set with a wet-style burrito. This orange-red salsa is so addicting... 

The restaurant is long and narrow like many businesses in the city; red walls and "Papalote" kites adorn the interior roofline. Seating is limited to a couple of small tables up front and a standup counter along the wall... 

Granted that you wouldn't want to drop $20 on a burrito very often, but I think that it is worth a try for the novelty of it. Their regular menu sounds pretty good too...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Used to love this place long ago. Their food is good but way too overpriced. You can easily find yourself paying $13 for a regular sized burrito. The prices are so bad that it overshadows completely what ever positives they bring. Salsa is unique and delicious but unfortunately also no consistent.
author: Tassos L.

description: This place was very small.. Not many table to sit at. We saw this place on the show taco trip. Really wanted to try the triple threat burrito... I also ordered some chicken nachos. The burrito was practically $20. For the price and the hype not worth it. The chicken nachos were so-so the chicken was laid out on top and the pieces were kind of big so you have to use a knife and fork. For being a taqueria and eating for 4 of us the total was almost $60. Too pricey to me. Customer service was ok.. Not too friendly. The chairs and tables were uncomfortable.
author: Dolores T.

description: Ate there twice recently and have decided not to go back.  The cost of my burrito (including a $2 tip) was $17.89.  Really?  We have now entered the world of $18 burritos.  That's not cool, but what put me over the edge was this:  I asked for a second little container of salsa to put on that burrito and was told that the charge for that would be fifty cents.  What kind of restaurateur thinks like that?  Bye-bye.
author: Bruce P.

description:
Burritos are terrible! I got the prawn burrito and the prawns tasted burnt with no flavor which doesn't go well with the disgusting house salsa and the wannabe spanish rice which was half cooked....I can't see why this place was voted best burrito anywhere let alone SF! I can imagine the majority who voted were a bunch out town hipsters who think they have "flavor."

Only positive thing I can say was that the girl working the register was really nice.

I learned my lesson the first time and will not be going back.....If I wanted to disaster of a buritto, I would have made it myself!
author: This Is M E.

description:
First off I was desperate and starving 3pm after the Giants Race i needed food ASAP! We were at the brewery next door and they stopped food service so we ended up here. I've heard amazing things about this place, seen them on food network and bought a bottle of their salsa in the past (Not a fan). I could not believe what they were charging for a burrito! They were going to charge me $11 for a steak and shrimp, oh hell no! Then I asked can I get half half, they said no...Fine! My friend ordered a shrimp super burrito, I ordered super carne asada burrito and we split it, problem resolved. Total: $23 for damn burritos, this better be good! 

Size Matters for SF Burritos- Compared to my favorite El Farolito, these puppies were medium size not tiny, not large. For $10 burriots I expect them to be huge or damn tasty!

Flavor: Super Carne Asada with refried beans- This was nothing exciting, ok flavor but I couldn't see the sour cream, or anything super burrito about it, look at the photo. 

Shrimp Super burrito with Pinto beans: I actually liked this alot because of the green chiles they put in it. I love chille relleno and it tasted like a shrimp chile relleno burrito. 

Will I come back, probably not because of the price for nothing wow! If I have to eat here again shrimp burrito it is!
author: Karen T.

description: Best Mexican food in the city. Salsa is the BEST. They truly cook the chicken and steak to order- and it tastes fresh.
author: D B.

description:
Triple Threat Burrito.

No I didn't order that. But that's what they're famous for, thanks to Bobby Flay's throwdown. In case you're curious what that is,  it's basically a burrito with grilled prawns, chicken and steak, rice, beans, salsa for $19.95. This will probably keep me full for two days so I guess that's a bargain.

Let's talk about chips and salsa. Damn their salsa is muy bueno! it's not chunky style, think a thick paste of fire roasted tomato and other "secret" ingreadients ground into a spreadable paste. The exact recipe is of course, heavily guarded but you can order their salsa online. The chips were a bit of a disappointment. We got some pieces that were stale but the others were fine.

I had two prawn tacos: big, juicy pieces with nice grill marks on it. Decorated with fresh tomatoes, lettuce, onions. BTW, radishes too. Why do I have radishes in my tacos! * shakes head * only in SF!

The star worth mentioning here is their chicken mole. I usually don't order mole, but bf was in the mood for it. This is a huge entree! Moist chicken breast drowning in that glorious mole sauce (you can order this vegan too) with rice, beans and pico de gallo. Cute tidbit: I came across Patty P's funny review about how that mole inspired her to buy a crockpot and make her own mole. Read it. 

Also, their horchata is yummy. I'm not the one to praise horchata as I usually go for agua fresca, but this was nicely balanced and not too chalky as other ones I've had in the past.

You'll pay for the quality you get but will get fast service with it. So, expect to pay about $20 without drinks. While not the best Mexican in the city, it's a solid choice especially if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Janice C.

description:
This place came in TO SAVE THE DAY when all I needed was burrito pick-me-up. And pick me up it did. 

Great prices, big burrito, and chips on the side-what more can you ask for! 

The chicken was cooked well and was pretty tasty, and I really just can't think of any complaints with this spot. 

A great place to stop for a quick burrito and then be on your way!
author: Marilyn M.

description: Never had so much salad in my shrimp tacos.  I liked their special chicken taco a lot more.  I will try more things next time.  Their orange sauce is good but not as good as San Jose's orange sauce.
author: Julia W.

description:
I come here at least twice a week. The burritos are delicious. Slightly on the pricier side, but well worth it.

The burritos are huge too. Sometimes I end up splitting them up over two meals.
author: Andy V.

description:
Being a USF student, I'm not going to lie about the fact that Papalote is extremely convenient and delicious. However, that being said, I probably wouldn't think twice about this place if it weren't for the fact that it was one of the closest decent food venues close to the overpriced doodoo that school gives us. 

Papalote will fill my appetite and my fill for Mexican food, but it's definitely not the "cream of the crop" of Mexican food compared to other Mexican restaurants in The Bay or the many extremely spectacular restaurants in Southern California. 

I'm not going to lie, the prices are a bit steep, but it's still reasonable. I do enjoy it, but I could easily get the same, if not better satisfaction out of a Chipotle for the same price.

I do LOVE their salsa sauce that comes with chips with each order and has a really great flavor and a bit of a kick that was just enough to make my taste buds sing. 

Prices range from $7.00-$10.00 for a burrito/quesadilla depending on your protein preference. I'll always be back, but again, it's more about that location, location, location rather than the restaurant itself.
author: Cara O.

description: I was over charged for my Mexipino burrito. On top of being given the wrong order the first time. So the cashier gives u a # so the server can bring your order and the guy dosent even bother looking at your number he just tells u what he has in his hands which is multiple plates super bad service.  Ive been here before and didnt experience that type of service but i will not return.
author: Freddiifromfortknox ..

description: used to be one of my favorite SF burritos. just had one for first time in years and is super salty and 80% rice. what happened?
author: Eric F.

description:
I love Papalote. If you are near USF you need to come here.

Its not authentic Mexican. Lets get that out here right now. 

Good quality ingredients, awesome flavors, such good carne asada! The best carne asada.
The best salsa there is. No one will argue that the salsa is not awesome. My buddy who is a vegetarian and I used to eat here all the time and he loved the soyrizo. It's also very good.  
My girlfriend has gotten the shrimp here and said it was bad. So theres that.  

I think the burritos are where its at.

The seating is a bit limited here, but I usually don't have a hard time finding a seat for me+1. 

For Mexican food, especially compared to authentic places, its a bit on the pricey side. But, compared to most other restaurants its average.   

TLDR; Such good burritos. Such good carne asada. I love it here
author: Jeremy B.

description: Purchased a carne asada burrito w/ guac & sour cream for dam near $14, which feels extremely high for a small walk up taqueria. The burrito fell apart into a complete mess after the first few bites and wasn't that good. The worst part is the attitude of the person running the place (operates the register) he had a bad vibe about him as soon as I started ordering. I asked for a refill of hot sauce and he said we charge .50 with a snarky attitude. I told him I didn't have any cash and only had a card, he wouldn't budge on offering a small cup (less than 1oz) and gave me a dirty look when I asked if I could pay by card. Luckily a nice employee walked over to me and put a hot sauce on my table and said don't worry about it. I won't be coming back based on this experience and would suggest others spend there money elsewhere. There are plenty of better taquerias in the city who charge less and appreciate their customer's business more.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
