I've eating a burrito from here twice. Both times they were bought for me and delivered to my desk. Getting a free burrito may have skewed my review, but I like them. My bosses love the breakfast burritos and I haven't tried those. The last burrito I had was the chile verde and they were nice medium to large size pieces of pork which were tender and flavorful. The burrito had a good ratio of rice and beans. They are slightly different from other mexican restaurants I have been to and so far those differences have been great. The flavor profile is there. The other thing that makes this place a 5, instead of a 4, is the salsa they give with the chips is absolutely delicious. It makes you think twice about salsa. It's creamy, spicy, and has different depths of flavor and spice. I love their salsa. I even try to save some to add to my other foods. They need to package that salsa and sell them in stores and tell me when they do it. Maybe they already do...I need to look into it, actually. haha

Overall, I love to order delivery from Papalote. My work place loves them. Everything I've tasted so far has been spot on and delicious. They're one of those places that gets you hooked after one bite and makes you believe there are drugs in their food.
author: Christina L.

description:
Not bad. Satisfied my hunger but at $4 a taco? And I get charging $0.50 for more salsa, but it's so small! Next time I'll just invest in a whole jar!
Service was quick but not stellar.
Will probably be back when I'm at USF and I'm craving some kind of Mexican food, but I'd rather go where I can get twice the amount of tacos for the same price.
author: Brituhknee S.

description: Nice burritos here with good homemade salsa to add in. Staff and service were so-so. Lot's of veggie options in lieu of meat if that's what you're in to (I'm not). I had the Mexipino burrito which was Chicken Adobo and loved it. Also tried bites of the carne asada and the steak tasted great. I recommend getting the trifecta of fillings (guac, cream and cheese) for a bit extra but the burrito is certainly good without.
author: John I.

description:
I eat mexican food in South Bay a lot, so I was wondering Mexican place in the city. 
It was tasty. Compared to burritos in South, this place's was a bit dry. Maybe I should have ordered wet one.
The interior is of course more modern than I had expected. I'll come back when I am really hungry.
author: Kaori M.

description: I ordered to go cheese w/chorizo was okay, I asked for carne azada fajitas, corn tortilla ALL TO GO and just got pieces of carne azada with rice and beans where are the fajitas???, no tortilla and no salsa, the worst service To Go ever!!!
author: Nelly P.

description:
People rave about Papalote but I found it to be just okay for the value. I had the chicken quesadilla with two extra sides of salsa and the extra salsa was a must!!!!

In my opinion, El Rancho Grande on Divis is the best taqueria in the area but since this Papalote is just around the corner from  my house so surely I'll be back and review again.
author: Lauren B.

description: STREET TACO is better. The main selling point is their Papalote sauce. Buy an overpriced jar and get a burrito elsewhere.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
My bf and I wanted to try another Mexican spot, and it needed to be semi-close by, so we tried this place. We've heard of it since they make salsa and put in jars around San Francisco grocery stores. 

I got the Carne Asada tacos. Our meal first started off with chips - SO WONDERFUL - probably because of the right crunch and salt ratio. We ended up ordering a refill for $1. But then my tacos came...they were disappointing. The taco shell itself was all soggy from the juices. I wish the presentation was served differently, perhaps in a bowl, to prevent the taco shells from getting soggy. The carne asada and other toppings, lettuce and sour cream were just average. Nothing really to write home about.

The seating was kind of awkward. All of the chairs/tables are bar seating, so you have to climb up to your chair, and climb down, just an annoying factor when you just want to wash your hands after an especially messy taco. 

Would come back here to buy a whole bag of their chips though. Man they were good!  Service was very nice too.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: A very reliable stop for delicious carne asada burritos.  The service is great too.  People rave about their chipotle salsa but I'm not as big on it.
author: Jay R.

description:
Some times Papalote is awesome.  Other times, I wonder why I ordered their bland sloppiness and paid premium for it.  

Grilled prawn super burritos are usually good and my staple item here.  Chicken is marinated well.  Everything is grilled to order and that makes a huge difference from many other joints.  All their ingredients seem healthy.

Salsa is good, but more and more watered down over time.  Maybe they're trying to squeeze out more salsa for the buck.  

I go here when I'm hungover and need a little saving...
author: John M.

description:
I've been to both the Fulton and Mission location, but I like the Mission location a lot better because it's bigger.

As a USF student I've been hearing about this place and their salsa so I had to try it. The first time I went to the Mission location I ordered tofu tacos with a side of mushrooms. Omg the tacos were so good and the salsa made it ten time better! 
The Fulton location is a lot smaller and can get crowded fast. I ordered the prawn tacos this time. It was okay, adding the salsa to the tacos gave them more flavor. The shrimp were hella small and they don't give you much. I think I'll just stick to the tofu tacos since I don't eat meat, but my friend got the chicken adobo burrito and she liked it! But the salsa is so good, I went to whole foods and bought myself a jar!
author: Kimberly T.

description:
Yes, I paid $20 for a burrito.  Before you do too, I suggest you read this first.

So when was the last time you ran 13.1 miles?  When you did, might you have noticed how F%#@ING HUNGRY you were after?  A friend of mine and I ran the Giant Race earlier in the day and, as expected, we were looking to fill the emptiness in our tummies with something substantial - hey, 13.1 miles, we earned it!  Because she (my friend) had seen Papalote featured on the Food Network, she had mentioned earlier in the week that she would like to go there for our post-race meal.  Funny how the spoiled always seem to get what they want, huh?

So I guess for no other reason than because it was on TV, we decide to go for the Triple Threat Burrito to see what all the hype was about.  And, as a half marathon will help you do, we throw in a couple of tacos to help wash it down.  

The burrito:  Well, with regard to size, you're pretty much just getting a standard super burrito (depending on where you are).  There's nothing "food challenge" about it - in case that's what you may have been wondering, and let's be honest, for $20, some of you SHOULD be curious!  From a flavor perspective, not much stood out from this.  As the bits of rice and beans that were stuffed in her cheeks fly at me, my friend says "something's missing".  I agreed, something WAS missing.  If there was anything (for me) that stood out from the Triple Threat, it was the flavor of the carne asada that was in there.  It was tender, juicy, and flavorful, but that continued to be masked and diluted by everything else that was in there.  Maybe just a carne asada burrito would have been better?... Perhaps.

The tacos:  Not really much of a difference with regards to our feelings here.  They were good.  Not great, just good.  Though I don't typically find myself employing a knife and fork while eating tacos, the tortillas fell apart here and necessitated their use - a point that would have been lost had the food been over the top amazing, but that wasn't the case.

The word that continued to jump to the forefront of my thoughts was "gimmick".  Don't get me wrong, I get it.  I see what they're doing here and I understand the hipster S.F. clientele that they're serving, and from what I can see, its working... WELL!!!  And I applaud those that have the courage to become a part of the evolution of traditional cuisine, but I guess my palate is a little too old school to wrap my brain around what they're doing here.  

What really summed up my (our) experience here was the fact that our conversation was ultimately moved toward the menus of other establishments that we found ourselves comparing to Papalote.  If I'm paying $20 for a burrito, your signature product, why then am I talking about somebody else's food?

Like Public Enemy said a quarter century ago, "Don't Believe The Hype!"
author: Manuel S.

description:
Meh, I don't know. When I think of Mexican food, visions of soyfu don't dance through my little brain. This place is catering to the hipsters in SF and I get that and all, so maybe I need to check out the shop in La Mission for semi authentic Mexican grub. 

Saw a segment on Food Network about the triple threat burrito and that's what lured me to this place. When I got there and saw that the triple threat burrito is $20, I decided that wasn't gonna happen. I just can't do it. As much as my brain was saying "do it, do it" I just found it difficult to part with a 20 spot for a burrito, from a place that was given 3.5 stars by my fellow Yelpers. had this place been a 5 star spot, maybe that 20 would have slipped across the counter. 

What I ended up with was a Chile Verde burrito and it was not too bad. The meat was served up in giant chunks that were tender and almost really tasty, but just left a lot to be desired. The whole wheat tortilla fell apart as I was grubbin' and that wasn't cool. The salsa was very good. It tasted fresh, had a little bit of spice to it and packed a decent punch. But let's get real. If the 5 star item on your menu is salsa, you have fallen short.

To make matters worse, the place is the size of a Muni bus stop. Literally impossible to sit down and enjoy a meal because if more than 4 people are in the house, you are shit outta luck. I am not gonna drop a 20 spot for the triple threat and wouldn't recommend it to my Yelp familia either.
author: Hector G.

description:
It's a bit overwhelming how good this food is. It makes me think about my life in a different way and I sometimes think about how my life would be completely different if I hadn't walked this way one day and walked into this place while hungry. 

But anyway- it's relatively cheap and it's good so just eat here.
author: Kenn P.

description: It is soooo disappointing to have to write this review. . . .because their fish tacos are incredible!! However, we ordered two orders of fish tacos, tonight, and the whole service experience was a fiasco.  They said 10 -15 minutes, I gave them 20, and when I got to the restaurant and approached the cashier for pick up - Nancy told me to "wait in line with everyone else". . .ten minutes later I picked up my order. . .what was the point of calling ahead? When we got home we realized that, although we ordered two orders of fish tacos, we only got one.  And while they were delicious, not enough for two people and we had to dine elsewhere!  It's a crime against deliciousness that this restaurant has such poor service.
author: Rachel S.

description: I've been going to this location for a couple of years now and was very disappointed on a recent trip here. Service was ok as usual and it was relatively easy to find street parking during lunch, which is pretty rare at this location. They used to stuff their burritos with a lot of meat and guac and used to use large prawns for their quesadillas. My boyfriend ordered his usual carne asada burrito and there was barely any meat in the burrito, as there was mostly just rice. I ordered the prawn quesadilla and when I received it I was confused because normally, the shrimp are so big that the tortilla is unable to close. Also, the mushrooms and peppers they put were a bit smaller in portion as well. The chips didn't taste as fresh as they normally do and the only thing we really enjoyed was the salsa. I'm hoping that we just visited on an off day because papalote's is usually one of our go-to's in the city. Here's to hoping that I'll write a more positive updated review soon.
author: Christine G.

description:
What's not to like about Papalote? Ample-sized, delicious burritos and chips/salsa that are even better.

The Fulton location can get pretty busy, but I prefer it to the Mission strictly due to its proximity to Lower Haight. Feels better to take a walk after eating all that food (rather than sit on the 22 forever.)
author: Jon T.

description:
Chipotle has better tasting food than here. We shared the triple threat burrito and let me tell you it was the biggest disappointment. Food was very bland and had to cover it with the green habanero bottled hot sauce that is at the table and add salt on top of that. The chips and salsa where also a big disappointment chips where bland and so was the salsa. 
I don't recommend a special trip to this place you will regret it!
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
I love this place. Friendly staff and fair prices for awesome food. 

The flavors are great and the meats are never dry or bland. 

Have yet to find a place I like more to compare it to in San Francisco.
author: Amanda Z.

description: Disgusting prices for mediocre food. Never again. What happened to you Papalote? Years ago you were so delish..
author: Emma C.

description:
Stopped by today for the first time, hoping it could be a  regular stop on the way home.  The food was pretty mediocre, and not cheap.  $8.50 for a chicken mole (regular) burrito with bleh mole and dried out chicken.  My daughter's prawn tacos completely fell apart, and the veggies with it were pretty flat.  That's $9.50 for two meh prawn tacos!

I admit that the salsa and chips serving was generous, and the salsa was unique and worth having.
author: G M.

description: Good service, good food.  I always get the chicken burrito and it is amazing all the time.  The salsa is really good and you can buy it in jars to take home.
author: Justin C.

description:
I only saved 1 thing from 1L- that was a copy of the 7x7 "Best Burrito in SF" edition. The magazines experts ate super carne asada burritos and then awarded their favorites. The results were: 1. El Farolito, 2. Papalote, 3. Taqueria Cancun.... RIGHT. OK. That list is a lie. A bold faced lie. I did LOVE and do LOVE me some El Farolito, and yes, Taqueria Cancun is surprisingly delicious. But I had been looking forward to completing my "Burrito Tour de SF" with an "almost as good as El Farolito but better than TC" burrito from Papalote. I mean, they hadn't let me down so far. 

TODAY I finally got a super carne asada burrito from Papalote. 

W....T....H?!? Seriously? You bay area kids "LOVE" these?!?! What are you guys, always hig- .... nevermind. Ok, look, I am not from SF. I am from LA. I like things dirty, and when I walked into this place the smell alone made me question just how much dirt I was willing to tolerate. The store smelled terrible. So whatever, I ordered a super carne asada burrito and my boyfriend and I took a seat with a view of the kitchen to watch our burritos be made. ... I don't recommend it, I kind of wanted to gag. 

But I did observe them cooking my carne and my boyfriends pollo fresh on the grill. Great, cool, I finally get your angle- "good healthy mexican food." Unfortunately thats impossible- mexican food is meant to be cheesy, meaty, salty, fatty, spicy, dirty, and delicious. Not healthy. Never healthy. 

So I took a bite of my burrito and I was underwhelmed. Their guac was terrible and I have made better guac and FAR better seasoned carne asada since I was 12 AND I'M A RED HEAD. And their salsa tasted like spicy marinara. I just sat there wanting to cry. 

Shame on you 7x7 for lying to me for the past year and a half. And shame on you Papalote for sucking really bad. Seriously, motion for sanctions because you are such a liar and so misleading my witness!
author: Emily D.

description: Honestly not sure why I gave this place 4 stars the first time. It is the best, hands down.
author: Joe F.

description:
Paplote has been on my bookmarks list for awhile and I recently had the chance to finally try them out. I've heard really great things about their food so I was excited to possibly find a new burrito spot.

After walking in, I looked over the menu a few times and honestly, nothing really grabbed me. I was craving a veggie burrito (even though I'm not a vegetarian, by any means) but even that didn't sound like something I'd like (I'm not a fan of mushrooms and carrots in burritos, but I can see why others would like this combo). I ended up ordering a super bean and cheese burrito and I thought it was pretty good but still nothing really stood out. However, it was a pretty good size and there was also a generous portion of chips & the salsa was pretty good too.

Service was quick and with a smile. I definitely appreciate that Papalote is affordable and close by campus. It's definitely another lunch option for me BUT maybe I'm missing something here? I've tried taquerias similar to Papalote, like Little Chihuahua, and I really enjoyed their food, but I wasn't wowed by Papalote - maybe I didn't order the best burrito combo? 

Either way, I'm giving them 3 STARS for now and will try them again in the future.
author: Stephanie C.

description: I just paid $11 for 4 small prawns in a quesadilla. Give me a break. I asked to verify that there wasn't a mistake and they confirmed. Wow. I want my money back.
author: Tom B.

description:
Hard to know where to begin....
Stopped for lunch thinking a Mexican meal would be a nice change in this epicurean city.
Well this classless hole in the wall was a BIG mistake!  Ordered a Chili Verde burrito (pork).  The flavor was undefineable.  I have no idea what nationality it attached to, but it wasn't Mexican!  And the only pork found in the burrito was in its name.  My hispanic wife ordered mole tacos.  She couldn't find the meat, but lots of chopped lettuce and tomatos.  
The salsa served with the chips was very good.  
We agreed we wouldn't recommend this place to anyone!
author: Harlan A.

description:
Guess I ought to have stuck to the mission Papalote. 

To start, its kinda grimey inside. Not well taken care of at all. Next is customer service. I asked for a simple change in order and they denied me. Guess since they started the preparation they couldn't pause and provide excellent customer service. Too bad. Finally, I got the nachos, not an easy thing to screw up. So I thought. Flavorless.

Won't be coming back to this location. Not even for its delicious salsa. 
Save yourself some green and go to mission store.
author: Cub H.

description: Wow.What rip off..I felt like an idiot walking outThe burrito was tiny and hardly any chicken.Over $11 for it?Ridiculous
author: John S.

description:
Sub-par food at best. Had the chicken tacos and the meat was not good. 

Guac also subpar. 
Not a fan.
author: Kayla A.

description:
My favorite burrito place in SF....actually, the only one I will even go to. Obsessed with their "super" burritos (added cheese, Guac and sour cream) and also appreciate that you can get them with whole wheat tortillas and brown rice. Service is also friendly. 

Their salsa is TO DIE FOR and the best on the planet. I buy it by the jar at Whole Foods or Cal Mart. 

One star off because I got really sick all night about a year ago from this place. Clearly, food was too good though to stop me from coming and haven't been sick from it since. 

Pro tip: call ahead to order!
author: Alexis T.

description:
Really the one thing I still crave from my SF days. Well, Dosa and Burma Superstar too but Spain has yet to do Mex right. I need some of their incomparable salsa shipped stat. I loved going here for a casual lunch break or to pick up for a park lunch. The veg friendly burritos and extraordinary salsa make it a must try, must have. 

Until we Papalote again....
author: Holly E.

description: I wanted to see what the hype was about. There and behold....That Salsa is BOMB! The last time I was there was sometime in October or November. The salsa is what I always look forward to and when I get the chance to visit this place, I always bring home a few bottles of the salsa. You can pretty much put that salsa on anything. I've put it on burritos from senor sisig and Mogo Korean BBQ. This by far is my favorite salsa I've ever tried. Its not too spicy and not too watery like some salsas. It's just right for my taste. The food is awesome as well. I need to try the triple threat burrito. This is on my list of things to eat when I come by and visit. The owner who is friends with some of my friends DJ's on the side (Mr.E). Cool to see alot of hip-hop/r&b artists stop by his spot to show love.
author: Steven O.

description: Solid Mexican food! I have to say, the salsa was the best I've ever had... It was cream-based yet not as heavy as an aioli at all. They sell the salsa by the bottle and I was very close to buying one had I not been in such a hurry. As for my burrito, I got the prawn burrito and ordered it with guac. Unfortunately they forgot to add my guac as well as my friend's :( I was pretty bummed! The burrito was good, although I wish that the prawns had been seasoned more -- it was just a tad bland. But not bad at all. I would definitely go again, but there are so many BOMB places in SF to check out that I think I would give those a try first and then make a decision on which is best :) Definitely worth stopping by!
author: Naseem K.

description: Worth taking a trip to this part of the mission for its burritos! Vegetarian or otherwise, they are some of the best in the Bay.
author: Katie S.

description:
The single dollar sign on Papalote's page led me there for lunch and I was not disappointed. My soyrizo quesadilla was ready in a flash and brought out to me by a friendly face who also surprised me with an unexpected side of chips and salsa. 

Papalote is far from fusion. They do the basics with some unusual ingredients thrown in and a good amount of veggie-friendly options. It's straightforward, but all-around tasty. The soyrizo had good flavor but wasn't very spicy. The guacamole was fresh, the salsa was an intriguing pureed consistency and maybe my favorite part of the meal, and the tortilla chips were nice and salty. If you're looking for a solid Mexican meal, Papalote will hit the spot.
author: Rachel Y.

description: $11.12 for a regular chicken burrito?..oh my...I'd hate to think what a super would cost....I felt like a complete idiot leaving here and completely ripped off....I will not be retuRning...DISGRACEFUL
author: Captain C.

description:
Heard from a friend this was voted "best burrito" in SF.........ahhhh not a chance.   I got the chili verde burrito and my wife tried the grilled chicken.  Both were very average at best.  Tasted a little burnt to be honest.   

Now maybe I got it wrong and my friend meant this place was the most expensive burrito place in SF because that might be true. 11 bucks for an average burrito is a lot.  They do have a bobby flay burrito that's $20 but I didn't try it.  Maybe that one is worth it but I kinda doubt it.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Stop. Please. The people who are saying this is the greatest place for a burrito in San Francisco let alone the entire country. Halfway through my carne asada burrito and have yet to have that special bite that would validate such a ridiculous claim.

The cashier, cooks and everyone who worked here are great. Shared a brief convo with a guy who gave me my food about the niners game. Real nice people. But the food was just average.

My mother makes a burrito way better. Disappointed with all the hype.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Location wise, kind've hard to find parking, but USF is right across the street so I'm sure they're making crazy business.  We grabbed food for take out and took some Mexican coke along with our burritos. Got a staple item, that I always get at every burrito joint: a Carne Asada (grilled steak) burrito with sour cream, cheese, guac, beans...and a side of chips and salsa. I got my kids a plan cheese quesadilla. 

Absolutely delicious Papalote!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Estimado Papalote,

You esuck. In the last year you have gone from the "go to" burrito shop to the place that can't get my order right, whether I call in or order in person. If I get it Super and pay $10 for a burrito, I'd be nice to have avocado and sour cream in the whole burrito instead on a small little dab of each at opposite ends of the burrito. Your carne asado is still tasty and so you get a second star.
author: Andy A.

description:
There's so many great Mexican restaurants in San Francisco. This is not one of them. Tacos lacked meat and flavor. Tortillas were not fresh. The salsa that comes with the chips is good though. 
Try Nopalito instead.
author: Maey P.

description:
How could their salsa be so good, and their food so lackluster?

Inspired to come here after buying a jar of their salsa at a grocery store. Delicious, smooth, it was everything I wanted in a salsa. Then went in an ordered their overpriced tacos, and was sorely disappointed. 

No salsa bar, it comes out in a small dish with the food. Food was underseasoned, and dressings like lettuce and tomatoes were clumsily cut, too large, too small, inconsistent at best.


MORAL OF THE STORY:

sneak a jar of their salsa into another taco shop, and get the best of both worlds.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Absolutely, hands down, the worst taqueria ever!! I was so embarrassed taking my parents there (they usually go to La Taqueria in the Mission).  I don't even know where to start.

1. My parents order in Spanish, and when the Valley Girl Bimbo working the register blankly stares at them, I should have known it would be all downhill from there.  So I order for my parents in English, (the cooks in the back who are of Latino descent are cracking up at the cashier's ineptitude)

2. At $42 for 3 burritos and 2 beers, I'm expecting something amazing. Like wow, this better be the best burrito I've ever had.

3. They bring us the burritos, and it's just pathetic.  My Mom unwraps the tortilla and the portions are pathetic.  There's more tortilla than filling. So what about the filling? The chicken is dry, the shrimp is non-existent and the two tiny pieces of shrimp taste off, and my tofu ranchero is dry and blah.  The tortilla chips served to us had more character than the main food.

I'm sorry, but who the hell are they surveying to get the best taqueria award? Are they a bunch of drunk techies who just moved here after graduating from some Ivy league school back East? Look you all, I know that some of the more authentic taquerias might scare you a little.  I know it looks a little different than your prep school cafeterias, or your tech campus' cafeteria for that matter.  But until you eat at a taqueria where the menu is in spanish and the clientele doesn't look preppy or ivy league, you will never know what real taqueria tastes like.
author: caio m.

description:
What's the hype about this place?? There salsa!!! I love this place! My bf n I come here a lot. Burritos are popular. I'm not too big of a fan on their carne asada though. 

Nachos are delish!
I always get the naked burrito with the pork cooked in green chile verde??? Something like that. 
Breakfast stuff is good as well.
author: Jangalina J.

description:
They've raised prices and quality of food is down. A regular burrito has turned into a skinny burrito. The steak tastes like old meat. 

The cashiers could at least smile, I mean, how hard is that?

I've been going here for the past 2 years and the overall quality is going downhill.
author: Ray C.

description:
Had to do you an updated review for these guys. I love this place and the hot sauce and the grilled chicken and steak....BUT .... Do NOT order the triple threat burrito. For some reason this burrito is 20 dollars and it's the same exact size as the other burritos on the menu that are half the price.  The only difference is that they put chicken steak and shrimp in the burrito.
I recommend ordering two burritos and a side of shrimp and mixing it all together yourself for 20 bucks.
A 20 dollar burrito should feed at least 2 to 3 people.

Come on guys WTF? You just lost a star
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I have repoltalote! (when you are sad you went to Papalote for any number of reasons.) 

Honestly, no idea how this place gets a best burrito in the city. I normally don't go against the grain but seriously, I think it should be on the bottom of the list. Nothing near top ten at all. Am I missing something. Are there people in this world that like to over pay for things that have far less value then to be expected. 
 
I have tried multiple items, "maybe its just me?" 

The Carne Asada is dry
The Mole overly salty 
The Chile Verde tastes rotten 
The Cameroons are dry and under odd flavored 
The Grilled Chicken is also dry 
The nachos , tacos, burrito all way under par!

Over and over I give it a chance but it always is either over cooked, under cooked, no flavor or just no flavors and nasty. 

Sometimes the staff is rude, no matter how nice they might be they always mess it up. I once waited almost a half an hour for my order while everyone who came in after for at least 15 minutes walked out with their food?

Zagat = #7 http://blog.zagat.com/2013/05/8-best-burritos-around-san-francisco.html

Yelp = #4 http://www.yelp.com/search?find_desc=best+burrito&find_loc=San+Francisco%2C+CA

10. Papalote Mexican Grill http://blogs.sfweekly.com/foodie/2012/01/san_franciscos_top_10_burritos.php

2. Papalote http://www.7x7.com/eat-drink/top-6-super-carne-asada-burritos-sf-ringer-thrown

It's won pretty much every burrito award imaginable. http://sfist.com/2013/10/09/best_places_to_get_a_burrito_in_san.php

HOW CAN THIS BE? 

The salsa is good and the chips are alright, I can give them that much. But not much else. Way over priced. 
It is possible that a bunch of people who have no clue moved in to the city and had their very first "Mexican" food experience at this place. As they have never ever ever had a burrito before in their lifetime they might come to the conclusion that "wow that's great" and then when it comes time to vote they have an opinion that is founded on one simple experience and totally unfounded. I think that must be what is happening. There could be another explanation, except this: Some criminal burrito conspiracy or that its a front for some something (and that could explain some things). However, I think the simple explanation is best. No one knows what the hell is a good burrito is and what it should taste like, then they vote and this place as gets some unfounded accolades.Don't fall for it San Francisco.  This place has food that can't come close to competing. 

Even when the place is dead they still manage to screw up my order. Literally no one and only one order to fill. Can't even get it right.
author: Ben M.

description:
I got the chicken quesadilla and it was good-just a normal quesadilla. Hard to screw up a quesadilla. This being said I'm not sure anyone should ever pay $10 for quesadilla. Adding sour cream was an extra $1.50 which is just ridiculous. I would go back for another or a naked soyrizo burrito mostly because it's super convenient to where I live.  
Oh the chips are nothing special. Mine were stale.
author: Mallory L.

description:
I'm really not a fan of this place any more.  I used to stop by regularly because the restaurant in NOPA is right around the corner from my house.  But, they seem to continually jack up the prices and now it's unreasonable.  I think a steak burrito costs $12 or more now after taxes.

El Rancho Grande on Divis. is where I go now.  It's a much better burrito and feels more authentic.
author: Alec M.

description: Definitely a great place for Mexican food! Meat was full of flavor burrito was loaded. I love how they kinda like toast the burrito giving it a crunchy feel to it. I ordered a carne asada burrito and man it did not disappoint.
author: Jorge G.

description:
A bit pricey, but if you're vegetarian it's worth it for one of the best veggie burritos in the city (and one of the best assortments). The achiote marinated tofu is incredible.

Oh, and the salsa... *swoon*
author: Alex Y.

description:
Pro's:
  * Big portion sizes: Well worth the money.
  * Lots of vegetarian (and vegan) options for the herbivores
  * Mole sauce: Chicken mole! (and a tofu option as well)
  * Delicious salsa: Apparently I can even find/buy this salsa at Whole Foods, etc.
  * HUGE bag of tortilla chips with every take-out order
  * Chilaquiles were extremely satisfying and filling.

Con's:
  * Street parking: Feeling lucky?
  * Small dining area: I can see this place getting packed around lunchtime.
  * I wish they had Horchata (but that's probably just me)
author: U C.

description:
I write this review with the hope that some hungry soul will have a great Mexican dinning experience, by going elsewhere.  I gave it 2 tries, totally uninspired; eat here only if you have to.  The place looks worn and tired.  (On a Sunday trash was piled high in front of the place, in anticipation of garbage day the next morning?  Classy.)  I tried the "naked burrito" the first time.  A mushy mess in a bowl over wilted lettuce.  Horrid.  Second time, just a steak burrito, a safe bet.  Bland meat, bland everything.  $9 dollars. (add 99cents for "super" to make it a $10. burrito; get this, they have a $20. burrito on the menu.  Pass.) 
It looks and smells dirty, and the food is marginal at best.  The staff not terribly friendly.   Maybe I am spoiled by the Mission or So-Cal Mexican joints. If you reviewed this place and "loved it!"  I have no idea why! I wont be back, ever.
author: brian s.

description: Walked in to an empty restaurant and proceeded to wait 15 minutes for a takeout burrito while they made a large catering order. I would recommend either communicating that they are stealthily busy or working on orders in parallel.
author: Robert Q.

description: I went to Papalote after seeing it on TV for one of the best burritos in SF.  Was very disappointed.  The burrito  I got was average at best.  Salsa not tasty or spicy.  Three adults was over $75.  Expensive for what you get.  I have been to much better places.
author: Bob B.

description:
Once again after trying a restaurant with lots of hype I am left dissapointed.

I took my food to go. Though while ordering and waiting for food, service was excellent and cordial and even the kites were pretty... (Papalote means "kite" in Spanish).

I had the chicken mole burrito and I was incredibly excited of the prospect of such. Overall the food is overpriced and bland. The chicken they used was interesting,  mole sauce had lukewarm moments of catching my attention,  and the ingredients seemed fresh. I did also like that the burrito was lighter compared to others and I didn't feel awful after eating the whole thing.

But nothing really wowed me and the hype this place gets really doesn't seem deserved. Food is just okay. Doubt I'll frequent this place too often as there are plenty of other more flavorful choices in the city.
author: Alejandro T.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped by before OSL to get a quick eat that would fill us up for a good portion of the day! We both opted for carne asada burritos and they were delicious and huge! I love that the meat is made to order which is fresher and tastier. It definitely puts Papalote above your typical burrito. The only downside is that you end up waiting longer! Their burritos are delicious with their creamy "salsa" which comes on the side with chips!

Although the burritos are almost $10. I think they are highly worth paying the premium!
author: Britney L.

description:
I've had the burritos before....they are satisfactory. Others in the neighborhood are just as good if not better. Green Chili Kitchen, El Rancho Grande etc.

I called in a steak and prawn burrito...I get one often at Las Palmas down on 3rd street. Was not given a total on the phone and was quite surprised when I arrive to hear $19.75. Apparently adding 3-4 prawns is a $7.75 upgrade!

I didnt argue and went ahead and paid the bill. Checking the bag they only give you one tiny cup of salsa....so I asked for one more please......"That will be 50 cents Sir"......I replied with "Um....I'm sorry but I just bought a $19.75 B-U-R-R-I-T-O.....can I please just have another salsa cup?"

"I'm sorry Sir....that's our policy"

Sorry Papalote....you aint all that.....and if you are going to hit me with "that's our policy" then you just lost a customer as I will never go back there again. I will be taking all my guests, friends and visitors elsewhere for our Mexican fare.

That just seemed ridiculous to me.....
author: Joe B.

description:
If you go to school at USF, you'd know that there really isn't a lot of restaurants that are within a few minutes (walking). Because of Paplote's proximity to the school, I have come here a few times. I have to say that I do not particularly like the burritos nor the nachos here. 

It's nearly $10 for a burrito and another $10 for nachos. That's a little expensive for a taqueria in my opinion. Yes, it's a difference of maybe just $1-3 compared to another local taqueria but for a $10 burrito, I expect more.

I got nachos the most recent time I came here and they were disappointing. The steak isn't like carne asada. There's not really much flavor to it to be honest. The cheese was no melty either. It looked like it was slightly melted and then quickly hardened again. I could have done with a little more guacamole too. I probably won't come back here again. I'll have to go to Chino's Taqueria in the Richmond district to satisfy my nacho craving!
author: Connie Y.

description: Chicken super burrito is my go to! I come multiple times per week, and it's amazing every single time! The carne asada is also good here!
author: Jenna M.

description: Update: pollo asado burrito is even better than carne asada! Delivery was fast and the food was still hot. Added bonus chips and fabulous homemade salsa were the cherry on top.
author: Liz G.

description:
Potatoes in burritos? When its not a breakfast burrito I just don't get it...
Many better places to get a tasty burrito, but to be fair I only went once and never returned to give it another shot.
author: Navjeet K.

description:
To be fair I have to say that the food here is not bad, but I have to say depending on what type of latin cuisine your looking for I would say that there are better.

 I often hear friends and others state that this is one of the best burritos you can possibly get here in SF. Also I hear people raving about the sauce here and how it too is also the best. I have to say that IF a burrito is what your looking for then look around, your bound to find a better one especially in the mission. Also the sauce, while not bad does not make the burrito from Paplote's the best. I feel like people really hype this up. With that being said its not a terrible place to go.
author: Stephen A.

description:
Great Salsa. I usually get a cheese quesadilla and they put rice and beans inside the quesadilla as well. 


Only downside to this place is lack of room inside. They have a half bar and only about 3 tables. 

Prices are fair for the city.
author: Grant S.

description: Have been here plenty of times due to it being close to my school. The burritos are average but the salsas are amazing, pricier than the mission burritos but its due to the location. I think the carne asada is the best in my opinion.
author: Josue V.

description:
Okay

People are nice. I got a regular burrito  - nothing especial.

Thank you.

Uttam
author: Uttam S.

description:
$30 later for two burritos and some machaca con huevo... I don't get why this place is rated at 4+ stars. 50 cents extra for every small plastic cup of salsa...what!

I have eaten at tons of burrito places and for 9 bucks a burrito, you should expect something out of the ordinary. 

I guess with place is popular because of convenience and not because of the food. 

My machaca con huevo didn't look too good as this dish is supposed to come with shredded beef. I gave it the benefit of the doubt and was way too generous.

Nothing but a big disappointment. Nothing worse than spending 9 bucks on a burrito and being disappointed.

The clientele is also not very mixed, which should give you a idea! My recommendation, is don't go
author: Brandon Y.

description:
On Papalote's website and menu, there were excerpts:
"Best Burrito, 2007" 
"Favorite Nachos in SF"
"...best salsa on the planet"

After my meal, I wondered if those critics and I ate at the same place. Not that the food was horrible, but I've definitely had better burritos, nachos and salsas. And in SF.

Super Carne Asada Burrito: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s8uX4sYQM2_HeCab7leG5A?select=11dpv3TjV06CWESN954dDQ) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s8uX4sYQM2_HeCab7leG5A?select=orQ0iJO1Ue2M7-3mNVQJPw) The carne asada was minced into such small pieces, it seemed to have disappeared in the mist of the rice, beans, guacamole, sour cream, salsa and cheese. The overall burrito was small for a 'super'. It also lacked texture. Too mushy. Could've been mistaken for a bean and cheese burrito.

Super Nachos: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s8uX4sYQM2_HeCab7leG5A?select=-D9wdVvXANbApBXKbPDrCg) With only 20 chips on the plate I felt jipped. And I paid 99 cents extra to only get a small dallop of sour cream and guacamole?? 

Chips and Salsa: Chips, slightly stale. Salsa, interesting orange color. Spicy but lacked flavor. 

Its supposedly a great place for vegetarians. So bravo for that.

2.5 stars seem harsh. But in all honesty, I've "experienced better".
author: Marti L.

description:
Cool place... just know what you want before you walk up to the register.

Burritos are filling. 

The salsa they give you is pretty good too....

A bit tight inside, but it's perfectly suitable in the end.
author: Michael K.

description: Came here during bay 2 breakers. Few things can satisfy a drunk exhausted craving like a super monstrous quesadilla with good salsas. Nom nom
author: Vinitha R.

description:
I eat a plant based diet (vegan) and grabbed a "vegan" soyrizo burrito from here last night, as take-out. The burrito was so-so, and then I bit down on something chewy. There was a big hunk of red meat in the middle of it.

Very frustrating and this shows that Papalote, at least this particular location, is not careful with keeping their grills clean and sanitized for those of us who avoid meat (albeit for allergies, or health, or moral, or environment, or other reasons).

So yeah. If you are vegan or vegetarian: AVOID.
author: Will M.

description:
I buy their salsa in the store all the time. Believe it or not there's a great pasta recipe using the salsa found somewhere online. But this has little to do with the restaurant.

This is a nice little stop for burritos or tacos for lunch, at least that's been my experience a couple of times.

Tasty flavors. Seems maybe a bit spendy for what you get though so it might not be your cheapest burritto joint.
author: Brad C.

description: I asked for a steak burrito bowl with extra meat, my total was a whopping $17.22 which I find absolutely ridiculous for a hole in the wall Mexican restraunt. When I got my food, I saw barely any meat and requested that they add more. They simply looked at me and said that there's already "extra meat".
author: Ali A.

description:
Instead of offering a full line up of salsa like other places, Papalote perfects their one and only salsa, and it works. It works. Hook, line, and sinker, as people say.

Well, I suppose it couldn't have worked without killer burritos, tacos, and quesadillas. While I haven't tried any of the entrees, I can attest to those three standard offerings. I like the meat choices, which include soyrizo and mole, though I would like to see chorizo as well. I like that there are seafood choices. I'm glad that there is no pollo and only pollo asado. I love that they offer black beans refried. I love that they throw the tortilla on the grill instead of a steam press to get it to a mild crisp before rolling it up.

This location compared to the other, has much fewer seats and operates at the same speed.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Guys cooking and packing orders are in a great mood. I do wish the girl at the front would have asked me what kind of tortilla I wanted when she asked about my bean choice. Also ask if we want it super! Upswell girl. I forgot to tell her..bummer. They now offer brown rice. 

Mole Burrito: made it a super for .99 added lettuce and onions! Really good. Not the best mile I have ever had but did the trick! Wish they would have put more sour cream. Not visible at all nor could I taste it. 

Chicken Burrito: made it a super. Nice and flavorful. Grilled chicken was moist.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Always friendly! My favorite go to burrito spot in SF. I order the "Super" tasty "Mexipino Burrito"(only place I know in the world that serves this) Or a delicious Carne Asada burrito, on a Spinach Tortilla wrap, with Black Beans and House Salsa is unique, one of the best I have ever tasted in my life, it's also sold in local SF Wholefoods Markets. If your used to eating cheap mexican food (that sometimes makes you sick)with cheap ingredients that tastes cheap go somewhere else. Papalote is my standard for good Mexican food. Also another larger location in the Mssion/Dolores Park area
author: Joe G.

description: I went here today for the first time and looked at the menu before I got there. I ordered the vegan mole.  I was under the impression that it was an entrée as that is what is said on the menu, however, I was given a Burrito.  When I asked the girl at the register about it, she said they don't serve that as an Entrée.  No explanation, apology or even kindness.  I felt like she was treating me as if I was an idiot.  I quickly left as it was clear there would be no discussion, with a burro I didn't want.... won't be back again.  Maybe I will try the other venue as the food seems good, just had a bad experience.
author: Maureen O.

description:
I'm not gonna lie. I think you could get a workout in before eating these burritos if you just do a few reps of bicep curls with them before peeling back that foil wrapper and ingesting what has got to be close to 2,000 calories in a tortilla. These suckers are h.e.a.v.y!

I also want to point out that it's nice that they have so many vegetarian and vegan options for people that swing that way. But, the best part is the flavors are still great even if you are a meat-eating machine. 

Based on all the rave reviews I had the chicken adobo burrito and while I agree the flavors were good the burrito itself was a tiny bit dry before I added in that delicious salsa goodness. Oh my! That really turned my burrito experience around, saving the day in my honest opinion. So I guess I'm agreeing with the hundreds of other people who have reviewed Papalote - yes, the salsa really is that good!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
This place is obscenely overpriced for the quality of food it provides. $18.50 for a burrito with steak and shrimp?!? A burrito should never cost that much unless perhaps there are pieces of gold and diamonds lodged inside of it. I have ordered the exact same thing from Panchos and the numerous taquerias around the city and it has never amounted to that much - at most $11-12 (and that's the pricier range). Perhaps I would feel less disenfranchised if the quality was worth the price. But seriously, the burritos here are ordinary at best. Nothing about their preparation sets them apart from what you can find anywhere in the Mission, and yet the prices are exponentially higher.

I should have gone to Celia's by the Beach where I could have gotten a really good quality huge platter of three enchiladas, rice, beans, chips and salsa for less money than what this one regular sized burrito cost me. A burrito which, by the way, doesn't even use fresh steak like they do at La Chihuahuas only a few blocks away (or even at Chipotle for that matter).

Utterly annoyed by this restaurant's INSANE PRICES yet again. Wish it wasn't the closest burrito shop to my school otherwise coming here wouldn't even be an option. But that's probably why they jack up the prices, because they know all the kids flock here because it is one of the only restaurants in near walking distance to campus. Seriously, Celia's, La Chihuahua, or even Panchos given the comparable quality and lower prices are way better bangs for your buck. Just sayin...
author: Courtney T.

description: Salsa for chips is not your ordinary.  Not impressed.  Mole chicken was too sweet.  Burrito was not standard pound I'm used to and not wrapped tight.  Fell apart!  I don't see what all the hype is about.  Service not great either.  Overpriced too!
author: Chris S.

description:
I live near this place--one of the only quick, not-so-expensive (though not really!) places in the neighborhood--and I've come here maybe a dozen times in the past year, hoping it would get better. It's just not worth the price, or the effort it takes to walk a block from my place, and I'm bummed to say that. 

A plain quesadilla with just cheese and steak is $9.71. That's too much--and burritos cost more. The beans in the burritos are never drained enough, leaving a soggy, wet mess (and if you get your food "super," AKA with cheese, guacamole, and sour cream, it's worse). The meat just doesn't taste that good. The chips are always stale, which I think speaks to how little they care about their food quality.

I really tried to give Papalote a chance, but I won't be coming back, no matter how lazy I'm feeling.
author: Julia R.

description:
Let's be real the burritos are amazing. The nachos are pretty good too.. A lot of people say this isn't "authentic" Mexican, but that's exactly the point. The city is full of cuisine that often melts various cultures together. 

However, with the Latin and Filipino influence, you would think the seating would encourage face to face or community style eating. Instead you sit at a small barstool 6inches from a blank wall. If you decide to open a new spot you should consult me about dining ambiance. Maybe get a place with a patio, that would be Ill. I know a lot of this is the SF landlords faults with their redic rental pricing. 

Don't order the tacos, I kinda wanted to ask for a refund because I barely got any meat and instead was greeted with a mountain of lettuce and tomatoes. If you're vegan that's cool i guess. 

It's def worth trying if you go all out and get a burrito with prawns and of course the hot sauce is a thing of legend. 

Btw, the owner of the joint is a dope dj check him out.
author: Jerry S.

description: Waiting time is ridiculously long!!! Waited for an hour for my tacos to be served!! Bad service. Will not come back.
author: Krizzia C.

description: So I came to this place since I saw lots of post on instagram lol. When I walked in they had iamsu playing so I found it pretty amusing. Everything was mostly vegetarian until I found some meat on the menu. Honestly best burrito I have ever had. PERIOD. The flavor was pure delight and the atmosphere was pretty chill. Took some salsa on the road because that's how good it was. Other than that the food was great and I will surely come back here again.
author: Luis M.

description:
I randomly stopped by Papalote after Bay to Breakers without even knowledge of their rating on Yelp (which is rare). I was massively craving a breakfast burrito and Papalote answered by craving and then some. I got a breakfast burrito and it was so well prepared. I can only imagine how good the actual burritos are. 

To me, the salsa wasn't the best thing about this place. I love a good salsa, but I like the more authentic sharp spiced salsa. The salsa wasn't worth the "hype" I guess, in my opinion.

They are also on the pricey end for a burrito... It was nearly 9 bucks for a breakfast burrito, a little steep especially for a place without any real seating. My consensus is that this was an amazing burrito, partially skewed by how hungry I was after the race. But it gets 1 star knocked down for pricing and another for the lack of seating. Food is solid, wouldn't say it justifies the higher pricing.
author: Diane P.

description:
Self proclaimed "best burrito in SF".  What an overrated experience.  The hype is definitely undeserved.  This place has always been popular with the hipster crowd but with the owners' appearance on a Food Channel show the promotion of the place has reached mainstream level.

The food is actually decent.  It's not bad at all and in someways reflects what you would get at your local chain Chipotle, a Chipotle without the value.  Everything you get in ingredients at Chipotle you get a little less of it at Popalote.  It's really absurd they are now charging in excess of $20 for a single burrito.  What's even more egregious is that the raising of prices coincided with the TV appearance.  A brazen attempt to charge more just because they know their regular customers are foolish enough to spend more.

There are many Taqueria's in SF that are better not just in value but are just plainly better.  It seems such as scam to proclaim the idea that we make better tacos and burritos because we are a "Mexican Grill."  I cringe at the notion that people go here instead of the other Mission Taquerias for the reason that since its decor is cleaner the food somehow must be more elevated.  

The way this place hides behind the idea that they are "organic" thus justifying their prices is laughable.  Go check out the Taco Shop at Underdog's for a true elevated "Mexical Grill."  geez, if you wanted to get mexican food from a place that only sources organic food simply go to Chipotle.
author: Stephen V.

description:
So the food is marginal to okay.  I've eaten here several times and find the value extremely poor.  Its close to my apartment so I opt to go here occasionally, but no more.  

We ordered a quesadilla  and chili verde, total bill, over $25 bucks.  See pictures.  The portion size is really below average.  The pork in the chile verde was dry, how do you dry out pork cooked in a chili sauce?  Save yourself the trip and find an authentic Mexican restaurant in the mission that gives you value.  Seriously you'll get double the portion size for what you pay here.  This place is taking advantage of the SF prices.
author: Ken B.

description:
Our home away from home. We live right behind Papalote, and on weekend mornings I can smell the sweet carne on the grill, marking time and reminding me that I have slept in till lunch. My roommate eats here so often that his mint.com account warned him that he was spending a disproportionate amount of his finances there.

One of my new year's resolutions for 2013 is to try every flavor of burrito (I know, dream big). So far I've had the chicken, roasted vegetable, soyrizo, steak and today, the Chile Verde. The soyrizo has been the most unexpectedly delicious, and to be honest, once my project is over I will probably be an exclusive soyrizo burrito eater. But I have to continue on with my resolution, and what a delicious resolution it is!

Really, you can't go wrong with the burritos. But DO stick with their burritos. I have done the tacos and they are nowhere near as good. Also, they are pretty much packed all the time, so ordering on the phone really is the way to go.
author: Serena Q.

description:
Papalote has great salsa -- that's its selling point. Their burritos are fine, especially once you drench them in that delicious salsa. Papalote is convenient for me, so I'm here all the time, but I don't think it's worth a trek if you're not nearby. 
Order anything, just make sure to a take a jar of salsa home!
author: Erica W.

description:
Favorites here include the shrimp burrito and the fish burrito.  All items are cooked to order, including the pan fried garlic shrimp and buttery, white wine infused fish.

Parking here is PAINFUL  --better chances of winning the lottery.  So walk in, walk out, and BART or MUNI away.

Seating is near impossible during much of the day, but these simple, steady and fantastic burritos live up to their reputation.  Eyes rolling into the back of your head goodness.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I'd heard about this place a few times - from friends and also as it was featured on Throwdown with Bobby Flay. 

Had the carne asada quesadilla and it was pretty good! The portion size wasn't super big (a la La Vic's) but was a good lunch size, and the accompanying spoonful of pickled jicama and beet salad was very refreshing (I do mean "spoonful, however).  I will also attest that the chips and salsa were just as satisfying as reported. I still could use a little variety though. :) I'll be back to try a few other menu items!
author: Rachel M.

description: This place is awesome. It used to be more awesome when it wasn't as popular but there's no way I can prevent that from happening. Their salsa as everyone knows is out of this world. Just wish they would fill up their burritos like they used to.
author: Gabriela H.

description:
I'll tell you what - despite what many claim to be the best Mexican food in the entire city, I think the fare at Papalote is just average at best. Sorry, y'allz. BUT, the salsa, on the other hand, could melt the panties right off of an ascetic nun. It's that good. 

Seriously, I'm not sure what kind of crack rocks they add to their fire roasted chipotle pepper hot sauce, but whatever it is, I'd very much like to be buried in a casket filled to the brim with heaping piles of the fiery condiment when I fade to black on December 21st, 2012 (if there's a living trust attorney reading this, please make note). There's a reason the crew at Papalote began selling in by the jar online, in store, and at various other grocery outlets in San Francisco - it's simply amazing!

They also have real Mexican Coca Cola and Squirt when you dine in, but watch out, the real stuff really packs a punch on the caloric scale. The nutrition label on the bottle of Squirt I drank in 35 seconds revealed that it rings in at 360 calories. That's an entire 30 minutes on the treadmill, yo!
author: Ruggy J.

description: Customer since 2010. This location has gone down hill, both in terms of quality and cleanliness. After my most recent visit 2 days ago, I do not think I will ever be back. I could taste cleaning chemicals on my food. Ironically, this place does not look clean at all. While ordering, the back area was completely open and exposed dirty floors and gross surfaces--I would have just walked out had I not been with a friend. Please clean this place up!
author: Alex M.

description:
Instead of the usual burrito full of succulent chunks of fish, I got a burrito full of rice and beans. While expensive, I'd say the fish burrito at the Mission location is worth the $11 they charge, because it's actually full of delicious fish. 

The burrito at this Fulton location sucked, and had maybe 2 tablespoons of fish, tops, with the rest being rice and beans. The taste was also not as good.

I wouldn't go back to this location, and the quality was so poor that I might just not go back to the Mission location either, for fear that it might have also gone downhill.

Standardize your offerings, unless you've totally sold out in the process of expansion.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
I typically eat here 1 time a week or more. I think the food is great aside from their chips which are not fresh and hard and very sad. They should make their own chips. 

I'm giving them a 1 right now because while I was waiting on my nachos I think 2 Fridays ago I watched the person working the grill. I watched as the person cooking the meat on the grill reached into the drawers below the oven and pull out slices of meat with his bare hands. He followed that up by grabbing the spatula and flipping the meat. He did not wipe of his hands or show any concern for the raw chicken he had on his hands. 

Well today I saw the same thing happen when I was eating in the Financial District at Tlaloc and I'm going to post on their wall about it now. 

YOU MUST LEARN PROPER FOOD HANDLING TECHNIQUES OR DON"T SERVE FOOD.
author: Mack L.

description: We have been to papalote a few times, but always the Mission location and were in the mood for a quick take-out dinner so decided to check out this location. We are vegetarians and papalote appeals to us because it is one of the few taquerias we have happened upon with a number of vegetarian offerings. We got the marinated tofu burrito, which was fantastic and better than the mole and soyrizo we have gotten before. We also got grilled veggie tacos, which fell apart by the time we ate them (10 minutes after carrying out) at home -- we would be willing to try the grilled veggies again, but not in the taco and will probably stick to burritos (or try it as a burrito bowl -- "naked"). While you do have to pay for guacamole, it is worth it. Their hot sauce is fantastic. This place remains our favorite taqueria in the city, not named Chipotle (JK -- sort of).
author: T K.

description: My "go to" Mexican restaurant! Their salsa is amazing, and I enjoy their ensalada when I'm watching my carbs. I especially like their pinto beans and shrimp (Camarones).
author: Nora K.

description: The location isn't all that nice inside and it's a pretty crazy corner of Divis, but I do love their burritos. High quality ingredients, a whole wheat tortilla option and addictive chips and salsa make this one of my favored spots. Phone ordering is the way to go... one brilliant innovation: a dedicated cashier for in store customers and another who manages phone orders.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
If you're into expensive burritos with only the best ingredients made fresh to order, then definitely try Papalote!  Your burrito arrives with generous portions of meat balanced with rice and beans. The meat is grilled to order and there is no sign of grease anywhere to be found.  Yum yum...

Parking sucks and seating is limited, but I crave those burritos all day.
author: Nathan E.

description: Papalote has the best salsa in the Bay!!!  Always ask to buy some fresh in the mason jars to take home. I pour them on my eggs almost every day.  If you go... get the chicken mole tacos or the mole burrito. You'll keep coming back for more!
author: Kris D.

description: Was very excited when we moved a few blocks from this Papalote location, as I had been to the one in the Mission a few times and loved the salsa and vegetarian options.  The upside is that as a vegetarian, you have lots of options to add the you burrito, quesadilla, etc.  Soy-rizo or marinated tofu in the quesadilla are our favorites.  On the food alone, I would give them 4/5 stars, but there are certainly better burritos to be had in SF--just not really around the Panhandle.  But 0/5 for service, so that averages to 2/5.  The people behind the register here should be fired.  Where is the owner, as his/her business is suffering?  They are rude, inattentive, and would rather be watching the soccer match on the TV next to the register.  If you can get their attention, they may do you a giant favor and take your order.  They stop answering the phone about 30 minutes before closing, presumably so they don't have to serve you.  They don't give enough salsa, then charge extra if you ask for more, whereas most other taquerias have self-serve stations where you can take as much as you like.  After charging me almost $14 for a vegetarian burrito, charging me anything for an extra 1oz of salsa is pretty low.  I would definitely go here more often if the experience wasn't so aggravating.
author: Damian E.

description:
When I go to Papalote, it's because of the delicious orange god sauce salsa. 

Words cannot describe the deliciousness of this salsa. It's this bright orange puree, super flavorful, with the right amount of spice. You can tell it's made from some combinations of roasted peppers. The guesses are endless on the mystery of what is in this delicious salsa puree. 

My only petpeeve with this place is whenever I go to the NOPA location the avocados in the guacomole always tastes unfresh. I'm overly picky about the freshness state of my avocados though, so it might just be me. It's kind of sad for me though, because I feel like I always have to ask to leave off the guac at the NOPA location and guac is kind of my thing. 

Overall a satisfying amount of deliciousness can be had here.
author: Kim C.

description:
Papalote never ceases to satisfy.  The options are vast, the quality is tremendous and that salsa is damn good.  Service is usually quite prompt and I love that they take credit cards including Amex without a dumb minimum unlike some of their compadres in and around the city.

As a vegetarian, this place is like heaven for me.  So many different options to choose from!  One that I recommend is the veggie soyrizo: very flavorful and filling.  

My only grip is the pricing.  It's a bit higher than what I would like, but I suppose it's in line with other burrito joints in the area.  I guess they get away with it in SF.
author: Kavi D.

description: Free Creamy spicy dip for chips when you eat in and the service is quick about 5-10 minutes
author: Jasper L.

description: Went here with some friends the other day, and this place has some of the best burritos in the city. I also loved their orange salsa.
author: Emily G.

description:
Considerably disappointed by this overhyped burrito. The guac inside had transformed into ghoulish brown gunk and obviously was not fresh/ had been sitting out all day oxidizing. The burrito was loosely rolled and falling apart as I struggled to get through my $10 worth of its mushy, texture-less contents. 
The best thing on the plate was the little side of fresh slaw (Jicama I think?) and their unique orange salsa, which reminded me of vodka sauce oddly enough.
Save yourself some heartache and stick with El Farolito or Taqueria.
author: Dana D.

description:
I believe Papalote to be perhaps the best burrito spot in SF.   I have eaten more burritos than I care to admit, and I have found the ingredients and flavor to be top of the shelf.  Not the cheapest spot in town- two super burritos cost me an even $20 today with a tip included, but they were well worth it.  All orders do come with free chips and their special salsa/sauce...

The quality of the ingredients is one of the first things you will notice when you take your first bite of their food.  Most burrito spots will smother/hide the lesser quality meats in sour cream and salsa, but not here. As with any place- you need to know what to order- and I keep going back over and over for their pork chili verde burrito- their closest comparable to a carnitas which comes in a spicy tangy green chili sauce.  Order this one in a whole wheat burrito with black beans and you are well on your way to happiness.  While I am not a huge fan of the chips, the salsa dipping sauce is phenomenal.  Spicy as well as a bit creamy.  Very yummy, so popular you can now find it on the shelves at Wholefoods.

Anyways, you will never go wrong if you visit either Papalote location.  My favorite all-time burrito spot (in Sonoma), Juanita Juanita, knocks it's socks off, but I can't drive 90 miles round-trip each day for a burrito.  Papalote compares favorably or better than some of my other local favorites, such as Gordo's, La Canasta, and Nick's Crispy tacos, all of which I now frequent less often because I usually go out of my way for Papalote.
author: Andy S.

description:
Food is quite tasty, and I know many people who have more taste buds than me that really like this place.  I would LIKE to give it a better review, but for the HIGH PRICES they are SLOW and PRETTY DISORGANIZED, especially in the land of hyper effective burrito teams.  They messed up my order recently and I had to go all the way back-- and note, there is NO PARKING on that stretch of Fulton, me with 4 hungry kids and the wrong order FOR NO REASON.

 As of 2013, crowded, super long waits, high prices-- THINGS THAT MIGHT BE FIXED but perhaps NO MOTIVATION when profit margins are THAT high.  SF needs less of this kind of thing.
author: Kurt S.

description:
The food isn't amazing. It's not bad, better than the chipotles of the world for sure but not up to California burrito standards.

but i swear their salsa has crack in it. It's so amazing and you just can't stop eating it. It's rich and smokey with just enough heat. I could eat it out of a bowl. without utensils.
author: Misha T.

description:
Papalote doesn't have my favorite burrito ever, but they come pretty close.

So it's noon on a Friday, you're hungover with a bag full of hangers from Lucky's across the street, and all you want is a super chicken burrito. And they've got it. Papalote has all the little extras you're looking for - from a variety of tortillas to thick, cheesy breakfast options.

The prices aren't great, but they're not horrible. It's to be expected. Pretty speedy time from register to bag, and you're out the door. There's not a lot of seating, but that's okay.

Mostly I just want to get home to eat the kind of food you can only eat in private: sloppy, delicious, and filling.
author: Jiordan C.

description:
Did you know this place serves breakfast burritos all freakin' day long? Where else does that? Not many places to be sure!

My current favorite is to get the Spanish Omelette burrito. Breakfast in tube shaped form! Beware, it is a bit salty, but I'm a big fan of salt. If you're not, you might want to avoid.
author: Rachel H.

description: I am not a big fan of Mexican food, but this place is actually pretty good ! I like how their burrito is not too heavy and it's not dry. I usually get the shrimp burrito without beans and I absolutely love it. Their tomato salsa is really good as well , so definitely get an extra one for the burrito too. I will definitely be back to try the other stuff on their menus. However, I am taking a star off for it being on the pricier side without much difference in ingredients than any other cheaper taqueria.
author: Lucy C.

description:
Incredible salsa!! Ohh man.

Ordered shrimp tacos. Really delicious grilled shrimp piled high with lettuce and pico de gallo. Although I wish they hadn't put so much guac and cheese on top of the whole thing. That sort of overpowered the other flavors. Next time i'll order it without.

I was surprised at so many veggie options. Tofu burritos, soyrizo, vegan mole! How cool. 

The place was jam packed with people, post bay to breakers hunger strikes. But the staff was rocking it. Smiling faces quickly making order after order. I was mesmerized by the burrito wrapping man. Each time, he skillfully folded the giant tortilla shut. Then he would flick his wrist and the whole thing would envelope itself in foil. It was like he was a speeded up cartoon video!
author: Sonia D.

description:
My friend described this place pretty well when we were eating here. "You don't get that shitty feeling after eating burritos here." That pretty much sums up how I feel about this place.

I got the Pescado Burrito and I didn't feel like crap after I devoured the beast (like I usually do). The ingredients tasted fresh and the chips/salsa they give is also tasty. The salsa is similar to the Orange Sauce at this other restaurant in San Jose called La Vic's. I also got this good Mexican lemon-lime soda.

Anyway, great place to get a fresh-tasting burrito.
author: Marlon T.

description: Chill small place. Girl who took my order had a low voice as if whispering. I order the super burrito carne asada. Size was like a chipotle burrito. I'm stuffed
author: B M.

description:
I fell in love with Papalote in the Mission back in 2005 before the Food Network/Bobby Flay Throw Down. The fact that it's blown up speaks for itself. 

The salsa is a must- buy a jar, you won't regret it. My regular faves are the Triple Threat (grilled chicken, prawns and carne asada) and the Adobo (adobo shredded chicken, garlic rice, and tomatoes) burritos. 

Get a frequent buyer card! Trust, you will use it.
author: S Y.

description: We came because my husband wanted the triple threat. His burrito was okay. I got a vegetable quesadilla, and the squash was hard. I ended up picking it out and turning it into a broken cheese quesadilla. Guacamole and salsa were great. Chips were good. Limited seating.
author: Steph D.

description:
Chicken mole is my favorite meat option at any taqueria, but surprisingly rare.  I was happy to find a place near my apartment that had it.  Three stars for a decent burrito and salsa combo.  The salsa was surprisingly creamy and spicy -- good I thought -- but not my style of salsa.  The chicken mole burrito was okay, but too boring to finish, even with the sour cream and guacamole additions.  

As I caste the remnants of my unfinished burrito in the trash, I still knew not the destructive source of my putrid demise.  Negative four stars for the ruinous food poisoning.  That makes negative one, but alas, no star rating possible can vilify this place adequately.  Seriously, avoid papalote and its bacteria-infested chicken mole.
author: Andy H.

description:
I can't figure out what the fuss is about this place.  It is an $11 burrito (really?) that is decent but not exceptional.  It gets packed in here at lunch and they charge you 50 cents extra for an additional tiny cup of salsa = pretty lame.  

Get down to the Mission to an actual Taqueria and spend under $7 for something that tastes better.
author: Kellan M.

description: Great little hole in the wall for some good authentic food.
author: Leo Y.

description:
Tip added during first visit since moving over here: "You may look at the Panhandle as the Rubicon, but cross it as this location is walkable from the Haight." 

And, I'll cross the Rubicon for a chicken mole burrito. It's a rare species. I'd rather hold my entree with two hands and in pipe form rather than on a bed of rice. Go ahead, it's okay, consider that a character trait that could translate in other ways.
author: Jon A.

description: Triple Threat Burrito because Aron Sanchez said so on Taco Trip. Meh....good but $19.95 is pretty expensive.
author: M J.

description:
I really dig the salsa. It's hard to find good salsa these days, especially one that seems to separate itself from all the rest. It's full of flavors and fitting for anything you choose to douse it with. 

I've been to both the Mission and Fulton location and they seem to be spot on with each other. At Mission, I loved their Mexipino burrito. At Fulton, I recommend the prawn burrito. I saw them cook it and noticed they only embedded at least 4 prawns. I kinda wished they put more. After taking a bite with some prawn, YES, I really wish they did. It was so fresh. And I can see why they took so long in preparing it. 

Your best bet is perhaps to take it to go. Space is tight here. I've also noticed this place seems much cleaner.
author: Will S.

description: The burritos at papalote are good, the salsa is better, but the service is incredibly slow. There is a Safeway across the street- I usually order my burrito, go shop for a week's worth of groceries, and come back so I only wait a few minutes.
author: Joe L.

description: Based on the way they make their tofu into something totally un-tofu, I have to give props to this taqueria. Big burritos, friendly staff, great chips and salsa - a wonderful discovery.
author: Lara W.

description: I really like their vegetarian burritos and I'm not vegetarian.   However, I think there is better carne places in the city.  If they added pastor I'd be a bigger fan.   And they seem to never get my orders right.   I guess that's a problem when you have too many options.  On the flip side.  Definitely the best salsa in the city.
author: Edgar C.

description: Delicious yummyness- just go try it out for your own judgement!! Zero points to the workers(one specific girl) with attitude who works as cashier. High 5 to the gentlemen that prepare the food, very dedicated and simply awesome!.
author: DeesQue N.

description: I love Mexican food, and have had my fair share of heartburn. Papalote is a reasonable place to grab a burrito, It is a little overpriced for the food that is somewhat bland compared to the rich flavors they could incorporate. The meat to burrito ratio could definitly use some work, but I love their salsa! And it's around the corner from my house it it usually satisfies my needs... and they have a complicated rewards system, that's slightly annoying.
author: Sean P.

description:
OK, so the location kinda sucks and the place itself is tiny and definitely not a place you choose to go to when you when want ta sit down dinner.  It's more of a takeout kinda of place.  Ot at least this location is. The one on 24th is more spacious and welcoming.

On to the food.  For starters the salsa (which can now be bought at Whole Foods) is so yummy.  And whatever you order comes with a side of it. 
I ordered the vegan mole tofu/veggie burrito and it was sooo good.  This is the only place that I have been to that even offers this type of burrito so major kudos!   I thought the flavors were spot on!  Also, the chips were very yummy and the food is moderately priced.  I have not tried anything other than burritos but I definitely will! 
Just writing about this is making me crave it, grrr.
author: Molly M.

description: Quite possibly the best burrito I've had.... ever.  I tried bits and pieces of my friend's but I wouldn't part with my Soyrizo.  So, so good!  Chipotle eat your heart out.
author: Nandini M.

description: This is a great mexican place! The quesadillas are amazing!! One of my my favorite mexican spots in the city!
author: Romain D.

description: As far as San Francisco burritos go, this is not what you are looking for. I had a chile verde regular burrito. It was tangy!?  Tangy is not a taste I'm looking for in a burrito.  There is not a pinto refried bean option on the menu. Instead there are black refried beans. That is fine and all, but they are vegetarian. The difference between good refried beans and bad refried beans is lard. Vegetarian options are fine for many menu items, but good Mexican food has good refried beans made with lard.  This place is ok for someone else's taste. But if you want real Mexican food look elsewhere.
author: Phillip H.

description: I really wanted to like this place after hearing so many good things about it but I was disappointed with my experience. I got a super burrito with chile verde in it to-go. The guacamole in the burrito was inedible. It tasted so rotten (it surpassed the overly-ripe stage) that it overpowered the rest of the burrito. It's too bad because the rest of the burrito was pretty good. Their tortilla was fresh, warm, and perfectly soft. I also tried the chips that came in the bag and sadly, they were incredibly stale. In the long-run, I'll probably look past this experience and try it again but my first Papalote experience was very unfortunate.
author: Hana K.
