description: Best salsa on the planet. Seriously. No contest. The rest of the food is just OK though. I buy the salsa at Whole Foods and make my own burritos at home.
author: Ross R.

description: This is Mexican street food just how I like it. Uncomplicated, cooked fresh and quickly in unpretentious surroundings. And packed with flavour.Between us we had the mole chicken and grilled chicken tacos which came with tortilla chips (the type I like but can't describe and seem more prevalent in the US), guacamole and a secret recipe salsa. Heaven on a plate. And, in three weeks in California, our best meal of any cuisine of the trip.And I'm told the original 24th Street location is even better!
author: Ashley G.

description: I had their nachos. Meat was very well marinated, their chipotle salsa is to die for
author: Trang B.

description:
Papalote, more like Poopalote! Not sure what all the hype is about here. I like to think I know what a great burrito consists of and have found some of the best burritos to be from the small Mexican Marts that makes fresh burrito's in the back.

The only thing great about Papalote is their salsa, as everyone will tell you, it's pretty fantastic! However their mediocre, small, over-priced, nothing but bean filled burritos are nothing special. 

I got a simple grilled chicken super burrito. Barley any chicken, mostly all beans, very small and nothing fantastic about it. It was decent, but like I said I've had way better, twice as big burritos from hole in the walls for half the price. My girlfriend got the grilled Prawn burrito that literally only had 4 over cooked little shrimp in the entire thing for $10.25. REALLY! 4 small shrimp in a $10 burrito. VERY disappointed.

They also have something called the "Triple Threat" burrito for $19.95. I inquired about it imagining a gigantic "Man Vs Food" style burrito, but was told it's just a regular burrito with 3x the amount of meat. Why would anyone pay $20 for an all meat burrito when you can simply add double meat for $2. For an additional $4 you can get 3x the amount of meat in your burrito without paying $20. 

Maybe it was a bad first experience, maybe i'm snobby with my burrito's, maybe I like my burrito's a little different then Papalote makes them. Some people rave about this place, so there must be something to it, but I certainly didn't find it with my experience and will probably never come back here again!
author: Uriah B.

description: In the broad spectrum of Mexican restaurants here in SF, Papalote seems to be the kind that's located somewhere between the classic hole-in-the-wall taqueria in the Mission to the trendy Americanized Mexican grills in other parts of the city. The ambiance, decor and cleanliness seemed to be on the spot, while the food wasn't something I would become a fan of. I got the Grilled Veggie Burrito, which tasted a wee bit healthier (is there such a thing as a healthy burrito?) but was dry and uninspiring. That's okay, because dry burritos can be made wet after a generous visit to the salsa bar, right? Unfortunately, Papalote does not have a salsa bar :( I think they just have one type of house-prepared salsa of which you get a complimentary serving. But you need to pay more to get more. On the bright side, that salsa tasted really well.
author: Srivatsan S.

description: Visited on a recent Sunday noon; very disappointed- this place has declined since I went a year ago....overpriced for what you get:  a passable burrito, but not delicious and juicy like the everyday Mex places serve. A super with everything at an authentic Mex place is around $8.50.  Here the barebones burrito starts at $9.50, and then everything else, such a guacamole, cheese, sour cream are each .99 apiece.  The cashier who wasn't too friendly was quick to say, how about some cheese, sour cream?  Of course, she wound up charging over $12 with these "add-ons.". And the carnitas wound up being about 7 pieces of beef, one so tough I couldn't chew it. Not very satisfying.  The salsa is divine as everyone always says it is, but the burrito itself is not so special as the delicious ethnic Mexican burrito shops offer. Anyway, as I walked out with my bag, I opened it to grab a chip to munch on and saw the scarcity of taco chips, so I turned and asked the cashier for a few more chips. "Ok," she said.  But that will be .99.  I was like, what?  So I just closed my bag and walked out.  For my next burrito I'll be back at those generous, friendly and scrumptious local neighborhood burrito shops rather than here!
author: fred w.

description:
There's some days when you just need a big, calorie-packed burrito and yesterday was it!

I almost passed by Papalote when I was looking for it! It's a pretty small place...4 tables that seat 2-4 people and then stools set up at a counter that runs along the wall. When my friends and I first arrived, ALL the seats were taken, so we were debating whether to try and find a cafe to eat at or if we should stand around and wait. Luckily, a table cleared so WHOO HOO!! I would suggest waiting to see if something opens up...I mean, you're waiting for your order anyway!

I got the soyrizo burrito with black beans and a whole wheat tortilla and I added guac and OHHH BOY. Total was almost $10! Eeesh. They charged me about $3 extra for getting the whole wheat and added guac. I kinda wish they had put on the menu somewhere that they charge extra for the tortilla rather than just saying, "ALL VEGAN!"

The burrito was OK, but very VERY filling! Their soyrizo was pretty good! :) The chips and salsa was good too, but they could've given more chips! Unfortunately, I'm pretty spoiled when it comes to Mexican food cause I was at school in San Diego, so I have pretty high standards, not to mention I got used to paying very little for a lot of good quality food.

3 stars for being pretty expensive and just A-OK burrito. I felt like Papalote is more like Chipotle or those other "gourmet" chain places. I'd probably go to the Mission if I wanted a cheaper, more delicious burrito.
author: Kei H.

description:
Yikes,  so I didn't try the tripple threat burrito (damn thing is $20) but did try a regular burrito and a kaysaaa dillah. Unless I'm missing something, but it seems as though many others might agree, there was nothing special here. Unless papalote makes their triple threat burrito completely different than the regular burrito I probably won't ever try it. In fact, the only thing I would come back to papalote for is their salsa. Ok... so the "salsa" much like a sauce reminds me of the Peruvian aji salsa, which I love love love. The love, I must say, ends there. 

If ever in the need for a burrito I wouldn't hesitate to go to gordos, el farolito, or even chipotle instead.

On the other hand, the place is clean and the staff is friendly ;)
author: Steven T.

description:
It was a coincidence that Bobby Flay had a Throw down vs Papalote just before my vacation to SF.  So of course this made me want to try the "Triple Threat" even more.

I came by for a late lunch and was really tempted to try the Triple threat, but after I saw the price of $20+ I decided not to.  

I got the super pollo burrito with refried beans and their guacamole.  I didn't know they gave chips on the side, so we ended up with 3 bowls of tortilla chips.  

The guacamole was lacking seasoning and flavor, it was just mashed avocado's.  The burrito was more than enough to feed 2 people, they were huge!  The chicken was flavorful and tender but I can't taste the different between these burrito's and any others.  

The place itself was colorful and decorated nicely with some cool kites hanging from the ceiling.  Service was helpful and quick.
author: Sandy C.

description: For Lil under $10 I had the regular Carne Asada burrito which was a good size and the meat was grilled  right after ordering. Meat was flavorful and salsa was a good compliment. The highlight of my meal was definitely the complimentary  tomato/chipotle creamy salsa . Overall food was good but not great and for the price I definitely could find better elsewhere. Apparently the owner was on the show throw down with Bobby flay, hence the pictures right above the grill.
author: Brian L.

description:
I am a sucker for anything they feature on the Food Network's Throwdown. On one of their last episodes they did a feature on a burrito place in San Francisco. Papalote's "Triple Threat" was the burrito to beat. Just seeing the carne asada, chicken, and shrimp, cooked to a perfection on the tube made me salivate. All I kept saying was,  "I want that"/

So I finally got a chance to visit this highly proclaimed place. Everything seem so promising, just seeing the cooks prepare the proteins fresh on the grill made me feel so confident that I would be eating a burrito that my taste buds have never experienced before.

I have to say I was quite disappointed. I ordered the super pollo burrito and It was not anything that blew me away. Just tasted real average. I have to admit that Iguana's back home is better and is cheaper too. I even purchased more of their highly coveted sauce. Their orange sauce was good but it wasn't even spicy at all. I guess when you are accustomed to a spicier sauce, anything else doesn't compare.

I purchased a carne asada burrito for my friend and also gave him half of my chicken burrito since I am so generous and trying to watch my figure...more on just being generous though. He preferred the chicken one more when he lives to eat steak. He too, also proffers Iguanas.

So I guess Papalote is SF's Iguanas with a less spicy secret sauce.
author: Wen C.

description:
So like every other sucker in town I decided to head over to Papalote to try this "triple threat burrito" featured in ThrowDown with Bobby Flay.

Ummm..excuse me?!

$20 for a burrito? 
Hold on, let me get my glasses, I must have read that wrong.

On no...it is true, it really does have a $20 price tag for A F*ING BURRITO.

Perdon senor, but are you out of your mind?! I was eyeballing others around me and I could see the same look of confusion, concern, skepticism, and " to hell with it"  on their faces. 

I decided to opt out  of the triple threat and instead go for a carne asada, which while tasty wasn't worth the almost $10 price tag. It was sort of dry, and served with a side of AT-i-TUDE. Their salsa was a flavorful blend of roasted peppers and creamy spice. If they bottled it, I would buy it in a heartbeat. 

Seriously, I heart Mexican food and am rather partial to the affordable factor in ordering a large delicious guacamole slathered burrito food baby...but I was not impressed with Papalote this time. Which is a shame because living over in Pac Heights there is a serious lack of tasty burrito places to frequent.
author: Kathy K.

description: This place was an extreme disappointment after seeing  prior reviews. Our takeout order did not contain half the items we asked for, even after we inquired, that we paid for in full. The Mole was substandard, dry and tasteless. Instead of guacamole and queso, we had a big container of refried beans. Perhaps there salsa is worth it but nothing else is.
author: Spencer S.

description: Luke warm, mediocre, overhyped food. I was so disappointed. My husband and I were told this was THE place for burritos, but clearly we were misinformed. I wish I could get those calories back. My burrito was cold. The chips were stale, and the guacamole tasted and looked like it came out of a can. Totally not worth it.
author: Elina B.

description: Their mole burrito was very tasty and satisfying. Complemented with their chips and house salsa it was a perfect dinner.
author: Veronica G.

description:
No Pico, please.

Well, it always seems to be a 50/50 chance that I'm getting a mouthful of raw white onion. They seem to have a 6th sense for it. When I eat in the shop, no onions. When I get take out - onion fucking city.
author: Paul Z.

description:
I've been a student at USF for quite a while now but I only recently ventured into Papalote. A current project is forcing me to stay on campus longer every day and the cafeteria food just doesn't cut it. 

I ordered (to go) the fish tacos (sauted in white wine and butter) and strawberry aguas frescas. The tacos were way overpriced ($9 after tax) and the drink was very watered down. The space is too damn small and every two seconds you have to move to make room for someone.  The tacos were not great and they were too small. The fish were in little chunks and there was little of it.  I probably should've gotten the super because the fillings were meager.

Unfortunately, I cannot cross out chips and salsa from Papalote off the 7x7 list just yet since I gave up chips for Lent. I did put the salsa on my tacos though. It did add a nice kick and it was moderately spicy but it is not to die for.
author: Vivian H.

description: I'm going to keep this short since a lot of good things have already been said about Papalote.  I stopped by here for the first time and really wanted to try their Prawn Burrito.  It was really good and I like how they grilled their tortillas to make them somewhat crispy.  However, it still doesn't compare to El Farolito's Shrimp Burrito.  I'll be back again soon.  Especially to try the Chicken Adobo Burrito that my friends keep raving about.  I also might come back for the Triple Threat someday.  Though for $19.95, it's a tough sell, especially when I can drive down to Iguana's a get Burritozilla for a dollar less.
author: Rodney H.

description:
7x7 list says chips and salsa. that's what we ordered and some burritos. Why not? Burritos were delicious. I ordered carne asada - yum. They were pretty big and damn, are they good. 

chips - fresh chips are delicious. yum. a little bit of their great salsa and damn that was good.

it's funny. the boy's brother lives about a block away from here. how is he not fat? we didn't end up meeting up with him since apparently he was gone to tahoe. not only that, they never see each other (the brothers that is). i feel like i would see my family a lot if they lived so close.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Probably the most inconsistent burrito establishment I frequent. I wish my burritos were always awesome (-___-)

-----------------------------------------
VEGAN MOLE TOFU BURRITO. You are my new favorite!
author: Cori W.

description:
hands down the best in SF. 
freshest ingredients with creative combos.
shout out to Chris and the rest of the crew for consistently having excellent customer service each and every visit! 
word up guys -keep holding it down!
author: Louie L.

description: This place has good burritos, but it's a bit pricey for my taste. It's also right next to USF, so it's popular with a lot of students there. I've had better burritos for cheaper, so I'm a little bitter about the price. One thing that caught my eye that I haven't seen anywhere other than back in Hawaii, is their Vegetarian Burrito which has potatoes in it! If I ever go back here, I'm definitely trying it!
author: Junel S.

description:
1.  Stupid Slow
15 minutes to roll up a burrito is just unreasonable - and it's every time.  Two equally high-end NOPA joints, Little Chihuahua & Green Chili Kitchen, both take under 10 minutes to make a burrito.  

2.  Way overpriced
I don't expect taco truck prices.  But the neither the size not the taste justifies paying over $11 for a meat super burrito.  Again, Little Chihuahua and GCK have just a high-end ingredients and cost less.  

3.  Rude!
Not merely indifferent, but overtly nasty.  The always cashiers give me the stink-eye before I even open my mouth, then pick up a phone call in the middle of my order.  Then the cook mumbles my order number.  When I ask if he means me, he rolls his eyes.  Really? 

4.  Fully Overrated
Look, I admit the salsa is delicious.  But that's the ONE this place has going for it.  Buy their salsa in a jar and bring it along with you to one of the many other burrito joints that are faster, nicer, better tasting, and a better value.
author: Trip B.

description:
It takes a lot for a burrito to be bad. I mean, how much variation is there really even room for? Yeah, I prefer crisp lettuce over wilted, and sure, spicy salsa beats mild, but really, a place has to screw up big time to ruin a burrito. It's everything good in handheld form.

Still, it's just plain, old good. Pricey though... extra for guac, sour cream, cheese, or veggies... those seem like default burrito ingredients to me. All burritos should be "super burritos!" Regardless, it's still pretty awesome, and the salsa makes up for all other faults. Seriously, this salsa is godly... spicy, tangy, smokey - just everything good. 

I would recommend this location for takeout rather than sit-down. It's pretty cramped (blame the highly addictive salsa).
author: Zoey S.

description:
This place should rename to burrito gentrification 

Low marginal utility burritos. Probably the whole menu is 20% overpriced. Their flavors are bland too. Oh and yeah their signature salsa is good however once you run out its 50 cents for another....tacky.

I gave it 3 instead of 2 solely on the fact that the meat is freshly cooked in front of you.
author: R G.

description:
I respect Bobby Flay, and if he thinks this place is worthy of a burrito throw down, then this place must be good.  

There is a good amount of choices on the menu, and I was impressed by the multiple vegetarian options (vegan beans, grilled veggie, soyrizo, and marinated tofu).  I figure that at any place, to gauge the food, order something simple.  Hence, I did not order the $20 triple threat, but the pinto beans & rice super burrito.  

The servers will deliver your food to you after your order and pay, which I thought was an excellent way to reduce the confusion that often times ensues at taquerias.  The chips and salsa were brought out first.  Chips, eh.  The salsa was pretty damn good; roasted, creamy, and with a good kick of heat at the end.  Too bad elite homie Carlo is correct about Papalote's being salsa Nazis; they charge extra for more.  The burrito was good; it was obvious that all the ingredients used were fresh.  Also, the horchata is pretty good if you like a lot of cinnamon in your horchata.

I can't say that this place has the best burrito in SF, but I can easily agree that it probably does have the best salsa.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Papalote is delicioso - great burritos, decent quesadillas, and the best salsa in the city. If you come, you must leave with a jar of the aforementioned salsa - $5.99, but you get a buck off when you trade in the old jar - which you will. I think it's the toasted pumpkin seeds that they put in to the mix that give the salsa it's great flavor, but whatever it is, I like.

The burritos are on par with most good Mission joints, though I was a bit underwhelmed by their burstage abatement. That said, the flavors were wonderful, and the chile verde was tender and cooked to perfection.

The place has been hyped a lot since Bobby Flay's throwdown, so expect a bigger crowd. And they raised the price of the Triple Threat burrito to $19.95!! Yeah, it's delicious, but $20? Dude, stick to stand-up for your jokes, not your burrito prices.

But I still come back again and again. And I always leave with a jar of salsa - the best part of the Papalote experience.
author: Jonathan M.

description: If you go to USF, you love Papalote freshman year. But my love for Papalote has only grown stronger. I'm vegan so I get the soyrizo burrito which is amazing. Of course nothing beats the salsa, though you should get something to drink other than water cause it's pretty spicy. I got the burrito punch card (yeah, that's how good it is) & am super psyched for my free burrito, but to be honest I would pay anything for this heaven. I had surgery & the first meal I wanted was Papalote. That particular time was disappointing, though because I found a piece of steak in it, but they were nice about it & gave me a new one. Minus one star because in general the counter people seem very unenthusiastic, though a few of them are nice.
author: Jess H.

description:
Ok. I'll give you another star if you clean the grill once in a while. It kinda defeats the purpose of eating a marinated tofu burrito if it reaks of 3 day old carne asada.

I kinda get the feeling this place is coasting on the USF kids and the " We beat Bobby Flay" reputation. It really used to impress me but now I'm just full and disappointed and smelling of onions. Not really what I was after. I'll be back but a little more weary next time.
author: Jesse H.

description: Not anything special. Chips were bland and the orange salsa didn't do anything to save it. Carne Asada burrito was fine, but I expected more out of it. Still think La Tapatia and El Farolito in South City are better, but I'll give Papalote another chance.
author: Jeffrey D.

description:
It saddens me to give this place 2 stars, because I even craved it and betrayed my old stand-by place (Little Chihuahua, I'm sorry, I will go back to you) to get a couple of burritos here for my girlfriend and I. 

So what's wrong with this place? Nothing's changed... and maybe that's the problem; there' s no serious competition in the area, and I agree with another reviewer about them keeping the business alive with the USF kids. 

Ok, so my gripes are three , so there's the -3 stars. I ordered the super carne asada burrito for me and the chicken mole burrito for my gf. The order comes with standard chips and their "special salsa" which tasted TERRIBLE, like they overdid it with one of the spices, or the tomatoes were not fresh when they made it, I don't know, it was just awful. I mean isn't this place supposed to be known for their salsa? It was gross.  

Result: -1 star. 

Then, the burrito that I ordered had very little if any pico (tomato/onions) in it, I couldn't taste the cheese or sour cream, and it was mostly beans, rice and tortilla. The meat does taste good here (which is why I craved it better than Little Chihuahua). But the problem with my burrito was that  they didn't stuff it correctly! I ate my first bite and got a huge chunk of tortilla. I thought "wow, that's a lot of tortilla" and kept going hoping for some nice filling meat and veggies and rice... nope.... I chowed down about A THIRD OF IT and then barely started to get some of the goodies. Not a lot of flavor in it, not a lot of veggies... sigh. 

Disappointed. -1 star. 

Finally, I don't know how hygienic this place is, but it seems like they need to up their quality standards and cleanliness. My girlfriend got food poisoning and she was feeling really crappy at work  the next day. I didn't eat the salsa but she did, so it makes me wonder which one it was, but still, this isn't a place I thought I had to worry about... $9 + a pop for a burrito should at least save you a few trips to the toilet, don't you think? 

Cause for concern plus food poisoning: - 1 star. 

So there you have it folks; I know the place gets packed and working on the line here must be crazy (I waited about 20 minutes for my order) but they should enforce some better quality to get my business. For now i'll just say, "No way Jose". See ya later Papalote.
author: Ben G.

description:
I would love to meet these people that have voted Papalote the "Best burrito in San Francisco" because it definitely is not. I ordered the super chicken burrito and took a seat. I was given the chips and salsa (before my meal) which was nice; I enjoyed munching on something while I waited for my meal. Yes, as everyone has stated, the salsa is pretty phenomenal. I ordered my burrito on a spinach tortilla because I don't usually see that at mexican restaurants. When my burrito came out it looked decent but I knew right away I wasn't going to be able to pick it up; this was going to be a fork and knife meal. I hate eating burritos with a fork and knife. I know it's hard to fold spinach tortilla wraps but if you have the balls to list them on the menu, you better know how to fold them.  

The burrito itself was just average. There wasn't anything stand out about it besides the fact that I was able to drizzle the amazing salsa all over it. There was a ton of rice and barely any guacamole/sour cream. What I also didn't like was they decided to garnish the burritos with old, spoiled, fruits and vegetables. What the hell were they trying to go for with that? 

In short, it's definitely not the best burrito place in SF, for sure. I'm probably not going to come back unless someone is willing to buy my meal for me.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Most miserable excuse for Mexican food I've ever had the displeasure of tasting.

I got the taco, my friend got the pescado burrito. A few dry/charred pieces of beef, NO cilantro, onions, and just a bunch of lettuce. That is NOT A TACO!!! And for $9?? WTF. Also took a bite of my friends burrito...completely bland- tasted like beany fish mush in a tortilla. 

These cheap bastards also charge you for sour cream and cheese AND pico de gallo. In what world is that not standard? 
Now, I don't have anything against the workers. They're just doing their job. But today I've developed a new found hatred for the owners and establishment of Papalote.

Btw, their salsa isn't even that good. Too sweet and tastes like spicy pasta sauce.

Fuck Papalote.
author: Janice Y.

description:
Fresh chips with salsa.
Damn sauce lives up to the hype.
Spicy and creamy.
How do they make it like that?
I wish it came out bigger.

Burritos are large.
Eat my own or split in two?
I did one myself.

Relaxed ambiance.
Reminds me of Chipotle.
Clean, and not a dive.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Papalote's burritos are ok / not great. I'm just not sure how their potatoes "fit" in the burrito. Somehow the consistency is more chunky and firm than it should be. The starchy consistency collides with the toothsome rice. Instead, why not calabaza? Hmm? I liked the soyrizo filling better, but in the end I just go with rice and beans and pico, and then it's not as good as other taquerias. I tore off the bottom half of the tortilla fold. Who wants a mouthful of dry grilled tortilla?

The garlic rice is oily and not tasty. If I order special rice, it had better be more tasty than the "regular" rice. If there's not some characteristic that fits well somehow, what's the point?

In the end, I will definitely return because their salsas are good (HEY PEOPLE THERE ARE OTHER GOOD SALSAS YOU PHILISTINES) and hey burritos are really good. Also I want more salsa.
author: Klevin D.

description: My friends had raved to me how much this place had awesome burritos and tacos and to be quite honest it was a waste of money. The burrito wasn't great, the guac inside was groddy and the tacos pretty much sucked, I have had much better. The service was also not so great. The salsa not hot at all.  oh well, the search for the best burrito continues.
author: Adriana D.

description:
Decent burritos, decent prices (depending on what you put in your burrito, of course).  I've gone a few times, and the wait's never been long -- the order line moves quickly, and once you've ordered the food comes out quickly, too. 

Not much seating, so don't plan on sitting here to eat.  You might get a table, and you might not.  Even if you do, you'll be uncomfortably close to folks at neighboring tables.

I wouldn't travel for it, but if you're in the neighborhood and craving some Mexican food on-the-go, it's worth a try.
author: Crys L.

description:
I dream about that fish burrito. White wine and butter makes each chunk of flavorful fish like a little bit of heaven in my mouth. So, so good.

Know what i don't dream about here? The salsa. Yeah, I said it. Every time I take the plunge and try a chip with that bright orange sauce I think, "Really? How does this consistently make the Best Of lists?" :( Maybe one day I'll love it like everyone else does.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Go with the carne asada burrito...shame on you Papalote, for charging $19.95 for your famous Triple Threat burrito...No burrito is worth nearly $20, but I guess the fame went to your head after beating an Iron Chef in a throwdown. 

By the way, their tacos had good flavor but the corn tortillas suck and are too flimsy. Go for the burritos, they're a sure thing.
author: Daniel B.

description:
My go-to item---Super Shrimp Burrito. Get the refried black beans if you like your burrito wet. (Yea, yea, that's what she said).

The Adobo Burrito (aka Poleng Burrito) is tasty, but there's a buttery flavor to their Garlic Fried Rice that makes it kinda weird. 

About a year ago they had a one day special where they made a sisig burrito in collab with Adobo Hobo that was soooo good! I hope they bring that one back = ]  That was one of the best burritos I've ever had.

Overall, good service and I respect that Miguel, the owner, uses his Papalote fame (the restaurant was featured on Food Network) to give back to the SF community through various fundraisers.

Tips: Park at the Lucky's parking lot across the street and if you just so happen to need to do some work on your laptop during lunch, you can catch the internet WifI from the Starbucks next door.
author: Valerie F.

description:
Wow I didn't realize this place was so popular!

I only had to wait about 10 minutes for my Shrimp tacos which isn't that bad considering I came at around 1pm when everyone and their mother was eating lunch.

The tacos were mehhh I mean they were fresh but seemed rather flavorless to me and the corn tortillas were already starting to rip from being soggy.  I think every order comes with chips and their salsa, however it didn't impress me, and was very watery with only a moderate amount of spiciness.  My friend got the burrito with EVERYTHING in it and loved it, and my brother has also told me numerous times the burritos were bomb.  Next time I come I'll have to try one, but +2 stars for my experience and +1 for what I've been hearing about their burritos.
author: Christina L.

description: Dank molé burrito, salsa is unique and bomb too. Papalote is very good option if you're feeling lazy and want to call in an order for pickup.
author: Cameron J.

description: Called in an order for three burritos. Drove across town to get them. All three orders were wrong--didn't realize it until I was back at home. Food is fine, not great. But service is terrible. They should either implement an online ordering service or train their employees how to take better notes. This is the second time this has happened to me from this place.
author: Stephen S.

description:
So I finally tried Papalote, leaving only skydiving, horseback riding and space sex on my bucket list. Having heard such rave reviews for this place ("and the salsa, ohmygawd, the SALSA!"), I have to say I was fairly disappointed.

The fire-roasted salsa reminded me of a smokier, red version of a creamy tomatillo salsa. Like the burrito, it had good flavor but didn't really burst in my mouth like some salsas do. The burrito itself--I ordered the chicken mole--was dry and needing of sauciness. I always get my burritos sans sour cream, guacamole and cheese, and I believe a good taqueria can make a stand-out burrito without the addition of these.

Papalote is good, and I'd definitely come back, but you won't find me raving about this place like the other half of San Francisco.
author: Keane L.

description:
I'm a fan of Papalote period!!! lol I love the owners and the workers too!! 

All their food is super yummy but the only downside to this location is that it's small and parking isn't easy if you're driving. 

If you have not given Papalote a try you must!!!
author: Liliana C.

description:
ugh, definitely not my favorite Mexican restaurant, but you can't compete with the service and speed of this place.  All the meals are pretty great in size, and the prices are about average.  I would say the best part of any meal from Papalote is the salsa and chips!! 

I recommend this place because of the delicious taste, the speed from start to finish of your order and the service! It's pretty packed during any night of the week, but worth the wait.
author: Alexa V.

description: The burritos are solid but charging me $11 for a burrito in.a city with one thousand great burrito shops is just silly. I remember when this place used to be great all the way around. What happened? Ouch.
author: Brandon D.

description: I used to be a loyal papalote fan when I was at USF. Now everything tastes canned.  I ordered a bean and rice burrito with avocado to go this week, and it tasted like the avocado was rotten.  I couldn't eat any of it. Also, the salsa used to be amazing, now it tastes like canned marinara sauce...not delicious.
author: Emily T.

description:
Seems to be going downhill. Multiple problems today. First, they forgot our salsa on our to go order! Got home with nachos and two burritos and no salsa. How do you eat all that without salsa? I called to let them know and she said she would give us extra next time.  Thanks a lot - big help:(  

Next, let's talk about the guacamole. We ordered a side of it.  It's just not good. It seems like the stuff you buy in the market in those plastic jars. Seems way too smooth and processed. Does not look or taste fresh.

I'm a bit of a nacho connoisseur and these  nachos were not good. They don't even give you sour cream and guacamole with an order of nachos? Too little cheese too. Half the chips were left with no cheese on them.
author: andy f.

description: Papalote is absolutely great for close by Mexican food. It's within walking distance from my place and whenever I'm in the mood it's right there. The quesadillas are good, but I typically order the carne asada super burrito. I wish it weren't so pricy... Be prepared to pay over 10 bucks for a burrito.
author: Alana R.

description:
Bumping them down to one star would be kind of harsh, and the place isn't THAT bad. But what restaurant that has a breakfast menu doesn't open 'til 11? Really!?! 

I know this place caters to the college crowd, which typically doesn't roll out of bed 'til the afternoon on the weekends, but us old farts who know how to drink the night before AND wake up the next morning to start day drinking (it was for a football game) would prefer sustenance sooner rather than later... 

BTW...I know I dissed there crappy breakfast burritos in my last review. The only reason I went back was because I was across the street getting my haircut so it was convenient, and I just needed something to serve the dual purpose of soaking up the alcohol from the previous night and providing some sort of foundation for the marathon drinking session that was about to take place that day...
author: George A.

description: I love this spot! Yesterday was the special Adobo Hobo burrito special!! If you get s chance to try the salsa you will NOT regret! Yummy! Check it out! Miguel the co-owner is a great guy!
author: Marie P.

description:
Used to love coming here when I went to USF.  Steak is good... but common now... it's 9.10 just to get cheese in the burrito.  It's definitely not worth it anymore.  Salsa still rocks and is still given in a rip off size. Since the price hike (a couple years ago I could've sworn it was around 7:50 but don't quote me), can't say I'll be coming here much anymore.

Skip this place and head elsewhere.
author: Adrian E.

description: Solid Mexican food.  I had the steak nachos, I love nachos.  They weren't the best nachos I've had but the steak was well done, thinly sliced and tender.  I think I would go back to try a steak burrito.  I think that would taste better than the steak nachos.
author: C L.

description: Hold on, $10 for a burrito???  This thing better be damn good.....  Nope, even with guac and sour cream it's dry and flavorless.  I mean really dry.  I'll give it to them, the salsa is good, but come on man, $10 for a burrito?  Pass
author: Scott L.

description: Sub-par food, overpriced and unfriendly service.
author: Ben G.

description: If this wasn't the one of the only places to eat within a mile radius I would never eat here. The food is okay to good, but everything is three dollars more than it should be. Expect to spend ten dollars plus on a normal burrito.
author: Logan T.

description: At first I was shocked about the price of the food here. Then I found out the meat they used was good quality, so why not, give it a shot, I was starving. I ordered a soyrizo burrito and my husband ordered a carne asada burrito. $9.50 for somensoyrizo and beans that were mediocre at best. Mmmm....no. It was ok. My husband received a burrito with beans, and very little quacamole and sour cream. We didnt see or taste any meat in his burrito. At almost $11 for that, it needs to be amazing. You could easily head over to the mission and get a super burrito for $6 that actually has meat. The staff was nice though... and they gave you free chips at least.
author: Liz F.

description: Salsa is only thing going for this place, everything else is ridiculously mediocre. I live half a block away and even when really drunk and hungry would be hard pressed to decide to go here (and there are no other quick options around here except walking down to Divisadero or across panhandle to Haight Street).
author: Carlin S.

description: Their burritos are pretty good here. I recommend the chicken mole one. However, it is the orange salsa that makes this place so special. In fact, I've seen papalote people promoting the salsa at whole foods, which means it must be good.
author: Herman R.

description:
Papalote is good Mexican food if you've never been out of Northern California, don't mind spending $10+ for a taco shop and love your burritos filled with rice and beans.

Papalote is easily the most overrated taco shop in SF. It's walls are lined with "best burrito" awards that are more of a reflection of the lack of good choices than the quality of their burritos.

The salsa is good if you don't mind blender salsa, meaning it's more of a sauce than a salsa. It's really good but there are no chunks of onion, tomato, cilantro or jalapeños. One of my stars is for the salsa.

The second star is because it's Mexican food and it's hard to screw that up. Otherwise, it's way overpriced and nothing special.
author: Justin A.

description:
Papalote is a really great burrito place. I have tried all three of their meats: The best is the pollo...which has a nice kick and is very tender. The pork is quite good and actually better than most places...it is not salty and not extra fatty yet with plenty of flavor. The steak is the least of my favorites...it has very little flavor besides that of bbq beef which is still good.

The guacamole here is fresh and mixed with chunks of tomatoe, cilantro and onions and is really good ( alot of place now use crappy frozen guac in a can ala costco....y'all know what I mean). Also their homemade salsa is really great...it is peppery and thick and creamy....so much different than the typical salsa cruda, or the roasted chipotle etc etc. 

My only beef with this place is that when I visited it wasnt that clean...there was a plastic pail next to the cashier filled with brown water and a bunch of utensils.....We didnt get sick so this is probably nothing. I highly rate this placed
author: David G.

description:
My mother always told me that I should focus on the positives whenever possible. With that in mind, the salsa verde tacos I ordered the other day used very fresh ingredients.

Papalote's flavor just wasn't to my liking. Perhaps it was because the salsa that came with the chips reminded me of creamy tomato soup. Maybe it's because my tacos had a spice level usually reserved for the residents of Branson, Missouri.

It wasn't terrible... I've just had better.
author: Christopher K.

description:
...And here we go!
I've been to this place too many times to even keep count, but every time I walk in with an open mind, expecting an improvement in the quality of the food I'm faced with the same disappointment. The food is mediocre and the inside of the shop is too small. If you're dying of hunger and this is the only place left to eat at, then please, by all means help yourself!

The only good thing about this place is the free salsa and its close vicinity to USF,
author: Niki J.

description:
These guys make huge, awesome burritos.  Got a carne asada one and it was delicious and very fresh, plus it came with chips and a very unique, terrific-tasting salsa.  I was all over it.  

Wasn't a huge fan of the pico de gallo inside the burrito, as the bigger tomato chunks felt out of place, so I used their signature salsa and used it as a dipping sauce as well and that was great.  Service was quick and friendly.
author: Daniel H.

description: This is like the cadallic of mexican food in SF. I really enjoy the fish burrito here with black beans and guacamole. Very consistent and quite good, fish is always freshly grilled. I usually drop in here post swim at USF. I only have a couple of issues. First is I never have enough salsa for chips and my burrito, just give me a little extra salsa by default so I don't have to stress. Secondly, the water glasses are small and always wet. Other than that it's a great high-end burrito experience.
author: Michael S.

description: I have eaten at Papalote lots and lots of times, and their tofu burritos are seriously delicious. However, last night I experienced my second bout of food poisoning from this place. Now I've had food poisoning from both locations! Eat at your own risk.
author: Kelsey R.

description: Some of the best salsa I've ever had, but the food is so-so and the prices are pretty high, even by SF standards
author: Bryan E.

description:
If you are a first-timer, definitely try the pollo super burrito with refried black beans! Everything they do is made fresh daily. The chicken and steak are grilled to order, and their salsa is famous!

Its one of those places that everyone should try
author: Nicolas M.

description: Papalote is overpriced to me. Their burritos don't have anything special about them, the meat wasn't juicy or delectable.   I used to go here when I was too lazy to travel further, but even that redeeming factor slowly wasn't enough for me. San Francisco has amazing Mexican food, Papalote just isn't it.
author: Victoria F.

description:
Papalote: Get Over Yourself.

I live about a block from this Papalote and I have to say- NOT IMPRESSED.  And $10 for this 'award-winning' pile of bland?

I have been eating burritos from here to Mexico for a long time, and even by San Francisco standards this rounds out the bottom tier of Mexican food.

Maybe all the attention went to their heads?  When did success make it okay to charge additional money for your industrially produced 'special' salsa?  Maybe to all the kids pouring into the bay from Wisconsin & Minnesota, Papalote burritos & salsa make their native Taco Bell fare seem like pig slop.  But I'm here imploring people to hone their taste buds & stop putting this place on a pedestal.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Me and my husband have been dying to try this and finally got the chance to so this weekend.  I wasn't too hungry but he was starving so we got the carne asada super burrito with 2 chips and salsa since they only come with 1 order with the burrito. The salsa was amazing hence the 2 stars but everything was "Ehh.". Definitely got way better everywhere else. Even at Chipotle! Sorry to say. . For a $9 burrito it should be amazing! Better than normal! Especially, if it's TV worthy!

It's a hipster joint so people are there for the salsa trend. . You can also tell how good a Mexican restaurant is by the number of Mexicans are eating there- needless to say there were none lol. 

Don't buy the food, just buy the jars of the yummy salsa :)
author: Miss M.

description: One of our favorite burrito places in the city! Lots of vegetarian options, but my favorite is the grilled vegetable burrito with pinto beans on a sundried tomato tortilla. Their homemade chips and salsa are also very good. (The salsa is a bit hotter than my usual preference, but so yummy, I eat it all anyway.) The staff are always very friendly and the place generally has a nice, chill vibe. We like to get our burritos to go, then eat them at one of the nearby parks, if the weather is nice enough. Highly recommended!
author: Terry M.

description: Super burrito with black beans and carne asada is pretty bomb. It's pretty expensive, but if you're in the area and trying to get a quick, high quality burrito, it's a good fix.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Um.  Yeah.  The burrito was not exciting and it was on the dry side.

I poured on the salsa but the salsa was really not all that.

I'm honestly confused by all the good reviews.

It wasn't worth the wait.
author: Mary F.

description:
Exorbitant price. 10.69 for a super chicken burrito? Insane.

On my way past the cooking area I saw a worker making salsa. He poured one container into another and used his bare finger to squeegee the lips of both containers of excess salsa. 

The taste of my burrito was not good. It also didn't come with any sour cream. I asked for sour cream and they gave me a little container with a bit in it. Again, a worker used his finger to clean the lip and scraped off the excess into the container. You kidding me??

The next morning I had diarrhea and 24 hours later I have what appears to be the flu. I've been in bed all day and can't work. My head is pounding. 

Fuck you, papalote. Fuck you.
author: Chris C.

description:
Best burritos outside of the mission. The best salsa I've had in sf and really quick service. 

The only downside I've found is that beyond the burritos there isn't much worth eating. The carne asada tacos were very plain and the meat was way to salty and dry.
author: Daniel D.

description: Probably the most expensive lettuce ever.  Two tacos, $8.  A sprinkling of carne asada covered by mounds of lettuce.  Buy the salsa and make your own meal at home, or just go to the Mission.
author: Kean S.

description:
I heard about this place  many times and wanted to try their burrito. 
I finally did. Sorry, but I don't think it's as good as people say.   I was disappointed.
author: Ellie J.

description:
I don't get the hype. Then again, I am a Southern California transplant who proudly sticks my nose up in the air when it comes to carne asada in the Bay Area. Granted, I grew up eating Mexican food by the border in San Diego. Then in the kitchens of my many Latino friends in LA, so I am very spoiled and very biased. Four years and I still have yet to find decent carne asada in SF. 

That being said, I went with some friends after a group blood donation to replenish.  And wouldn't you know it, just today, I saw that Papalote made some top 10 list for top burrito joint. I should have known...I'm soooo hesitant to order asada in SF due the numerous failures so far. And Papalote is just another notch on the asada fail belt. Bland meat, bland hyped up salsa. I asked for a hotter salsa and they said it could cost $.55. WTF? I was too lazy to get up and stand in line again to pay so I used the bottled stuff on the table. The only good thing was the black refried beans, though they did make the tortilla super mushy. 

Aside from the asada, my friend ordered a $10 prawn quesadilla. It only had 4 shrimp in it. Then he asked if he could have more tortilla chips...$1 extra. And, of course, $.55 for more salsa. He said he should have saved the money he tipped to get extras. At that moment, we both look up and notice a "Cheap Eats" award on the wall. Really?
author: Jenny C.

description: I got a carne asada burrito with cheese. I was disappointed to find that the $9 burrito was probably 80% rice and tomatoes. I read reviews that warned of this, but I decided to try it anyway. I may give the restaurant another chance, but I won't be ordering a burrito.
author: Lily H.

description:
I had a bad taste in my mouth about them after they didn't let us in one night when we finished dinner at Poleng and we were still hungry.  But I was determined to come back and eat a burrito.  Because sometimes I just have strange burrito cravings.

The carne asada burrito was nothing special, but I devoured it nonetheless.  Worth my extra dollar to make it super, aka drown it in sour cream and guac.  Chips and salsa were worth it as well (aka free).  If you don't make it your main meal, this is a good place to stop by to hold you over until the next meal.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Not bad at all. I thought this would be one of those insanely overrated chain restaurants, but they are about 100 times better than Chipotle. 

I had a little party here, even though space is limited, so I don't really remember exactly what I ordered (probably a chicken burrito) but I do remember it was good and worth getting again. Although I prefer neighborhood taquerias, Papalote offers yumminess you don't find at other chains.
author: Sara K.

description:
Sloppy, messy and oh, so good. Papalote is one of my go-to joints for when I'm in the area and feel like a gut-busting burrito. The place is always busy but the line moves quick. Sometimes it can take a while to get your food but the wait is worth it, these suckers are huge and you will be full after ingesting this goodness. I've been three times and all three have left me with a happy tummy!

I usually go for the Chicken Mole Super Burrito ("super" means the addition of cheese, sour cream & guac) but the Carne Asada is also good. If burrito's aren't your thing, the Chorizo Con Queso has also been known to make my stomach happy. Their legendary salsa is also available to buy and take home, if you want but I'd rather eat it there with my Super Burrito. 

I will go back again!
author: G C.

description:
We came here because the place was listed on the Big Eat 2011 list on 7x7, but upon review they listed Papalote for their chips. The chips!? Parking is WAY too hard in this neighborhood to drive there for just chips, if you do at least go down the street for pie at Chile Pies on Fulton and Baker to make the trek a worthwhile endeavor. 

Moving on...We had the triple threat burrito which by itself was almost 20 dollars, I guess because it has chicken, grilled steak and prawns. It's good but at almost 20 dollars it is SERIOUSLY over priced. 

My burrito barometer is the mighty Expresso Burrito at Burrito Express (on Taraval and 26th or Divisadero and Bush) It is a "wet" burrito with steak beans cheese and rice inside and guacamole, melted cheese and sauce on the outside. 

The triple threat at Papalote was comparable in size but the Expresso has it whipped when it comes to flavor, and value; as the flavor of the steak and chicken "called in sick". They were surprisingly bland in the triple threat leaving the grilled prawn to do the heavy lifting. The prawn were big and savory but not to the tune of $20.

 If I came here again I would give a prawn burrito a shot but I won't be going out of my way to come here again.
author: Jose U.

description: The service is fast and friendly, and I'm constantly craving their soyrizo burritos! Papalote has a beautiful vegan menu.  Their chips and dip alone are worth coming for, everything is amazing.
author: Angela M.

description:
I've been here many times already and have tried most of the food.

I'm usually a carne asada or carnitas type of person, but the two veggie options here are so good that I don't order the meats when I come here. 

The veggie has carrots, mushrooms and potatoes and the grilled veggie has eggplant and zucchini. I would order the burritos to-go or get tacos or quesadilla versions if i'm eating there. The chile verde(pork) is also very good. The chicken can be dry though. 

The best thing about this place is the salsa and warm chips that you get with your meal. I just love how smooth and spicy it is. I buy a jar of it almost every time I go there. The salsa goes great over most anything. Keep it at the fridge at work, pour a bit over Trader Joe's tamales or fish sticks makes for a great lunch, spread it on bread for a spicy sandwich etc. They just started offering a factory-canned version but I just don't think it is the same. Just ask for the fresh made and they will fill a mason jar for you to take home. ($5.99 per jar of awesomeness, totally worth it if you ask me)

During peak dinning hours though the place is a little too crowed for dining-in so this is a very good place to get a quick meal to-go.  

Free Garage Parking is available under the Lucky's across the street. People, Please don't double park.
author: Diana G.

description:
Run for your life!

Dont usually yelp but felt like it had to be done considering the circumstances!
Found a METAL Washer in my burrito!  Next week a buddy of mine found SAND in his burrito. Yea... Not sure what else is on their ingredient list..
author: Jesse S.

description:
Food is superb 

The wait is an awful painful drag

and nowhere to sit

ZzzzzZZZzzzzz
author: Bobby B.

description:
OMG love this place!  if there was one in nyc i would go all the time.  go the carne asada tacos - super tender meat, fresh greens, soft tortillas.  comes w/ this homemade secret recipe salsa which, if i lived local, would buy and take home.  i tried the homemade strawberry punch which was so yummy.  i liked this place so much that when i was in the mission, i checked out that location too.  didn't love the decor as much but food was def just was good.

will be on my to do list next time i return to SF for a visit.
author: tien n.

description: Pretty good (yes the salsa is quite yummy) but is it 50% better than any other burrito joint? I personally don't think so but the prices are inflated by that much. $10 for a burrito. Not sure if I would come back or just visit little chihuahua next time.
author: Natasha F.

description: Came here with a friend the other day and neither of us understand the big ol hype of this place. I'm not saying it is completely horrible because it's not.. but it does lack in some areas. We wanted to try the triple threat since it is so widely known but that damn thing was $20.. I mean I guess its understandable since it has three meats in there but still.. that is pretty ridiculous. So we decided to go with the Adobo burrito and carne asada super burrito. We split both and tried the adobo first.. it came with garlic rice and grilled tomatoes. It lacked in flavor so i had to pile on their salsa to add some to it.. it was much better with the sauce but the blandness to me didn't cut it.. the carne asada was also bland but a little better since the meat was more flavorful. All orders come with chips and salsa.. and I must say I really like it cause it has a real nice creamy tomato flavor to it. I honestly have to say this is catered to the people who are scared to go into a place on Mission street to get a REAL burrito... just sayin.
author: Tiff C.

description: This place clearly doesn't read the reviews on here, because nothing has changed and I have experienced some of the same aforementioned issues... They have forgotten my "super" at least 3 separate times, and the chips have been stale the last few times I've been to the Fulton location. Time to figure it out; either drop your prices to make up for the shortcomings of the kitchen, or make sure they're making the damn food correctly! The 2 stars is because I really have experienced better, and expect better!
author: Alex G.

description: Decent pollo asada burrito (super). My only real problem was the lack of chicken. It was mostly rice and beans. (Side note: the refried black beans are pretty good) 6 of us each had the same issue with our burrito. I don't think it was just a one time fluke.
author: Craig I.

description: The food is amazing, but I wanted to bring a friend of mine who uses a wheelchair here, but there are no tables for us to sit at! That's ridiculous! Come on guys, the ADA was passed 25 years ago.
author: A S.

description:
Whenever I am in California, I get a craving for Mexican.  Which can be a downfall because I am always in Northern California and I don't think of awesome Mexican food coming from the SF area.  This burrito place is walking distance from where I always stay.  Since it's so hard to park in SF, I don't feel like being a burden on the people I stay with and ask for a ride to a different place or trying to maneuver getting around on the BART or MUNI (convenient of course, but I feel I would get lost)

During one of my many trips to SF last year, we came to this establishment because we were told it had been on some show on Food Network.  I am obsessed with Food Network, so I thought why not.  I was very excited.

My review is almost like a lot of the other reviews.  My first time here, the place was packed and the line almost out the door.  I ordered the chicken burrito, the guy I was with ordered a carne asada burrito.  His was given first and it felt like I waited almost 20 minutes before my chicken burrito came out.  I was just going to assume the wait was because chicken takes longer to cook, or maybe they just forgot about me.  The burrito wasn't bad, the chicken was decent.  The burrito overall was okay.  I've had better.  The chips and salsa they gave however, was another story.  It was the best part of the meal hands down.  It is the only reason to go back in my opinion or if it is the closest Mexican place.  I wouldn't go out of my way to go back for a burrito.
author: Kate T.

description: Had a carne asada from here tonight.  9 years ago this place was great, and I was excited to go back.  I'm not sure what happened but the burrito tasted terrible.  Each bite had overly chewy/fatty steak, the beans tasted off, there was very little rice, the chips were stale, and the salsa wasn't spicy at all.  The woman who took my order was rude as F.  I don't recommend anyone go here unless your plastered and absolutely need food.
author: W W.

description:
I will start by saying that the food here is actually better than 2 stars, but a review is supposed to be based on a dining experience as a whole, and my dining experience at Papalote was less than stellar. The burritos sit somewhere between better than Chipotle quality but not as good as others you will find in the city. The Chile Verde burrito was pretty good. What really turned me off from this place was their customer service, which is important to me.

I had a 30% discount voucher through BBE and I followed all the fine print except that it was supposed to be good for dine-in only and I had to take it to go to bring it home because my wife couldn't come down with me. I understand that fine print is there for a reason but I thought it was ridiculous in this specific case, especially since there is virtually no seating available in their cramped space. They should actually be happy that I was taking it to go to free up space for other patrons. Instead, the girl at the register would not waiver at all and was quite rude about it too. 

The funny thing is that they lost money because they didn't accept my voucher. I decided to order much less food because of this and not to buy a jar of their salsa/sauce, and now I will not be returning. I am not a "customer is always right" person, far from it. However, I am about taking each situation as they come and deciding what to do that is the best for your business and to please your customers, and not to be rude. The only difference from dine-in and to-go was to wrap my burrito in foil instead of putting it on a plate. Bad business decision.
author: Frank J.

description: The BEST chicken and carne asada burritos HANDS DOWN!! Yes, I know we all love Chipotle but this place is even more authentic and they also serve horchata and Mexican beers in the bottle along with Mexican coke. They have the best salsa which just adds to it. They make and grille the food right in front of you so you know its fresh and made to order. The meats are tender and the flavors are mouth watering. This is my go to spot in NOPA and found myself her many times.
author: Paul D.

description: Very good burritos, and amazing chips and salsa.  It's often crowded but call ahead and they will have your order ready!
author: Jenchris M.

description: I got a chicken and black bean burrito. It was almost $10, tasted dry and burnt. I will definitely not go back.
author: Amanda F.

description: Papalote's "mexipino" burrito is my darkhorse favorite burrito in SF. I get it 100% of the time I go - sometimes naked (no tortilla + lettuce in a bowl) and sometimes in all it's carb loaded glory. You can get a super carne asada burrito anywhere, but I don't know where else to get an adobo chicken and garlic rice mexi-mash-up. And please don't get me started on the salsa. I've built up a veritable mason jar collection from all the times I've picked up jars their creamy tomato habanero salsa to go.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I paid $16 for a chicken burrito with a small side of guacamole. Rip off. Burrito was 80% beans and rice. And the chicken was chewy and hard. 

Definitely would not recommend.
author: E Z.

description:
I don't get it.
So many people and so many publications swear by this place.

To be truly sure of myself, I tried this place twice:  Once in the mission, and once at this location.  Both times I was led in by enthusiasm and then left with disappointment.

The sauce is what this place is all about.  If you're looking for a kick ass sauce, this is where you want to go.  If you're looking for a tasty burrito, go somewhere else.  If you want extra sauce to put on your lame burrito, fork over an extra 50 cents.
author: Yeeman N.

description: What I can say is just the salsa is good.  Pricie n not a good taste in the shrimp burrito I had.  (Couple shrimps). Also de guacamole was so bad.
author: CR F.

description: Burritos amazing!! I love having this in my neighborhood. But so sad to say I won't be coming back yesterday night I came In and Literally walked right back out saw a huge RAT running out their back door felt disgusted Never again :(
author: Mylie R.

description:
I'm three burritos away from a free one - huzzah! Today I got a veggie burrito with potatoes, carrots, and mushroom. Verdict: Delish!

I got the carne asada the last time and that was great as well. Hard to go wrong....
author: Chung N.

description:
What can I say about Papalote that hasn't already been said? Still, being a big fan I'll add my two cents even if I'm probably just repeating what many others before me have already expressed. 

First of all, what makes Papalote famous, aside from the burrito throwdown with Bobby Flay, is their roasted tomato salsa. It's absolutely delicious - so delicious they've bottled it and are now selling it at places like whole foods. I have no idea what they put in it, but whatever it is always leaves you feeling like you haven't gotten enough. The only drawback I can think of is that they charge you a buck or two for a second serving, which wouldn't be a problem at all if the servings weren't so damn tiny. 

The ingredients they use for their burritos, tacos, and other dishes are of high quality. The steak and chicken are lean, tender, and tasty. The flame broiled flavor is very pronounced and quite gratifying. I do wish they'd put some more pico de gallo inside their burritos, because they tend to be a bit light on it; and call me weird, because I like lettuce in there too, which they refuse to put in. But in spite of those minor shortcomings I still can't get enough. 

I've seen some reviewers here talk about how the burritos are so huge and for the life of me I can't figure out what they're talking about. If anything they should be a bit bigger, but again, they taste good enough to me to make up for what they lack in size.

Some other things I like are the fact that they offer four different types of tortillas for their burritos: flour, whole wheat, tomato, and spinach. I also think their service is top notch considering the volume they handle - everyone is friendly and proficient at what they do there. And finally, Miguel, one of the owners, is a class act and a multi-talented guy. Not only is he an entrepreneur as a part owner of two successful restaurants and now a product selling at the grocery store, but he's also a respected, established DJ.

In summary, good service, quality ingredients, and excellent flavor. The only thing keeping me from marking this one 5 stars is that I feel for the prices they charge they could give just a little bit more food. But really, Papalote is as close as you can get to 5 stars without being a full 5 stars.
author: Don W.

description:
Tastes pretty good.  Nothing spectacular.  Got the Carne Asade Super Burrito.  Really, what's the difference between the ingredient and what I could make at home?  Nothing, but the flavors were decent, except for the chips which were stale and was pretty sure they were store bought.  

Here is the thing about all these SF burritos, they are about as close to authentic Mexican as Tex Mex.  I mean the Triple Threat where they just pile on three kinds of meat is ridiculous. But the Tex Mex burrito was my expectation and Papalote met it without reservation.  In a pinch, I wouldn't mind trying it again.
author: Zack S.

description:
It's all about the SAUCE!
I'll be the fifity millionth review for Papalote.  This place is definitely a unique find among Mexican food restaurants and probably the worst kept secret now.
I've been coming before the Bobby Flay visit and have always loved the burritos.  The meats are grilled to order and the ingredients are fresh.  The custom make your burrito if you're picky and it's no problem.  
But the draw without a doubt is the sauce.  It's now being sold in jars too.  The sauce must go onto every bite of all their food.  The drinks are awesome too!  Usually fresh watermelon or strawberry, it's the best strawberry drink in SF!
Street parking can be tough and the prices are deserving of the quality.  A great place for a burrito!
author: Pablo R.

description: I had heard really good things about this Burreetery and it did not disappoint. Had the chicken mole burrito, which was pretty top notch. Chicken was flavored nicely and the burreet was huge. Highly recommend and would definitely go back.
author: Jim T.

description: Thought this would be great, had their salsa and ate at the Mission location years ago. We ordered 2 roasted veggie tacos. Waited at least 10 minutes and the place wasn't crowded. There were 2 slices of undercooked carrot and potatoes and a few mushrooms. Who puts potatoes in veggie tacos? Where's the zucchini, peppers? Rest was a huge handful of lettuce and tomatoes. Truly disappointing and tasteless. Then to make it worse. We asked for an extra micro container of salsa- extra 50 cents?! Mind you we had bought 3 jars of salsa with our order. What Mexican place charges for extra salsa? What attitude because they charge for their jars now? Sell them in Whole Foods? I was so excited to return to this place after having good meals in the Mission location. But this experience and the attitude about their salsa was truly disappointing. Don't even know if I want to buy any more of their salsa. This is what happens after a little success. Sad. Back to reliable, tasty, friendly Pancho Villa.
author: Rosie P.

description:
Just back from a long trip to New York, I had no food in the house and was craving some San Francisco comfort. And what says SF better than a burrito? 

Well, my chicken burrito at Papalote was more like a slap in the face than a warm embrace. Dry, dry, dry. No flavor. And at $8, I felt downright ripped off. Sure, it came with a small container of their fantastic salsa but the chips tasted like they came out of one of those giant Costco sized bags that you can get for $3.

No fucking bueno.
author: phil h.

description:
I came to this place after learning that their burritos were rated the best in SF. Being from Texas, I've been having issues finding good vegan Mexican food (sorry Gracias Madre, I just don't understand what all the fuss is about). I ordered the veggie burrito which had potatoes, carrots, mushrooms, refried black beans and rice on a wheat tortilla. This burrito was HUGE, but one hungry person can definitely eat it. I really enjoyed this burrito - it was classic veg Mex food done right, nothing fancy. The ingredients were all very fresh too.

I know that this place is famous for their salsa, which I think has pumpkin seeds(?). The salsa was definitely different, but I prefer a classic red salsa. Even so, I will definitely be back to this place!
author: Sarah S.

description:
This joint is basically La Victoria in SF. If you're from the East Bay and South Bay then you know what La Victoria is. Papalote is the ONLY Mexican Grill in SF. I have to eat this once a week when I come to SF for grad school and it's a no brainer. I recommend the shrimp super burrito. They even have tofu for all you vegans. That earns my coveted 5 star rating. I'd give it 4.5 stars only because the seating isn't tremendous. But this is SF. Real estate isn't cheap. 

Eat here and go home satisfied.
author: Jon H.

description:
It's all right.  The chips are great, the salsa is good (better than average, but I don't get the breathless accolades) and the burrito is well balanced.  The carne asada is acceptable (a little underseasoned to me, but that's why they put salt and pepper shakers on the tables.)  The place is bright and spotlessly clean, if, you know, that matters to you.  There's not  a lot of seating, and what there is isn't all that conducive to hanging out, so it's more of a dine-and-dash place.  Basically I'm saying it's middle-of-the-road fine.  If I'm in the area already and I want a burrito, I'll go here, but I wouldn't bother going out of my way to get it.

On one hand, it's a little more expensive than usual for a burrito.  On the other hand, they take credit cards, so it's not like I'm spending real money (er, until maybe the end of the month.)
author: Eric W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because their logo reminded me of the Thundercats logo, but alas that was not the case.  I got the Chicken Mole Super Burrito and was really disappointed by how dry the chicken was.   It's true that the burritos are large, but at $9 each, they'd better be!

My friend was similarly not impressed with her Chile Verde Burrito.  I would rather go to Green Chile Kitchen which is just a few blocks away.  Or The Little Chihuahua which is a few more blocks away but they put PLANTAINS in their burritos for extra starchy goodness.

The salsa that comes with the free bowl of chips was tasty and the service there was friendly and fast. I could be persuaded to give them another try.
author: Amy C.

description:
Love this place!

Pretty Reasonable for the amount of food you're getting.

Burritos are filled with so many delicious flavors.  Food comes out pretty fast, considering how busy it gets.

The only negative is the seating.  There are more people than seats.  Tables and seats are close together, so you can definitely hear the other groups talking.  

Otherwise, this I always look forward to coming here!
author: Alisha L.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place.

1) their chips and salsa are the bomb diggity. seriously. i would go back just for those.

2) their burritos are ... OK. The ingredients are fresh, and you can taste that,  Their meats are cooked perfectly, and so initially I got super excited. But the meat lacked any "zing".  It's like you put a bunch of fresh stuff together, but it doesn't melt and make something OMG delicious. Its just a bunch of stuff, wrapped together in a tortilla. Also, when I ask and pay extra for a super burrito, i expect more than a measly half-dollop of guacamole and sour cream at the bottom of my burrito. I felt a little jipped.

3) The atmosphere is chain-like, badly decorated, and the chairs are really uncomfortable. I suggest grabbing your food to go.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Came here with some friends because they said this place was amazing. Honestly was not impressed. Tried their adobe burrito and it was super dry. The salsa made a little bit of difference but not much. Apparently the salsa one of the more amazing items that they serve here. It was ok, but I honestly didn't give it a second though.

Definitely had way better.
author: Jaydee C.

description:
Pretty good but doesn't quite live up to its reputation. The burritos are good but not excellent, and they are relatively expensive (although I used to live in the Mission so...). Their house salsa is really good tho.

That said, their guacamole is not great and they are super inflexible with regards to their menu - can't make minor changes to a dish without huge extra charges. Some of those things are pretty weird and arbitrary too - like that you can only order tacos in pairs of two.
author: Felix B.

description: I used to enjoy the burritos at the Valencia Papalote. Fulton's is terrible. Even a $10 "super" burrito is packed with beans and rice instead of the stuff that's supposed to be in there. Everything is ridiculously overpriced. No salsa is worth this kind of ripoff.
author: Grant P.

description:
First time experiencing Papalote yesterday and we ordered the chilliquilles and mole tacos. Both were super tasty!
I would definitely recommend either of them. My friend and I shared both and I have to say it was a lot of food for the price. The quality of the ingredients were fresh and what I loved about my taco is that is stayed together the whole time. The tortilla did not fall apart.
I'm pretty picky when it comes to mole sauce and lemme tell ya this place did not let me down.
I will for sure be returning.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
Love love love the vegan tofu mole burrito and the soyrizo is ... Oh so good too!

There is usually a line and parking sucks ... So order over the phone; then there is no wait! everything on the menu is so tasty good! From the chicken mole to the super soyrizo burrito on a spinach tortilla... You'll be happy til the end! Try ordering a side and half a burrito with a friend! The burrito has to weigh 2lbs a piece, so don't stress... You can save half for later too!
author: Ashley D.

description:
Great as usual! Called in the order and it was ready to be picked up in 10 mins as I was told. Tasted great! And being able to park across the street in a garage for free, priceless.

Ordered:
2 Carne Asada Super Burritos
1 jar of salsa
author: Ka C.

description: Gross. I went the other day and the chicken was rubbery and the salsa tastes more and more like marinara to me. I don't know if it's me or them. I think it's them. Sad.
author: Maureen G.

description:
I know everyone's got their thoughts about what's "authentic" and what's not.  These are the same people who insist that you can't possibly put pineapple on a pizza, or veggies on a pastrami sandwich because it violates the code of authenticity.  Personally, I prefer to ask whether the resulting conconction tastes any good, independent of the original version.  

So yeah, it turns out that cookie dough is pretty good in vanilla ice cream, a hamburger can be quite tasty on focaccia instead of a bun, and jicama really isn't all that bad on a taco.  Enjoy it.  It's different.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Dear Papalote Mission location- you rock. 
Fulton- this is my 5 th time to your location and can't tell you my continued disappointment. Got a to-go order today as the chips are stale, you forgot my "super" again and the salsa was mostly water. Please step up your game to be comparable to the mission location.
author: Michael G.

description:
what's up with all the buzz? the food barely meet "A-OK" standards and the prices are not comparable to their food. Maybe i've been spoiled by all the tasty 'real' (as real as it gets in san fran) mexican food in the mission?

salsa? it's cool. It's definitely a new twist on the original and it doesn't taste half bad. I prefer the original medley of tomatoes, onions and cilantro. that's just me.

food average. prices above average. overall, not worth it.
author: Alex C.

description:
When I saw that a second Papalote had opened, I wondered if they'd be able to re-create the dishes that made their first restaurant in the Mission such a hit. After a preliminary visit to sample the chilaquiles, the verdict is clear - they've managed to carry the beloved flavors of Papalote successfully to Fulton Street. This newest outpost is a bit shinier but the excellent salsa most come for is here. Also there's none of that weird incongruous table to chair ratio you'll find if you're banished to a seat at the far end of the Mission location. However, do take note that the metal chairs will be a cold shock on your bum if you come early.

While I've heard this is inauthentic, get the chilaquiles with egg - a great enhancement to a lovely, spicy Mexican breakfast dish.
author: Miriam W.

description:
YAY!!! DING DONG THE TANGO'S DEAD THE TANGO'S DEAD THE TANGO'S DEAD! DING DONG THE WICKED TANGO'S DEAD!!!!!

This place rocks! Finally, something decent has opened up in this space to cleanse the palette of the revolting Tango 20.  Good burritos, quality ingredients (they use white meat chicken), reasonably priced, and all directly across the street from my house. The burnt orange colored hot sauce is tasty! I couldn't be more thrilled.  Please patronize this new burrito shop so they don't go out of business.  

Help spare us the threat of yet another taco debacle!

Update 4/26/06: friggin' sweet carne asada tacos. $4.15 for two!!!

Update 9/25/06: Tried the breakfast burrito with chorizo, eggs and cheese yesterday.  Pretty good stuff, although it could have used a little more egg for my liking.
author: Rick H.

description:
Beans, cheese & rice w/pico & guac on the side was awesome. Avoids the wetness of the burrito (unless u dig that sort of thing) & keeps the brightness of the flavors the whole time. If u have any salsa left over from ur chips--try a dash if that on ur burrito too. Sooo delish.  

On the downside, seats near the restroom smelled like cleanser, luckily we were able to move more towards the front to avoid that from hindering our full enjoyment of their awesome food.
author: Caitlin L.

description:
After leaving Southern California seven months ago, we were finally up for some Mexican food. I was doing the AIDS Walk so instead of wandering the Mission and hoping to get lucky, I did a little research and found this gem not far from Golden Gate Park. We called our order in (per a yelp suggestion!) and I ordered a burrito with grilled tofu. There was minimal seating but I was tired after doing my part. I just wanted to go home, put on a romantic comedy and veg out. 

Maybe I was just starving post walk, or maybe I still haven't adjusted to how San Francisco caters to my vegetarian self, but this burrito was beyond amazing. It's been  a week and I still want another one. It was huge too! It was lunch and dinner and frankly it could have made a great breakfast. 

Grilled tofu super burrito with a spinach tortilla. If that sounds delicious to you then go to Papalote and order just that.
author: Mai W.

description: Carne asada burrito was basically all beans. The little bit of beef was chewy, grissly. It took ten minutes to make and still nothing tasted fresh.  No thank you.
author: Greg W.

description:
