I am by no means a burrito expert (does that nullify my opinion already? Perhaps). However, I do know that Papalote serves a kickass marinated tofu burrito. I used to treat myself to one on the way home from school when I knew I had a long night of studying ahead of me...

... or had just finished a test...
... or was rushing to get to hula practice on time...
... or was simply starving...

...ok, so maybe I kinda just picked up a marinated tofu burrito whenever I felt like it. I can't help it--it's so fuckin tasty! Haven't had one in a while though, since I've joined the ranks of employment at my nonprofit job... yeah, 7 bucks for a burrito is pushing it, I'll admit... especially when you've had better for $5 in the Mission. But that's the Mission. This is NOPA. 

Also noteworthy: the nachos--HUGE!
author: Kate V.

description: Not worth it at all. 15 dollars for a chicken quesedilla and some chips and guac. The quesadilla wasn't even great. The only thing I enjoyed was the salsa and chips. Customer service was as bad as the prices.
author: Clarissa M.

description:
My friends and I were craving Mexican food one day, and it turns out that this place is like the best Mexican place near USF. 
I had the chicken quesadilla which was pretty delicious, in my opinion. The portion was also really filling (but then again, maybe it's just because I'm small).
My favorite part was the chips + salsa! The Salsa is really as good as everyone says =) 
Prices were pretty decent.
The restaurant itself is pretty small, so I can imagine that seats would be hard to find on a busy night.

Definitely the place to go for mex food , esp if you're at USF.
author: Ashley N.

description:
Pretty decent.

My first experience was much better than the second.  I'm thinking I may have been starving during that first trip.  The carne asada super burrito was pretty good the second time, but the first time it rocked my world.

Also, I love the salsa here.  I could eat a gallon of it.  But it's not your typical salsa, it's more of a saucey puree type...  And I believe you get chips and salsa for free with your order which is ALWAYS a plus.  

There really aren't very many good Mexican spots around my neighborhood... this may be the best taqueria.  I grew up on Gordo's, so I think I might just be sick of them.  But, I'd say this place is probably pretty comparable.

I will have to try Tango 20, apparently....
author: Lauren R.

description:
This was definitely a great tasting burrito, but the "Super" wasn't as big as I expected it to be.  In our gluttonous world, I thought that an average American man (aka Fat) would be able to enjoy this "Super" burrito without asking me if I ordered two for him and that I must have been joking.

"No," I said.
  
Although, I do agree that this is a Great tasting burrito.  I can definitely find a bigger burrito for a cheaper price at some other Bay Area locations which I will not dare compare.

Papalote, 

Are your tortillas not big enough?  Do the spoons have holes?  Are you trying to make MORE money by skimming on the goods?  I don't know, but I do hope that the next time I come in here, I will be not only be amazed by the great tasting burrito, but by it's girth as well.

The chips needed salt, but chips' taste change with each cook.
author: Jesse O.

description:
Three words: Chicken Adobo burrito! nuff said! It's there, but not on the menu so you have to ask. Their salsa is on hit too!! I only wish I can come here more often. 

Great place for some mexican eats. It gets crowded and not really a place for a group to go eat there, but the food is delicious!
author: Kyra R.

description:
I live about a block away from Papalote, and I have to say that I must be one of their more frequent customers. I eat here usually multiple times a week and have tried almost everything on the menu. 

My go to is usually - chicken super burrito with the refried black beans. Very addicting! Get the black refried beans you will not be disappointed. I also enjoy the fish burrito, I was skeptical at first, but it is awesome. When you order a burrito you get a bag of chips and a small cup of their salsa. The salsa is amazing as well. 

Do yourself a favor and call in the order. The place is always busy and if you order it there it takes a while. Also, Sriracha and Papalote are made for each other.
author: Drew H.

description:
Its really dangerous living less than a block away from this place.  Definitely my go to place for burritos in the city.

For us vegan/veggies out there you can choose from tofu mole, soyrizo and grilled veggie style. 

The staff has always been super quick and friendly.  I went in one Friday night just before closing and the line was nearly out the door. Fifteen minutes after placing my order they realized that I had been skipped, promptly apologized and even gave me a free burrito card.  

Do yourself a favor and purchase a jar of the fantastic salsa to take home.
author: Elyssa D.

description:
Why in the world did I wait so long to try this place? and why in the world did I even order those tacos? DON'T ORDER THE TACOS. 

I split the prawn burrito with a friend (damnit, another mistake). I not only split it but I made him cut me a smaller piece since I didn't want to be stuffed (mistake number three?)

Papalote's burritos are so delicious that I feel awful for having eaten only 1/3 of their deliciousness! I can't wait to go back and do it right!!
author: Sarah Z.

description: This is a place you visit for standard fare. The portions are decent and the interior space is small. However, the sauces they have are quite incredible. It may be worth it to come here just for the spicy salsas!
author: Lily C.

description:
Too much talk too overrated by douche bags like Bobby Flay.

However, there is no denying the quality of their products. The carne asada is the best quality I have had in San Francisco. Their salsa is truly there own flavor and is good.  
My problem with Papalote is the price. $11.00 for an asada super burrito is no longer a burrito. A burrito is half that price!
Just raising the price to throw a whole bunch of gourmet products together doesn't  cut it.The burrito lacks the cohesion, the grit and the symmetry of flavors that the true great burrito joints have.

I will be back... Next time I'll try and order just a big plate of Asada
author: James B.

description:
Rockin' Mission-style burrito, you elude me still. I sometimes think you lead me on this futile chase while mocking me from beneath that aluminum cover of yours. 

Papalote, king of so many 'best burrito' lists, I was sad to say that I found your products only slightly above average. I got the super carne asada burrito (with guac, sour cream and cheese) on a whole wheat tortilla. I liked that there are so many options for the beans and tortillas. I'm not sure about this, but they seem to target the vegetarian crowd by have an extraordinary number of vegetarian options, including a soyrizo meat substitute. I have to say that there wasn't anything wrong with my burrito, but it just didn't strike me as anything significantly better than a lot of other places out there. Getting the burrito with the 'super' additions made the whole thing somewhat of a mess. 

Also got the prawn quesadilla. Shrimp were well cooked, not a whole lot else going on there. At least they give you chips with your food. Thumbs up for that.

A lot of raves about their roasted tomato salsa, but they give you a small container to go and charge you an extra $0.55 for more. Dude, I need that much salsa just for my first bite. I'm almost tempted to order each thing separately so they'll give me a container with each order. And I hear that the stuff in the jar just isn't quite the same as the stuff you get at the restaurant. 

Two hour free parking in the Lucky parking lot across the street, but the place is fairly small, so it's not exactly a good place for groups. There's a counter along the wall that was pretty empty. 

My search continues...
author: Saunders C.

description:
P erfect salsa -- and that's about all you need to know
A ll of the hype lies in the little complimentary cup of creamy goodness
P robably could down a jar of it in one setting
A nd, yes, they sell jars of the salsa to go (they make excellent gifts)
L ook past the "best burrito" claims -- it's good, but not great
O ne could compare their fare with Chipotle's, only with much better salsa 
T here are only a few tables in the front, so it isn't the most ideal for groups
E xpect to take a bar seat along the wall -- and enjoy your salsa
author: Anthony N.

description:
There is something addictive about the chicken mole.  It's the only thing I can order when I go there.  It took me a while to figure out what it was about the salsa that made it so... different.  Then it finally dawned on me.  It tastes like Doritos, but in a good way.

Seriously, go for the chicken mole.  Yum.
author: Guesty G.

description:
This place is by far my favorite place to get burritos from. To me every taqueria serves pretty much the same kind of burritos, but Papalote's burritos are way different. I always get the Super Burrito with carne asada.

The one thing I like about their burritos is that yes it is filling, but not to the extreme point where I feel like I have a food baby! Every time I have eaten burritos from other places, I feel disgusting. Papalote's makes their burritos slightly smaller than other places, but the meat they use is super fresh, juicy and tender. I like their tortilla and the way they cook them. I don't think they steam them, since mine tasted crunchy (just the way I like it!). The burritos are just the right size and I can get a perfect bite whenever I eat it! It also comes with chips and salsa. 

The place is pretty small, but it is in a good location for students to come for lunch (it is located near USF). Also, their burritos may be considered pricey since its portion is not as large as other taquerias. Honestly, I think it is worth the money. You want to feel good after you eat, not like you have gained a bajillion pounds!
author: Katrina T.

description:
I know I know. 3 Stars for the most awesomest salsa place. It's really just that I am from San Diego so this place kinda blows in comparison to our Mexican food. ("Oh wow, look at this SD chick getting so elitist on us") Yeah well, when you are born and raised in a Mexican food heaven, it's hard not to be so judgmental.  

It really just lacks flavor. The salsa makes up for it as much as it can, but it doesn't make it a 5 star review. 

The staff is very nice, the bathroom is a bathroom (but a single stall for all you public poopers) and the price is indicative of San Francisco "Mexican food" found outside of the Mission.
author: Kat M.

description:
After seeing Bobby Flay's throwdown episode and glancing over the 7x7 list, I decided that it was time to try out Papalote.  I went around 5:00 pm, for dinner, because I was already in the area and the place was already pretty full. 

Since we weren't that hungry, we ordered the Prawn Quesadilla ($9) to share.  You get a number from the cashier and sit down.  The place isn't really that big and my boyfriend and I were lucky to find a table.  They have water in the back for you to serve yourself.  Fairly quickly, an employee brought us a basket of chips and salsa/sauce.  The salsa is pretty unique, kind of creamy-ish? It was pretty good.  The chips are nothing special though.  

Our prawn quesadilla came out in less than 10 minutes and when I saw it, I was pretty disappointed.  For a $10 quesadilla (after tax), I expected it to be super cheesy, filled with shrimp, or at least have some rice/beans on the side.  But instead, it was a flat, hardly cheesy, 5-shrimp quesadilla.  The prawns were pretty tasty, all 5 bites at least.  Needless to say, after eating the quesadilla, my boyfriend and I were still really hungry, actually even hungrier than before probably.  We ordered another bowl of chips/salsa ($1.50).  After finishing those, we then decided to get a carne asada burrito (super) ($8.50).  This was a much better choice than the quesadilla.  The burrito was quite large and tasted pretty good.  The beef was grilled nicely and the whole burrito tasted solid.  I asked the server if we could have some salsa for the burrito and he said it'd be an additional charge of $0.55 (which isn't a lot, but is still somewhat annoying considering I am not by the cash register/sitting at my table, and I just want to eat my meal).  

Overall,  avoid the quesadilla.  Burrito is decent.  Chips are ordinary.  Salsa is good.  I don't know if I'll be back though because it's out of the way for me, and I have many other places to try still.

Note:
-Street parking can be difficult to find.
-They charge $0.55 for another container of salsa/sauce
-They charge $1.50 for another chips and salsa/sauce
author: Samantha L.

description: Why does it always take you 25 minutes to make a burrito? You're seriously the worst, Papalote. No one cares that Bobby Flay liked your salsa a decade ago.
author: Mathew L.

description:
This is my 2nd time at Papalote. After a long hiatus of reviewing on yelp, my accumulative experiences are compelling me to finally write a review for this place. 

1st Visit - Ordered the $20 Burrito. Verdict: Hell NO
If you're literally throwing down a twenty for a burrito (which is UNHEARD of), it'd better be the most damn delicious burrito in your life. I've had $5 dollar burritos at hole in the wall places that tasted WORLDS better than this burrito. (La Taqueria Cancun!!!) The 3 different meats didn't have much flavor to them other than dryness and burntness. It was all girth and quantity, no quality of flavor. They also packed the burrito very unevenly, so that all the special toppings (guacamole, cheese, sour cream) were all at one end! FAIL! 

Sadly, the best thing in this meal was the orange house salsa which is good but does not justify the cost or flavor of the burrito... The salsa itself isn't super duper awesome, its just good. Not enough draw by itself to bring me back to this place.



2nd Visit (today) - Ordered a Chorizo Burrito (not on the menu) Verdict: Yum, but... (see below)
Chorizo is crazy greasy (normal I think) and rich in flavor. Def enjoyed the burrito. SUPER DUPER Pissed because paid more to "Make it a Super" and didn't find any "Super" fillings in it at all. I went at 2:30pm so it wasn't even bustling... how hard is it to get an order right when mine is the only order going on???

Debating whether I want to go back. Might if I have no other options available to me and I am in my "burrito, do or die" mode. =\

Side Note: Tortilla chips are O-K in flavor. The ones I got today were stale. Horchata isn't bad.
author: Beck P.

description:
Oh how living in San Diego for 5 years can change your perspective on Mexican food. After going to school at UCSD, Mexican restaurants in NorCal just don't live up to the wonderfulness that is SoCal Mexican food.

On a rainy Sunday, in the early afternoon there wasn't much of a wait, which was surprising. We also got a parking spot right out front...an amazing feat in San Francisco. 

I ordered super carne asada tacos (2 in an order) and the boyfriend ordered a super carne asada burrito. The carne asada was tasty, but they only use one tortilla for each taco and both of them fell apart as soon as I tried to pick them up. I had to eat most of it with a fork. The boy said his burrito was okay, but he has the same (if not higher) standards for Mexican food as I do.

Also, the famed salsa that comes with the complimentary chips is just okay. I didn't think it had that much flavor and they don't have any other options for salsa. 

It was a good try, Papalote, but we are still on a search for great Mexican food up here. Good thing we are off to visit San Diego in a couple weeks...time to eat enough Mexican food for the rest of the year =)
author: Annaliese D.

description:
I agree with just about everyone else.  Went for the triple threat expecting something special, and it was just like any other mission burrito, except with 3 kinds of meat, and more than twice the price.  Bobby Flay must have been off his game.

Yes, the chips and salsa were good, but I really ding these guys for having the nerve to sell a pretty ordinary burrito for $20.
author: char s.

description:
I must admit I was drawn to this place by their appearance on Throw Down for their Triple Threat Burrito as well as their salsa making the 7x7 list of top things to try in San Francisco before you die; this place lives up to all the hype!!!  This place has the wonderful smell of grilling meat as soon as you walk into the door.

Triple threat- I can see why it won the contest!  Now normally I would balk at such a hefty price attached to a mere burrito, but its worth every penny!  The carne asada, chicken, and shrimp all fresh off the grill provide an explosion of texture and flavor in your mouth, simply amazing!  I need to go back!

Salsa- WoW I went back for 2nd and 3rd helpings, this stuff is like liquid gold!  A great combination of spice and flavor, and an amazing texture.  Definitely a must try if you can handle spicy!

Atmosphere- Bright, colorful, and clean; what a nice combination!  The beautiful insects (i think they might be kites) decorating the ceiling are a very unique touch to the decor.   Im a fan of fine dining, but sometimes the best food is from those small spots that just know how to put that homestyle spin on flavors.  

Overall a great gem in SF, parking can be a lil tough at times but well worth the effort to eat here
author: Christopher C.

description: Loved the food. Ordered a veggie burrito with zucchini and mushrooms. The salsa they have is awesome. Seating can be tight, but they do a good job of moving people around and turning tables quickly.
author: Veeral S.

description: Friendly staff, fast service, good salsa. Too bad food was really bland. I had prawn burrito, my bf had the carne asada plate. We had to drown them in salsa for flavor and try to make it worth the $35. We didn't even order alcohol. Plus, my bf was still hungry when we left. The food isn't terrible but not worth the price. There is much better Mexican food elsewhere in this town.
author: Marci N.

description:
What the hell is this? I ordered two tacos and what did I get? One giant wtf is this taco. I came here because of its great yelp reviews and I suspect all of those are from white people not from San Francisco who don't know what a good taqueria is. I Live not to far from this place and I never went in before because it looks too fancy which to me means expensive, little portions, and non-authentic and that is exactly what I did indeed get. This is not an authentic taqueria it is an American-Mexican taqueria like Pancho Villa or Chipotle

The taco tasted like it was made by some hippie putting only "green" ingredients in. Yes the ingredients seem to be fresh and the whole place seems sanitary, and the people are nice, but thats where the good ends. I guess I shouldn't be to harsh the taco was ok, but I had to use a fork since it was twice as large as a real taco you cant hold it while eating it. I wanted to eat it outside but had to go back home to eat it because I needed the fork.

Point is when SF has so many great taquerias why would anyone settle for this one? Answer is, its for people that don't know no better.
author: Josh E.

description:
ANOTHER favorite. i have too many favorites. but this IS my favorite Burrito place!! I always always order the carne asada burrito and it is always perfect and i always leave SATISFIED. 

They first give you their chips and salsa which is a ORANGE SAUCE that is SOOOO GOOD. I don't know how they make it but its crushed tomatoes with some magic-ness to it. they only give you a small container of it so don't finish it before your burrito comes cuz it pairs with it perfectly.

The carne asada burrito is huge! and packed! i usually get it with black beans, guac, cheeese and the usual burrito stuff. the meat is made to order and the meat is in huge juicccyyyy chunks! i feel like im eating a freshly grilled steak in my burrito! The bf always order the spicy verde burrito which is pulled pork cooked with their green pepper (i think). he LOVES IT and says its the best burrito he had as well! the meat is sooo tender and moist. not those dried up pulled pork u eat at other ghetto burrito joints.

A super plus is that this place is CLEAN!! people always say..the dirtier the place..the better it taste.. i DONT THINK SO! not papalotes! its clean and its good. can't say anything else.
author: Linda N.

description: No real complaints about Papalote, its across the street from my school so its convenient.  They give you good sized portions,  the ingredients are fresh and the restaurant itself seems pretty clean.  The food is not authentic though.  So if you are looking for taqueria styled food...this is not your go-to.
author: Angelica  C.

description:
05/20/2010

If it wasn't for the Food Network's show, Throwdown with Bobby Flay, I would have never visited Papalote's in San Francisco.
The owners and brothers, Miguel and Victor Escobedo, won with their signature burrito, the "TRIPLE THREAT BURRITO".      Intrigued, my buddy Dave and I headed up to SF for lunch.

The Triple Threat Burrito:  4.0 stars
Jam packed with tender grilled chicken, tangy carne asada steak, and four large prawns, this was definitely a mighty pound for pound burrito.     Ask them to make it 'super" and you'll get your breakfast, lunch, and dinner for $19.95.     Yes, the TTB is $19.95.     I know it might be expensive for most Yelpers, but I'm a major foodie so I don't mind trying this unique dish.      The prawns are the best part along with the asada (both were very succulent with its intense flavors).    I didn't care too much for the chicken.    No veggies here.   I would have liked to have the chicken moist with its natural oil oozing out.   Instead it was dry and left on the grill to long.   Now the size of the burrito isn't intimidating.   It looks normal size.    What you're paying for is the ingredients.    The asada are served in big chunks and the prawns are expensive on the market.   So it balances out when you consider the cost to make the TTB.   Definitely a come back.

The Chicken Adobo Burrito aka the "MEXI-PINO": 4.0 stars
So if I married a fine Mexican girl, I'm going to come with my own MEXI-PINO dish....aka Tamales inside a Lumpia!  LOL!  
Oh... and we'll have cute babies too!    

* BAM *


I know what you're thinking.   How can two Mexican guys come up with a Filipino dish and flip it with a Mexican twist.   LOL!   That's what I said until I saw this:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4BFUXAyPrxU
Yes, the taste is there!   They got it down with the Adobo....................... however............... this time the chicken was very dry.      I'm going to suggest to dip that chicken into the adobo grease and oil for an extra hour bro!  GET THAT !@#$% GREASE UP IN THERE!!!  LOL!!    As for garlic rice, its enough for me to say they got it down like LOLA  (Grandmother in Filipino).   Good Job guys!     I'll definitely be back for this one!    I know.  I know.  I could make this at home.   But... Support your local home boys!

Notes:
- Parking.  We got here at 11:00am on the weekday.   Parking is horrible because it's all street parking.   There's a Safeway across the street, but you'll be paying meter and walking.
- If you're not from SF like me, I suggest getting one to eat there and one to go.    And support your local home boys!
- Ask for a burrito card.   Buy ten burritos and get the 11th free!   Sorry does not apply towards the Triple Threat.
- If you got extra cash, buy the jar of the home made orange sauce.   Its spicer than the ones in San Jose.
- Papalote means kite.  Check out their awesome kites hanging from the ceilings.   Sorry I forgot to take pics of them!
- Don't come here if you're on a diet.   Seriously.  There's no such thing as a healthy burrito.  If you want make a healthy burrito, go across the street .... buy yourself a bag of tortilla....lettuce.... that's it.
- Yes... I did buy both burritos on the same visit.   My bill was $31.14.   I ate the abobo burrito for lunch and shared the TTB.   Besides, I run weekly so I CAN eat.....BITCHES!!!
author: Walter P.

description:
Triple Threat Burrito! Massive eats for those who are hungry.  Had to cut this in half and share with a friend, so glad i did.

You get chunks, nice sized chunks, of Carne Asada, Chicken and Prawns.  Everything, every meat meshed together nicely.  Not one over powered the other in flavor.  It was well cooked, seasoned perfectly and put together as a burrito like no other.  

The other plus side of this is the free bowl of chips that comes with the famous Papalote Roasted Tomato Salsa!  Nothing can beat that, not even Bobby Flay himself!   So good, that i got a jar for me to bring home!  Yet i left it at my San Leandro home and forgot to bring one with me to Santa Rosa...order one online?? hmmm, I just might!
author: Max-Adam A.

description:
EWWWWWWW!

How the heck did this place end up with 4 stars?! I think I can get better Mexican food at a Taco Bell. 

I give them 1 star for having a very clean bathroom and preventing me from starving to death.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
First impressions are everything (for the most part), and at first the sticker shock pricing almost sent me out the door. Why would I pay $11 for a super burrito I can get for $6 in the mission. But alas, I was starving and it was the only mexican joint close-by.

The staff were alright, I felt like I was being a little rushed to get out. I payed by card and wasn't offered my receipt. I didnt even know the transation was finished because the girl didn't say anything to me after swiping my card, just handed me a number and turned around to talk to a fellow co-worker.

My number was called and I brought my plastic card up only to be stared at by the cooks like I did something wrong. The food wasn't even ready, why would the call my number just to have me stand there and look like a chump? I waited a couple extra minutes until they yelled my number again, like I didn't get the memo that my number was called.

I decided to get the carne-asada super burrito, but I guess that's code for bean burrito with a light sprinkle of meat. I'm not exaggerating, this was a straight up bean burrito for $11. The meat that I did manage to get was quite nicely flavored, but it was really dissappointing getting mouth fulls of refried beans bite after bite. All together it was really just a sub-par burrito.

Needless to say, I won't be going out of my way to come here. I know its pretty much the only game in the neighborhood, but i would still just head down to the mission if you want a legit burrito for the right price.
author: Corey F.

description: Overpriced overrated food. Not to mention incredibly slow service! Walked in and ordered a burrito - took 1 hour to prepare! Not to mentioned it was half-arsedly prepared. If you really want Mexican, take your money elsewhere.
author: Rich J.

description:
As a child, you may have been told that on the 7th day, God rested.
I'm here to tell you this is not true. 
On the 7th day, God created Papalote's salsa.

The burritos are okay, pretty average for the most part, and too expensive. The burritos alone are 3-star. But the salsa gets them an extra star.
author: jared c.

description: DELICIOUS burritos that will keep you full all day long! And their salsa is very unique and flavorful as well! Loved it!
author: Aditi G.

description:
I have heard great things about this place and was glad to actually give it a try. Unfortunately I was disappointed. 

I ordered prawn tacos. I'm not a fan. The prawns were pretty burnt, so basically my 2 tacos tasted like burnt bbq. Not that appetizing. 

I will eventually give this place another shot, but avoid the prawn tacos.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I'm not sure why I've never heard of this place before last week, even though I'm constantly on the search for the perfect burrito.

Papalote rivals Pokez, but even thought it's slightly more expensive, it wins out because it is closer to me. I had the soyrizo burrito and it was phenomenal. Also, I don't really like salsa, but this salsa was delicious. This spot is tops in my book.
author: Natalye R.

description:
Papalote, how I wanted to love you, but the 2nd time was not the charm.  i ordered the carne asada burrito that I ordered last time and didn't get and it was mediocre at best.  I should have known when they served it on a plate and brought a fork and knife that something was wrong.  Once again, the tortilla was grilled and crunchy so it was cracking before I bit into it.  i prefer them steamed so they stretch and don't break.

The meat tasted ok, but it was too tough and the pieces were too big so instead of getting nice bites I would take a bite and pull a big chunk of the meat out with each bite.

Now, the rest of the burrito is where they really failed.  I ordered a super and there was no crema and very little quacamole.  The entire burrito was dry, dry, dry.  My mouth felt like the sahara minus the heat when I was done eating it.  The only saving grace was their salsa and it was not even all that.  Either I am out of touch or there are a bunch of people reviewing this place who have not had a decent burrito in the mission.  Check out El Faro, Farolito, or Las Cumbres for a much better burrito, hell Chipotle would have been better than this.
author: Chris L.

description:
This is a great place to bring your Grandma. She won't be frazzled by any vibrant mariachi music. She won't have to ask you why there are so many "Hispanics" in this "restaurant." There won't be any salsa varieties to confuse her deteriorating mind. She might even like the soapy taste in the cups they provide.

It comes down to a matter of personal values with Papalote. Yes, the food tastes good and the ingredients are of high quality. It is also expensive and void of atmosphere. The portion sizes are small for the price and they only give you one tiny cup of salsa.

Worst, worst of all. They have no scruples at Papalote about playing that old dirty trick - "Do you want sour cream, guacamole, and cheese?" Hell yeah I do. Oops...yeah...that's another two bucks added to your charge before they ring you up. Who can say no to that unfair question? I'm on a budget here and I don't need to waste my time being tricked by an unloving and over-hyped burrito pusher.
author: Glen P.

description:
Chicken adobo burrito!

Not sure if all the Papalote locals offer this (not on the menu), but you should ask for it!! The burrito was an homage to their (now departed and relocated in San Mateo) neighbors, Poleng Lounge. A bit of mexican and a bit of filipino - how can you go wrong?!?! 

Garlic rice, adobo chicken...oh my!

AND of course, the salsa is kick ass! We usually get a jar for home.
author: Christy L.

description:
There's something really appealing about meat, sour cream, sauce, meat and cheese in a tube form.  Thick, juicy, warm, tube-shape that I can hold in my hand.  Neither too squishy nor dry, turgid, just like I like my cylindrical meat-objects.  

But $10 for a carne asada super burrito?  And it was not the size of my calf.  Instead, it was a very reasonable diet sized.  Small, even.  The flavor was pretty nice.  And the proportion was very good.  Neither too much bean nor too much rice.  

But it was $10.  I was not happy with the price.  I want to go back to Fruitvale and buy some street tacos, damn it.  I hate dieting.  I hate expensive food.  I'm so full of hate right now.
author: Christina C.

description:
Papalote was featured on Man v. Food and I have heard a lot of people talking about it from the Panhandle area.  I think it is a zoning procedure that if you have a college, you must also have a neighborhood tacqueria.  Davis has Guads, USF has Papalote.  I have eaten at a lot of tacquerias in my hayday, however, Gordo will forever be number 1.  Entering Papalote, business was bustling.  It was crowded yet the serveurs were very amiable.  I ordered the super burrito with pollo while my girl got the mole burrito.  I believe the difference between a regular burrito and a super burrito is that on the latter, they give you sour cream and guacamole.  The walls were adorned with achievements they had gotten such as best burrito, etc., however, when it comes to Mexican joints, i hardly take those into account.  

While waiting, we were given chips and their special papalote roasted salsa.  Dipping the chip in, the salsa was different.  It was a sauce so there were no sliced cubes of tomatoes.  It tasted almost like curry and I did not like it too much.  It had a kick to it, but for me, salsa isn't salsa unless its traditional cut tomatoes.  The chips were decent, good enough to pass the time until the burrito arrived.  According to their video, all their meat is cooked fresh and their pollo chicken is their specialty.  Taking a bite of the burrito, I hardly tasted any chicken.  In addition, the burrito was already breaking.  I am used to those shenanigans from Chipotle, but if you are a legit $8-$9 burrito, that should not be happening.  As a result, halfway through, the infrastructure could not hold anymore and it broke, rendering me to eat it with a fork.  Inside the burrito was the traditional picca de gallo.  The refried beans were good and the sour cream and guac were good, however, the meat was very scarce and I felt as if I was playing hide n go seek with it.  No mater how good the condiments are, the meat is the lifeblood of the burrito and the IV drip was down to its last drop.  I took a bite out of my girl's mole burrito and it tasted like yams.  It just tasted weird.

I really do not understand the hype behind this place.  I do not feel this place is authentic and I further widened the chasm between award winning "best burrito" given out by huge syndicated journals and papers.  The burrito was poorly constructed and while fat, do not let the girth fool you.  There is hardly any meat.  In addition, I do not like the tortilla where its semi-crispy as if placed on a grill.  I prefer it softer, steamed in that machine.  In addition, the burritos are pretty expensive. However, the staff are friendly, pepping you with ear to ear grins so if you like a friendly atmosphere with subpar food, this place is for you.
author: Brian V.

description:
A friend of mine suggested we try this place since it was featured in FoodTV Booby flay throw-down and they won. I have very high expectation from my burrito since I live close to Gordos and eaten at almost ll the taquerias in mission.

The place will not disappoint. The use fresh ingredients and your meat is cooked to order. You have choice for your ingredients; tortillas, black or re-fried beans the cheese is god quality. 

The Burrito won't disappoint you but it also won't blow you away.s They are famous for their salsa and I'll be honest it's not for me. I like choice of salsa and chunk, hot salsa. This is more of roasted tomatoes. People seems to love it though.
author: Subhash J.

description:
Props for fresh ingredients, grilled tortillas (for that slightly crunchy texture) and the large portions.

I got whole black beans for my regular carne asada burrito (I found out after the fact that their refried black is delish ... and that they have other types of tortillas, e.g., spinach).  Oh well, next time!

Don't really see what all the hype is about their chips and salsa.  Yeah, it was tasty and filling but salsa wasn't that great (more creamy and less "tomato-y" than other places.
author: F. P.

description:
The burritos are fine.  Nicely sized, but not cheap. I like Pancho's better. 

As for the food platters, well I've only tried the mole plate and that turned my digestive system in to a biological weapon that fired for nearly 2 hours straight.  After that experience, I decided to KISS.  

The lines can get ridic and aren't helped by the clusterfuck of employees behind the grill.  Can't I place my order and *then* pay like everywhere else?
author: John H.

description:
I fell in love with Mole at Papalote. This location is just as delicious and awesome as the Mission original.  The mole burrito is seriously addictive, best thing I have ate in SF in a while.  

Their unique salsa is so good and rich, you can even buy a jar of it to take home.  

But seriously, the mole, you have to get it. 

My only wish is that they would pair up with Green Chili Kitchen for some event cause I dream of eating their burritos with green chili.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: I ordered a chicken burrito here today at he counter and it took 41minutes for a to go burrito. This is the slowest place I have ever been for Mexican food.
author: Dakin G.

description:
For veggie burrito options, there is nothing better than Paplote.  (I love Pancho Villas mind you, but I'm talking options here.)  Papalote has vegan mole (rich and chocolatey), grilled veggie burritos and my fave, the Soyrizo burrito.  

Their chips and salsa were on the 7x7 magazine "100 things to try before you die" list.  The chips are corn which isn't my all time favorite, but the salsa is really unique and so scrumptious.  Someday I'll have to try the fish burrito and something else non-burrito-y there!
author: Mac M.

description: The pescado fish burrito is outstanding.  Soyrizo is good too, but the pescado is so delicious that I never order anything else.  The chips and salsa are scrumptious too.
author: Neill T.

description: Papolote was my first taqueria when I moved to San Francisco and I still use as the REFERENCE for mexican food!
author: Khaloud D.

description:
Just dropped by last night after having seen this restaraunt featured on Throwdown with Bobby Flay on Food Network. The chefs here won the competition but Bobby Flay always gets his butt kicked more than half the time.

The burrito they featured on the show was the triple threat which of course I wanted to try. But then I saw the price tag ... $19.95? Are you kidding me? $20 for a burrito? It's not giant sized or anything. I think I'll pass. I ended up trying out the Prawn w/ Lime Juice Super Burrito, Chili Verde Taco, and the Guacamole w/ Chips with my wife.

The ingredients used are indeed fresh. Maybe it was because I had a prawn burrito but I wished there was more prawns in it. The chili verde taco just fell apart on me and was kinda messy. I ended up finishing it with fork and knife. Great flavor in the sauce but the pork in it was tough and not tender. The guacamole w/ chips was great but $6.25 for that was kinda pricey to me.

This place dishes out above average food but expect to pay close to or more than $10 for a burrito if you add guacamole, sour cream, etc. (The prawn burrito was $9.25) I don't mind paying the premium price for an awesome burrito but I expect much more than what I am getting here.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I used to love this place, because they had really fresh ingredients and you got a lot for your money's worth. But lately, I feel like they got more expensive, and when I taste their food, it's good, but not something I'd remember later on. I still come here though, because it's better than other mexican food places in the neighborhood, and the people are nice. 

Maybe management changed or they had to cut quality cuz of the recession, I don't know...but I wish they'd bring back the flavors I used to think about and crave!
author: Emy s.

description:
Overrated, overpriced and tiny portions. Add that to the horrible parking situation in the Mission, and this is a def "no, thanks" place.

I agree with what others have said - if the Food Network (or basically any food TV show, for that matter) have visited a restaurant, it's basically a heads up that you shouldn't visit (Hello, Red's Java House, courtesy of Anthony Bourdain. Or, basically anything Rachael Ray "recommends.").

Anyways. Yes, the salsa is good, but my theory is that they try to stuff you with the free chips/salsa so that you're so full by the time your food comes, you will magically forget that you just waited 30+ minutes for a tiny "prawn" quesadilla with three whole prawns and a pollo burrito that seemed to be missing chicken in the first 1/3 I ate. 

Do yourself a favor and walk two blocks down to El Farolito. Trust me, you won't regret it.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
I live around the corner from this place so occasionally I will visit this place(about once a week). It's generally okay, nothing to be wowed about. But today I ordered a burrito and asked for super and told them I don't want sour cream. My stomach can't handle sour cream. I asked if I could have extra guacamole instead. The response was "we don't do substitutions". I'm sorry but if you're running a food establishment a place should be more flexible when it concerns their customers.

I will now walk the extra four blocks to Green Chili Kitchen for a better quality burrito (organic meat) that actually is CHEAPER and they DO substitutions.

Papalote if you read this you lost a regular customer who comes in once a week just because you won't substitute for a customer.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
3/5 stars on the Wing Scale... 

- Quality of product: 2 of 3 stars 
- Quality of service: .5 of 1 star
- General feelings of happiness: .5 of 1 star

We ordered the triple threat and a variety of burritos to share on two occasions. We found the food decent. There was general consensus, however, that this place is completely overhyped (thanks to Bobby Flay and Food Network). Maybe it would have been better if we didn't go in with such high expectations? To be fair, we did enjoy the chips and salsa-- definitely above average in terms of tastiness! ;) The location is not bad but seating is tough for bigger groups.
author: Wing Y.

description: the sauce in this place beats any other burrito sauce i have ever tried in my life. when you go, you must order extra sauce. mmmmm even thinking about it makes my mouth stomach cry for some. i get the carne asada super burrito.
author: Ashley D.

description:
While it's one of the better taquerias in the area (perhaps second to only Green Chile Kitchen) this place isn't anything special. 

Everything is on the pricer side for Mexican food, and the restaurant itself is a little cramped. If you do go I reccomend their carne asada, but the real highlight is the salsa (not a great sign). 

Final verdict: Good if you're in the area, but not worth seeking out.
author: Murphy O.

description:
i've been wanting to give papalote mexican grill  a try after i got super exciting seeing a local place on throwdown...and to top things off, they beat bobby flay!  after eating their oh so famous triple threat burrito, it made me seriously doubt bobby flay's food...

the triple threat burrito contained carne asada, chicken, and shrimp straight from the grill...although i appreciate the freshness, the burrito was extremely tasteless.  we even added guac and sour cream which was extra by the way...but nada...no flavor..i had to douse the whole thing with salsa.  

speaking of the salsa...their chips and salsa are on the 7x7 list for sf...also quite disappointing.  don't get me wrong, the chips were decent and so was the salsa...but eh, i've had better.  

what saved the meal was my bff's plate...she had the fish tacos.  the fish was super fresh and yummy...the tacos were a good size...much better than the burrito.

i saw a bunch of people getting the mole...and the chile verde looked pretty good.  maybe if i ever decided to give this place another chance, i'd go for the chile verde.  BUT...the prices here are absolutely ridiculous.  spending 20 bucks on a burrito?  i expected greatness.   for 20 bucks, the burrito better dance or something...but nope...it was just sadly disappointing.  the parking around here is ridiculous...but the extensive menu was nice...

many pros and cons...just not for me.
author: Jen W.

description: Ultimate San Francisco comfort food!!
author: Carlos E.

description:
Apparently this place is popular, most especially among the USF student population, but I may be one of the few who doesn't agree with everyone else. What a disappointment my experience was.

I was totally excited to come here and try it out, not only because of its popularity at my school, but also because they won a challenge against Bobby Flay on The Throwdown. So when I finally came here a few days ago with my cousin and her friends, we all ordered the chicken adobo burrito. It was surprisingly JUST okay. The chips and salsa stood out more for me more so than the burrito. The burrito was dry and lacking in flavor. To add on extras to your meal is pretty pricey, some of them $2 or more (like sour cream, beans, rice, etc.) Wow is all I have to say. I also ordered the horchata, which was average. This place was a total let down for me so I don't  think I'd come back...
author: Anne Y.

description:
i used to LOVE papalotes 7 years ago when i was at USF and decided to come back for the first time in years for a bit of nostalgia and was overwhelmingly disappointed. 
first of all, i paid $10 with tax for a burrito that didnt even include cheese, guac, or sour cream.
i had about 5 pieces of meat in the burrito, and the beans and rice were just plain overcooked. like mush.
i mean, i'm not picky, but for $10 i expect a bit more.

to top it all off there was a huge hunk of hair in my chips. not just a hair, but like a big wad of it. disgusting. had to stop eating after that.

won't be coming back, don't waste your taste.

the 1 star is for the salsa, it's still quite good.
author: Jim T.

description:
Triple Threat burrito and a drink 25 bucks!  Had to try it just for the hell of it...  this one supposedly beat Mr Flay's.. (wut the hell does he know????)  The burrito was soggy and bland.  Lacked any kind of authenticty.   First and last time for me.  

You won't find any Mexicans here.. just a bunch of hipsters with no clue:)

Check out the real deal...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zdTGLVYox-M
author: Demanding T.

description:
getting a TTB on my way back to LDAC...

I love love love Papalote.  I hate hate hate the fact that mommy groups try to jam all 5 of their strollers in here for lunch.  C'mon folks, its barely a hallway...really?!?!

I always get the triple threat burrito...and stretch it out for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  The salsa...omg, the Salsa...sooo good!
author: Rochelle D.

description:
This 2-star review is all about the price. Like every other sucker in town, my b/f and I decided to get burritos from here after the Bobby Flay hype.  He got the Triple Threat, I ordered a vegetarian burrito (rice, beans, cheese, guac).  We ordered by phone, went to pick it up, and was told the bill was $29.43!  Whaaaaat?  "That can't be right - we got two burritos".  The reply: "Oh yes, that's correct, the Triple Threat is $19.95".  Dang - okay, this better be a good burrito.  We left, went to a favorite sf watering hole and sat down with some friends to eat our lunch.  Was it good?  Meh.  It was pretty good, my boyfriend thought.  It was tasty.  Was it $19.95 good?  No f-ing way. Bummer of a price, when there's a LOT better places to get a MUCH better burrito for less than half the price.

This leaves me to my side note that my vegetarian burrito (again, rice, beans, cheese, guac) was still hovering in the $10 range.  NO WAY was this worth 10 bucks.  It was totally eatable fine burrito (even though I've had better), it just wasn't worth the price tag.

Don't be a sucka - we did it for you!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Well, I can't tell you how disappointed I was with my visit to Papalote on 24th Street x Valencia. I saw the Throw-down episode last night ( 2/28/10) and was very excited to try the triple threat. I knew the burrito was going to be expensive when I couldn't find the price listed on the website, but I thought I'd give it a try anyway....GULP!!!! $20.00??? Really??? I ordered a side of guac and chips, the chips were store bought not made on site, possibly because they don't use any oil....UMMMM please use oil! With out a beverage my bill was $29.00 and some change....get real!!!!

The first time my overpriced burrito came to the table it was missing the chicken, and the person that was sitting across from me was also missing the carne asada...hmmm weird...but they fixed it for both of us... 

It was very mediocre at best. I didn't find that it was anything special, and I feel ripped off to tell you the truth...I am a little embarrassed to say that I even went here, it wasn't memorable at all...I'll likely forget it's even there.....hopefully!
author: Jackie K.

description:
I grew up in San Francisco, and Gordos was the only mexican food that I ever ate.  I love Gordos, but after having a burrito at Papalote, I realized that you can still have a tastey burrito without all the grease!
If you are looking for a burrito that is on the healthier side, but still has all the taste, then this place is for you!  Don't forget to try their salsa, best in town!
author: Joe E.

description:
Dear Yelp,

In the interest of fairness, I'm going to dock a point off my original score.  I recently downgraded Ike's Place from five stars to three stars, citing an unnecessary raise in prices as well as a slight dip in quality.  Papalote has also raised their prices recently thanks to their much deserved notoriety, but as I stated in the Ike's update, places shouldn't raise prices just because they can.  Also, the burritos are noticeably smaller than they were a couple years ago, so you're paying more for less.

Having said that, it's still the best burrito in the city.  I went there after B2B and the place was packed, however the wait wasn't that much longer than usual and the quality was top notch (Ike's could learn a thing or two here).

And of course, the sauce is still as crack-tastic as ever.

I give Papalote Mexican Grill a fantastic score of 4 out of 5 stars.

Love,
James
author: Cheryll M.

description:
How the hell is this place going to be featured on Throwdown?  That makes me lose so much respect for Bobby Flay (already a potential douche-bag.)  

I keep going here even though i really don't like it.  Maybe one day i'll learn not to go here anymore.  And has anyone noticed that their salsa has gone downhill lately?  So inconsistent... one day will be a thick batch of salsa, the next it will be pure liquid garbage.  

And the price? Lord. $9 bucks for a super carne asada burrito?  Hate to sound like a snob, but where i come from, guacamole comes with the g.d. burrito.  And you get a bigger, better burrito for $5.  

I need to stop this review, i'm starting to get pissed off.

"We're gonna give this glass of water a South-Western kick to it!
-Bobby Flay
author: John B R.

description:
$20+ for an effing burrito?
Even if your tortillas were hand-rolled each day, and your chickens were corn fed, and the beef were Kobe, and the prawns were ocean fresh from the market and the beans and rice and filling were all organic (oh- this burrito is none of those things)- its still not a Freaking $20 burrito JUST because Bobby Flay can't seem to make a burrito.   
If I hadn't just had a Surf & Turf at High Tech Burrito the day before, I may have thought this was something special- but really, minus the chicken, the triple threat tasted EXACTLY THE SAME.  And at 6.95 at High Tech, I can just stick to that.  My 3 stars goes solely to the sauce that came on the side to go with my chips... now THAT sh!t is the bomb.
author: Jen S.

description:
Addicted to their nachos!  

Place is petite and to the point.  They have a small (but nice) selection of bottled beer, including PBR and Chamay...which makes me happy.  Food is cooked right in front of you and tastes fresh.   Oh and food comes with chips and yummy salsa!

Staff is super nice and friendly.  Has only a few tables, but a bar like counter to sit at that fits plenty!

Apparently this place is known for it's burritos, but I haven't had them.  I am a nacho whore, but everyone else RAVES about the burritos.

Only con...the tacos.  The corn tortillas fall to pieces and become soggy almost instantly.   Avoid them and I think you can't go wrong.
author: Lindy C.

description:
Just moved right across the street from this place, we picked up a couple of burritos last night. OMG, the best burrito I've ever had, & we're from the LA area.
You won't be disappointed!
author: Julie S.

description: I was told by one of my colleagues that I HAD to try the burritos and their special sauce.  I was addicted after the first bite!!  And we were there for Cinco de Mayo!!  Of course I had to have a Corona with lime to wash it down.  I had the Veggie with black and pinto beans.  The size was mammoth!! I was so full that I never ate dinner.  I have to order some of their special sauce.  We just do not get flavor like this in Fort Lauderdale!!!
author: Jody L.

description:
Came here specifically for the adobo burrito and I didn't really like it. Yes, it did have the adobo flavor but it was missing something... like some kind of sauce to bind it all together and some kind of texture since it was so soft. And being that it didn't have any sauce, all the rice kept falling out and ended up in my lap.

Halfway through the burrito, I decided it needed more flavor so I started to pour a ton of that green habenero sauce they had on the tables. That made it better.

Also got a carne asada burrito to take home and that was way better. Chips and salsa were good too. So there's the 3 stars.

I would be back only if I was in the area to get a carne asada burrito... or if someone was to treat me out to the Triple Threat burrito.
author: Britney C.

description:
Hands down the Best Burrito in bay area. 

I had their vegan soyrizo and it was out of the world. I am a vegetarian and this place has 3 veggie options. I have tried all three options, all of them are good but soyrizo is my favorite.

Another good thing about this place is if you are not in a mood for a big burrito, they make tacos and quesadillas with the same ingredients. 
 
Their salsa is not a hype, it is absolutely sumptuous.
author: Pratima A.

description:
What's the big deal with the Triple Threat?  This is gimmick food at its finest.

I thought i would give it a try, but i will never be coming back to eat that or anything else here.  The counter service was ridiculously bad - the cashier taking the orders completely messed our order up - we ended up with someone else's food and didnt notice it until we got home.

But i would have even dismissed that as an aberration until i discovered that the papalote brothers are just greedy gimmick slingers.

This is a $20 dollar burrito, no bigger than any other burrito they make.  Twenty dollars!  That's ridiculous.  And its appalling when you learn they had just jacked the price up $5 after being on the Throwdown program.

You can simply buy three tacos for the three meats for less money.  It's not like there's some magical blending of flavors stuffing the meats into one tortilla - in fact when you eat it, you pretty much go through one meat at a time anyway.

The 'family-secret' sauce is also just okay - does not add anything to the flavor.

This is a trendy mexican place, with owners ripping you off by sticking with gimmicks that get attention instead of attending to the quality of the food.
author: kevin w.

description:
Food - 4 stars
Parking - 2 stars
House salsa - 5 stars
Ambiance - 2 stars
Average - 3.25 stars

Came here for a meat-less and gluten-free meal the other week.

Had the Grilled Veggie Fajitas which consisted of zucchini, carrots, eggplants and what I think were yams.  The veggies were fresh and grilled well. It came with jicama salad, rice and beans (I went for black beans)

The corn tortillas were a + since I'm trying to be a GGFG (that's "good gluten-free gal"), but would've been better if they had been hand-made instead of store-bought.

Good thing the meal came with chips and their famous salsa which is really creamy, yummy and didn't disappoint.

As for drawbacks, the place is really small and noisy and parking is tough, although I lucked out finding parking on a street off Masonic. The ambience is better at the original outpost in the MIssion.
author: Bodhi D.

description:
We used Papalote to cater a guest speaker event at USF Law yesterday.  They were so fantastic to work with!  Not only did we get a great deal from them on burritos, chips, salsa and guac, but they even gave us a ride up the hill to school since we didn't have a car with us and it was a lot of food.  I have used them more than once for catering our events, and each time we have received great service and great food.  The staff is unbelievably friendly, and the food is always ready on time and packaged well.  I can't recommend them highly enough to cater your event!

Apart from catering, I also love to grab burritos from them on the run.  They are large and delicious!  

And Papalote salsa is off the charts!  Did you know you can buy a jar of it? YUM!
author: Alexis L.

description:
First things first: I'm a San Diego native, and there is absolutely no Mexican food like the kind you can find at the various xxxberto's back home. Well... maybe in Mexico.

Mexican food in San Francisco is, however, a different beast. Here, it's all about the big burrito, soopear o rehgoolar. Shit, sometimes all I want is meat, salsa and cheese!

Despite my differences, I think Papalote is doing the San Francisco burrito right! Crisp tortilla. Every ingredient is fresh. Carne asada is packed with flavor. The red sauce rivals that of La Vics. Their guacamole is the shizzle, my nizzle.

Dislikes:
- No carnitas?!
- I think extra red sauce costs $1
- Guacamole is pricey... but when is it ever cheap?
- The Poleng (adobo) burrito barely tastes like adobo. Maybe if you closed your eyes and dreamt of adobo, then had a Filipino auntie cooking chicken adobo in a pot next to you... maybe it tastes like adobo.
- the chips are aiiiiight.

Definitely one of my top three taquerias in the city.
author: Harold C.

description:
I have found a new favorite burrito. The chicken adobo burrito with garlic rice and tomatoes. But don't make it Super (guac, sour cream, cheese) because it takes away from the flavor of the marinated chicken. However, I like to add cheese just because I love cheese. Don't get me wrong. I still love the camarones but the chicken adobo is my new love.

....only note is that they have raised prices since I first started coming here going on four years ago but that's only natural. I know some people have complained that the burritos are expensive but you won't find another taqueria that makes their burritos the way Papalote does it. They cook the meat fresh on the grill so not only is it hot but you can rest assured it's fresh too.

Plus SF Weekly has voted Papalote the best burrito so if that's not worth paying $10 then what is? Would you rather pay $2 less for a mediocre burrito or pay a little more for a much higher quality burrito? You make the call.
author: David C.

description:
Awesome burritos.  Anything with that salsa is delicious.  

Carne Asada super burrito - delicious!
Love the chicken burrito with guac - the best.......load up on the salsa.  Love it ----- the location in the Mission is excellent too.
author: three's company M.

description:
Of all of the mexican places in SF, why did I randomly choose this one? I ordered guacamole, a diet coke, and a fish quesadilla and it was $18..well, I could have spent that $18 on three better quesadillas elsewhere.

My fish quesadilla was good, but I thought it didn't have that much flavor, after good reviews, I expected more. The guac was good, fresh, but not amazing, and definitely not worth the $6. 

If you live next door, I can understand coming here more than once or regularly, but seriously, if it isn't out of convenience, why wouldn't you just eat somewhere better, with comfortable seating?
author: Ashley H.

description:
Go with the Fajitas! Yes, grow some cajones and switch it up. The  burritos are good, but the fajitas here are great! 

Papalote does not make your average fajita.  Instead of bell peppers and onions for veggies they use grilled carrots, zucchini and eggplant. They marinate the veggies and steak/chicken in their famous roasted salsa and then grill them right when you order. Delicious!

Do expect a long wait, a packed place and San Francisco prices (same as any place in SF w/ great food).
author: Vanessa R.

description:
This is like a bad SF version of Chipotle. Just mediocre food. The "salsa" was just ok.

With so many better options for Mexican food, Id much rather go elsewhere ...despite everyone's infatuation with the place. 

I think the main reason people love it is because of it's proximity to USF.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Whoa mama, Papalote packs a lotta punch. While this location is more gussied up than the original Mission spot, the menu and food seem pretty identical. 

Seating is functional. All high metal bar stool chairs and small circle tables...good for a duo or a group of 4 max but larger groups aren't gonna be comfy. 

The counter service is quick and friendly. While you wait, they serve up insanely tasty salsa with the complimentary chips. I've never had anything like it; spicy, creamy...a king among dips. My super chorizo y huevos breakfast burrito was monstrous. Despite fasting all morning in preparation I still couldn't get through the entire thing. Every bite was perfectly cheesy, ricey, chorizo-y.

Now, can you just open a location in Manhattan? Thanks.
author: Jane K.

description:
Just came here for dinner. Even though they were a bit busy, the staff was friendly and courteous.  I got the prawn tacos.  The seasoning on the prawns was tasty (a nice spice w/ tangy lime flavor), as was the dip that came along w/ the tortilla chips (kind of like a creamy, spicy, tomato based aioli). The tacos were simple and fresh - topped w/ diced tomatoes and crispy lettuce.

My quips - the prawns were more chewy than meaty. The tortilla was a little thin (there was only one per taco, I prefer two) and could not withstand the toppings (holes formed and the taco began to fall apart).  Personally I prefer more of a "bite" in my corn tortillas and more of an earthy corn flavor - there wasn't much flavor to the tortilla.  I also prefer a simple cabbage for a nice crunch on my tacos, rather than lettuce which can wilt easily. 

This was my first meal here, and although not blown away by the tacos, I'll be back to try the burritos!
author: Meg L.

description:
i literally came here for the chips and salsa. 

i would say the mexican food here was fresh and rustic feeling but i def had a variety of more/better/different elsewhere. it was just so convenient to my old apt and they had mexican cokes! i would say the prices seemed about $1 or so off, but it's probably based on where/how they source their ingredients.

bonus: cash/credit!
author: jaclyn g.

description:
Disappointing... If you want a college made and taste approve burrito. Then this is your place. YES it is located close to USF so maybe thats why they have much business.
I first heard about Papalote in7x7 magazine.
 I ordered a super carne asada burrito $7-$8ish.  
The server set up our utensils before the burritos came out. A knife and fork?? Really? BLASPHEMY!!! A burrito should be eaten with your hands. Then when you get down to the nitty gritty I use a tortilla chip to scoop up any remaining meat and rice.  To top it off the skin looked as if it was pan fried or tasted. I like my mine steamed. I got it and cut open to check out the guts. Its was a big messy mush inside.  I personally like my "Mex-Wrap"  when you can see and name every ingredient.  You cant judge a burrito by its skin however. Taking a generous bite it tasted bland to me. I asked one of a the workers "what was Papalote's trademark item on its menu"?. The server replied " The salsa, but honestly I don't think it is." I agreed. Not the best. Ive had better salsa.
author: Brent W.

description:
I finally had an opportunity to visit Papalote, although I went to the Fulton location--didn't realize there was a Mission location.  Anywho, I ordered the prawn super burrito, hubby ordered the pescado super burrito and I washed mine down with a strawberry agua fresca. Luckily, they come with chips and salsa so we didn't have to tack that onto our order.

 The salsa was really good but not as mind blowing as I thought it would be. Still, I'd buy a jar for some late night snacking and make my own chips.

  My prawn burrito was a little disappointing. It was definitely big and large enough to feed two but the prawns were a little overcooked so it lost its juiceyness but it did have a nice grilled flavor. My other qualm about the burrito is that I only came across 2 shrunken prawns in the half burrito I ate. There was also so much of everything else that the prawns almost got lost in it. Please, Papalote, add more prawns, keep 'em juicy and add less filler! Just my preference...

My hubby's pescado super burrito turned out just ok as well. Tasty, moist fish but not enough of it. Lots of filler.

The agua fresca was refreshing and the best thing I ordered today. Tastes exactly like the agua fresca from Dos Pinas but minus the juicy strawberry pulp bits. Either way, it was good.  The only thing that would make it better is if they offered a large sized cup...I was so freaking thirsty that I could have downed two and those little cups they had just weren't cutting it. 

Would I return? Maybe but I'll probably try the Mission location and see if its any better and will also try the carne asada burrito or tacos. Overall, there's nothing incredibly special about this place so far but I'm hoping the Mission location will change my mind.
author: Marie-Laine C.

description:
Had their carne asada super burrito and it was damn tasty.  The burrito was definitely full of flavor.  I love that I can always make two meals out of a burrito.  

Their salsa is also very addicting.  I swear I could have just ate chips and salsa if I really had to.  

I don't venture into the city all too often and when people show me their neighborhood joints, I'm definitely game and this is one spot I can venture again if I'm around the hood.
author: Meshell C.

description:
I live close by here so I've gone a number of times- always consistently awesome!

Burritos have a unique Papolote quality to them I haven't had elsewhere. Mole burritos are GREAT and so are the fish tacos.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I recently had pang for a burrito. Seeing as I was at USF I had two options. Eat at the cafeteria and have hell-like bowel movements, or take a small walk down to Papalotes for a burrito. 

The salsa as usual is bomb and definitely something that I come here for. Their carne asada burrito is the same, just as tasty and filling as before. I do believe that they have yet again raised the prices. 

The reason a star has been dropped from my original review is because.. quite frankly the chicken adobo burrito was dry, terrible, poorly wrapped, and tasteless. Everything on their original menu is still good though. But I came into Papalote with high hopes for their chicken adobo burrito.. maybe it could have been just a bad day?
author: Tony W.

description:
The hype is quite right.  Best take-out I've had in years, anywhere.  Too bad it's all the way on the other side of the country... it's very easy to be a regular here!

The staff here are magicians- how do they keep the lettuce and other vegetables on the taco to-go so crisp?! Amazingly good stuff.
author: J C.

description:
We went to USF to grab some graduation gear and needed to find a spot for lunch. Papalote's was just the right fit. The food was hot and handcrafted when it was delivered to our respective tables (we had to sit at different tables since the seating was difficult at best). Luckily though we were able to sit at tables next to each other. It didn't take long for our heavy conversation to die as the food was shoved in our faces.

The mole & chile verde was superb and the quesidillas that a few others had looked fantastic. I may consider moving from the south bay just so I can have eats like this more often.

Plus points: 
Fantastic food
24oz of PBR

Needs work:
Seating is sparse
author: Michael N.

description: Avoid the naked burritos.  Lettuce did my appear to be washed-- it was gritty and ruined the meal.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Go for the salsa, stay for the salsa.

This incarnation of Papalote is definitely the best burrito/taqueria in the area.  And on a whole, both Papalotes are up there in the elite tier of SF burrito places.  

Bonus stars for bringing the SF burrito to the masses and whipping that ass Bobby Flay on his TV show.

I like to sing this song when i go there, to the tune of Lady Gaga's "Paparazzi"

I like good burritos
they are just so tasty
Oh-Hey!
Papa
Papa-lote!!

...and then I mainline the salsa straight into my veins.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Pros:
- best salsa ever
- fresh and tasty vegetarian food (love whole wheat tortillas)
- usually ready in 5-10 minutes (I recommend calling ahead if you are picking up)
- buy 10 get one free burrito card

Cons:
- half the girls working the register have major attitudes
- they mess up orders too often
- found a piece of steak in my veggie burrito (gross)
- water cups are practically shot glasses.  they don't wash them well so the water tastes like soap.  bring your own water bottle
- they just raised their prices
author: Heather C.

description:
We were told by the cashier that the Triple Threat Burrito (Grilled Chicken, Carne Asada and Grilled Prawns) was big enough to feed 2 people. For the $20 price tag, it should!

We decided to go with that since we came in late could only order togo, and eat it in our car. The chicken, carne asada, and prawns were cooked perfectly. Every bite of the burrito was fuckin badass! But the $20 dollar burrito was not enough to feed 2 very hungry people.

Not the best burrito I've ever had, but the meat inside the burrito and the sauce make me wonder what the other items on their menu taste like.

Make sure to bring a Sharpie or paint marker to leave your name on their bathroom wall!
author: Bo G.

description:
This week, I have started to eat my way through 7x7's 100 Things to Eat Before You Die 2010. It's sort of like Julie cooking Julia Child's recipes, but without the dishes and time required to cook. What's in it for you, one might ask? Reviews, lots of reviews on Yelp, and other sites...that's what's in it for you! Now, let's get cracka' lakin. 

Drinks - I did not try their aqua fresca, or other drinks, but it looks like they had horchata and tamarindo available, as well as a selection of Jaritos soda pops. This is generally a good sign

Mains - I had a craving for a good, LA-style Chile Verde burrito, and Papalote did not let me down. In fact, they down right surprised me! First, with the refried black beans, and then with the freshness of their ingredients. I mean really, how often have you seen Carne Asada cooked to order for your burrito or Tofu Quesadilla. More than likely, you get meat that has been sitting in a warming pan for a couple hours.  This is freshness that you can taste in every single bite you take. The pork in the Chile Verde was tender, moist and delicious. Finally, I found a Chile Verde burrito in San Francisco that can challenge those of Los Angeles and El Metate in the Mission. 

Service - This is an Order and Pick-up establishment. Orders are taken quickly, and your food is ready in approximately 5 minutes. Now, that's darn quick if you consider they are cooking many of the ingredients to order.

Oh, 7x7 mention was for the Chips & Salsa at Papalote. Again, I was surprised,  first by the fresh, light chips, and then by delicious red salsa. Thumps way up to 7x7 Magazine for turning me on Papalote. I will be returning here again, and again. 

** Note: Bobby Flay vs. Papalote in The Burrito Throwdown! Be sure to tune in to the Food Network for the Premiere Wednesday, February 17 at 9pm and midnight.**
author: Jaime R.

description:
Well OF COURSE they won on Bobby Flay's Throwndown last night. Their burritos can't be stopped. The salsa alone will beat out anyone or anything. Congrats, Papalote!! 

I am a loyal fan of the prawn burrito with extra salsa - it's easily the best in SF. Now can you please stay open after 10pm so I can roll in late night? :)
author: Kate S.

description:
Went here with a co-worker in the new company, RIGHT HAND DRIVE, car.. the Mitsubishi iMiEV... it's a pretty neat all-electric vehicle.

Anyhoo, at first glance from the outside, it seemed like a place you'd pass by all the time and never notice.  The moment you step inside, it's packed.  TONS of people eating what appeared to be delicious food, drinking beer!  Nice!

The co-worker ordered their Triple Threat... grilled steak, grilled chicken, and grilled prawns on a bed of rice, beans of your choice, and other fantastic things I can't seem to remember.  He made it "super," so in went guacamole and sour cream.  It looked AMAZING.

I ordered their steak quesadilla, "super."  To say that this was just good would be an understatement.  It was fantastic.  Very flavorful steak, lots of delicious cheese, and their sour cream and guacamole combo are to die for!  

It was too crowded in there to sit down, and cramped to the point of feeling awkward standing so close to other people because the staff would have to walk by occasionally with stuff and would need quite a bit of space.  Having to jam pack yourself against something to make room was kinda... weird.. in a claustrophobic kind of way... even though I'm not claustrophobic.

Anyway, I didn't stick around to watch my co-worker eat his Triple Threat, but I imagine that he enjoyed it ridiculously.  I'll get some feedback another time.

4 Stars for great food and pretty cool staff.  I didn't give them 5 because of just how crowded they were today (standing room only!) and their lack of organization when it came to lining up.  Oh well, I'm sure my next experience will be better (if possible!).
author: Johnson N.

description:
Best burritos in SF, hands down. I'm a vegetarian and have only tasted the soyrizo burrito, but I always dine with meat eaters and they all love the animal options.

It's hard to get a place to sit if it's busy, so plan ahead...grab your burritos to go and hike over to Alamo Square for a picnic!

Oh, and I can never get enough of their salsa, and luckily it's now sold at Whole Foods in the Bay Area!
author: Jenny K.

description: The salsa is crack. I follow Mr. E on instagram (@papalote415) and he'll post when they're about to do 1 day specials. The lobster burrito was ridiculously good. You can taste the quality of their ingredients. Good stuff.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
Convenient and delicious mexican 'fast' food. small place, not so ideal if there are more than.. 2 of you. great place to pick up food and eat at home.

Salsa - everyone seems to love it, i think its alright. 

super prawns burrito - delicious, but kind of expensive. 

sometimes it takes forever to get your order, and they have forgotten my order one too many times -- but its good, so i keep coming back.
author: Sarah A.

description: Obviously some of the best salsa in town.  Pretty good burritos but I prefer mine more working-class.  The rice and bean tacos are an unbeatable value.  Chilaquiles are the hidden gem of the menu, especially for a hangover or after a day climbing mountains.
author: Ryan O.

description:
One of the best burritos I ever had, One gets the best quality for the price. 
They have the best salsa. My favorite is grilled veggie and Super of course. 

If you visit SF never miss this.
author: Sricharan M.

description:
I admit, I saw this place on Throwdown and I had to try it since it's not often that a local joint gets featured on that show. 

Papalote is a super small place, with 4 tables for 2-3 people and then counter space for about 8. I had the Prawn super burrito with refried black beans ($9.25). The tortilla was grilled first, which I like and there were about 4 seasoned prawns inside. They were tasty, but too few. The refried black beans were good and vegan (for those of you out there). Burritos came with chips and salsa for each person. The homemade salsa was much different than most, but not quite as good as I had hoped. I read other reviews of it being "addicting", "amazing" and "out of this world". I would have just called it "pretty good". I think La Victoria's orange sauce is a little better. One thing I didn't like, was that there wasn't enough rice in the burrito. Because of this, mine was very squishy with the beans, sour cream and guacamole in there. It needed something to hold it together. 

Parking was ridiculously hard this trip to Papalote and though I would come back, I don't think I'll crave it and go out of my way to visit. If it were in my neighborhood, I would be bigger fan I think. 

Also, I didn't see the Chicken Adobo Burrito on the menu at this location.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
I must admit I really like Papalote on 24th St. Sure, it's not AUTHENTIC Mexican food, but it's fresh, excellent quality, and their customer service is consistently good from my experiences. And oh my god, that salsa. That freaking salsa.

However, since I live a good 2-3 miles from the Mission, I decided I would give their Western Addition location a try as it's less than 10 blocks away. A few tries, actually, because I really wanted to believe this place is as good as the original. Unfortunately, it's not even close. And after having lunch there today, I'm swearing off ever going there again.

The main thing to consider is that everything that makes the original Papalote good is sub par in every aspect here. The flavor and texture of the food is bland and mediocre, their customer service ranges from friendly to borderline rude, the seating is far worse than the Mission location (OK seriously, just a second, how is that even possible), and the worst part of all? THE SALSA ISN'T THE SAME. It's a runny, bland, watered down version of the original mouthgasmic salsa you will find at the 24th St. location. It's literally weak sauce. Their guacamole also tastes like it's store bought, as opposed to the original location's totally delicious homemade-tasting guacamole.

I ordered a carne asada burrito and asked to have it cooked medium, and the cashier just gave me this confused look. I then clarified my request, and someone else behind the counter showed her how to enter that on the touchscreen (I guess?) but when I got it, guess what, it was completely well done.

Ugh. Really wanted to like this place because it's so close, but I'm done giving it any more chances.
author: Brendan R.

description:
The people running this place are unreal.  3/4 of the time we go here, they botch an order.  The quesadillas are well-made, the salsa is very good, but the horchata is too sweet, and the counter staff don't know the difference between corn and wheat, or can't be bothered to remember.

Good food, but hardly worth going because I'm guaranteed to not get what I order.
author: Brendan C.

description:
A lazy Sunday afternoon between the Giants NLCS game and the Niners night game. What to do...What to do....
