Carlos (and anyone else who dares challenge Jessica), here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HgqbCq_sxmo
author: Connie C.

description:
Damn good salsa.

A wide variety of options for vegetarians.

However, it is a little more pricy than you expect for a taqueria.
author: Sheena M.

description: I would agree that over the years their prices have gone up but they've gotten a bit skimpy on the protein. Tonight my naked chicken burrito bowl was over 50% lettuce. Sure they've messed up our to-go orders before and yea, their salsa is way better than the stale chips they serve it with...but I think we keep going back because the quality is fresher than places like El Toro. We keep hoping they'll focus on the food again instead of the bottled salsa business (which isn't even as good as is at the restaurant).
author: Des R.

description:
The "shake, shake, shake Senora" song* from Beetlejuice is probably the best burrito eating song ever. Especially if they're playing it in Papalote, because then you can do a barely-noticeable little booty shake and people will think it's related to the music, when really it's related to the fact that FINALLY there is some edible food in this goddamn neighborhood. Four years of college, do you hear me?? Four years I spent scavenging hunter-gatherer style for something decent to eat without a bus ride. Then, as if to mock me, the neighborhood waits a few years and busts out with this.

Anyway, it was cheap, delicious, veg-friendly (you know, in case that's your thing), and the guacamole was fresh. As in, appeared to have been prepared shortly before hitting the table. Also, I noticed that on the menu there's no price listed for the guacamole, just "Market Price." Like it's a fucking lobster or something. Because they charged about $6.00 for it, which was more than my whole burrito. Clever place to stick the profit margin. Guacamole: it's the new alcohol!

Also I'm pretty sure it doesn't need to be said but Papalote's roasted tomato pumpkin seed magical secret ingredient salsa is fucking delicious and you will want to pour it all over your body. That's a fact.



* which is "Jump in the Line" by Harry Belafonte, in case you were wondering.
author: Megan W.

description:
I want to give this place higher marks, but feel like it is a bit of a poser. You walk in and it practically screams at you "I am a mission taqueria, but clean, and nearer to your home SO THERE!". 

Then you look at the pristine menu board and notice that there will be happy vegans because everything is not carnitas this and carne asada that. Not an important factor for me, as I LOVE carintas this and carne asada that...but nice that I can go here with my veggie friends. Also, everything tastes really good!!

But when you look at the prices and star power is suddenly lost. There is actually a burrito on the menu that costs $13!! What??? Extra sour cream will run you $1.25! My very average sized quesadilla, a side of beans and a drink were $11. 

No one should have to mortgage their home to eat at a taqueria, that's all I'm saying.
author: Drue C.

description:
I ate here after running the San Fran half marathon, and I was so ravenous probably anything would have tasted awesome, but I was pretty happy with my burrito.  
I had the rice and bean super burrito with the refried black beans.  They were a little too runny for my refried bean taste, so next time I would stick with the regular black beans.  But overall it was tasty and very filling.  
The burrito included chips and 'salsa' which wasn't like any other salsa I have had... kind of creamy and spicy and oh-so yummy.  Perfect post-race meal!
author: Molly T.

description:
Dont Believe The Hype,.

Listen.  I'm a little piggie who will usually eat anything put in front of me and talk about how its the best thing i have ever eaten.  Because of this i usually give everything i eat 2 thumbs up, 5 stars, or 2 snaps up in a circle.  So for me to give out 1 star - shit, you know its gotta be bad.

Well.

I am that friend who sat on the couch, drinking cans of beer discussing suicide with Annie P after having what would become the most anti-climatic burrito experience of my life.  It really changed the whole vibe of my day.  And if you think its strange that a bad burrito can ruin someone's day, then fuck you too.  Thats probably why you like Papalote in the first place.  You wouldnt know a good burrito if it smacked you across the face.

I suppose my first clue that this was going to be a complete bastardization of the burrito experience was the insertion of "Mexican Grill" into the name of the establishment..  No boys and girls, this is no taqueria.  And what the hell are you doing ordering burritos from anywhere else?

The only good thing that happend to me here was that i accidentally nailed a hipster dude in the chest with my elbow (an accident, but one of those accidents you're really happy about afterwards)

The chile verde burrito i ordered was such a bland mess and i couldnt remember what it tasted like after each bite. The ingredients were poorly mixed, resulting in multiple bites that were completely rice and tortilla.  Boo!  Hiss!

Oh and get this shit.  They wouldnt even give me a fucking lime for my Corona!  

I will say the salsa we had was pretty good, but thats just not enough.  

This place has absolutely no heart or soul.  I cant agree with the way they try to boast that somehow they are a more sophisticated taqueria.  There was nothing but white people dining up in there - and folks, that should be a dead give away that you are going to get a generic and uninspired meal.

In summation, if they were giving away free burritos and i was in the neighborhood, and i hadnt in eaten in 5 days - i might possibly call up a friend that i dont really like and tell them to go eat at Papalote.
author: Kirsten S.

description: Easily my favorite Carne Asada super burrito in San Francsico
author: Adam H.

description: The prawn burrito was so good!! Flaky tortilla, succulent shrimp...Yum.    Papalote also has tofu, grilled veggies and soyrizo, the real triple threat.
author: Wakako U.

description: Reviews got me away from my old fav Pancho Villa. Steak burrito, carnitas tacos... not bad. Delicious steak, the way Pancho's used to be back in the day? Might just be my memory messing with me. Nonetheless, this is a solid Bay Area burrito.
author: Jon O.

description:
I just got home after trying Papalote's for the first time, so my rating is solely based on one visit.  I went crazy over their special today: Shrimp and mushroom enchiladas with rice and refried black beans. Plus, FREE SANGRIA until 7pm. Two glasses at 1pm was good enough for me. Next time, I plan to order the Triple Threat burrito, which contains steak, shrimp, one other item, plus the works. Ooooh, and next time, I'm buying a jar of their salsa...off the hook!

Advice: park across the street in the garage, then have Safeway validate your parking.
author: Kat M.

description:
First off let me say that this place is not bad, not bad at all.  I'm even tempted to go back up to three stars because the two stars looks so dramatic, but I have to be honest and think about what I'd personally like to see in a review. 
I lived for a long while in the heart of the San Diego taqueria land and of course I am partial.  However, I have lived in SF for many years now and have come to terms with the mexican food here.  And like I've stated in my other review, I think that salsa is one of the most important things at a Mexican restaurant.  If the salsa is no good, forget it. But the food has to be right too. So let's take a look:

Again, this place is not bad. But, it has no competition in this neighborhood, so it's all relative. The food is prepared well and feels healthy, but not unauthentic. I have tried many things on the menu and I'd have to say my favorite is the shrimp burrito that is cooked in white wine. 

Now for the other stuff.  Although I said that this place is not unauthentic, I wouldn't call it authentic.  This is a place is where my friends who don't eat at taquerias go.  The cooks are legit mexicanos and are very friendly, but sometimes the young girls working the register are a little over-zealous and at times can get a little annoying. I'm not trying to be mean. It's just a little annoying when you're looking up at the menu and no one's behind you and the girl keeps yelling, "can I help you? can I help you!" Even after I'd said that I need a minute. But I guess it's better this way than the opposite of ignoring you!
      
As for the salsa. I don't think it's that great. It's not bad. But nothing to write home (or yelp) about. Also, they charge an extra 50 cents for a second tiny container of it. And it's not the money, it's the principal of it. The other day I paid the extra change when I ordered. Then when they didn't give me the extra salsa with my order, and I asked for it, the girl made such a big deal about it and went back and checked the old receipts to make sure I had paid for the extra tiny container.  No big deal, but weird.

The reggae and dub they play there is super cool. But the whole thing of, "do you want to make your burrito 'SUPER'?" is weird and too McDonald's-like for me. 

In short, I'd say it's better than El Bolazo on Haight St. 
But go down to the Mission and eat at El Toro instead.
author: sonrisa m.

description:
A good burrito is an exercise in escapism, a hedonistic trip to Yummyland when you're really treading in 1000-calorie Fattyland.  But I was somehow convinced that perhaps Papalote would be different due to the high praise on Yelp. 

Tried the grilled veggies, grilled chicken, mole chicken, carnitas, even soyrizo. The meat has been dry, the veggies tasted blech, and your soyrizo was a constant reminder that what I was eating was, in fact, fake meat (good fake meat is an illusion). Beans are cooked ok, but the pinto beans are vegan (meaning no porky taste goodness). The benefit of a whole wheat tortilla (though they do grill them) is not worth it to me when the experience of eating the burrito becomes one extended episode of regret that lasts for hours upon hours as I fight my food coma of displeasure. 

Papalote, I'm pretty sure that you are a resident of Fattyland despite the pretense of "healthfulness" with your whole wheat tortillas, fake meat, and vegan beans. But you can't fool me into thinking you're healthy OR that I am actually in Yummyland, and that's the saddest part of all because that's the whole point of the ride.
author: Steph P.

description: Closest burrito place to me so I do make trips often here.  The burritos are good, but not amazing.  And convenience only goes so far.  The burritos are on the smaller side and at $9 a pop, I usually take my choice elsewhere.
author: Evan M.

description: I thought this place was OKAY!  Granted, I was feeling a little bit under the weather when I went so perhaps this isn't a fair review but I didn't leave wanting it again.  Hubby got the burrito which he liked and I got a veggie and chicken taco, which were a bit better than mediocre.  This is a neighborhood joint for us so perhaps we will be back but maybe not!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
(I give it a 4 and half stars and not a 5 because I reeeeeeally like ice and in my water and they don't have that. No ice here baby.  The water here is in a room-temperature only.) 

A really nice little guy kept bringing us chips 'cause we devoured the tiny bowl 30 seconds after he brought us a new one. Heh. THAT'S HOW GOOD THEY WERE.

The chips. Yum.

I would go to this restaurant just for the chips and the spicy salsa.  I love SALSA! Spicy! Hooray!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

-------------------------------------------------------------

Update: I have now changed my rating to 5 stars because this place is my favorite. Ever. I keep getting the veggie burrito (it has potatoes in it! POTATOES!) and I can't force myself to get anything else because it's so good. And the chips and salsa are still just as desirous. I go here once a week... if not more. And the guys who work there are nice. And I love when I get the table by the window to people watch in front of Albertsons. Hooray for Papalote!
author: Chantal H.

description:
I really liked this place. It's a no frills americanized messican place. The salsa was really good! It was creamy, with no chunky stuff, which is actually how I like my salsa. It actually stuck to the chips. 

Eugy and I completely ruined our appetite though. We stopped off at In-N-Out cause I wanted a milkshake and he wanted a snack (remember, snack for him is a meal to most others). We ordered a #2 with a strawberry/vanilla milkshake. We split it and of course, when we're supposed to eat dinner in only an hour, by dinner we were still full. 

So we shared a pork quesadilla. YUMMERS!!!! 

And they have Negra Modelo. YUMMMMMMERS again!!!

Cheap too... No frills... Fast... I like.
author: Jen D.

description: It's the sauce. I guarantee it. Okay, so it's obvious Papalote doesn't compare to a burrito in the Mission BUT I can't help but rave about it. Papalote isn't the best, but its burritos hit the spot every single time. Sometimes, I walk out of other taquerias thinking "last time the burrito was better" or "maybe they're having an off-day?". NOT Papalote -- and that's why I keep coming back! Papalote has a large variety of burritos compared to other taquerias -- even options for the vegans! I also like the fact that Papalote is very clean and the burritos aren't as greasy or "dirty" like other places. The menu is also a bit pricier compared to other taquerias, but you'll feel better knowing the ingredients are fresher and more well-prepared.
author: Linda T.

description:
Burrito addicts can not afford to be picky in the -117.  Honestly, as much as I am a taqueria nit picker, I do genuinely like Papalote. They are the only taqueria I will ever get guacamole from and their refried beans, salsa and grilled to order chicken can't be beat. 

But, if anyone decides to open a dirty Mission style taqueria in the Western Addition, WATCH OUT.
author: Maria D.

description:
Oh Papalote.....I am so glad you moved into my hood a couple years ago. Before that....well, I was slumming it at Fruitful Grounds.

While people like James I. might say you are the best Mexican food ever, he is from Minnesota and not Southern California (cough cough). 

Nonetheless, this place is still VERY GOOD AUTHENTIC MEXICAN FOOD. It is also the best place to go if you want to feel less guilty when eating the normally high-fat Mexican meals.

Papalote has plenty of healthy options including their soy rizo which I was obsessed with before I OD'd on it. After taking a hiatus from the soy rizo burrito, I was eating their nachos and chicken burrito. I always make my food here "Super" which means guacamole and sour cream. Ahh hell, let's not kid ourselves. Even though Papalote is healthier than most Mexican food joints, once you load on all the crap that makes it  tastier, you will have maxed out at least three day's worth of Weight Watchers points.

I recently had the carne asade burrito super here and I liked it more than my usual chicken. 

Although I am not a huge fan of their sauce here (aside from using it for chip dipping), most everyone else is bordering on obsession with it and probably wish it could be on tap in their kitchen. The place has great atmosphere but prepare yourself for a line. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order it for pick up.

If you haven't given the Pap a whirl yet, you're missing out on some top dog Mexican food.
author: Jackie M.

description: Ordered the carne asada burrito. Liked the chips and salsa the best. Flavors in the burrito were good but the meat was grissly. Liked the grill on the tortilla but would prefer a qdoba burrito to this any day.
author: Kerry C.

description: Love the fresh ingredients! What happened to the side salad?! I still like the food, especially the special sauce!!!
author: L T.

description:
If all they sold was chips and their amazing salsa, I would still love this place. What is in the salsa that makes it so amazing? 
This is my favorite burrito place ever. The fresh ingredients, the flavor, the clean airy atmosphere (clean enough yet without the generically sterile feel of chipotle). The fajitas are also delicious. As great as they make the burritos which are not lacking in flavor, sometimes they can be a little bit dry so add sour cream or guacamole or mole if for no other reason than texture. My faves are the fish in wine sauce burrito, camarones burrito, veggie burrito, and chicken mole. 
Add chips and amazing salsa, a corona and lime or a ginger beer= one tasty meal!
author: Allegra W.

description:
Dear Papalote, 

Thank you for making the most delicious burrito ever. I love you so. The way that you grill my chicken right when I order it is so sweet and thoughtful. It really makes for a superior burrito. I promise, I have changed my ways. I will no longer be the steam table skank of my youth. Thanks for helping me see the light, and loving me so tenderly.

Love, Rose
ps, your salsa is delicious
author: Roseanne W.

description:
I count myself very fortunate to have Papalote as my neighborhood burrito place.

Definitely a notch above your usual. (Whether it deserves the "Gourmet Burrito Bar" term I've heard bandied around, is a matter of opinion...) What's for sure is that Papalote is a clean, quite hip joint that serves (IMHO) the best Pollo Special Burrito, and also (as an occasional substitute) quite excellent Carne Asada Burritos. I get an odd pleasure out of waiting at the counter as I see the meats being grilled, and the burritos being assembled and packaged up with great efficiency.

Friendly staff and mmmm, very, very tasty food, with an outstanding smoky salsa on the side -- gives me a very good reason not to cook that frozen pizza for dinner tonight!
author: donal c.

description: Expensive and small. Ordered a chicken super burrito and carne asada super burrito.  Got a regular chicken, and not sure about the carne asada. Thought maybe we could taste cheese and thought we saw a dab of white that was sour cream.  Not joking or exaggerating.  It was fresh and the staff was friendly.  They were fast.... but wasn't worth the money.
author: S M.

description: Shame on you Papalote.  Shame on you for riding the wave of Food TV, Bobby Flay, and your best salsa awards.  There is no reason why ANY burrito should cost $20- I remember the days when that burrito was almost half the price.
author: Clarissa P.

description: The food was good, quick service and FANTASTIC chips and salsa. I had the carne asada burrito and carne asada tacos both were very good, but will stick to the burrito on my next visit. There is not much seating so plan accordingly (If you're going with someone don't go during the height of lunch expecting to sit together.)
author: David B.

description: The super carne asada burrito is the way to go. If you eat in they give you chips and their amazing special salsa, which makes the price of the food kinda fair at $9. Papalote makes my beloved Chipotle or Freebirds look silly, since they cook the meat after you order it. It really makes a huge difference in the taste as it's not sitting in some container for an half an hour or so. And it's easier to just say, "super carne asada" instead of waiting for them to point to each thing you want in the burrito (Sometimes Bob forgets to put guac when I tell him to).It can get a little crowded as there is limited seating, but it's definitely worth a try! You
author: Yusaku K.

description: Since leaving San Francisco, and giving up my guilty pleasure (Papalote salsa), I have been searching for a comparable salsa, to no avail. Until now! You can order the salsa on line! Amazing! I searched the website, and apparently it is stocked on the shelves in local grocery stores as well. Best. Idea. Ever.
author: Marta C.

description: I ordered the shrimp tacos. Good. Hits the spot. And an even better deal that the place scored a 100 on sanitary. I'm a fan when a place is clean. The price could use some work, but I can't complain. The tacos are average, but I'm okay as long as I know my food is made in a clean vicinity.
author: Nathalie N.

description: I did what was expected to do here...I tried the carne asada burrito and the chips & salsa. I don't know what it is but Papalote's burritos don't taste like your typical bay area burritos and they actually remind me of socal burritos, which isn't to say that either one is better but I couldn't help but notice that upon the first bite of my burrito. The carne asada is good and there's something about the way the fixings of the entire burrito come together that make it special. Plus, I wasn't overwhelmed with grease dripping down the side of my mouth or a puddle of it sitting at the end of my burrito. The tortilla chips are fresh and crunchy and sit perfectly in a wooden bowl brought to your table before the rest of you order is delievered. Alongside the chips is Papalote's flavorful yet spicy red salsa.  While the salsa is good, it's more of a blended salsa and I typically prefer chunkier salsas. However, Papalote's salsa really is that good because they sell it in jars for those of you addicted. Overall, a must try place!
author: Maya S.

description:
In order to properly review, I must weigh the pros and cons.

Pro: The meat is grilled to order.
Con: The meat sometimes takes forEVA to grill.

Pro: They ALWAYS get the order right. Even when it comes during peak lunch rush from an office of 20 who all fancy themselves burrito mixologists - each with their own special recipe. They often label the burritos with the owners name!
Con: The burritos are expensive and that fancy tortilla is an extra buck.

Pro: The chips. Sweet Jesus, the chips.
Con: Three chips are included with your burrito and if you want more, that'll be a dollah. More salsa? Make that a dolla fitty.

Con: The salsa is the equivalent of chipotle ranch dressing.
Pro: CHIPOTLE RANCH DRESSING! Nothing can ever be wrong with that!

Pro: REFRIED BLACK BEANS.

It's official. As much as it annoys me that this was voted best burrito in SF when clearly it's about as non-authentic as a burrito can get, they've won me over. Suggest it to your job for lunch and hope that someone else'll foot the bill.
author: Chelsea T.

description: YU-mmy. This is the type of place that you want to try something different every time you go because every time you order something it is totally delicious. I had the fish tacos the last time I went, and the fish was delicious, fresh, flavorful, and cooked perfectly. Can't wait to try something new on the menu the next time I go.
author: Cindy M.

description:
In a word: Overrated.

The tofu mole burrito was recommended to me by half a dozen people as the best in the city.

Even had it not been hyped, the burrito consisted bland insides surrounded by an unremarkable tortilla. Tofu chunks were flavorless and the mole sauce was...just, boring.

The inside atmosphere smacks of a cramped Chipotle.

I didn't think Tonayense quite lived up to its reputation either, but it is a much better place to grab a burrito than papalote.

Thanks, but no thanks.
author: Joel P.

description:
The quality ingredients and proximity to my abode make Papalote the go-to spot when it comes to burrito pangs. I'm partial to the super soyrizo with black beans on a wheat tortilla and there are plenty of other vegetarian options. Sure--it's a little more than I'd usually pay for a burrito. Yeah--it's not massive in size and doesn't immobilize me after consumption. You got me--sometimes there's a line or wait time slightly longer than preferred (you didn't need to blow up this spot even more, Bobby Flay).

But...the burritowork is superb. The salsa is off the chain. The burrito IS the message.
author: Derek F.

description:
I don't really know of many places that serve mole, and it happens to be one of my favorite mexican things to eat. Papa Lote has several mole items on the menu and they are all delicious. The location on fulton is a little hole in the wall. It's great for a quick bite or take out. There's parking right across the street in the Lucky shopping plaza.

Prices here are really good. Pretty much everything is 5-10 bucks, with the exception of a couple plates that are $11-12. There's a lot of vegetarian options too...like tofu mole...hmmm....that's creative :)
author: Kandace K.

description:
I killed a man in the Papalote bathroom. Ok, that is untrue.  Truth is, the only thing that ever died at Papalote was ranging hunger for some delicious tacos.

A few days ago I sat down awaiting my tacos and ended up in conversation with the owner of this establishment where I did not kill a man in the bathroom. After a few accolades regarding the quality of his salsa, he presented me with a jar of this sweet ambrosia (I use this term intentionally, because unlike much salsa, the Papalote salsa is a viscous liquid rather than a chunky mixture).  

Delicious. If you're around, stop in and have a taco.
author: jack p.

description: The burrito and service were so bad it compelled me to get a Yelp acct to let everyone know. The cashier was the rudest human I have ever encountered - and the Carne Assad burritos (2 of them) tasted like fish. How this place got rated as having a great burrito is beyond me. There are WAY better places to spend your money
author: B S.

description:
I was in the city on vacation. And I had the privilege of eating at Papalote's twice. Miguel, the owner is a super nice guy and hooked it up both times. The first visit I had the Triple Threat Burrito (named after some hometown DJ heroes) with refried black beans. It was a monster burrito and thank goodness my friend was there to split it with me. The chicken, beef and huge shrimp made my tummy happy. 

It was a damn good burrito. And this is coming from someone who grew up in SD, where we know our Mexican food. It's definitely a different style then what is standard for SD, but it was good nonetheless. What "hella" intrigued me was the salsa that they serve their food with. It's crazy good.  We spent most of the conversation trying to figure out what was in the sauce. Definitely some chipotles, but the rest was hard to deduce. 

Day 2: So came here on another occasion to have brunch with Miguel, and so he and my friend could talk business. He is the nicest person you could meet. He decided to jump behind the line and make some special chilaquiles for us and holy heck they were delicious. The sauce and tortilla combined so well and complimented the egg and cheese perfectly. We tried to pick Miguel's brain to have him reveal the ingredients for his salsa but he said only a few select inside men know his secrets. Oh and he said the copycat recipes that you find on the internet are "way off". 

Overall, you can't go wrong in the city with Papalote's. It fills that need for Mexican food when you can't bask in the glory that is "Carne Asada Fries."

p.s. 
If you don't know about Carne Asada Fries, get to San Diego and hit me up. I'll school you correctly.
author: Michelle P.

description:
If I name my first born Ed, now you'll know why. It's because Ed M. led me to Papalote, home of soyrizo Mexican food. 

It's been a long time since I've had satisfying Mexican food. I mean, let's face it --- I'm a no-cheese no-meat girl. And that means no Mexican. You can't order a quesadilla and say, "Um, but can you leave out the cheese, please?" Yeeeahhh... 

You can't do that.

So when I threw meat and cheese out the window, I accepted the fact that with it went Mexcian, for the most part. I had to settle for Mexican food in the lame ways still available to me (special-ordering the hell out of a burrito, for example).

And then last night, a soyrizo burrito from Papalote changed my world forever --- again.

What is "soyrizro," you ask? I don't know, exactly. But they swore it's entirely vegan. And it made my food taste as through it was REAL Mexican.

Hallelujah.

And the magical soyrizo appears in EVERYTHING at Papalote.

Oh --- and their red pepper salsa is pretty good, too. Weird texture and I was a little bit unnerved by it at first, but then suddenly I was picking up steam with the chips and I probably could have just emptied the dish straight into my mouth. 

I guess what I'm saying is, it grows on you, okay?

I'd like to give this place five stars. Believe me; I would. It's really hard not to. But, I realize that the vast majority of items on the menu are indeed NOT soyrizo. And the vast majority of people eating here are NOT vegans. And there are a million taquerias in this town. So this place actually could be nowhere NEAR the big leagues.

But if you've got a hankering for some soyrizo, THIS IS YOUR JOINT!
author: Lisa T.

description:
I was skeptical of this place when it first opened. It looked too much like it was trying to be an event. But then I thought about the fact that I also occasioned 1751 Social Club (RIP), and that place really looked like it was trying too hard, so I gave it a shot.

I was not disappointed.

OK, if you're looking for a true burrito, you will be disappointed. Sorely. But if you're a veggie like me and you're tired of not wanting to ask whether they use lard in their beans, rice, tortillas, water, etc., then this place will really do it for you. The tofu is good. The soyrizo is good (it really is). The seating and atmosphere are not good.

I'd give this place five stars for vegetarians, but I'm trying to rate this more with the masses in mind.

UPDATE:  3/22/09
==============

OK, I didn't really know what I was talking about when I wrote my initial review.  Papalote makes excellent burritos of all kinds.  I've been doing takeout regularly on Sunday nights, and although the wait can been semi-long because this place is all the rage with USF students these days, it's well worth it.

The actual atmosphere inside leaves a lot to be desired.  It's cramped, and the chairs and stools aren't particularly comfortable.  But they do play really random break-dancing movies from the '80s all the time (in addition to scary old cartoons), and the flat-screen TV has weird stuff burned into the screen.  That more than makes up for the uncomfortable seating.

UPDATE:  3/7/10
==============

I'm knocking Papalote down a star for a few reasons.  First and foremost, the place isn't wheelchair accessible except for takeout.  Yes, a wheelchair can physically enter the building, but the counters and tables are all so high that a wheelchair user wouldn't be able to eat here.  How difficult would it be to have one standard-height table?

Also, I'm concerned about their recent price hike.  Whereas this place was a decent value before, it's now slightly overpriced.  I'm even more worried by the fact that my burrito from here last week seemed smaller than usual.  Hopefully, they just folded the tortilla differently or temporarily ran out of standard-sized tortillas.  If smaller burritos are the trend, I might knock them down another star--and stop my weekly visits.
author: John S.

description:
Papalote, you are soooo good to me. :)
I ordered a cheese quesadilla but what I was really there for were the complimentary, savory chips and salsa. OMFG! Their salsa is to die for. The only downside is it gets crowded fast and there isn't enough group seating area. The customer service is friendly and fast, just the way I like it. Oh and although I don't drink soda on a regular basis, I ALWAYS end up ordering a mexican soda from here. 
So thank you Papalote for being super delicious!
author: Jasleen K.

description:
Ay Papi!

Mi quesadilla del pollo era tan bueno. El pollo se cocin perfectamente con todas las especias correctas, era personas buenas apenas malditas. El queso. ah mi Dios, el queso era tan delicioso que senta como una fiesta de bumpin en mi boca. gravemente, verifica este lugar fuera!
author: Richard T.

description:
You know, I wanted this place to be so much more. Finally, I didn't have to trek to the mission to get a burrito. I could walk a mere block and find serendipitous sustenation wrapped in tin foil.

I was wrong.

Sure, the place is clean and hip and convenient...BUT, the chicken is dry, the normal extras are ridiculously high in price (over a $1 for sour cream? come on. I could run across the street to Albertsons and buy a VAT) and it's not very authentic. 

It's not even fast food, bc I remember waiting quite a bit to get my lunch and there were only 3 other people in the joint.

I went there in for a quesadilla. Because I'm a cheese whore. And because guacamole makes me dance. But the quesadilla did not make do any of the aforementioned. Maybe I should give it another try but it did not impress me the first time. I'd rather walk the extra few blocks to Green Chile Kitchen!
author: Jessica P.

description:
This place is good if you're hungry and in the mood for middle of the road, mexican food. We've all been there.

I'm torn on the rating, because it's clearly not meant to be an intimate, top quality, authentic place- but that's what it takes to really earn my love.

3 stars for tasty burritos, but mediocre everything else, and "chainy" atmosphere.
author: Irene P.

description:
I go to Papalote after Pilates class. Theoretically this means that, after working my booty off, I counteract my efforts with fast food. Or is this an unjust observation?  Sure, it's possible to cram way too many of your daily calories into a single meal there, but you can also make healthy choices.  My favorite meal is the tofu quesadilla, with a (specially requested) whole wheat tortilla.  Not sure where this falls as far as the US RDA of whatever, but it's gotta be healthier than the average restaurant meal, right?  

More importantly, it's tasty, tasty stuff.  I don't know what they use to marinate the tofu, but the result is excellent. Not only this, the also fantastic salsa has a bit of a kick.  It's not spicy-spicy - I can't handle anything definable as HOT - but it's enough to make things interesting.

In conclusion: Papalote is yummy enough to lure me in 2-3 times a week, and it is not counteracting my grand plan of Getting In Shape.  In fact, I think the salsa may be encouraging those sculpty Pilates muscles. Win-win!
author: Janna M.

description:
Bottled Coke? Check
Delicious and unique salsa? Check
Guacamole that can save a marriage? Check
Cool decor and cooler plates? Check

Did I mention Bottled Coke?????!

Oh yeah and this place makes mexican food! 

I cannot say enough about this place. I tell all my friends about it who think that mexican food has to be dingy and greasy. This place makes mexican food healthy (ish) with premium ingredients. 

I enjoy the carne asada burrito with refried black beans...
author: David L.

description:
I am from San Diego (err lived in San Diego for 6 years) and the SF burritos vs the SD burritos do not compare.  San Diego will always win.

However, for a San Francisco burrito this was the worst burrito I have ever had.

I got the mole tofu, my boyfriend got the mole chicken.

It was awful.  I could not finish my burrito (as in, this is soo gross I don't want to take another bite).  My boyfriend ate his, but hated it.

I have heard nothing but good things for Papalote.  Maybe their mole is just the worst of their food?

Because it was so bad, I will not be going back to try other burritos
author: Amber L.

description:
Love this place. Order in a call and it is freshly made in 15 minutes. Parking is not terrible (a few 10 minute zones help). Get the super steak burrito. 

You know how you try a new spot and its good the first few times and then they disappoint, this burrito spot hasn't ever let me down.
author: Haileab B.

description:
Pretty over-rated mexican place.  I had heard really good things, but it just didn't deliver on them.  On the plus side, it's cheap.  On the minus side, there's about 10 better taquerias 5 blocks away in the Mission, like Pancho Villa or La Corneta.

I got my usual, a burrito, and found it relatively small compared to burritos from other SF taqueries.  The flavor was decent enough, but nothing special.  My girlfriend got her usual, nachos.  They have refried black beans, which is nice, but there was very little salsa or cheese.  Also, the chunks of carne asada were way too big.  The chips themselves also aren't good, mostly because they're thin.

With so many better options, I don't see why I'd ever go back.
author: Chad H.

description:
On Rick H.'s suggestion I decided to try here.  So whaddya know, we've gone from zero to two burrito places in the N. Panhandle.  Hooray for free market competition.

The house salsa here is really great, and I found myself stuffing the complimentary tortilla chips down my gullet whilst waiting for my chicken quesadilla.  The quesadilla was not greasy or soggy at all and the chicken was beautifully spiced and grilled.  However, there was no sour cream, lettuce, or guacamole on the side, and I found the cheese/meat alone a bit unbalanced.  

The portions are large and the prices very reasonable.  I think  http://www.yelp.com/biz/z50O47Al64Y6YrLsVmnjpA (Green Chile) is better but also more expensive.  What turmoil it will be to choose between the two.

Update: I've been back a few times now.  Shrimp Burrito OWNS, and the carnitas is great too.  I always get super and really for the price, this place cannot be beat.  I find myself going here more than Green Chile kitchen now because quality wise they are both delicious, but this place saves me a couple bucks.  Also they play GOOD reggae here a lot.  I'm adding  a star...
author: Eric X.

description:
I come here for the vegan soyrizo burritos.  They have a decent vegetarian selection, which justifies a buck or so more when I don't want to eat lard-soaked beans and rice elsewhere.

OK, so it's a little less authentic than a regular taqueria and soyrizo instead of chorizo isn't ideal, but my heart thanks me for not injecting more cholesterol into my veins.
author: Surf R.

description:
Not too shabby if you need a burrito STAT!

Things I do enjoy about them:
* they are always jamming out some great dub music here
* got some homegirls at the counter
* they have a yummy veg burrito
* they usually have planet earth playing on the LCD screen...
author: .V X V.

description: I guess I need a primer on what to order. I was feeling "healthy" so I got a grilled veggie burrito in a wheat tortilla. $8 diarrhea!
author: Kaleb S.

description: I dunno. I guess my expectations were higher given how much some people love this place. The salsa is fantastic, but the burritos aren't anything to write home about. I've tried the mole tofu twice now, and it just doesn't live up to it's potential. To its benefit, this Fulton location has a vibe that's way more relaxed than it's sister shop in the mission.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Solid burritos, very vegetarian friendly.  Good carne asada.

HUGE downside: they charge for extra salsa.  I felt like I was back in Europe paying for ketchup packets.  Paying for salsa is like a hooker charging you $50 bucks for a condom -- you goddamn need it so you pony up, but you know you are getting fucked (in two ways [ed. zing]). 

I would give them 5 stars if the salsa flowed freely.  This is extra aggravating because the salsa is amazing.
author: Mike I.

description:
You have to get everything here "super" because super = delish! For the extra buck you get guacamole and sour cream, and who doesn't like that combination? 

For my first time in this little gem of a restaurant I ordered the fish tacos and a beer. It think my total was about $8 and I was pleased that they also serve you chips and salsa. The tacos were really good too and perfect portion for one person. The kites flying above our heads were such a bright (and semi-creepy) added touch.
author: Natalie N.

description: Ok if you go to usf you need to check this place out.  The food is made fresh and it is good, ever sincd they went on that challenge with bobby flay ghe prices went up.  I had to try that triple threat after I saw that.  It was good but you gotta be ballin if you want to buy that everytime its like over 20 bucks.  The other entrees are fairly good, the burritos you should always get the super.  That comes with guac sour cream and all the good extras.  The thing you must try is the salsa. It is good and spicy, I had some smuggled home to hawaii cuz its good.
author: Kendal T.

description: All I can say is AMAZING! All of their burritos are amazing. The people there are so friendly and fast! If you go there hungry you will leave satisfied and happy! I love the carne asada super burrito.
author: Jessica D.

description:
2 Winters ago I caught in the hail storm here.  They have a weird tin hoof or something cause it was so loud.  These tourist were so scared.  I laughed.

I like this location because it less crowed and cleaner.  You can see them cooking your food which is fun.
I love their salsa, but they are so stingy with it.  Why should I have to pay extra for more salsa, lame.  The chip are so crispy though.  I can't get enough.
I'm one burrito away from a free one.  Yes!
author: amanda v.

description:
Like many other Prodigal Sons, I have turned my back on Papalote only to return begging their forgiveness. After trying more burritos in this city than I care to mention, I can safely say this one tops them all.

At Papalote, it is all about quality ingredients. No matter the type, steak, chicken, or soyrizzo, it is made to order. You wont find any vats of week-old mystery meat here and clearly, that's a good thing.
author: William S.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 94

yummmmmers. yes, i am a fan.

though i got an "interesting" burrito, i was so stressed from my work day that i didn't care. i got the veggie which i didn't know was VEGETABLES: like potatoes, mushrooms (i think), and all that jazz. though yummmmmers (refer to above), it was quite odd.

but i enjoyed their one of a kind salsa that's on the creamy side and quite delectable. 

btw, my first time here was with reina t., our fellow yelper. she introduced me to papalote and to shortening words such as "totes" for totally and "situash" for situation...

anyway! enough name dropping. i do want to return and try more more more burritos and less less less potatoes. 

gracias.
author: Kristina C.

description: Ordered the carne asada quesadilla. The cheese was bland at best and the steak was tasteless. The chicken quesadilla my friend ordered was better but still mediocre compared to La Taqueria. Maybe I should try a burrito? But then there are so many awesome places in this town that you have to ask, why try to like this one?
author: Sarah K.

description: You really cannot go wrong with this place. They are very inexpensive, fast, clean, friendly and have great fresh Mex. There are a lot of vegetarian options too. The salsa is amazing too. If you ask, they will sell you a jar of it. I typically order the fish tacos. They are light and very tasty.
author: Aly V.

description:
Yes, the salsa is bomb! No doubt.  I wish I bought a jar of it to go...yes, it's that good.  

This location is tiny, way tiny.  Walking in and out of this place reminds me of being in a packed club.  There's only four 2-3 seat tables and the rest of the seating is at the bar. The guy that took our order was impatient, and looked and acted like he hated his job...way to kill the mood mister! He didn't even ask us if we wanted anything other than water to drink.  Ordering for the first time here is a bit confusing.  Standard burritos only come with rice, and your choice of meat and beans.  That's it.  Everything else is extra charge - including - cheese, sour cream, salsa, guacamole, etc...So an average burrito with all the fixings can cost over $10 alone.  My bf went got the green chile pork burrito and I had the chicken burrito.  We both went with the spinach tortilla, which we both enjoyed.  Each burrito does come with chips and the amazing salsa. Both burritos were pretty bland and lacked flavor.  I'm not sure how their burritos beat out Bobby Flay's creations on Throwdown.  Such a mystery! The only thing I would really come back for is the salsa - best salsa I've had in my life...I think.  And to the staff, crack a smile once in a while, will ya?
author: Cindy T.

description:
So many of my friends have recommended this place. And they were right!

The salsa that came with my chips was sooo yummy!

And it was really nice to be able to get mole in a vegetarian dish. I had the tofu mole soft tacos and they were great.

For the price, this place is amazing.
author: Dani G.

description: Very expensive for what I was given. Would have felt less cheated if the food was good...but it wasn't. Had much better in the Mission. Don't think I will ever be back.
author: Alexmy R.

description: Mmmmm delicious and reasonably priced. Although I wish they gave you the salsa for free-- I kind of think Papalote's salsa is a basic human right, not a commodity.
author: Jen N.

description:
Forgive me Yelp, for I have sinned....it has been too long since my last yelping.  So I hoped to make up for lost time by letting you know how much I LOVE Papalote.  And since I ate there two nights in a row this weekend, I couldn't imagine a better time to tell you my true feelings.

I like my mexican food just as much as you, but alas, the truly authentic taquerias?  yep.  there's lard.  lard in the beans, lard in the rice, lard lard lard!!!  gross.  I eat fish, but otherwise....i'm a veggie.  So I like to know what's in my burrito.

Papalote?  no hidden lard.  Just super yummy, fresh and veggie friendly.  the veggie burrito has roasted potatoes and carrots.  and the fish taco's are my favorite in the city. lucky me, i can walk there from my house.
author: Isabel C.

description: I ordered the marinated tofu burrito and added the Super ingredients. I came back an hour later for a second one. This was by far the best burrito of my life, even though it had no meat. My mind was blown. 5 stars.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
If you went into any other place and ordered a Tofu Mole Burrito, it would cause a stir amongst those who aren't very secure with their masculinity. But at Papalote NOPA, one is amongst the intelligentsia, the digerati, the hipoisie, so you can just sorta yell it out all Tay Diggs like, "I'd like a freakin' TOFU MOLE BURRITO please!" And if anyone gives you a look, you just up the ante by bustin' out, "Dang right I want dat with HOT SALSA! Make it Super Caliente." 

Papalote has the bestisist Tofu Mole Burrito this side of the Mission. They've got the Mission covered with their place on 24th. Best chips as well!
author: Johnny C.

description:
Why do people love this place?  I mean seriously, it's like a CULT with the rabid following it has! 
I eat burritos @ least once a week, but will gladly walk the additional 10 blocks to Balazo to get a good burrito because Paplote DOESN'T SERVE CARNITAS!!  What self respecting Taqueria doesn't serve carnitas?
I tried the green pork burrito but it just wasn't the same.  I tried other burritos JUST because they're close and cheap, but was underwhelmed by them all. 
Also, everywhere I order burritos, I get them without rice.  For some reason, when I get them without rice here, I get a tube of bean juice instead of a burrito--I take one bite and the entire thing explodes like an overfilled water balloon.  Can't they learn to drain their beans like every other place in SF?  It ONLY requires a slotted spoon...

I try not to be a hater, but this place does nothing for me.

ps. They got 1extra star because their chipotle salsa is AWESOME (even though they charge you $0.50 if you want more than a tablespoon full)
author: D C.

description: Just ordered food for pick up. The shrimp qeusadilla was throw in the trash. I would rather starve. Burritos were ok. Extremely overpiced.  Never again.!
author: Karen M.

description: Ok....the last time I wrote the review for this place I was writing while I was frustrated.  I'm upgrading their rating to 3 stars because the food is not that bad.  If you live around the area, make sure you call in to order so you don't have to wait 10 mins for them to make your burrito.
author: Danny P.

description:
EDITED REVIEW: After I posted my original review, the owner of Papalote emailed me to make things right.  Papalote, te quiero otra vez.

Ugh...
My husband and I usually order from Papalote on Fulton at least twice per week.  Each time, I order the same thing- grilled prawn tacos with cheese. Every time, my food is awesome. So, why the lousy review?? Tonight, I ordered the same thing for about the 500th time and I ended up with grilled prawn tacos with guacamole and sour cream. Not a disaster BUT when I called the store to let them know about the mistake (and that I am allergic to avacado) they told me I would have to purchase another meal. 

Papalote, you have let me down!!! I won't be back for some time.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Fine for what it is.

Let's put it this way... there was only one other Mexican customer besides myself and he looked about as happy as I was.

--update -- 
Had to lower my review after getting a rather lame response from a part owner.  The integrity of his message matched that of the food served.   Funny, the food is about as authentic as a rubber clog, yet the guy was going on about customers wearing Sombreros and what not.   Anyway, not my kind of "Mexican food," and to each his own.
author: Dan M.

description: This place is fantastic, if you're some nitwit East Coaster who wouldn't know a good burrito if it slapped you in the face. (Bobby Fley comes to mind). This place Is the opitomy of anglophied, yuppie, overpriced, bastardized Mexican. Let me cut to the chase. I ordered a chicken "super" burrito.  My burrito Cost $9.30. Did you hear me? $9.30!!!!  That is not just  expensive, it's daylight robbery.And it was the size of a friggin toothpick! The chicken tasted as if it had been marinating in a vat of strictly lime juice for twenty days and twenty nights.. This is precisely what happens when a non Mexican native opens a Mexican Establishment. I read the positive reviews on this place and I am reminded that most people in S.F don't know what the hell decent Mexican is...
author: Tim E.

description:
This is now my second family!  Last week, I passed a HUGE exam, a very big landmark in my life.  So, where to go to celebrate?  Well, once my appetite returned after days of anxiety and I found out I passed, I ran to Papalote.  And, they were wonderful.  Miguel gave me a bottle of champange and I celebrated with him and Vincent.  I told them before I even called my mom.  Like I said, my new family!
Aside from that, I always feel taken care of here.  All the staff are very friendly, and of course, the salsa rocks.  They even made me a punch card just for quesadillas.  The strawberry agua fresca is like a sugary heaven, too.  Mmmmm.....If only they were open 24 hours a day.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Everything I've had there has been amazing.

Everything said about the salsa is true, in fact it's so good it can also be used as martini mixer, massage oil, and surf wax.  I buy it by the case.
author: Evan A.

description:
I LURV these burritos so much.
Usually, I find most places to have the burrito meats sitting in tubs that they scoop out.  This place cooks the stuff fresh on the grill.  So it takes a whole 5 minutes longer, but the taste is unbeatable.

Service is great, and I'm definitely a repeat customer.
author: C B.

description: The food is good, but not great. WAYYYYY too overpriced. You end up spending $10 on a burrito, and I just think that for half the price and better taste, I'd rather go to Gordo's.
author: Madeline Z.

description:
IF you don't mind spending a little $$, Papalote is so good.  The grilled tortillas flake off as you consume, the Salsa is custom for this place and is amazingly tasty.  They'll put POTATOES in the burrito if you like!!!  It may not be terribly authentic, but potatoes have been in my burritos since I was a kid ---- and this is the only burrito place in SF that has even considered this concept. 

My only complaints are that they're too expensive, this location is all about Reggae, and they charge you for any extra salsa after you've had just ONE... I do like the sauce, and they make a great  (yet, stingy) salsa.
author: Jake B.

description:
Good joint to get some healthy taqueria eats... however... not worth the 5 star hype that it gets all the time. The roasted salsa is not a favorite of mine and neither are the chips. Sometimes the signature salsa tastes like its got way too much tomato paste in it... or just way too sweet. I am a big fan of the fresh chopped cilantro, tomato, onion, and jalapeno salsa...so this was a big minus one star for Papalote.

Good place to go to for tofu and veggie tacos. I do adore the fact that fillings are made to order.
author: Sarina U.

description:
Papalote's salsa=crack cocaine.

No joke. It just might be that addictive. It's this blended concoction of God knows what--even Chow magazine tried to figure out the top-secret combination in an article a year or two ago. But in any case, the salsa is nice and salty with a healthy dose of heat. And here's a tip: You can even buy a jar of it for, like, five bucks if you ask up front.

You know what else I love? The ingredients are really fresh and cooked to order. I went yesterday for lunch and got my usual, the fish tacos. They're piled with chunks of white fish, tomatoes and lettuce and served with a little bit of crisp jicama salad on the side. I get the fish tacos, a side of guac, an extra order of the crack-cocaine salsa and a Coke. I mix it all together--well, everything except the Coke, silly--for the perfect combo of meaty, fresh, creamy, spicy and sweet. 

Seriously, I'm not a taqueria expert, but it's pretty damn good.
author: Karen P.

description:
By Far this place is one of the best mexican places around, total awesomeness!

i absolutely love their Soyrizo Refried Black Bean burrito with Guacamole, totally sweet :) only gripe is that their salsa isn't free and it appears that they are stingy with their chips. 

but this place is totally awesome, seating can sometimes be rather limited, and parking can be a pain, but their is underground parking across the street at the fulsom market grocery store. 

nachos were awesome too but i'd rather just get an order of chips & salsa and refried beans :)
author: Gurvinderpal S.

description:
Good veggie options.

Minus - I ordered and paid for the "super" burrito, however, I was given the regular burrito.  But, since I got it to-go, I did not learn this until I got home.

Moral of the story:  Be sure to ask the server what burrito is in your bag before you leave.
author: Yelper H.

description:
tacos start at 4.15 for 2, burritos start at 5.45, and quesadillas at 5.00 for meat varieties, veggie and tofu are cheaper. there's also plate combos for 10ish. the usual nachos are also on the menu. 

their carnatis burrito  is the best i've ever tasted. you get a choice of black, pinto, etc beans. their special sauce sings. their  dipping sauce with the gratis chips is great. 

street parking available but difficult to find.
author: Victor G.

description:
When I lived in the Nission some years ago, the original Papalote was a regular hang-out for me. To this day, I think they do some of the better burritos in the city, and in a much cleaner dining area as well. Plus the owners over in the Mission were characters, still are.

I now live in DMV Heights, where this Papalote is located, actually right next to Poleng. They've replicated the magic in terms of food, and it actually seems to be busier than the original. They don't serve beer yet, so no five stars, but it's a welcome addicion to the 'hood.
author: Nish N.

description:
I don't care about the "oh it's not authentic" crap people like to spout off.  Does that really matter when it comes to taste?  If you don't like it, fine, just say that.
Anyway, not to sound like a b*tch, but PLEASE.  Damn, I must have DOWNED my burrito in under 6 minutes. 

And for me, THAT is saying something.

By the way, the salsa is great (like others have said).  Kind of reminds me of a creamy chipotle flavor. Unique.
Their soyrizo (vegan-duh) was really, really good.  I took my meat-eating friend's advice and tried it.  If an omnivore loves fake meat, that's impressive to me.

I've heard their breakfast burritos are good. I'll try them next.
author: Robyn E.

description: I love the Mexipino burrito, adobo chicken and garlic rice, so good!  I add super and jalapeño and it's magic.  Also the fresh salsa is addictive, I have so many empty ball jars I just use them as water cups and a nice tip is to bring in the empty jars for a dollar off.  Love this place.
author: Jake S.

description:
The first burrito I had here wasn't very good. The super carne asada I had almost drove me away from this place. But since my boyfriend, the Mexican burrito expert insisted that I give Papalote another try. I got a super chicken burrito, so damn good. Their chicken is slightly marinated, beans perfectly cooked (not hard and cold like from Pancho Villas), and their guacamole has extra zesty lime. Each tortilla is toasted, melting the cheese. My only qualm is that they don't have their effin fantastic jicama salad for for sale. They only have it as a little extra on the side on your burrito. Bahhhh. 

I suggest you try this place out once, if you don't like it, then go elsewhere, eh? Go out to the Mission. Whatever suits your taste. But you cannot deny the quality of their burritos. Orale. The only thing that probably takes away from away from their "authenticity" is their lack of grease and lard.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Roasted red tomato salsa is worth a visit in itself.  Popped in here yesterday for the first time for a carne asada burrito -- which was good, but could use some better craftmanship, a little too loose, which made it sloppy to eat.

But the salsa and chips they give you on the side was some freakin' tasty stuff.  I'll likely be stopping by here for a pint for home -- it is that good.
author: John R.

description:
Is a burrito better if the ingredients are fresh? I'm not so sure the answer is yes. But in San Francisco, it seems fresh ingredients a good burrito does make. Hailing from San Diego, I cry foul.

Twas Halloween 2009 and we happened to be riding BART due to the fourth consecutive day of bay bridge closure. "Why not get a burrito in the Mission?" my girlfriend did ask. Sounds great... as a burrito almost always does.

So we embark to order our food. Granted, it is Halloween, I understand that. I understand it's going to be busy. But when you say the wait is going to be half an hour, it had damn well better be less than a 30 minute wait. This is called the C. Montgomery Scott school of expectations management.

-- Scene

"The dilitheium chambers have ruptured captain! It'll take at least 2 days" - Scotty

"You've got to work quicker Mr. Scott! We haven't got two days, we've got two hours!" - Kirk

"Aye sir. I'll give it all she's got." - Scotty

[Scotty sits back in his chair knowing full well he has an hour and fifty minutes to enjoy his twelve year single malt in piece before he actually has to do any work]

/ Scene

In other words, you give yourself some wiggle room. There's absolutely no excuse to tell me my shredded chicken burrito is going to be ready in half an hour (a travesty in and of itself, but again, this was Halloween) and let me wait a full hour to deliver said burrito. There are levels of savagery that are acceptable, but making a man wait 100% longer for his burrito is not amongst those acceptable levels.

All that being said, the burrito wasn't bad. It was a decent burrito, but the fresh ingredients did make me think I was eating at Baja Fresh for a couple of bites. And no one should ever have to eat at Baja Fresh. I think it was just the salsa fresco.

All in all, I'd recommend the place, but you had better be prepared for a wait. I just wanted a burrito... it didn't have to be made to order.
author: James G.

description:
We saw this restaurant on Bobby Flay's Throw Down show and decided to try it out.  We did it today, and felt the same way as many other reviewers:
1.  The first impression walking into this restaurant is small and crowded, which is OK, we are here for the food.
2.  On the show, they competed using Triple Threat Burrito and we decided to try it out.  It was $19.95.  We also ordered Carne Asada Quesadilla for $7.95.  This was also promoted on the show that they use flank stake, marinated.  When I looked at the bill, it came out to be $32.42 including tax.  They added $0.99 twice for "+ Make It Super" (didn't know what that was).  Hey we were there to see the best, money is no object!
3.  We received salsa and chips before the meal, this maybe the "Super"!  The salsa was in paste form and good in flavor, they supposed to use grilled tomato.  However, we were used to fresh chunky tomatoes.  Something different, OK.
4.  When the food came, the presentation was BLAH!!  The Quesadilla was flavorful.  Beef was a little over cooked and dry, but OK.  The Triple Threat Burrito had 3 kinds of meat - chicken, carne asada, and prawn.  The chicken and prawn did not taste marinated, so mostly just felt the texture.  

In summary, we have tried the most expensive burrito we ever had that was presented on the Food Networks.  Way OVER RATED!!!  After all, the food was OK, but not any bit better than other Mexican restaurants.  Because it had charged a premium, our expectation was higher, and did not meet our expectation - we gave a 2 star for failing expectation.  

Hey, shame on you, Bobby --- Lost to such an ordinary burrito!
author: Leo L.

description:
This is an extremely clean, extremely friendly, extremely fresh place to eat.  The staff all say goodbye as you walk out the door, and they bring your burrito to your table with a smile.  

I'll admit it:  This just isn't the best burrito I've ever had.  At the same time, they're on the right track.  If only the tortillas were a little squishier, and the burritos a little wetter, we'd be there.  

However, the mole-like salsa they serve up on the side?  It's original, it's spicy, it's thick, it's smoky.  It's worth it.
author: Ann M.

description:
me: Pretty good actually. Blows chipoodle out of the water.
G: mmmm 
G: i am not a huge chipoodle fan
G: TDM all the way man
me: Yeah this makes that place resemble a dog food factory, but Papalote actually makes their food fresh to order so it shouldn't be compared to either.
G: blah blah blah
G: its just [mexican] food
me: It was my first trip. I thought it would be the same shit as every taco stand.
G: yelp it
me: I just may.
author: Ian M.

description:
Oh the joy that is Papalote...

The bean & cheese dip appetizer is so fantastic, you might almost forget to eat the rest of your order.  
Don't do that though, because whatever else you ordered will be deelish!

Their homemade salsa is bomb-tastic (& for sale to take home). 

 If i had to, I could easily (and happily) survive on their salsa, guac and black refried beans.
author: Heather P.

description: The first time I ate at Papalote I had a great experience. I had no qualms about going back. Unfortunately, it was a big mistake. I ended up with pretty serious food poisoning for 24 hours. It saddens me to say but I will not be returning for a third time.
author: Onllwyn D.

description: Its the sauce that gets you. I love the food. It isn't really super authentic traditional mexican but it's still damn good. My only complaints are about the size of the place. It can get cramped and if you come durring a rush then it can be uncomfortable to stand around. I suggest getting your food to go unless the place is empty.
author: E.N. C.

description:
Call it three and a half stars. 

I've been getting the carne asada burrito, but the last few visits found the beef a little fatty. Today I went for something healthier: the grilled prawn tacos, in warm corn tortillas with lettuce and fresh tomato salsa. Delish! Add a little of their house chipotle sauce- just perfectly simple and smoky and not too filling. 

Then I had a bite of my brother's super shrimp burrito with black beans, sour cream, guac... and holy smokes, I nearly stole it from him. It was definitely one of those rare burrito-nirvana moments when everything is just firing. Papalote grills their prawns with lime juice, but the shrimp they sautee with wine and butter. So not on the diet, but next time I get my own.
author: Madie S.

description:
Dude, so Xamot came running back to the car after picking up a couple of things at Papalote with a giant jar of delicious salsa cradled in his arms. This salsa is the shit and since we live in LA, we wanted to get a bigass bottle to tide us over between bay area visits.

"Does it need to be refridgerated?" I asked in a worried tone. 

"Well, she said that it may lose its consistency and texture if it gets warm, so let's try to keep it cool."

I suggested we find a styrofoam container ASAP to keep that shit on ice, but we had places to be and people to see, so I had to think of a Plan B. So I took it upon myself to carry around a jar full of Papalote salsa in my purse all weekend to insure the integrity of the all important consistency of this beautiful salsa. 

It was a warm ride back on the 5 to LA, but I made sure Salsa was kept cool and safe. I am happy to report we are back home now and Salsa is quietly "chillin" in the fridge, awaiting my fat ass.

Woo hoo!!!!!
author: S A.

description:
In my experience (which is material), probably the best burrito in san francisco.  

Grilled at end is key.  Excellent salsa made fresh from chile de arbol.  

Other menu items not up to the same standard, but the burrito is worth going out of your way.
author: Bruce M.

description:
Did anybody get sick after eating food from Papalote on the evening Thur, Mar 8th?

I had a shrimp burrito made about 9 pm and am just now recovering from food poisoning.  Felt so bad and vomited so hard all Thur. night, I burst my hemorrhoids and had to cancel all my appts. Fri. to  see a G-I doctor the next day.  Not kidding.  This was not the first time I had eaten food from Papalote but we'll never go there again.  

I don't care if this is rated one of the best Mexican delis in whatever continent, but mishandled food is mishandled food!

No, it couldn't have been something else.
author: Vera P.

description:
This is my favorite burrito place, carne asada super burrito with black beans was the perfect after/in between class meal: filling, not too expensive and damn tasty.

Also I never liked salsa and by never liked, I mean HATED, not sure why but it has always been that way. That was until i tried the salsa here, whoa. I've been assured by friends that this isn't just your average salsa, this stuff is great, I'm even tempted to bring a jar so I can stock up at home...
author: Chris H.

description:
There are not many days that go by that I don't wish I could walk into this place and order a burrito with chips and the divine salsa.  I had a Camarones burrito with shrimp broiled in white wine, mango chunks, rice and black beans.  

Papalote's salsa has no peer.  Charred tomato, with chipotle peppers and a slightly creamy taste.  Best salsa I've ever had, with Chevy's charred tomato salsa and perfect ultrathin chips coming in a close second.  

You people in SF have no idea what you have...Down here in Hollywood and Los Angeles, I feel like I'm in a desert of the real where you all are in the Matrix, enjoying your steak.  There is nothing that even comes close to the quality and taste of Papalote down here in L.A.  Sad...
author: Danny K.

description:
OK, so I'm thinkin more like 3.5 stars, but since I gave the other Papalote a 3, this one can get a 4 and average it out. This location is right by my house, so I've had the opportunity to go back a few times, and I've discovered an odd factoid: I do not like Papalote's chicken (which is probably why I didn't like my burrito from the other location). It's boneless, skinless, grilled chicken breast, so wtf? How can I not like it? Turns out they use some spice in the rub that doesn't agree with me (or maybe I don't agree with it). Anyway, it sounds like a presonal problem...

No matter. I've changed my opinion on the chips--they are pretty good...especially when smothered in cheese and beans and guac. The nachos are great. Delicious steak tacos. Cheap. Bien, bien! Gotta try the seafood (fish tacos, shrimp something....mmmm, shrimp) next time I go.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
I feel like I'm slighting you here, Papalote. And you deserve better than that. But honestly, I can't justify more than three stars when better burrito joints in this town get only four stars from me. 

Granted, Papalote is closer than most spots, which is convenient. And as far as burrito joints in the panhandle go, the only other place I'd rather go to at this point is the Green Chile Kitchen (& that's more of a New Mexico-style place).

But the burritos at Big Papa are just Solid. There's nothing spectacular about them. It's a good place for Western Addition & Panhandle folks like me, but you wouldn't make a special effort to leave your 'hood to come here.
author: Pete J.

description:
I'm not from San Francisco. In fact, I'm from Canada. What do I know about burritos then, son? Probably not all that much, but I know what I like, and a veggie burrito that's vegan by default is one of those things. 

Not only do normal, regular veggie burritos come without cheese, but there's marinated tofu, soyrizo, and grilled veggies on the menu. I like to keep things simple, so I just get the normal veggie burrito (which comes with potato, carrot, and mushrooms), which will cost you a cool $5.70, and comes with warmed-up corn chips (a big deal for us Canadians who are not accustomed to such finery) and a small ramekin thing of god's own salsa. 

There are those, I hear, who don't like Papalote's salsa, and they are wrong. The only thing I would change about Papalote is that in my perfect world, they would sell their salsa by the gallon if you asked them nicely. As it is, I have to be content to ration my container appropriately so I can dip my chips and put little dabs of it on each bite of my burrito with my knife.
author: Jordan P.

description:
This is a good taqueria even if it is very Americanized. Since I don't eat meat, I usually order the fish tacos or the achiote tofu burrito. I'm really impressed by the achiote tofu. They marinade the tofu in this amazing achiote chile sauce and then saute it until slightly crispy. The tofu mole is so so. I still prefer homemade mole, but it's still worthy of some praise, nonetheless. The fish is super fresh and perfectly seasoned.

Their guacamole is not my favorite but they do make a mean salsa. They don't have a salsa bar but they do have pickled jalapeos and carrots in the back (if you know where to look.) This place is usually crowded and there is never anywhere to sit, unless you sit along the wall in the back. I'm not a picky eater, but I don't really like the tomatoes they put in their food. A little too sweet and squishy. I tend to favor those tart, crunchy tomatoes you get at other taquerias.

Although I prefer to get burritos at non-Americanized taquerias, Papalote is still a good place to eat. I give them 4 start because the service is good, they are fast, clean, and they offer achiote tofu.
author: L. L.

description:
High Quality Burritos.  Had the Carne Asada as the meat and ordered a grilled chicken too.  Not sure if they do this all the time but the meat was grilled fresh and directly from the grill to your tortilla.  Well, after it comes off the grill they dice up the meat first and then it goes into your burrito.  That adds to the Freshness of the burrito and the meat had this smoky flavor to it.  Grilled and charred to perfection.  

But they are a little more than some in terms of price but still not on the level of certain well known places that I will not name.  

This is not your "in the Hood" burrito.  But a more refined version and so you pay slightly more for it but I'm not complaining too much.  It doesn't burn a hole in your pocket.  

For the most part, here are the prices.  Regular at this point is $5.45

To make it Super (Sour Cream and Guacamole) add $.99

Add in Uncle Sam's cut and you are paying close to $7 per...
author: Mark W.

description: make sure you try the orange salsa! you'll thank me later.
author: Nehemiah M.

description:
I didn't see the 13 dollar burrito but I got my steak burrito super-ed with guac cheese and sour cream for like a buck.. the meat is fresh and tasty.. I like clean and fresh so i disagree with the guy who claimed it is a poser burrito joint. I think it is more along the lines of a baja fresh ( a chain - but good) than a mission burrito joint. the house salsa rocks!

good brie toes and cleen place to eat em.
author: Jacky J.

description:
The nachos in this place is a must...I haven't tried it with the vegan sides, but there's always a next time.

Seating is pretty tight. You have a counter wall of stools and then there's the couple of bar steel stands with hard chrome chairs to go with. If you're lucky you get those...if not you face the wall like dirty criminals on the lam for good mexican noshing.

The portions of all their entrees are pretty big and they're prepared to order, not sitting all day under some hot lamp.

Nice servers but don't block the way to the kitchen or you'll be rolled over.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Pretty darn good...I prefer my Mexican a bit greasier. They do have great veggie options, many of which I've never seen anywhere else (tofu mole...). The pureed salsa they give you with chips is incredible. I wish that was the salsa that came on the burrito.
I hate it when I forget to ask for no salsa. Raw onion and cilantro are bratty kids who steal all of the attention away from the quiet, well behaved beans, rice and meat.
author: Lauren T.

description: I always get the bean and cheese and a side of chips and salsa. Every now and then it is a little sub par but for the most part I liked it. I went to school nearby and there was a limited number of places within walking distance so I went to Papalote on a weekly basis. Haven't been back since graduating but I would probably order the chips and salsa if I could.
author: Shohreh M.

description:
Worth going to just for the salsa.  My coworker thinks that they put mayonnaise in it.....I'm not so sure.

I love this place though.  The tortilla are always crispy and warm and the fixings are top notch.  Not authentic Mexican but delicious none the less.
author: Josh V.

description:
Papalote is best. What can I say? I've recommended this place to everyone I know who loves a good burrito- unfortunately, most people I know don't live close enough to warrant a trip for a burrito. Sadly, if they only knew the incredible burritos this place puts out, it would be far worth the trip. 

I've only ordered two burritos from here: carne asada and the prawns. I don't think I need much else. The carne asada is really nice due to the fact it's grilled right there- none of that beef being ladled (with juices galore) onto your precious burrito- this is grilled and chopped up right in front of your eyes. They do everything else the same way, which is nice. Oh, right, the prawns. Well, let me just say that the first time I had it, I couldn't talk until I finished the whole damn thing because my mind wouldn't let me stop eating. 

The salsa (liquid-y rather than tomatoes galore) was incredible- thin but full-bodied, smoky with just the right kick- it has your mind trying frantically to identify that one thing they throw in there to make it so damned irresistible. (Answer is pumpkin seeds.) Also, they have their salsa available for sale by the jar. Though it's not advertised, I've done so- $5 for half a quart, I think. It might've changed, so don't hold me to that.
author: Shelby C.

description: I am eating Papalote right now and i have one word.  Wow!
author: D D.

description:
um what?!

"$11.21"..... all I ordered was a shrimp burrito, no sour cream. I think they must think I ordered soup with it or something.....

no... huh...? $11.21 is CORRECT?!! .....WHAT THE F!?!?!

I know your Mex is good and you were on Throwdown and all but an $11 burrito is just  plain SHITTY.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This is healthy, and yes clean, tasting burritos, but not necessarily crave worthy. Then again, this may have something to do with the fact that they are healthy, and personally I like a little gluttony in my burrito--which is another way of saying grease and lard, I guess.

This place is conveniently located in my 'hood, and it's true that the red salsa is nice, but it's not all that spicy to me, and there aren't any other options for spicing up the burrito or tacos, and no pico de gallo (the salsa is a little more in line with a mole or thicker chile-based sauce that would go over an enchilada). Personally, I like to sweat a little when I eat Mexican food--there are studies that say hot food increases metabolism and creates a sense of euphoria of sort, hence, not doubt the reason I tend to eat it so much. Anyway, this salsa doesn't provide the requisite kick, and the burritos are a bit on the bland side. 

Now, on the other hand, their grilled lime prawns tacos are pretty nice. They have a bit of delicious crispy singe to the edges of the prawns and are served with a tiny portion of jicama salad (I usually ask for an extra dose of this salad - it's quite good). This is a pretty healthy option to the burrito, and why bother with their large, though somewhat bland version. 

The service here is courteous and friendly, but sloooowww. So sloooww. They really need to pick up the assembly-line philosophy here. They often give me something different than what I order, though. And there isn't much seating, either (I'm wishing they would take over that weird Korean bar a few doors down that seems to be conducting some sort of illicit business - they have enough seating, but rarely any customers). 

So, reading the other reviews, I know I'm in the minority here, and it's no doubt a matter of taste, but I prefer my Mexican food with a bit more flavor and decadence (think El Castillito, El Farlito, La Taqueria, La Corneta, Cancun, Gordo and Cactus in the East Bay). Maybe you do, too? I give them two stars for the food and another star for simply taking over Tango and giving us some sort of burrito place in the neighborhood (wouldn't want to look the proverbial gift horse in the mouth).
author: Chrissy L.

description: Pretty good burrito. On the pricey side, but not bad. Service can be lacking at times. When they get swamped they seem to struggle to run the kitchen effectively. I've had to wait and watch others come in after me, order, and get the exact same thing I ordered before me. Not cool.
author: Dan W.

description: Ok, after seeing the Throwdown with Bobby Flay, I had to try this place out.  I ordered the Carne Asada Burrito (Super - with sour cream, cheese and guacamole).  The burrito was OK.
