It was kind of lacking in flavor but it was fresh.  I had better in the Mission and was much cheaper.  But the salsa was amazing!!!!! It was tangy and had the right amount of heat.  I think it was way overpriced. I paid almost $12 for the burrito and a coke. I would have only gave it 3 stars but the salsa brought it up to 4 stars.
author: Tony L.

description:
Pros:
Definitely great place for vegetarians - finally some interesting options! I got the marinated tofu burrito and I tried my friend's soyrizo burrito. Both pretty solid options. The tortillas were delicious, as was the orange spicy salsa that was brought to our table (great service!) before the meal. Jalapeños in a jar = awesome. 

Cons:
The ordering situation was slightly stressful, as there was no good place to stand and look at the menu. There was confusion between the people waiting for food and who was in line. Not many drink options either. I love a good fountain soda (with refills), but all they have are a few bottled options. The chips that came out with the salsa were slightly stale. 

Lots of hype about this place and I'd probably have rated it 3 stars if it wasn't for the veggie options. That's definitely the best part.
author: Katie S.

description:
No, it's not uber authentic "Mexican," then again, do they even have Burritos in Mexico?

Anyhow, any haters of this eatery are either ultra-foodie-hipster nerds, or they just don't like food. 

Plain and simple, Papalote is borderline addictive.

Yep, the price is slightly high, especially when compared to some spots in the Mission or off the truck, but the food is cooked healthy, and the spot is spotless. I order the chicken burrito -super, if I exercised that day. The chips and salsa are free and the salsa is some of the best in the city.

On top of that, the owner is heavily involved in the community ( donated food to an event at the African American Art & Culture Complex supporting the SF8: www.freethesf8.org ) and and besides being a DJ and an events promoter himself, he allows others to drop off flyers for promo as well. That's the definition of cool.

Oh yeah, they play good music too. Anything from Reggae to Zion-I to Mos Def... c'mon hipster foodies... get on the train, yo!
author: nate m.

description: I came here to try the chips and salsa thats on the 7 x 7 Big Eats List. I must say I was VERY DISAPPOINTED! The salsa is nothing really special. Its like an orange spicy sauce like Le Vics I guess you can say? And the burrito was not good at all. I was very very disappointed because I haven't had Mexican food in over a month and it did not do my Mexican craving well. I got a carne asada burrito. The meat was burnt tasting and dry. And it is pretty pricey too.
author: Annie L.

description: BEST BURRITO I'VE HAD IN THE CITY BY FAR!!!  One of these day's I'll stumble in on a sunday morning and try the breakfast burrito.  Everything I've had has always been amazing!!!
author: Brandon N.

description:
I chose to visit this place because it's close and it seemed like a fast cheap way to get good Mexican food. It was indeed a delicious feast. The carne asada burrito was juicy, the meat in it was tender, the tortilla was just the right texture - not too hard, not too soft, presumably grilled - and the burrito was "packed" well-enough so that I could eat it with my hands and not make a giant mess. I'm happy I got it "super" (sour cream and the works) and while the Orangina seemed like a good idea at first, now I kind of regret it :)

The service was fast, the inside is fine, and I got to see a hot lady order food wearing basically a bikini and a soft shell. And it was pretty chilly outside. How can you beat that? :)
author: Dumitru E.

description:
Really good Mexican food with a modern twist (ie tofu if desired) at a good price.
You can see that some love is going into the preparation of these plates and the salsa is off the hook, i recommend buying a jar to take home (thats if you can stand the spiciness....cissies!!!, hehe just joking, dont call the aclu on me, {{hands in the air}} im a good guy)

Downsides are it can be a bit cramped in there, but not a big deal, and you gotta pay for more chips, but makes sense when the chips are that good, ya know?

plus mr. e the owner is a good dj, there you go, papalote's get to know one.

peace
author: James A.

description: Really filling and yummy burritos. A little expensive for a burrito but at least the portions are HUGE. I'm not a big salsa fan but i loooovvve the salsa here. I always use every drop of salsa I get. I usually get the veggie burrito and I must say I'm very impressed. I have found it hard to find a good vegetarian burrito, but this place does not disappoint. My only criticism is being a san diego girl, this doesn't really live up to my standards of real hole in the wall amazing mexican food. Go here if you are looking for hearty burritos and ridiculously good salsa. Try another place if you want legit mexican food (enchiladas, tamales, tostadas etc).
author: Julie C.

description: Oh my. The fish tacos here are elegant and simple. The salsa, as pretty much anyone will attest to, is what gives this place the cult following it deserves! My only reservation is that I find it weird and cheap to charge for extra chips and salsa. I can see that rubbing people the wrong way. But that minor irritant fades when the salsa gets passed to you.....
author: Brigid S.

description: Best burrito in the world!!!  Gold metal delicious!!!  If I lived closer I would be a great big fat person and very happy with it!  Super chicken burrito no rice.  Fantastic!  Love love love.
author: elliott a.

description:
This place has some truly delicious tacos. However, they are cruel, and they play games with my taco-loving heart. First time I ate here I got the verde pork tacos, which were awesome, but they made them with only one tortilla each! Needlessly to say, they fell apart with a quickness. Despite that, the crumbled pieces still tasted awesome. What made matters worse, however, was that my friend's grilled chicken taco was made properly, with two tortillas for extra fortitude. I had guessed that they just flubbed that one order.

However, I was in the neighborhood again last night, and was still dreaming of those tacos, so I dropped back in to grab some to go. Again, with the verde pork, and again with the single tortilla action! Why must they taunt me? I'm thinking I might have to specifically request the double wrap next time, because it really is a shame that I haven't eaten a single decently put together meal here yet. Until I get that sorted out, this place is only going to be a tease to me.
author: Tom H.

description:
Que bueno!

Great burritos.  Fantastic salsa/guacamole.  Do they have to ration the salsa like it's made of stem cells instead of, I dunno, tomatoes?  Peppers?

Minus a star for that stinginess.  Otherwise, a really spectacular joint.
author: Holly F.

description:
All I have to say is, soyrizo rocks. At first, I admit, I was a little scared. The concept of REAL chorizo grosses me (as a vegetarian) out completely. But SHAZZAM! Papalote's Soyrizo burrito or quesadilla are a perfect post-gym treat.

Yes, I realize eating a huge burrito probably cancels out the benefits of going to the gym, but I think I should get points for effort.

Anyway, thank god we have a burrito place in our neighborhood that doesn't charge $8 for a basic veggie burrito (like the places on Haight), and I'll add an extra AMEN for their yummy, tangy salsa.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Papalote is quite possibly one of my favorite Mexican joints in the city. There are a couple reasons for this: their burritos are bomb and they're not too far from mi casa. There IS a closer taqueria within walking distance from where I reside but, when I'm really in the mood for some way better than average Mexican, I make the trip. They're salsa is also one of my faves...spicy and of a different (in a good way) consistency.

On to some other important elements...this time the service was a little slow but it was pretty packed in there (testament to their excellent grub). On a regular basis, I'm in and out in no time. Not to mention they're very friendly and the place is well-kept. 

Definitely would recommend.
author: Kristin R.

description:
This isn't my numero uno for veggie burritos, and I'm not a member of the cultish following of Papalote's salsa... but their soyrizo veggie burrito is pretty fantastic. The place is also quite clean, and across the street from our nearest supermarket, so win-win.
Side note, re: veggie burritos... if you love El Far veggie super burritos, do NOT order their veggie burrito; the potatoes are big taste-reducing, space wasters... and I had to waste a ton of sauce just to appease my tastebuds. The soyrizo burrito with some hotsauce and sourcream though, is original and fabulous.  The soyrizo nachos are bueno, also.
author: Tiffany M.

description: The salsa here is definitely one of my favorite salsas ever. I could've seriously eaten that salsa and chips for my lunch and be completely content with that. It's creamy and rich, and its flavor is spicy and peppery. without being too overwhelming. I would give Papalote 5 stars if I judged solely on the salsa. However, the rest of my meal, the carne asada burrito, was just OK. It was also a little more expensive than what I usually pay for a burrito of similar quality. I wouldn't go out of my way to return, but if I was in the area, I'd come back.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Straight up delicious.  The burritos are HUGE and they just taste so good.  I don't know what it is, but they are better than most burritos which, to me, tend to just be a mess inside without any real flavors standing out.  For some reason, they stand out better at Papalote.  I also must eat chips & salsa any time I'm at a mexican restaurant, and the salsa at Papalote is some of the best I've ever had.  Now I just have to resist the urge to go there too regularly.

The seating is pretty limited, so don't plan on going with groups.  You're probably best off ordering to go and enjoying at home.  Just make sure you take home enough salsa!
author: Amit M.

description: Lunch with Harry C, Terence & Rod in the city consisted of sharing burritos. Mine for obvious reason ( I never finish my food). Harold said they had some great burritos so we hiked it over to Papalote on Fulton st. Harry and I went with the carne asada with black refried beans worked out well because we were both gearing torwards this burritto anyways. It was pretty damn good. I wish I could of eaten more but I was super full. The guacamole was AMAZING and super fresh. I think that was my favorite part about the restuarant. Good little eatery.
author: Valerie G.

description:
Finally, a good burrito place near the Panhandle! If I get change back from $5 for a super bean + rice burrito, I'm a happy girl. Combine that with Mexican Coke in a bottle, and happiness inches closer to elation. (What makes it a Mexican Coke? Cause it says "hecho en Mexico" on the bottle.) Mexican Coke in a bottle is the only kind I'll drink. Because, unquestionably, it's far superior to its sub-par U.S. counterpart.

I feel like the salsa is getting spicier though, and as a hot food prude, this keeps me off it it lately, which is sad because it's otherwise hella good.
author: reb f.

description:
I enjoy this place, despite it being overpriced and overrated.  Had the chicken burrito.  Liked the flavor...  Almost Tandoori-like.  The sauce is good here!

Friends thought that it was mediocre compared to other joints in city...  C'mon - extra charge for a thimble of more sauce?? ...  Extra charge for a few more chips?? ... 
Burrito chains should never skimp on the simple things..
Where's the never ending pancho villa salsa bar???

Not the best around but certainly worth the return trip on the sauce alone, but worth skipping altogether for their miserly attitue.

2 stars... Service sucks...  Food is OK.
author: Scott S.

description:
Growing up in San Francisco, and being used to great mexican cuisine... and burritos, I decided to give the chain a try.

Wow. I ve never have a Chicken Mole burrito, but now that I have I want more.

This place is definetly a go to place from now on. I love it that the grill their tortia instead of putting it in one of those steam machines. It has that crunch to it.

This hot sauce was awesome. Give this place a try, I can't wait to try more things off their menu.
author: yana Z.

description:
Nice clean place.  We enjoyed the carne asada burrito and the grilled lime prawn tacos.  The chips were fresh and the salsa was nice and spicy, quite different than from what I have had in the past.  I was used to the more pico de gallo style, but this was more on the creamy side.  

Watching them create the dishes reassured us that the food was fresh and there was only a short wait. 

The place is a little small, with just a few tables to sit at and a wall lined with bar stools.  We had to wait for a table, but not too long.  

Over all, this place does rank as one of the better burrito places in my book.
author: MooMoo L.

description:
OK, I'm over the pricey guac. I've been to Papalote many, many times and the food is consistently good. Plus, if I get my burrito "super" for $.99, they will put the guac on the side if I am so inclined...and it avoids having to pay the "market price."

I am at peace.
author: Beth T.

description: Another check off of my list of must tries, the infamous Papalote chips and salsa.  I wonder if anybody would stare at me if I started drinking the salsa.
author: Sophia C.

description: The service here is way better than the one in the mission, but the Mission Papalote taste better in reference to their carne asada. I am always down for the carne asada super tacos and super burritos at any Papalote!!!
author: Minh V.

description: JUMMY! this place is solid. I live within walking distance so I'm happy to add to my waistline and fork out my hard-earned paper to Papalote. Big ups to the chicken burrito... next on my list is the carne asada quesadilla... I'm comin' for you buddy.
author: Bridget W.

description:
Ok so pretty good prices...pretty good food...yummy salsa...huge portions...and very close to where I live. When I need a giant burrito or some nachos in a hurry then Papalote is definitely acceptable. 3.5 stars if I could. They're also very nice there.

But come on people. This is San Francisco: land of opportunity for Mexican food lovers. You mexiCAN get better.
author: Ali W.

description: Stopped by for a chile verde burrito on the way home today.  It's tasty enough I suppose, but I don't understand all the hype around this place.  Plenty of better burritos to be had in this city (like at Little Chihuahua for example).   The salsa isn't anything amazing either, as it has no heat whatsoever.
author: Joshua W.

description:
Opening up this review page literally made my stomach growl.

This place used to be around the corner from my house and I ate there at least once a week, if not several times a week. I have since moved far far away and miss it like an ex-junkie misses heroin.

Get the super burrito, it's worth the extra 99cents. The marinated tofu was my favorite but I also quite often went for the chicken, soyrizo or fish. My suggestions would be the tofu and chicken with black beans, fish with pinto and the soyrizo in the breakfast burrito. They provide different tortillas for no extra charge, spinach or sun dried tomato. Don't forget to add their hot sauce. It beautiful.

They also have this black bean dip that is simply black beans with cheese melted over the top but it manages to be magical. I've had the tacos and the quesadillas and they've never disappointed but the true stars of this place are the burritos. They won best burrito in SF three years in a row or something like that. I believe it.

Service is surprisingly quick too, even when there's a line out the door. There's about ten people behind the counter ensuring that. You're in and out within ten minutes and a burrito and a beer will cost you less than $10. Can't go wrong.
author: Torey B.

description: I guess I'm pretty picky about my burritos. I didn't find this place particularly special. I was super excited to try this place, but my food tasted average. The space is small also, so good luck finding a table. I sat at the "bar", but the door kept opening so it was pretty chilly.
author: Lily Z.

description: I was sorely disappointed after my first visit here and I took my friends visiting from LA who raved about this place after seeing Bobby Flay's Throwdown on  TV. I tried their prawn quesadilla and fell short of my expectations. Even the strawberry agua fresca was a miss, I had better ones at other places. The six of us all agreed that we won't be back. Meh.
author: Mika D.

description:
I first discovered Papalote's on 24th between Valencia and Guerrero.  I fell in love right away!  The ingredients are fresh and everything is made to order.  Nothing is worse than a burrito place that makes everything ahead and then just slops the ingredients out of a big bucket into a tortilla.  Although I'm not vegetarian, I do appreciate the vegan rice and beans!  I also love their soyrizo!!  

Don't forget to take home a jar of salsa -- I use it as a marinade on fish or chicken.  Also great as a base for any shellfish!  Their salsa is slightly different every time because they use only fresh available ingredients.

Yum!  I am so happy that the Fulton Street location opened!  Now I can go more often!!
author: Sarah T.

description:
I f---king love this place.  As far as I'm concerned, it's the best super burrito in town, no matter what any of the Mission partisans say.

The salsa totally makes it - it's the best I've ever had.
author: Adam B.

description:
I'm typically not a burrito fan, but I love their burritos. And the chips and salsa they give too.
I've had their tacos too and those are pretty good too, but if I had to choose I would go for the burrito supers. (super as in avocado, sour cream. etc. on for I think 99 cents)

Their pretty fast too and efficient. I usually just ordered them to go and ate them at home but you can eat there too. But I preferred taking them to go because it just felt odd eating a burrito on a plate with a fork and knife.
author: Michelle L.

description:
(revised review... I have since received an email from one of the owners and that right there... earns them more stars... please read:

"Ok, so our tacos are lame. But I think that once you get past the initial lameness...I'm sure you can appreciate a smaller amount of freshly grilled steak, than half a pound of previously grilled meat that has been sitting in a steam table for hours...the old quantity vs. quality conundrum, I guess. Be that as it may, if you ever end up at Papalote again, and you feel like having tacos I would like to recommend the following: The fish tacos (white fish sauteed in white wine and butter), the mole tacos (our dad's mole recipe with chicken breast or with TOFU! What? Try finding that in Mexico...no way Jose). and lastly try the Chile Verde tacos (Juicy chunks of pork in a tangy greeen sauce). Them are good! (I heard this expression a lot in Wichita, KS). "



(old review)
Dear Papalote, have you guys been to Mexico lately? Check it out. Making tacos is actually quite simple. I know this is gringo land, but I am looking for meat in my tacos, not roughage. Ya dig?

( i hear the burritos are yummy, but once again, I am talkin Mexican. My friend says to please write that she was happy that they have the option of the green tortillas for burritos and quesadillas. I explained that this don't exist in Mexico, but she loves Papalote and I love her so there ya go.)

TACOS:

carne asada. lame. small amount of reasonably flavored beef with a half a cup of lettuce and tomato. 

soyrizo: lame. a teaspoon of soyrizo with a half a cup of lettuce and tomato.

The tofu quesadilla wasn't bad, but I can make that at home.
author: Claudia O.

description:
Nice! Only a few blocks away from work, so I'm only a few minutes away from some damn good burritos. I think the most important thing you'll need to know is that the burritos here are a little different from other SF burrito joints...a little drier, but I'm totally OKAY with that!

This place is not really for sit down dining because it's pretty tiny unless you dig eating at a counter off the main stretch of space. But you can always grab and go if you need to. Agua fresca is good here and you will love love love the salsa.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Really Papalote? Really? 
This place has been in my hood for years. I grew up in SF proper and while this place has always been damn near the closest burrito shop to my place, I've always ventured elsewhere. That's because their burritos have been just average and SF is FULL of top notch burrito shops more worthy of my money. 

I saw this place on Bobby Flay's a few weeks ago, though, so I decided to go back. They beat Bobby with their "triple threat" burrito (steak, chicken and shrimp). It looked pretty damn good. So my bf and I were all excited to give this place a new shot. We'd been looking forward to breaking our new years diet with this mean lookin burrito ALL day. But we get there, and the damn thing is $19.95! Are you kidding me? For a burrito? So I asked the nice lady at the counter how much it was BEFORE they got all the publicity from the food network, and she says $14.99. Ok, now that's just bad business. I mean you know that being on TV is going to increase volume. That's a given. you dont need to jack up the price because your foot traffic is going to double or triple anyway. But NOW that you have increased it, a lot of the people that come in are now not going to spend the $20 and would rather just opt for your regular old $9 carne asada.  So that's what we did. We opted for one of their other not so famous burritos and not to my surprise, it was as average as I remember and I will not be returning. I'm sorry, but with all the incredible mexican food in this fine city, I find it absurd to spend $20 on a burrito...even if i'm rollin' in the dough.
author: Catharine C.

description: I am updating my review because they raised the prices here to borderline ridiculous. When I pay nearly $10 for a damn burrito, I should get a happy ending. I understand raising prices, but a $2-$3 increase is INSANE! I wont go back here anymore.  ... thanks a lot Bobby Flay
author: Jena D.

description: Mole burrito... You are so good. I usually get annoyed when I go to places like Chipotle and their burritos cost 7+ dollars, but it is completely worth it here. The burritos are huge and man... I just can't describe how good a mole burrito is. I've never had one or seen one on a menu before.
author: Liz K.

description: Maybe it was the lack of sauce?  Maybe it was what i ordered?  the triple threat - carne asada, chicken and prawns (recently featured on Food Network's Throwdown) was just okay.  it's also THE most expensive thing on the meny.  was it worth the $20?  uh...no.  Dry and a bit bland is how i'd describe it.  have i had better?  definitely.  have i had worse?  definitely.  their homemade sauce is hands down great...but why not put it on the burrito?  hmmmm....the aqua frescas were very good though.
author: Sonia C.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and was happy to learn of this second (yes second) burrito place to open up in recent months.  Well, it's not all that surprising since things seem to come in pairs around here:  There are two independent cafes on the same block, though one is being remodeled (Central Coffee and Cafe Organica).  There are even two Starbuck's on the same block (one inside of Albertson's).  What's next, a competitor to "Gabin"?!? 

Papalote serves up some good grub.  The chips and salsa are a great start, and the various burritos quite flavorful.  I usually get the burritos with pinto beans because the refried black beans tend to drown out the other flavors.  

Above all, you gotta try the CHILAQUILES.  So addicitive that I could have them on Saturday for breakfast, and then again on Sunday.  This is one of my favorite Mexican dishes, and Papalote does it right.  Note: If you are health conscious, ask them to go easy on the cheese.  

My main criticism of this place is that it doesn't serve coffee.  Bottom line is that I need a cup of joe with the my chilaquiles.  If you find yourself in this predicament, run over to Starbuck's (pick one) and get venti, extra hot whatever with shot of whatever.  Upon your return, you'll be rewarded with chips and salsa right next to your number.
author: Leon R.

description:
Wow -is all I can say for this fine taqueria in the Western Addition - 
Ingredients are fresh and so so good. Thier tomatoes are nice and red not like your typical taqueria tomato wich carries a faint reddish hue.

MMMMMM.. Papolete Love
author: Christian S.

description:
Halfway through my meal, (a grilled veggie quesadilla w/ soyrizo) I had to slow myself down because I wanted it to last longer.  I'm a light eater, but I definitely cleaned my plate on this one. And even licked my tiny to-go container of salsa clean.

I took advice from a fellow Yelper and tried the soyrizo. And survey says...it's AMAZING. In fact, it's what inspired me to actually create a yelp account. I don't really like chorizo, and I don't  like fake meat, and I don't like paying extra for things (it's an extra $2.00)...but lemme tell ya, soyrizo is legit, and worth it.

The soyrizo has a wonderful spice--similar to the salsa, but I think the salsa is actually spicier. By itself, or as an entire burrito, it may have been overwhelming, but it was a perfect addition to the quesadilla, and would have likely made a great taco. 

I begrudgingly gave my sister a bite, and she also thought it was fabulous. She looked a little disappointed to return to her chicken burrito. However, the burrito is a better bang for your buck--the quesadilla, though tasty, is slightly underwhelming if you're looking for a solid meal.

Tips: 
1. If your meal comes with beans, get the refried black beans. My sister said they've got enough flavor and tastiness to make upgrading to the super unnecessary.

2. If you're ultra cheap, like me, stop to get a drink from the Albertson's directly across the street. You'll need one for the spicy salsa, but they're priced to rip you off.

3. Try the soyrizo. Honestly.

We ordered food to go, so I can't rate the service. We were late picking it up, and it was still hot. Which either means it was late, or they're amazing at sealing in the tasty heat. The lines are notoriously long, so I'd recommend calling ahead.
author: Paula T.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet:

Go order a super burrito with carne asada and refried black beans.  Be generous with the smoky, spicy salsa as you eat the masterpiece.  Come and thank me for opening your eyes to heaven.

Honestly, this is my favorite burrito in San Francisco.  El Castillito is the 'Loin is solid, El Farolito is renowned, I've ever met my share of El Buen Sabor devotees- but nothing, and I do mean nothing, tops Papalote.  And in my opinion this rests on two simple factors:  fresh ingredients and incredible flavor.

Every single protein option, including the marinated tofu, is perfectly seasoned with a booty-load of flavor.  The chicken is hot and well-seasoned- but not really spicy.  Leave the spice for the salsa which, as I mentioned above, is perfect.  I am generally a bigger fan of salsa fresca and don't fawn over smooth, blended salsas- but this stuff is magic.  The fish, the soyrizo, everything is just perfect no matter how you slice it.  

Put your delici-osity in a taco, get a quesadilla if you like, but me, I can tell you what-  I'll be asking for a burrito and enjoying a gut-busting piece of heaven, courtesy of Papalote.
author: Jeff M.

description: Okay, Paplote's prices were bad enough before Throwdown, and now they are just ridiculous. It has become the most expensive burrito joint I've ever been to, and I have been to plenty. They are way too cocky. Probably wouldn't make any money at all if they weren't so close to USF. Such a rip-off for veeeery mediocre Mexican food.
author: Andria M.

description: not a fan!  i've tried this place many times, since my husband likes it, but  I have failed to find something I like!  I would go as far as saying the burrito I got last night was GROSS!  I couldn't even eat half of it.  I got the chile verde burrito "super"= with sour cream, guac and cheese.  I miss the days when sour cream and guac were scooped rather than poured into burritos, bc this thing was a slimy, wet mess of a burrito.  the chips are good, but the nachos are terrible.  I've previously ordered nachos topped with grilled chicken.  They just melt shredded cheese on the chips (which gets greasy) and then add a sliced dry chicken breast on top.  More like chicken jerky! The only decent thing is just a plain bean and rice burrito (no super) and then it's just ok.  not worth the wait or the hassle of paying an extra 50 cents if you want more than 1 ounce of salsa.
author: kathleen A.

description:
Look, I walked in wanting the special of the day but since this was my first time, I opted for the Triple Threat. My girlfriend and I figured if this is why they're famous, let's go for it. However, at $19.95, I also ASSUMED it was going to be huuuge, especially when they cashier asked if we were sharing it. 

Well it came out and it was quite small when halved but they did a great job with two plates. The prawns were friggin delicious, the carne asada was lean yet tasty and the chicken (although dry) had good charred flavor on it.

I ordered the chips and salsa and they came in a small bowl. I finished the chips in 2 minutes thinking there were free refills on chips. I heard my neighbor ask for a refill and they said $1.50 more. WHOA!

Luckily the guy gave me an extra salsa when my burrito came. Salsa is as good as they say.

My gf also got the horchata and it was very disappointing. 

Overall, their burrito is one of the best ever. But at $19.95, never again. However, I do think $8 for their other burritos (carne asada or prawn burrito) is definitely worth it. But like others have said, there are other taquerias in town with way better value. Meal for 2 (while sharing 1 burrito) was $25. ouch

FYI, if their burrito and salsa were just ok, I'd easily given 1 star because of the price. But yes, they were that good so 3/5.
author: Eddie L.

description:
I live right around the corner from this place so I eat here all the time. And to be fair, the food is three star quality. However, it earned the extra star for a couple reasons:

-The staff are ALWAYS friendly, no matter how packed it is
-It's a good value
-Their meat is fantastic!
-Their bathroom is the cleanest on earth
-Its fun to see and chat with regulars

I usually get the carne esada burrito (make it super style for sure) and that is delicious. When you ask them for super they add in guacamole cheese and sour cream. Nice. On a sad note though, yesterday I tried the prawn burrito. I was really excited after the first bite because the prawn i had just bitten into had this great blackened, spiced and grilled orange color. It looked great. It was flavorful. However, there was seriously three prawns in my entire giant burrito. C'mon, Papalote! Still, that's it is consistently a great place.
author: Jay C.

description:
Went here the first day it opened and two plus years later, Papalote is still going strong! 

I swear, this place just gets better and better every time I visit. And the jars of salsa you can now buy for $5 are a steal! 

Keep rockin', y'all. Keep rockin'.
author: Kate P.

description:
Let me first start by saying, I have been coming here for years (the original one at least, and have always loved the food), however, I am writing this review and giving my rating based on my most recent experience. Like a lot of people, I (re)visited Papalote after their "triple-threat burrito" was featured on the Food Network show "Throwdown with Bobby Flay". 

When I first arrived at the restaurant, I was excited to try their famous burrito because I was super-hungry and it is rare that my girlfriend agrees to eat mexican food because it's her least favorite type of food. I think if she wasn't as hungry as I was and not a big fan of the show and Bobby Flay, I couldn't have convinced her to come here. 
When we entered the restaurant, they were sweeping the floor which I found odd, but went straight for the register to order. I almost ordered without realizing the triple-threat burrito was $19.95!!! WTF, why would ANY burrito cost that much? Maybe, the price would have been justified if the beef was Kobe beef and the prawns and chicken were extremely high quality, but, as with most burrito joints, that was not the case. Honestly, I think they are just taking advantage of the fact that their burrito was made so popular by being featured on TV and they know enough people (like me) will come in and eat it just for that reason. In any case, the burrito was delicious (despite the price) but not even close to being worth it. I have had better burritos at El Farolito for about $6 and most places that have similar burritos charge at most $10. What really upset me was, knowing that my gf and I were sharing the burrito, they still only gave us one small bowl of chips. When I asked for more, they said it would be $1.25 extra. I just spent $23 for a burrito with all the fixing and they are nickle and diming me for some extra chips. Are you serious??? That's not all, they continued to clean the floor (now with a mop) and I smelled dirty mop water and cleaner the whole time we were eating our lunch. Not very appetizing to say the least. I might come back here, but not for a while, and I would definitely order something else.
author: Rudy G.

description: Just because there are no real taquerias within walking distance doesn't mean you get street credit. Yeah, the salsa is great. Well get the canned version to go and pour it on your less overpriced Mission burrito. You know, the one that actually tastes good. I hear the fish burrito is good. Well, just because one of the items on your menu doesn't suck doesn't warrant the 11$ charge. My best guess for the current good rating is that - due to its general proximity to Haight Street - ppl are generally high when eating and rating this food.
author: Janett R.

description: I ordered the famous Triple Threat after watching Throwdown and because it was now a novelty, I spent $23 (includes tax) for one.  I noticed the burrito wasn't as big as how it looked on TV.  I thought to myself, if a burrito is gonna cost that much and it's called the triple threat, it must be 3x bigger than a normal burrito.  Nope.  It was actually smaller than the burritos I normally get around the Mission.  I must admit though the burrito was good and so was the salsa, but definately not worth $23.  I was planning on taking other people there but I'm glad I checked it out for myself first and those plans have changed and we'll probably never go back again.  By the way, the other burritos there average $10 each.
author: Ben E.

description:
I love you tofu burrito super with refried black beans!

Still will never replace my precious pokez tofu super vegan burrito, but since I am too many miles to count from it I will claim you the almighty awesome tofu burrito! 

now on to the hunt for the perfect nacho (ie not microwaved, yellow shredded cheese and tortilla chips still hot from the grease, no corn chips allowed! anyone have any ideas?)
author: A. Gun n.

description:
This place offers great-tasting, progressive and fast mexican food.  It's nice and clean and the food is up there with some of the best in the city.

In the end, it's not better than El Farolito which in my opinion offers the best fast mexican.  It's also pretty over-priced.  I bought two burritos that would cost me about 15 bucks at El Farolito and paid 25 bucks for em... absurd.  I recommend giving Papalote a chance but, in all honesty, I don't think it lives up to the hype.
author: Alexander T.

description:
I've always loved this place but recently the service has gone down hill.  I can handle rude service...but don't mess up my burrito two time in a row.  

And oh yeah, when I ask you to fix it DON'T give me attitude about it. 

I'm still going to give them 3 starts because when they do make my burrito correctly it's pretty damn good.
author: F B.

description: This place was horrible!! 9$ bland burritos, no flavor at all. The salsa, its not that special either. Everything there tastes like it was out of a package, nothing seems fresh at all. Gaucamole & chips is 8$!! If you ever have the chance to go there, just take 20$ out of your pocket and burn it and that should be about the same experience I had.
author: Casey C.

description:
Papalote re-introduced Mexican food to me and I cannot thank them enough. Since my pescatarian days started, Mexican food hasnt been the same. There's only so many combinations of beans and cheese and tortilla you can eat, so I kinda gave up on Mexican food as a main staple of eating out.

However, Papalote accommodates my eating preferences - fish, shrimp, prawn, veggie, SOYRIZO. I love their soyrizo since it basically gives me a "meat" to get burritos back into my diet.The salsa you get with your chips is really good too. Pretty spicy, but really good.

If i would criticize anything, its their horchata. I wish it wasn't so watered down and that you get more for your buck. But even despite that, I give them a shining recommendation.

5 stars!!!
author: Brian M.

description: I guess I came here because it was quite late one night and there was not really any other place opened, and one time my friend brought back some lunch from there it was a burrito and it seemed decent I suppose now I think of it it was good maybe because I was a new college student and was not really good at picking the choices and places to eat yet, now I reflect on it it was only decent rather than pretty dam good but I thought well if I was to take the bus anywhere every place I go to would be already closed, and the place over on Fulton and Masonic seemed okay because I had the burrito from there once so I sat down and they served some salsa first which seemed decent warm chips seemed tasty then came my taco which really wasn't great, I guess I was expecting too much it turned out more like fast food and that's all it was, there was way too much toppings and not enough taste besides those toppings and I really couldn't concentrate on the tacos itself and after I finished and I took what I had left home I seem to be taking home was what was left of the toppings and some taco shells that was by Ben not any good any more, so I ended up doing was just throwing out the rest, really it was at least something to eat I guess, did I enjoy it, not really, would I go back, if it was absolutely the last thing to eat, maybe
author: Rachel N.

description: Great tasting pescado (fish) super burrito and handmade chips and dip.  Definitely in the top 5 of the best burritos I've ever had, and I've tried many.  As most of the other 600+ reviews have stated prior however, their prices are WAY HIGH.  My burrito to go was $14.  There's several other places in the Mission and elsewhere in the City where you can get a comparable meal for half the price.  Also takes a little bit longer to make your food here as they carefully craft and prepare everything when you order it.  This could be a problem during rush times or if you're in a hurry.  Parking around the restaurant can also be a challenge.  I'll probably now start searching for other places that are equal but cheaper.
author: Darrin K.

description: You have got to be kidding me here. I have read all these reviews thinking mmm I am going to get a great carne asada burrito. NOT. I could have gone to taco bell and got more steak in my taco then I did at this place.  If u wanna pay 10 for rice and beans in a tortilla then be my guest.  There was no salsa bar, the server was eating while I was ordering.  This place is bunk Stick with Taco bell if you want better mexican than this.  other wise you can go to a good place like El Farolito
author: Jason M.

description:
I'm constantly on the search for the "perfect" burrito. I'm vegetarian so it gets kinda limited.  I recently moved to NOPA and quickly became a fan of Papalote.  The SOY RIZO burrito is freaking AMAZING!  It is, in my opinion, the "perfect" burrito.  Make it a super and you're in heaven! 

On top of great food I LOVE the service.  They always come right out and give their salsa (YUM) and chips.  It's mellow, cheap dining that hits the spot in the best of ways!
author: Bobby B.

description:
Papalote is not a taqueria.  I hail from Santa Cruz and know the value of a great taqueria, however, I also value what Papalote has accomplished.  Think of Papalote as a miniature sized In-N-Out, but Mexican.  They cook the meat to order; the ingredients are fresh; the staff is sentient and on point.  Despite their extra care in preparing the food and lack of space, the well-oiled burrito crew delivers food in a more than reasonable waiting period.  Hats off to the Papalote crew!

I'm also a major fan of the punch-hole card.  You know, where you get nine haircuts, or in this case burritos, and the tenth is free.

I would recommend you all trying a super burrito with the refried black beans.  I've never seen refried black beans before Papalote and I really like the combo.  That is, if you're gonna spoil yourself and go super.

They have very unique, blended, and almost creamy salsa.
author: Bill U.

description: I wanted this place to be much better than it is. Last week after seeing them "Beat Bobby Flay" i stopped by and tried the carne asada super burrito. Meh. Taste and quality were mediocre, service was a a little slow. Today I stopped by in an attempt to have a better meal.This time I tried the chorizo con huevos. While waiting 20 minutes for my meal the staff decided to open the door so they could run out a catering order and just left it open taking the place down to a nice balmy 50 degrees. The meal was below average, the tortillas were stale and the eggs were just not good. This place in a town full of very good tacquerias is at the bottom of the list.
author: Jon W.

description: Tried Papalote again, this time successfully getting a super burrito.. still found the burrito to be dry, though. Maybe chicken isn't their specialty.
author: Kathryn B.

description:
Excellent chicken burrito, you need to make it super also. Some good stuff and the sauce that comes with the chips are especially good, put some on the burrito too.
I don't know where else you can get the sauce, it's probably unique to the place. It's a little on the spicy side, but very good.
The order is fast and the portions are big. Good place to eat a fancy burrito.
author: Loi L.

description:
Honestly, save your money and walk a couple blocks down Fulton and eat at Green Chile Kitchen. This place is totally not worth it.

I come here from time to time because it's convenient - I go to USF and live a few blocks away and some of my friends really love it here. I admit I do get cravings for their chips and salsa though, they're actually really good! But the burritos are subpar. I'd rather get a burrito at GCK or El Farolito!
author: Danny H.

description:
Small place. Second try. I remember last time I wasn't super impressed- why did I come back here? Oh right, it was on the way.
I was confused about the line cuz there are people holding numbers milling about, but sometimes you don't see their number and you don't know what they are up to... While I was laughing about their "$9 for 2 tacos item" in my head and figuring out whether the mole was worth trying, some folks breezed past up to the register- demonstrating how it is done. 
So we followed ordering our 2 burritos for $20 (um what? pinkies out, folks!) and waited awkwardly by the door cuz that was the only space left. Got the stuff a while later, and I was pretty hungry so it tasted good, turbo saucy too. This was NOT car food - laundry, please. The super burrito is 2 meals so price wise that kind of evens out, right? The Mole wasn't a blackish Mole which I was hoping for, (the classic choco chili peanut pepita rad mix with sesame seeds on top) I get that a mole is any sauce that has been ground up, but I always hope for that one, and wonder why it isn't in more burritos!  The mans burrito (not Super) was d-r-y so he poured the salsa on it and was ok with that. 
This place made me miss the East O taco trucks, I'll remember that.
Other than competitive eaters, who orders a $20 triple threat burrito?
author: Catherine R.

description:
Not the biggest burritos nor the best in SF(in my humble opinion), but it's the dub music which they play here that draws me in!

Oh, they also get a star for sponsoring the Egyptian Lover gig at Milk Bar last year. Mad respect yo.
author: Patrick W.

description: Great salsa, but prices keep creeping up. $10+ for a burrito is getting a little excessive.
author: J G.

description:
I have heard many rave reviews about Papalote and I was hesistant to try it after I had surfed over to their website to see a lot of gibberish about organic ingredients.  Don't get me wrong, organic is great, but it just didn't seem like it went with Mexican food.  I consider Mexican food to be like my Chinese food, cheap and good.  

However, after running around the Haight for The Go Game, I enjoyed two delicious chicken mole tacos.  They gave a generous amount of chicken and the sauce was tasty.  Only complaint is that they didn't double the tortillas!  If you're going to put so much sauce you have to double the tortillas!  I ended up eating it all in pieces.

I would say I'd come here for a snack and get a couple of tacos for $4.75.  I don't think I'd be too thrilled to drop $8 on a super burrito that isn't so big or a breakfast burrito for $8.75.  Flavors and options seem good at Papalote, the prices seem a little off for the type of cuisine though.
author: Christopher W.

description:
To me, this is one of my favorite burrito places in the city.  Not my favorite (that honor goes to La Fonda in the inner sunset for its amazing Azteca Burrito) but good nonetheless.

Their burritos are of hearty portion, and the chicken is always tasty and tender.  To top it off, when I say I want it spicy, they make it spice, not flamethrower spicy, but a nice heat to it.

The salsa they serve with chips has a nice bite that leaves just the slightest bit of fire on the tongue, and their chips are freshly made.

They are consistent, tasty, and hey they even have a rewards program, buy 10 get 1 free!  Good enough for me!!!
author: Ab B.

description: Easily one of the best burrito joints I've ever been to in my life, and that's saying a lot because i have been to millions. I think the only burrito joint to surpass their awesomeness is located in San Diego off Mission Beach. If I'm even remotely in the area, I definitely make a stop here. It's always a little packed with the USF heads and others from haight, but it's worth it. TRUST ME. The burrito is just an explosion of yumminess in your mouth.
author: Tom I.

description:
MMM mmm good.

Love my Papalote when I'm too lazy to cook, or when I have a craving.  Make sure to get your frequent burrito card punched!
author: Carrie A.

description:
Papalote is pretty awesome. Not only do they have a wide selection of tortillas, killer salsa, and high quality ingredients, they cook your meat after you place your order! Steak, chicken, or prawns are all fantastic, although they tend to fail at cutting the steak, and oftentimes I find myself pulling out half the meat in one bite. Let's try a little harder, guys.

The prices are semi-high considering the burritos are on the smaller side, but if you want a lot of meat you can order the special burrito that comes with steak, chicken AND prawns. I have never ever enjoyed a prawn burrito before, but theirs is so well-cooked, juicy, and a great contrast of textures. 

I dislike that they usually skimp on rice, beans, and all the other ingredients, but I think the tortillas must be small because the burrito always seems at capacity despite the fact that I know there's only seven kernels of rice in there. I think it could be improved if the burrito was bigger, with a better ratio of ingredients. Other than that... fabulous! (but totally different than La Taqueria or other greasy yet classic burrito joints)
author: Amanda C.

description: Great carne asada burrito but the so famous sauce was not hot enough for me
author: Frank B.

description:
One word: Crack Salsa

Doesn't feel as authentic as eating a burrito in the mission, but it will suffice.
author: Ben R.

description: Quick n cool service. Very attractive staff!
author: Justin E.

description:
Dear Papalote,

Please do not feel threatened when i eat mexican food from other restaurants.  Deep down, I still think of you.

Salsa sauce, you were my first...
author: Michael N.

description:
I walk in.
It's loud with music, people, and food.
I order.  Smile.
Pay.  Smile.
Wait for the man to call my number.
31.  Smile.
Walk 3 blocks home.  No smile.
Hot, cheesy, guac covered asade.  Smile.
Smile.
Smile.
Smile.
author: Girls Named Cherise C.

description:
I am totally crushing on the Chicken Mole Super Burrito right now!
No, I can't speak to the vegetarian options that seem to predominate, but I can speak to the complex amazing-ness that is their Mole.  It is smokey and velvety and sweet all mixed in a burrito with moist chicken.  I can easily say its may favorite burrito in the city right now.  It is also "paired" perfectly with a Negro Modelo and some chips.  
I don't even think I have anything to add.  The guys here are waaay friendly and I always seem to find a place to sit.  Plus it is really a pleasant walk afterwards through USF's campus on my way home.  Makes living in the foggy Richmond almost worth it.
author: Sheila Y.

description:
I walked in and at first felt confused...I thought I had walked into Chipotle by accident. But no, it was indeed Papalote....I guess the layout seemed similar to me, so I was taken aback.

Mmm, pretty good stuff here! Had the chicken mole burrito and was pleasantly surprised to see that chips came with the burrito (maybe this is common at other places? *shrug*). Anyway, the burrito was very filling and flavorful. Service was quick.

This Papalote seems like a nice hang-out spot for USF students....I should probably go check out the other Papalote in the Mission to compare the ambience at both locations. 

The only complaint I have is about the cramped seating....but I suppose more people order to-go than eat-in. Hm.
author: Helene K.

description: I feel like I got let down by Yelp. This place is like one of those mexican restaurants you find in the mall. It is on the same level as Chipotle but way more expensive. I got a carne asada burrito and it was nothing special. Meat was flavorless, in fact, if it wasn't for the hot sauce this place would get two stars.
author: Darius A.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  After living through 1/2 of two different menu choices at the taste-bud turning Tango 20, Papalote is a fantastic addition to my neighborhood.  Taqueria Cancun is still my favorite but given the proximity, Papalote is now a regular meal stop. I've had the carne asada and pollo asado burritos.  Big ups for making both with freshly grilled meats when it's not busy enough to have the supply trough full of pre-grilled meat on the other side of the counter.  The house salsa is both unique and delicious-I especially enjoy the chip-dipping-friendly plastic receptacles.  The guacamole is also fresh (bright green in color) and tasty as well.  

Please support this place so I can keep getting my Sunday morning chorizo and egg hangover helper!!!

Just adding this - the salsa is absolutely incredible!  I dream about it smotherd all over my.........burrito.
author: J P.

description:
Shit shit shit!!!  Noooooo!  In my recent review of Papalote in the mission I expressed my deep relief that I did not live anywhere near this place.  (Pescado quesadillas... evil.)

I had successfully managed to ignore the sign over the door of this place for months now.  But this week I walked right by it with the boyfriend (who introduced me to the $%&# quesadillas in the first place) and there it was.  2 blocks from my apartment.

Shit.  

I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day.  I will not eat Papalote every day. 

Screw it.

I'm moving.
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
Best Burrito in San Francisco :) Get the shrimp or the chicken. The mole is also delicious. 

Also - bring a jar and buy the salsa - best.salsa.EVER.
author: linda t.

description:
Nice staff, pretty good burrito, however, not into the $1.25 charged for a cheese addition. However, I have limited myself to shrimp and plain RBC burritos, so I can't really judge until i try some carnitas. Big props for the grilled, deliciously fresh tortillas.

Update: Food snobs beware: I believe they serve pressed chicken. Anyone know what I am talking about?
author: Nicole S.

description:
It's not so much that this place is pricey -- Green Chile Kitchen is more expensive and arguably not as good -- but when I fork over that much for a burrito I want to get coddled a bit.  It's one thing to pay for nachos or guacamole, but they give you literally 15 tortilla chips and charge you for more.  What the fuck.  I find myself waiting for people to leave and snatching their leftover chips.  Seating is also an issue, as is the semi-surly cashier girl.

Incredible salsa, though.
author: S P.

description:
Not overly impressed with this place. The hot sauce is good.

The chicken burrito is just ok. I've had a lot better and for a lot cheaper.

I got the chicken burrito, "super" - with cheese, sour cream and guac is an extra .99 for a total of - a $7.00 mediocre burrito.

This is not a destination taqueria, but since I work close and it's convenient, I may return if I'm dying for a quick bite.
author: Chili B.

description: I don't know why everyone likes this place so much but the burrito was just ok. It's just the sauce that makes this place great. Not enough meat for a guy like me who eats a lot and maybe they should put more variety of meats (cabeza, lengua, pastor and carnitas) perhaps? If you go here, have them put the pico de gallo sauce inside the burrito and not on the side or else you'll be begging for more and they'll charge you for that extra sauce. Be prepared to pay about $9 for a burrito with everything in it. 3 stars go only for the pico de gallo sauce and that's it!
author: JB L.

description: The re-fried black beans are great but the burritos are ok. I don't think it's worth the money. The prawn burrito is $10 plus if you want guacamole & sour cream its $.99 extra.
author: Ammala B.

description:
I came here expecting something really delicious and I was just really dissapointed. About the only thing neat here was the overabundance of hipster-post-teenagers from USF and the surrounding area.

The grill-to-order is nice, but it would be better if it actually tasted good. I ordered some tacos and was sorely dissapointed when I got soggy and flavorless tacos. The salsa was really bland, and the chopped lettuce was not particularly exciting either.

I might come back to give it another try, but definately not ordering tacos or a burrito.
author: Tom S.

description:
Tomorrow I start the Low Carb diet...YIKES!  So, how do I spend my last night of happiness...

Why with a carbo-licious burrito of course!

I am new to this area and I happened to pass by this restaurant a few times.  Tonight I gave it a try and I am more than satisfied.  I'm a vegetarian so I was really pleased to see all the other options.  They also had a whole wheat tortilla available which was great!  

We will see how this low carb thing goes and if I can't handle it...Papalote will be seeing more of me!
author: Dominique T.

description: A damn good burrito that's not a gut bomb. Got the tofu mole with black beans, tons of veggies and rice and cheese. Fresh and melty. Ate the whole thing and didn't slip into a food coma. Next time I'm getting the Soyrizo one. I like their burritos better than Cancun. Eff you, I said it.
author: Laura M.

description: Almost TEN DOLLARS for a burrito with meat and sour cream/salsa/guacamole??  I realize that this Papalote's is located right next to USF, which is occupied with thousands of rich brat students, but seriously?  Ten dollars?  If their salsa wasn't so good, I would boycott.  And Bobby Flay is a joke, it doesn't mean anything that he lost.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Super Veggie Burrito w/ Black Beans and the amazing salsa/chips FTW
author: David C.

description:
Thank god WESTERN ADDITION...errr i mean NOPA (north of the pan handle) is having a foodie renaissance.  Green Chili, Poleng, Papalote - i must  dance for the "reasonably priced and pretty damn tasty restaurant gods" (now dancing emphatically in my boxers adding the occasional pelvic thrust).

No longer do I have to make that trek down to the mission for some authentic mexican food - mad kudos on the salsa by the way.

Not only that...the owner of the joint (MR. E) is also a well known DJ in the SF Bay area.  Musical influences are found all over his joint - flyers visible on the ledge, spiffy tunes coming from the inhouse system, posters of MR. E's gigs placed on the windows.

One thing though, Papalote should consider opening its doors on the late night tip...especially on the weekends when hungry drunk folks from the Poleng Lounge next door are feening for that perfect burrito!
author: J puff marshmellowman C.

description:
As someone who's worked their share of food gigs over the years, I have to say that I really appreciate the lack of turnover at this place. The same people work here for years at a time, and from what I've heard, actually get paid respectable wages. Other bonuses: no loud jukebox, good beer,  good salsa, and very vegetarian and vegan friendly.

A friend of mine also had a running account here for her kids - when they were little, they could come in here and just put their lunch or dinner on their tab (very independent city kids, obviously) and she'd know they were eating (reasonably) healthy food. I find this adorable.

I will say, I wish that they were a bit more offbeat and creative and occasionally had something with cactus in it. But what they do, they do very well.
author: H. S.

description:
Papalote was one of my first comforts when I moved out to San Francisco. I remember thinking how lucky I was that a decent Mexican place was within walking distance. After living here a year though and systematically buying every single item on the menu and expensing it to my company, I do have a couple of comments:

    - First and foremost, what the heck is up with the kites?? They are a little bit creepy and they don't even look cool.
    - Secondly, black refried beans. That's not a common sight. Mainly because this isn't really "authentic". Pretty tasty though.
    - Thirdly, the salsa is pretty effin amazing.
    - Fourthly I was addicted to the burritos for some time until I got a bad case of heartburn. It felt like death. I started writing a will. But after eating burritos for a few days in a row and refusing to eat them while sitting upright, I guess I had it coming to me.
    - Fifthly, the plate with chile verde meat is SO FREKIN DELICIOUS. YUM EVERYWHERE.
    - Sixthly (and this is getting ridiculous), the triple threat burrito is not worth it but I admit that it must be tried.
author: Michelle N.

description:
The first time I went here was with a couple of friends for a late night dinner. And that's usually when I got to Papalote, after a long day and realizing around 9pm that I haven't had dinner yet. Very convenient location at Fulton and Masonic.
For awhile I only got the carne asada burrito, but have recently tried the chile verde, both are superb. I always get my burritos 'super', which adds sour cream, guacamole, and cheese for 99 cents, good deal. The salsa that they give you with tortilla chips is amazing, and there's usually some left to put on your burrito too, YUM.
The staff is always quick and efficient, if there isn't a clear table for you after a rush they will have it clear for you in only a couple minutes.
author: Emily P.

description:
I love these burritos....For two and half years I had the pleasure of attending the USF MBA night program while working full-time. The one positive every Wednesday evening was getting either a carne asada or camerones burrito from Papalote. All the ingredients are fresh and the grilling of the burrito melts the cheese nicely. Great chips and salsa are a bonus.

Papalote is the only restaurant on my cell phone speed-dial.
author: Michael P.

description: The Mission location is just so much better in my opinion. I ordered a tofu molé burrito today and granted my best friend placed the order to-go but they completely forgot the molé!!! This is the second time I've eaten here and I've ordered the same burritos at the 24th Street location and have been charged less over there for some reason.  Luckily I live a few blocks away from the other location. Their chips and salsa are awesome at both places though.
author: Amanda M.

description:
My roommates are die hard Papalote loyalists.  My first experience with Papalote was via the jar of Papalote salsa my roommate keeps in the fridge ;) He said it's the best salsa in the City and I agree!

I'm a regular now to. Their food is top notch and I'm hooked on the garnish of Jicima and Radish that my roommate says is an authentic aid to the digestion of spicy food.  The staff is also really awesome to the regulars and this place is always packed with people!
author: Eric J.

description: The only exceptional thing at Papalote is their amazing salsa.  Like 5 star salsa.  Everyone needs to try that salsa.  Equally lame is that they will charge an extra 50 cents for a tiny extra cup of said amazing salsa.  The triple threat is perhaps their one good burrito.  I haven't tried everything there yet (there is an Adobo Burrito I will try next time I want to buy some salsa which they sell in jars for like $7?) but the ones i have have been only decent or bland.  Something about their burritos is missing that savory umami.  Yet, i think the triple threat does somehow blend a nice briny shrimp flavor with the steak and chicken.  It's actually quite a mystery.  Maybe I need to try the triple threat again.  Maybe the triple threat isn't as good as I remembered it? Maybe that Adobo Burrito is actually amazing.  The bulk of my enjoyment eating here is slathering my burrito with their salsa but about half way through my burrito, this enjoyment ends.  If you are prepared to buy that extra 50 cent mini-cup of their salsa, you might enjoy the 2nd half of your meal as much as your 1st half.
author: Nat L.

description: Went here today for the $20 burrito that my boyfriend and I split. Included steak, chicken, and shrimp. There was shrimp in almost every bite I took. The refried beans are yummy. This isn't my first time here, and I'll be coming back if I'm ever in the area again, BUT I wouldn't go out of my way to get to this place. Their food was good, but not "drive out of your way" good.
author: Maria C.

description: I have been coming here for a few years now and finally came to the realization today after I ordered a chile verde burrito with the rice on the side that this place is pretty far from authentic. Please dont replace the rice with extra beans and skimp me on my meat stacks. I understand that the typical gringo likes rice in their burrito but not this one. Meat, onion, cilantro, maybe a little bit of beans, damn thats the bomb. I must say that they do a great job with their meat, just a little to far from the border for me.
author: Bryan M.

description: What separates Papalote and some other burrito joints is the presentation of the restaurant. The dine-in area is very nicely modeled and has tall ceilings. I also like how the meat is grilled to order. Chips and salsa comes with your food and the salsa is awesome.
author: Lou T.

description: I had heard this place was good, so I walked FOREVER to get to this place.  Walking long distances makes me feel like I am really working hard to get to something good.  I had a super carne asada burrito and it was everything a burrito should be - big and filling!  Was it worth the long walk?  Ehh...I think I'll just drive next time.
author: Aurora L.

description:
I think I prefer the mexican I can find in the Mission, but this was really tastey anyways.

I got a grilled chicken burrito with black refried beans (which was yummy) and from what I hear it is best to stick to the burritos here.  The salsa and chips were nice but they were a little skimpy on the chips.  

I don't really have any desire to go back, but I'd rather find more authentic food options in this city.
author: Amanda M.

description:
This place is a jem of a find! Originally disappointed that Jannah was closed until dinner, Paplote's beckoning sign was a lighthouse that ushered us in with the smells of Mexican grilling and I was never so happy for the change of plans. We walked in and there were a bunch of people eating and we scoped out the food to look at the sizes compared with the prices. Burritos so huge they were being eaten with a knife and fork? Nice. Chips and salsa delivered to each table? Score. Veggies being freshly cut behind the counter for each dish? Sealed the deal. I ordered the grilled vegetable fajitas with corn tortillas and it came with a plate of spanish rice and beans. This was a monstrous plate and for $11.75 it's a really good deal. The veggies were marinated in a delicious sauce and it came with zucchini, eggplant and some carrots (maybe a couple of other things but I was too busy wolfing it down). Tortillas were delicious and warm and I was loving the salsa that comes with the chips. Almost reminded me of a close yet distant relative of the La Vic's infamous orange sauce. Ahh bliss. 

Papalote's is clean, friendly, and in an awesome location. I can't wait to come back and make my way down the quesadilla menu...
author: Emiko T.

description:
Ridiculously good salsa. 
Like, so good you want to smuggle a couple of to-go containers of it home in your jacket and tell guests that you made it yourself.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Though Papalotes (or Pap's as I sometimes refer to it) is an really americanized take on mexican food, I have to say their burritos are BOMB... as well as the salsa.

ITS ALL ABOUT THE FREAKING SALSA. It's not your "typical" salsa kids, so all the haters need to shut up cause who gives a crap if the food is americanized and the salsa isn't chunky. The burritos and the salsa are just sooooooo goooodd. I mean a bean and cheese burrito for like four dollars with a side of chips and salsa if you eat in the restaurant, and it taste good? It doesn't get much better then that.

Oh wait, it could if Paps would stay open later so that me and my friends could get our burrito fix at 2 am when we are coming home. Alas, I am destined to wait another day.


*shirmp burrito with the guac (guacamole that is).*
author: Sarah S.

description: Few friends and I were deciding where we wanted to eat for dinner,  First choice was SO, but turned out to be closed.  Decided on coming here....yes I know a complete 360 from Chinese to eat Mexican or some bastardized version of it.  I ordered triple threat burrito that was featured on Bobby Flay's Throwdown.  The thing was huge, steak, chicken and shrimp.  It was tasty but it's not $22 tasty.  Dear owners of Papalote, please lower your price of this burrito to $15.  The red sauce is good though.
author: A L.

description:
Papalote is good and conveniently located across the street from my apartment. Regular Mexican-style burritos. They're big, and they're made quickly. Granted, you could get them quicker and cheaper in the Mission, but if you're not in the Mission, you can't really get them quicker, now can you? I had a chicken mole burrito and a Mexican coke (since so many Americans like the Coke with cane sugar instead of corn syrup, why don't they make some here? After all, they've got 30 other types of Coke). She had the carnitas super tacos and a horchata. They bring chips out to your table. Ours seemed a bit stale, even though it was the first day, so maybe they brought them over from another store or something. The salsa was mighty tasty, sort of creamy and spicy, which helps the sticking-to-the-chip factor.

Later that week I tried the chicken quesadilla. They marinate this Achiote chicken, and it's just wonderful. Best quesadilla that I can remember. I'm sold.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I'm on a quest to find the best vegetable (not vegetarian--that's very different) nachos in the city and Papalote makes some darn good nachos.  They're made to order, with lots of crispy chips, not too greasy cheese, refried beans, and tons of yummy and garlicky roasted eggplant and zucchini. I'm not a fan of salsa, but if you wanted it, you'd get that too. (Should you not want nachos, the same dish can be had in burrito form.)

Despite ordering a dish that is, essentially, chips with toppings, I always am served a dish of chips with their house salsa, which, though peppery, I enjoy. 

There are only two things about both this location (and their Mission spot) that I dislike are: 1. There is not a whole lot of seating and a lot of it at this location is in the form of a bar; therefore, if you are hoping to go with a group, you had better hope you are lucky enough to score one of the few tables in front. 2. The proximity to USF means lots of hungry students who call their orders in ahead of time making what looks like a decent wait (based on the line in the store) much longer than that. 

Overall, though, Papalote is a super tasty restaurant that I am more than happy to travel to if I suddenly get a craving for those nachos.
author: Katie I.

description:
Wowie wow wow!


 I'll start this off by quoting my friend after we stuffed ourselves here: It's the best healthy burrito I ever had. And he's not lying.


 Chilling out on an unusually hot Sunday, my pals and I were yearning for an overstuffed, beany, meaty, guacamole-infused treat. So off it was to Papalote, and as I entered and looked at the menu, my heart sank. No offense to the veggos out there, but vegan refried beans? Various healthy versions of tortillas? Red flags went up all over my little carnivorous mind, thinking there's no way this would hold up against a typical, meat juice-covered taqueria.


 I was happily proven wrong. I watched the grill in eager anticipation, all the while scooping up as much of their bright orange salsa as I could shovel in my mouth. It's no ordinary salsa, it's like crack salsa! Our orders then arrived, and we shared everything to get a good taste for the food. The vegetarian bean-rice-cheese burrito was surprisingly good. The vegan black refried beans were easily some of the best frijoles I've ever had. The carne asada was cooked to perfection. The guacamole had huge chunks of fresh avocado in it. The chili verde was tasty, if a bit dry. Even the vegan soyrizo tacos that my friend ordered on a lark were delicious, if a little watery.


 In fact, the only bit of whinging that drags a star off the rating is that the tacos are presented in single-tortilla fashion, inducing premature taco meltdown. Sorely disappointed by the taco offense, I slurped at my cane sugar Mexican coke to comfort myself.


 Highly recommended, but stick to the burritos. With a traditional flour tortilla, thankyouverymuch.
author: Omid T.

description:
Word of advice: don't go here with lots of people.  Unless you like getting your food at separate times.

And don't get the nachos, I make better nachos at my house around the corner.

But do get the two tacos, because they are really cheap and they get you a lot of food.  The burritos ain't half bad either, but can come with some funky ingredients (who puts carrots in burritos?).  And personally, I'm a big fan of getting Coca Cola in the bottle (hecho en Mexico).  It's made from sugar and not corn syrup, which is how it should be.

This place does do it for me in terms of SALSA.  They make it sort of, how do you say?, creamy I guess!  I don't know what they do but they must put crack in it- a 'once you start, you can't stop' eating it kind of thing.

As for decor and vibe, I dig it.  There're usually some reggae videos playing on the TV in the corner.  And the staff is friendly.

Whenever I go to Papalote, it's usually on a whim.  The burrito cravings get intense and it's my closest option.
author: Shannon M.

description:
If you're into vegetarian they do offer soyrizo dishes which I was excited to try. Even though I wasn't wowed by any of them I can suggest giving one a try if you're bored with the usual Mexican veggie fare.

Other than that Papalote is just OK. I've given it a fair shot when friends relying on foot wanted mexican and I've had burritos, tacos, and nachos here. The outcome is always the same ... the only PRO to this place is the walking distance. Next time I think I'll try walking east to Cocina Poblana.
author: jizzie b.

description:
I've been getting the super prawn with refried beans and that heavenly salsa. Ri-diculously good burrito.
I recommend calling it in ahead of time, once you've seen and gotten to know the menu that is.
Hard working employees, too.
author: Vale C.

description: Honestly, I think Papalote is a great place! I love their burritos, and definitely LOVED their prawn tacos. They were made fresh (had to wait longer than I would've liked)...and their homemade tortilla chips are really good. They've always been pretty busy when I've gone there...considering I don't usually go when the big lunch/dinner rush is there. I also like Jarritos drinks and any Mexican place that has these are good in my book!
author: Alyssa G.

description: I hit this up when I was last up in San Francisco.  I got the "Triple Threat" burrito, it was awesome!  Their chips are pretty good too.  The salsa is great!  It has a unique flavor, but its very good.  Another bonus, they have PBR tall boys :)  Its a little pricey, but they have a burrito for pretty much anyone.  Next time I wanna try their marinated tofu burrito...
author: Ryan H.

description: This is the (tied) best emotional burrito money can buy. The salsa rocks my world. I could (proven) eat a super rice and bean (half black, half refried) burrito on a spinach tortilla every day of the week. Sometimes for two meals. I had to move out of the country to shed those burrito pounds.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
This place spoils Mexican food for me. In the sense that no other burrito can hold a candle to this place. 

Every piece of meat is cooked fresh to order. I come here at least once a week if not twice. Everything here is great, even the veggie choices and I'm quite the carnivore. Every time I come home from traveling this is one of the first places I choose to eat at. 

I prefer this location over the one in the Mission for a few reasons: 1. there are less people I rarely encounter a line more than 5 deep, 2. I can almost always find a seat here, 3. this is one of the places me and my housemates can always agree on, 4. it's closer to where I live now than the Mission location. 

I'm in Europe right now, and just from writing this review my mouth is watering for a Pollo Burrito!
author: Sasha A.

description:
The best fish taco and burrito hands down.  Everything is so fresh and tasty.

$10+ for a burrito is a tad expensive.

Minus one star for their slow service.  Does it really take over 30 minutes to wrap a burrito?
author: Kate L.

description:
The panhandle is blessed to now have a Papalote! 

Their fish tacos cannot be beat, best in the city... and the friggin salsa they do there is so goddamn good that they sell it? Yes, and worth every penny.

While the wait in line and wait for food is a bit of a drag, the fact that the eats are so stellar make up for this and gets 5 stars.
author: Joe R.

description:
Salsa ... to die for.

refried BLACK beans ... pretty hard to find, and these are damn tasty.

The chips ... also damn good and sometimes really fresh tasting.

It feels a bit ... yuppie, burritos are tasty, but don't always make me feel satisfied. (maybe not greasy enough?)
author: Alex C.

description:
I've been here countless times and it is indeed one of my top bargain eats in all of San Francisco. 

Yea, a lot of people don't consider this an 'authentic' tacqueria. Why? Probably because this place is spotless, uses fresh ingredients, cuts down on the grease and cares about your health. That's just a guess though.

You really can't go wrong with anything here, but you gotta love the burritos. And the chilaquiles here are my all-time favorite post-party breakfast food.
author: Jon N.

description:
I liked my super prawn burrito a lot. the prawns were really good. as was the tomato tortilla it was in. it was a very mushy/watery burrito, and it broke apart since there was too much salsa and/or it wasn't wrapped that well (or maybe i'm just a lousy burrito eater), but it was DELICIOUS.

the closest comparison to papalote would probably be chipotle... americanized mexican food. there's nothing wrong with the food being americanized cuz it can still be good. 

papalote has much more variety than chipotle, ESPECIALLY if you are a vegetarian -- almost half the items are veggie. however, i find the burritos at chipotle tastes fresher. I think it has something to do with the tomato and corn salsa i always get there. BUT papalote i do have to admit was more flavorful overall than chipotle. offering different kinds of tortillas (flour, whole wheat, spinach, tomato) definitely helps.

if i had to pick between the two though, i'd probably go with chipotle, since it doesn't get all over my face as i'm eating it. those things matter!
author: Jessica W.

description:
So glad this place has made it out this way.

So, I'll agree that you'll find more authentic Mexican restaurants.  But this place is healthier, and their vegetarian options are quite varied.  Some Mexican places have similar variety, but Papalote does healthy(ish) veggie Mexican better than any place I've been to.  And it's on the not-too-overpriced side too.

On the downside, parking isn't always that convenient, and service can be a bit slow, especially if it's during the rush.  But, I think it's worth the hassle when I'm in the mood.
author: masa s.

description: went there sith my homie to get the "best burrito in SF" but found out it was $18.99  WHy I ask, I worked at a retail spot who carrried thier sauce and asked the delivery driver why it was so expensive and he said "the products are fresh"  I think other places cook with fresh ingreiediants and dont charge $19  bucks for a burrito.
