That is no reason to ask for 19 bucks for a burrito with shrimp, steak and chicken.  Its not  bigger  then any other burrito.  Had something else and all we could talk about was where we should have gone other then that place.  Not happy with this place. NO RETURN.
author: Mike C.

description:
I used to love the prawn burritos here. It's so expensive though, and recently I haven't really liked it that much. However recently my parents got a Mole burrito, and it's delicious. It's also cheaper than the prawn burrito. Yummy. The place is a bit loud so it's kind of hard to order/hear the people, and the service is kinda slow. Other than that, it's a good place to go to pick up a dinner burrito. 
Oh and the salsa is very unique and yummy! It's pretty spicy I think, but it tastes really good with their tortilla chips.
author: Shizuka L.

description: This place is pretty good. Friendly staff and low prices. LOTS of food for your money. Tons of variety. A little gringo-fied, but solid mostly Mexican food.
author: Lina L.

description: I like papalote. It's really good. I had a carne asada burrito and I liked it a lot...expect the rice was softer than I would have liked. The chips were good, the salsa was good too, but not as great at I thought it would be considering the fact that it was on the 7x7 100 things to eat before you die list. It is pretty expensive for a burrito though. I could get cheaper ones somewhere else. But I think they have the best burritos in that area considering the fact there aren't very many mexican restaurants in this area. it's worth your money if you're a student at USF. The burritos they sell on campus suck, so just come to papalote.
author: Breniel L.

description:
For months, the spot across the street from Albertson's was vacant.  So when I noticed that a mexican spot had opened up in the space last week, I had to go in and try it out.  As I hadn't experienced Papalote before, I really didn't know what kind of treat I was in for.

Looking like a typical grub place, I was expecting the average kind of mexican.  So imagine my surprise when I bit into the amazingly good quality steak in my steak nachos!  It griled perfectly, tender and moist it complimented the yummy nachos.  I also had their Chilli Verde Burrito which was also VERY yum.  The tender chunks of pork just melted in my mouth. And the tangy tomatillo and serrano pepper sauce made my mouth sing!

The spot is not cozy but it's clean and bright. The high chairs are not meant for lingering but they suffice for eating your burrito and run.

I'll definitley come back for pickup next time so I can enjoy the burrito in the comforts of my home.
author: Steffy W.

description:
Best Salsa anywhere hands down PERIOD, EVER!

Get your free fix of extra salsa now, once they have the neighborhood hooked they will start charging for extra like they do on 24th st at the original location.  Seriously - its like crack - but tastier.

Always fresh, always grilled to order - you cannot beat this burrito,
author: Rick R.

description:
I'll start this one with a story. This one time, my friend and I were at Milk and spotted a couple of unmarked pizza boxes, one on each table. Complimentary bar food? Catering for a special occasion? Who cares?! We dove right in, discovering--much to our delight--that it wasn't pizza after all but a quesadilla-type thing stuffed with an unidentifiable yet deliciously addictive ingredient. Our pigging out sesh was soon interrupted by an intimidating-looking dude who approached us going, "Are you eating my food?!" Whoa.

Who could be stupid enough to leave what turned out to be soyrizo quesadillas from Papalote's unattended at a bar?? Dummy. That's what you get 'cause we devoured the whole thing. Like all 10 slices of it.
author: Jenn W.

description:
this is a healthier version of mexican food.  They actually have "soyrizo" which I enjoy in my spinach wrap buritto.  Nicer version of some taquerias.
Good salsa and they have beer!  If you're in the hood (right across the street from Albertsons), check em out for a quick bite.
author: Aga N.

description:
An average grill.  The burritos are all I've tried, and they have been decent.  The spicy sauce they give with the chips is actually quite good, but they are stingy about giving out chips and sauce.  The sizes are large, and the addition of guac and sour cream is only an extra buck (if memory serves) and is worth it as the plain burritos are blah.

Also is a very small place, seating is uncomfortable and crowded during lunch.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Nothing special.  I had the Chile Verde super burrito.  It's like a litmus test for me.  A burrito place makes it or breaks it for me on the chile verde.  The meat itself was pretty good, but the burrito was lacking the complimentary flavors.  I didn't taste any cheese, the guacamole was there but flavorless, and the sour cream was a slight white hue of nothing.  I'm leaving this place to the vegetarians since they seem to be falling over each other trying to get here in the reviews.

Hint: buy a pack of gum (or claim to have) across the street at Albertson's for free parking.

*-------------------update----------------------*
 Papalote, you've won me over.  The chicken mole burrito is tasty.
author: Rob U.

description:
All the time I hear people rave about Papalote and how good it is, but looking through the window, it never seemed appealing. Tonight I was wrangled into going so I decided what the hell, let's see what this place is all about. 

The interior is so hokey. The shiny tables and the cheap utensils in a cramped space turn me off. And the $1 charge for using a debit card was annoying. Give me a break, really. Also, something was real funny with the water. It tasted disgusting. How do you fuck up tap water? Gosh. 

With that said, I thought that the food alone was the best thing about Papalote. The salsa was smooth and delicious, and my super grilled veggie burrito with the black refried beans was tasty. I would maybe go back if I felt in the mood but definitely order to go. The less time spent there the better.

p.s. I tried the mole tofu the other day and it was disgusting.
author: Faye P.

description:
I ate there once, and found it to be mediocre at best.  But, I decided to not write the place off before eating there a second time, so I did just that (ate there a second time, that is).

The chicken mole burrito was most excellent - and it was my first time having anything with a fabled mole sauce, so I really didn't know what to expect.  Well, I think I'm in love - the burrito was quite substantial, and the mole sauce has that nice hint of chocolate, without being overwhelming.

There will definitely be a third visit in the near future!
author: Carly P.

description:
Thank GOODNESS Papalote replaced whatever the F the place was there before - Tango 20 or what?  That place was terrible.  $5 for plantains and $9 for a burrito?  Yikes.

OK, let's start with the positives: salsa, freshness, fish, salsa, no more Tango 20, refried black beans.

Negatives: no carnitas, no baja style fish, no salsa choices, takes awhile to get your order because everything's fresh.

It makes me angry when people say this is the best burrito place in the city.  It's not.  It's really good, but  Pancho Villa and Yellow Taqueria crush 'Lote.  Best mexican in the panhandle, but when you're only competing against Taco Loco, it's not saying much.
author: Matt S.

description:
Grilled chicken super burrito, with black beans and hot salsa. Yum. And make sure to eat every drop of the hot sauce they give you on the side. Smokey and delicious. Not bad prices - and well worth the wait - since they make everything FRESH. 

 Dig it.
author: Alexa S.

description:
"Do you want it spicy?"
"Um...yah."
"Really spicy?"
"Sure."

This is how I ended up with a carne asada burrito filled with slices of freshly cut jalepeno peppers.  Now usually I like it spicy.  I am glad they have two kinds of hot sauce at Paplote, the green bottle of vibrant jalepeno sauce and the red bottle with the smoky chipotle sauce.  Of course this is in addition to their highly addictive orange taqueria salsa, of which they give you one small dish to get you hooked.  After that each additional dish will cost you!  Bring in a jar and they will fill it up and sell it to you.  Yes, you will be craving it later.

Anyway, it turns out that even though I usually use up about a whole bottle of hot sauce on my burrito, the addition of the fresh japepeno peppers really ramped it up.  

I only needed about a half bottle of hot sauce this time.

The burrito was delicious, although getting a grilled tortilla seemed to confuse them and my tortilla ended up being a bit cracked, flaking apart and leaking a bit halfway through the meal.  

But you know what?  They still make a damn fine burrito.
author: Adrian B.

description:
Seeing the rave reviews makes me second guess my mediocre rating for Papalote's, but you know what, it just WASN'T THAT GREAT.

I had a burrito, so maybe I just need to try something else to understand why people looooove this place. It was fine, but nothing special.

The price is right, so I'd definitely come back and try something other than their burritos which I find to be somewhat bland.
author: Sophie D.

description:
First time I had this food someone else had ordered it in and I had no idea where it came from...after the fact I kept thinking about it, wondering where that excellent burrito came from....

Since that point, I've figured out Papalote was the source and now I am hooked!  

Favorite Entree: Mole Chicken Burrito w/ Black Refried Beans - made Super - i.e. w/ Cheese and Guacamole...no Sour Cream - its spicy but not so much so that I can't take it and hits the spots for a (slighly guilty) lunch out!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
a block and 2 half blocks from my house makes this my favorite burrito place in sf.  AND it's actually a damn fine burrito, too.

i feel good about giving them my money in exchange for the fresh ingredients, made-to-order meat and fast, friendly service.

(also, you can buy a big jar of their salsa.  for all the salsa lovers.)
author: Ge O.

description:
I don't know what I can possibly add to the reviews for this place. Especially since I, as a lowly New Yorker, am so totally humbled by (and insanely jealous of) the quality of just about any burrito joint in SF.

As said before, amazing, addictive, delicious salsa. And the soyrizo burrito is nothing short of divine.

Ok... the chilaquiles are basically soggy Doritos, but I can overlook that. Love is blind.
author: Nick E.

description:
YUMMMMMM.
Chalk this up as another delicious super burrito in SF!

I got my food in house and it was really nice to have it brought out on a plate, instead of handed to me in a paper sack like most places.  (Don't worry, sometimes I love the paper sack).  

But I think the key part of my experience there was the chips and salsa they brought out before the burrito was ready.  The salsa was soooo good.  It looked like it would be spicey, but for someone like me who usually orders mild it was perfect and had a very unique taste.  I ended up putting it on every bite of burrito.  

At $6.10, that's worth 5 stars.
author: Levi B.

description:
I think it says a lot that, while training for a marathon, I try to incorporate running routes that will lead me to this mexican haven. 

It's also a motivating factor to run with images of camarones quesadillas and delicious chips and roasted salsa ahead of you.
author: Betsy V.

description:
Excellent experience and great food. 

5:00 call in order to go;  tacos for  7 people.  
5:15 leave work drive up to SF
5:45 arrive at Papalote
5:50 arrive to USF with food in hand for entire class

Entire class satisfied with the tacos (carne asada, chicken, and fish)-priceless!!
author: Shelley B.

description:
If you are a vegan/vegitarian and are searching for a goof place to find pretty good Mexican food, come here!

You don't even need to be a non-meat eater to like this place. The people are friendly, the food is good, and if you go to USF, this will become a staple!

I recommend the black bean dip and a coke.
author: Allison P.

description:
SO delicious!  Right near the bank so whenever I am doing chores I know I'm in for a great lunch.  Their burritos are off the hook and the green sauce on the table is DIVINE.

Sometimes they've gotten my orders wrong but whatever I get tastes good anyway.  The decor is cool and they play AWESOME reggae music.

Sometimes it can be hard to find a spot to eat and it is a little noisy and cold, so it's hard to want to stay and hang out.  Also the horchata is too sweet and not homemade tasting.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Came here often for lunch during summer school. Each time I did not order because I would let my friend Em order for me. She knew the REEL GOOD burritos. She was right every time! Although I like it, I always feel like there is something missing...something to make it the BEST burrito.

I also get the rice water drink. I do not know what it is called because my friend orders that for me as well. LOL.

Not a really helpful review. LOL.

If you want a delicious burrito, and you're nearby Papalote is the place to go!
author: Chatree T.

description:
So, I tried this place for the first time today.
The pros, my husband picked up the burritos to go and they were still superhot by the time he got home. The salsa is very tasty, I'm very much a fan of the roasted tomato pico de gayo they put inside the burrito. I got chicken which was flavored very well and not dry. My hubby got the carne asada and was only okay with it. 
The cons, not enough pico or guacamole. Too much rice and beans, and the chicken was stuck on one side of the burrito with the cheese so half of the eating only tasted like rice and beans. The chips are just eh, I prefer homemade. For 10 bucks you don't need to be all chincy with the toppings.
All in all, way better than Gordos but if I'm going out of my way La Taqueria totally wins on the price.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Best SF burrito outside of the Mission.  

Yes, the chips and salsa are amazing as well.  Personally I find the regular burrito a little dry, the super with guacamole is perfection.  Nice staff too, thanks guys!

So proud to be a neighbor.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
it's true, the salsa kicks ass! i love it.

it was crowded in there on a weekday during lunch, which is a good indication that excellence inhabits Papalote. everything smelled great and looked superb.

i, however, made the mistake of ordering the "Poleng chicken adobo burrito." it was incredibly bland and i'm sad i wasted my time and money on that burrito. but i'm not sure if i should blame Papalote or Poleng, considering Poleng's windows are currently covered in newspaper. either way, i'd like to come back and try something else so i can give it a proper review.
author: Regina C.

description: I went with a bunch of friends and we tried nearly everything. The salsa was good but everything else I thought was just average at best. The burrito tasted uninspiring given all the hype of this place.
author: Mike A.

description:
OK. just when I thought you went and screwed everything up...you completely redeeeeemed yourself! 

Had another order of the tacos and they were legit, no soupy circus of shrimp and tortilla this 'go round.  **insert golf clap here**
author: S M.

description:
Don't Fall Victim
The triple threat burrito as seen on throwdown with Bobby Flay is just ok and is definitely not worth the $20 price. My wife and I went there this evening and decided to split it. It is no bigger than a normal burrito just cost twice as much. I have had better burritos in the city. 
The salsa was good, but only came with a couple of chips. I'm sure that some of the other burritos are good, however get suckered in to the triple threat.
author: sean g.

description: The staff was very friendly and the interior was clean, however the service was terribly slow. Only one person in front of me in line and it still took almost 15 minutes for two burritos.  The chicken burrito was average, but the pork was quite bad, with no flavor and small portions. The chips provided with the salsa were hard and stale, which is unfortunate because the salsa was actually quite tasty. Finally, the price was just not worth it, over $22 for two burritos of marginal quality and old chips. It's a shame, the friendly attitudes aren't matched by the product.
author: Justin B.

description: I feel like this place has gone down in quality a bit, or maybe I've just had my eyes opened the handful of better burrito spots around the city. I'd say they're still in my top 5 range. Their salsa is still bomb but the overpricing issue has only gotten worse so I have to downgrade to four stars.
author: M L.

description: 3 stars for the carne asada super burrito but +1 for the salsa alone.  It was out of this world amazing.  The burrito was ok but nothing special.  The carne asada was good although it didn't fill the burrito and the pieces were too big.  Come here and order whatever you want off the menu just for the chips and salsa, then get some more salsa.
author: Margaret T.

description:
This review may be a bit skewed as I am a fan of almost any Mexican food that I come across.  So be it...

This place on first glance reminds me a lot of Chipotle.  The service was quick and friendly, and I ordered a carne asada burrito with the works.  It was a good burrito, but what really stood out to me was the salsa that came with it.  I'm not sure about exactly what was in it, but it was slightly sweet and went very well with my burrito.  A unique taste experience.

I can't comment much on the interior/seating as we got ours to go, but Papalote is worth checking out at least for the salsa.
author: Karl B.

description: I am one of many who love this place.  They know me.  Vegetarian options are really delicious.  Try it but be warned - you will be addicted.
author: Duanne G.

description:
Convenient. If you are looking for something of a quick lunch and don't have time to head down to Haight, Papalote is an acceptable alternative. While it certainly beats the overpriced crowed zoo that is the USF cafeteria, it isn't that much better.  I usual get the same thing every time; a super bean and rice burrito.  It's pretty hard to mess a bean and rice burrito and getting a super makes it just filling enough. Everything else I've tried has been par at best.  The guacamole also has a weird consistency, almost like scrambled eggs, I really don't know.  Oh, the salsa they give you with the chips is pretty good.

PS. Make sure you stress it if you're getting a vegan option of a meat dish. Or else you might end up tasting chicken for the first time.
author: Chris F.

description:
Sweet burrito loving baby Jesus I am so bored with the burrito craze that mega-franchises like Chipotle are exploiting.  The menu beckoned me when I saw they served fish quesadillas.  I typically dislike quesadillas but thought "oh man, someone is attempting to make quesadillas tasty with fish."

And... holy shit.  They were delicious.  So much so I asked the ladies at the register to tell the cooks.

Definitely recommended.  [Totally makes up for the cockroach soup I had for lunch at a certain Thai place in the Haight that claims to be "best of noodles"...ew.]

[updated:  After giving it a little more thought (and coming down off my fish quesadilla high) I decided it's worth mentioning that the wait time is a little long and the nachos and salsa they serve are weak. Minus one star in hindsight.]
author: Bartosz S.

description:
If you're complaining about the price, go eat the dogfood somewhere else. 

Papalote is AWESOME. The food is fresh, the meat is trustworthy, the people are nice to you. The salsa is just that right spicy oh too spicy.

If in doubt, have some white wine and butter-marinated fish tacos. Wow!
author: Cate F.

description:
I'm so pissed that everyone found out about this place! I used to eat here when it was first open, and now the place always seems to have a huge crowd in it. With that being said, my food comes pretty quickly and it happens to be on of the best Mexican spots in the city. 

My personal favorite: Pollo Asada burritto in a spinach tortilla....SUPER.
author: Joe G.

description:
we hit the one on 24th St right as they opened on Saturday.
My friend said the breakfast burrito was the way to go. That and a mango aqua fresca. Yummers, dat boy was right!
author: Betsey L.

description:
Yummmm! I love their burritos! I love all their options, including tofu and grilled veggies. I also love that I can buy their amazing salsa that I'm obsessed with for days when I can't make it over there or a burrito is just a little too much. 

They also have never messed up my call in order, which I greatly appreciate.
author: Carmen C.

description: I had the $20 super barrito. It was amazing! Shrimp, chicken, and steak, they call it the Tripple Threat. I was very much excited! And it tasted awesome the next day. I want to try more food from they're menu!
author: Kameelah R.

description: Super friendly staff, very fast service and average food. They have bottled coke!
author: J E.

description: Burrito restaurants, I think it's time we had a talk about how little straight up tofu you're willing to put in your fare. It's a shame. Soyrizo is all well and fine, but it's just not the same. You should all take an example from Papalote, which has marinated tofu, grilled and delicious, to add to any burrito or taco you take a fancy to. I've been craving another since the first one I had, and I don't think this desire will ever wane.
author: Bier S.

description: The fish in the pescado burrito is sauteed in butter and white wine. It's about one of the best things I've ever eaten. $9 but totally worth it. Also, the tortillas here are simultaneously crisp and soft and come in many varieties. You must get the pescado burrito.
author: James P.

description: The salsa is made of crack or heroin. Either way Im addicted and go through withdrawals if its not in my fridge.
author: Bri R.

description:
I can confidently say that Papalote's pretty much serves the best burritos in SF/Bay Area (that we've tried..) 

They have 4 different vegetarian & vegan burritos.. all of which are delicious and freshly prepared. They offer whole wheat tortillas, black beans, fresh guacamole.. all good stuff :) Definitely not your typical mexican / burrito shop. The place is clean, staff is friendly, service attentive.

They have always been VERY busy but we've never had to wait more than 10 minutes for our meals. 

The salsa they serve with their chips is AMAZING. I skip the tortilla chips and use the salsa for my burrito. They also serve white radish and jicima slices on the side of the burrito, tasty :)
author: gibronandsahar K.

description: I must admit, I fell in love with papalote's. I think that it is extremely affordable and just plainly incredible. When I was there I had a super steak burrito, and wow was it good. Everything about it just made my taste buds jump. Beyond that, they have probably some of the best salsa I have ever had. Quite frankly i couldn't get enough of it. I would recommend this Mexican food restaurant to anyone who is a lover of Mexican food.
author: Scott P.

description: 6/2012 - Hmmm. Not impressed w the burrito I had. They filled it w way too much rice w a sprinkling ofchicken. I know this bc I gutted the burrito. Although im a huge fan of the salsa in which they now give you comp tortilla chips and their great salsa. last time I ate at their Mission location, they charged. Too bad their food cant match their great tasting salsas.
author: flashegirl e.

description: I just came back from a trip in the Philippines and the hubby said he was craving for Mexican food.  Not your traditional Mexican food spots, but definitely healthy and definitely enjoyable.  So I read somewhere online that the salsa and chips were an item that you must try in SF.  Yeah that salsa was pretty tasty.  I stole my hubby's and used it on my burrito.  Quite addicting.  As far as the burrito, we were both surprised how full this got us.  I could barely get through 1/2 the burrito.  And I didn't feel guilty because it was healthy - chicken, rice, black beans.  The only downside was the cashier wasn't too friendly especially.. But I tend to forget that if the food is worth it.
author: Allison J.

description:
I can't believe the prices that they have now! Papalote's was always such a treat, especially since I'm a broke college student. Now even the rice and bean burrito comes out to like 6 or 7 bucks. It's still delicious but the prices really turned me off :( 

Anyway, my favorites include the Nachos with grilled veggies and the rice and bean burrito. Always make it "super" (sour cream, guacamole, etc). The salsa is amazing. Some think its spicy but I grew up in a Punjabi house, so I'm used to it :)
author: Navi K.

description: Pretty damn good burrito.
author: Johnny J.

description: It is all about the salsa here...so good! Burritos are tasty as well as practically everything else. This was always my go to spot when i lived in the inner richmond...or maybe Gordos.
author: Loe B.

description:
This place never fails me
This is one of the best (hands down) burritos you will have in your life, make sure you some famished!
I often have to wait some time for my burrito, but its well worth the wait. Everything cooked fresh (they dont really have time to let the meats sit around, its so damn busy)
You can always call ahead and have your burrito made before you get there (take out is a nifty idea when the crowd is rather large).
Carne Asada  Burrito with refried black beans...

Did you know that you can buy that amazing SALSA BY THE JAR? YES!!! I'ts like $6 and its AMAZING...
Salsa, yum ... you have to try it ~ YOU GET IT FREE WITH YOUR BURRITO
author: Michael K.

description:
For the past two and half years of law school, I have eaten here at least once a week. (Thank you, convenient Fulton St. location) The burritos are delicious and all the beans are vegan. The bean and rice tacos are my current favorite, with the veggie burrito (carrots and potatoes and mushrooms, oh my!) a close second. So affordable, so fast, so yum. 

Although perhaps not the most authentic, there are so many delicious vegetarian and vegan options to choose from: the mole tofu and soyrizo are awesome! And the salsa for the chips is delicious on everything!

Eating space is limited, and you order at the counter, so I prefer to take mine to go and eat somewhere a little more atmospheric. 

My only complaint? They don't make a broccoli burrito.
author: Michelle M.

description: delicious.. amazing and one of a kind. Split a burrito with a friend if you are not super hungry and do not forget to have your burrito card stamped! you have to order a cokeacola in a glass bottle, perfect pairing with carneasada deliciousness! my heart and s
author: Kathleen P.

description: I think 4 stars is just about the right rating for Papalote. Great food, very casual atmosphere and not particularly comfortable seating. More of a grab&go type of place. But they do have a number of great vegan and vegetarian options, including soyrizo burritos and mole tofu quesadillas!
author: Jeni K.

description:
i LOVE their salsa-that's the four stars alone

shared their triple threat burrito (chicken, carne asada, shrimp) and it was pretty tasty.  a bit too much meat for my liking but all ingredients were pretty fresh and well prepared.  oh and this special burrito is $20.  so unless you're sharing, probably not worth trying.
author: Helen T.

description:
Although I ate my fish burrito from Papalote more than 3.5 hours ago, I am still overstuffed.  My mistake was "super"-fying my burrito.  With all the added sour cream and guac that comes with the "super"-style, my little fish was lost in the mush.  And, by "super"-stylin' my burrito, I managed to raise the cost of the thing to close to $9!  Damn! 

The fish did taste good.  But, my burrito did have the uneven roll - you know how it is, one bite all beans and rice, the other fish and quac.  

I'm giving the place a 3 cuz my boyfriend's soyrizo tacos fell apart.  However, they must have been good cuz he didn't even offer me a bite.   Also, the place was crazy busy which is good for business, but led to a chaotic dining experience (OK, really just ordering was kind of disorderly).  

And a 3 also because really, I just don't like feeling this full HOURS after eating dinner.  I didn't even eat the whole thing!

Dammit, now that I'm thinking it about it, it was good.  I'm gonna go ahead and give it 4 stars.  And I'll give my boyfriend 3 for not offering to let me try his sloppy tacos.
author: Jackie D.

description: I LOVE Papalote!!  The burritos are fabulous, the salsa is to die for, and the owners are great people!!  I dont have anything bad to say about this place.  The Mission location is still my favorite, the atmosphere, the colors, the music, the art...the new one is just as nice but more modern, bar seating and Starbucks lighting.  Great restaurant!!
author: Keagan M.

description:
The best just as long as you stay away from the Mole...that one tasted like beef stew.
The carne asada is the best in the business and the salsa kicks ass...I hear you can buy it in a jar too.
author: S M.

description:
Pretty much totally gringo mexican food, and tasteless.

If you order a "super" taco you get a big pile of romaine lettuce and tomatoes, unseasoned, unflavorful meat and way too much watery guacamole and sour cream. I've never seen romaine lettuce on a taco, I can't say I like it. They add a little jicama into the taco fixings which is a nice touch, but it's not enough to help the meat that is just bland and boring. Expect to be surrounded by starving USCF students who think Mexican food is the best thing since they pizza.

One thing to their credit however is their salsa. It's very ununsual. Sort of a habernero / creamy tomato sauce with a decent kick. It's one thing you can look forward to at this place.
author: Andreas T.

description:
This place is legit.  It's right by my house, and serves up some retardedly good salsa.  The burritos are pretty good, they pull that scam where they charge hella for the burrito, and THEN ask you for another dollar to make it 'super' which means adding the ingredients necessary for a good burrito.  If you know that going in, you can't complain.

It's clean.  They grill everything right there (no delicious steaming bowls of 6 hour old meat).  Kinda a small space, so call ahead and get it to go.

Oh, and guys:  It doesn't make you any more Real or Interesting to poo-poo mexican food that isn't some shitty, dirty hole in the wall.  Believe it or not, it IS possible to make good mexican food without violating health codes.  

Get over yourself, and take those stickers off your messenger bag; I'm not impressed.
author: Michael P.

description:
Love the FISH BURRITO!

Sometimes the fish smells funny...unfortunately,
but most of the time, it's goooooooood.
author: Shine W.

description:
Mmmmm soooo good... I love 2 things here... and when I say that I mean I have built a mental shrine to their Triple Threat burrito and their Fish burrito... 
The Fish Burrito:
Light buttery in  a light tomato sauce soooo good for when you're hungry but want something light.  
The Triple Threat: 
Oh.So.Good!!! Tender steak, big juicy prawns, cooked just right chicken....need i say more? You may not be able to eat this in one sitting but I always get mine w/ pinto beans and w/o rice in a whole wheat tortilla... makes me feel like I'm eating healthy never mind the total lack of a vegetable... don't ruin it for me...
Yuuuuuum I've NEVER had cravings for burritos before Papalote and now I can't get enough!  Dang I can actually taste it now.

I prefer my burritos regular instead of Super (which I believe is cheese, guacamole, and sourcream) I find that it muddles the flavors and I'm not a fan of cold melty spots in my hot food... I may feel differently if I ate it there and had the sauces on the side where i could add it to my forkfulls and have the guac/sourcream be thick and intentional.  But I don't miss it and could do without the extra caloric hit.  

The complimentary chips and dip are good.  The chips are warm and crunchy and the dip is peppery and I have witnessed many a friends pouring it over their burritos... They also have a (pico?"sauce") the chopped tomato/onion/cilantro .... so worth paying extra for.  Oh yah and it comes with a little spiced jicama salad garnish... I always pass on mine but my sister can't get enough.

Tip: If you get your burrito "for here" have it wrapped in foil... if you prefer eating w/ your hands.

(The Mission Location has better guacamole but they also have a 2 star fajita plate... but we won't get into that)
author: Paula Y.

description: Decent  Mexican food with a welcoming dining area,  The meats here are grilled, the chips and salsa are fresh, but the prices are a bit high.  I guess that pays for a cleaner eating area.  Service is a bit slow though, just as the tables don't turn over and sit unoccupied.  Overall it's something to grab if I'm in the area and don't feel like looking parking elsewhere.
author: MTBer I.

description:
Cruised in for lunch today just before noon and was lucky there wasn't a wait. Every time I come here its packed, probably because the food is so awesome! Papalote's really got their shit  together. 

We had two grilled chicken burritos with black beans. Just the right amount of ingredients makes the burrito delicious, and not too filling. Salsa is bomb, and it comes with a side order of chips. Threw in a couple of mexican cokes and we were set --for 22 bucks. They are lacking on the super spicy salsa, but I didn't get up to ask for some so they might have it behind the counter. All in all, a great place for lunch dinner or any of your burrito needs.
author: Nick A.

description: Papalote is in my hood, which makes it really easy to call in and order my burrito to-go and pick it up right when I get there. One thing they don't advertise but I would highly recommend if you're a regular is their burrito punch card. If you buy 10 burritos, your 11th is free! Their fresh made salsa and chips are pretty bomb diggidty and come free with your entree. Also- make sure you get your burrito "super" which means they add guacamole and sour cream for an extra dollar.
author: Sarah T.

description: My new favorite Mexican spot in SF. The grilled chicken is perfectly seasoned. I've had it both in a super burrito and quesadilla. I don't think you can go wrong. I've also had the carne asada which is good but doesn't stand out as much. I hear the prawns are a good choice too. Great salsa btw. Apparently you can buy mason jars of it for home. Question, do they have giant tankers of salsa for sale?
author: Mike C.

description: I haven't been to Papalote in about 4-5 years, and my view of it hasn't changed much since.  I just don't understand why people love it so much.  When I went long ago, I liked that they had a veggie/grilled veggie burrito - up until they started putting in what I thought to be filler like grilled carrots and potatoes (if there are going to be potatoes, it better be a mf-ing San Diego-style California burrito).  Having been ruined (in a good way) by Sarita's Taco Shop, I'm now always looking for a NorCal equivalent of a superb shrimp burrito.  It wouldn't be San Franciscan if they didn't offer things like whole wheat tortillas and soyrizo, but even with that, black beans, and Papalote's famed salsa, the goodness of the burrito was mainly assisted by the fact that I was very hungry.  Maybe I'll see you again in another five years Papalote, but until then, you can find me at Little Chihuahua.
author: Jenn C.

description: Being new to the city I was impressed with the freshness even after reading everyones gripes about the new prices. I understand the grievance about making such drastic $ changes due to a recent celebrity chef appearance. However it was still really great. The salsa was phenomenal and the chips were still super hot and extremely fresh. I ordered the Super Chile Verde Burrito and it was one of the better burrito's I've had in a decade. The pork was perfectly flavored and the crispyness of the tortilla was golden brown perfection. I look forward to my next experience here for sure.
author: Tyler B.

description:
I used to love this place, and the food is excellent. Salsa is amazing, however....

We spent $25 on 2 burritos and 2 coronas. We ate in the resteraunt. After they brought my chips, i devoured the salsa the came with it. They then brought my burrito, and i went to refill the salsa. At this point they informed me that they where now charging $0.55 for a refill of salsa. (which wasnt posted anywhere, not even on the menu)

 I've seen this before when ordering out, or taking a to go cup, but not when dining in. Not after dropping $25 on a meal that should have cost maybe $20 max. 

After getting over my initial anger of being charged extra for a small cup of salsa, i went to take my $0.55 to the guy behind the counter, and he informed me i'd have to wait in the now 6 person deep line in order to pay the $0.55 for my salsa. At this point it took every once of restraint to not flip my loose change into their bucket of refriend beans and walk out. 

Never again! The Little Chihuahua is closer, and lets me have all the salsa my heart desires.
author: J Z.

description: I really don't know why this place has 4 stars. Possibly the non-vegetarian selections are better than the vegetarian ones. They at least try to be interesting with vegetarian burritos and such, but nothing I have tried so far has been any good. Green Chili Kitchen, just a few blocks away, is a MUCH better option for this area, I think.
author: Robyn C.

description: I really don't have time to write reviews, none the less a bad one.  This is only based on the fact that an $8 burrito comes with 1  2oz salsa and ask for any extra and it's extra charge. FOR REALS! Major fail.  Won't take my burrito $ again.
author: Matthew G.

description:
They have a size quota, my clairvoyance breathes new life everytime i end up at this upstart. I always look at their innovative burro's and think " why didn't the assembly bloke just keep packin'? Vegans like bulk. Check out any supermarket." Their grilled tofu has become my liasons dangerous, overflowing with attractive textures and features, boasting to others periodically about our rather ghoulish rendezvous exploits. What a martyr it has become in it's own head, such a dashing example of exorbitant arrogance. See, my psyche personifies "inanimate to the naked eye" curds, making them into bastions of cunning, of sexual dominance and pulverising misanthropia. They taste like nefariously coagulated tandoori bricks in a thriving wheat compound alongside my other chief nutritive booty call's. What the fuck else am i supposed to say?


p.s. try the god forsaken salsa already. I mean, what is with you self appointedly keen tallywhackers, akin to grease reverance? Too "fresh mex" for you unctuous purist artery mercenary's? I don't want to live forever either, but i do want to feel better while I'm here. You might even walk away from this place without a death puddle in your ostensibly hemorrhaged colon (cuz yah know its inevitable).......i need a dust bin.
author: Christopher J.

description:
I actually wanted to give Papalote 2 stars because everytime I have it I am very unsatisfied.  But then I felt guilty becuase its not like it is really bad...its just, well it is just unsatisfying.  As lazy as I am I would rather get in my car, drive to the Mission, deal with parking, etc  to get a burrito rather than make the short walk here.

I'll say 3 stars instead of 2 becuase the guacamole is tasty and fresh
author: b s.

description:
I am very spoiled that Papalote is my neighborhood burrito spot. 

Bias aside, its one of my favorite burritos in the Bay (Taqueria La Morena in SSFand San Jose Taqueria in San Rafael are the others).

Their hot salsa is RIDICULOUS. I love it. I love it so much i take baths in it. Not really...but i do buy it by the jar to have in the fridge.

I generally get a pollo burrito, but sometimes I get crazy and get pollo and camarones...which is again, RIDICULOUS. 

When I am in the mood for a snack and not a burrito (rare occasion), I turn to their nachos which are loaded with beans and more chicken (or your choice of meat) than you can pile on a chip.

Needless to say, I love this place...and so should you.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Papalote stole my heart from El Metate. I had absolutely no idea a vegan burrito could be so good! The grilled tofu con achiote is to die for and they even serve the elusive black refried bean. The veggie selection is awesome too. You can choose from a zucchini/eggplant combo or potato/carrot/mushroom, or if you don't like your veggies mixed together you can just add one.
The only downside is that my burrito cost $8.00, but that's because I'm greedy and had to stuff it with everything imaginable. A regular tofu burrito with rice beans and salsa is $5.15, and with the addition of guacamole that's all you really need. Not super duper cheap, but it's money well spent, for sure.
author: .'antigone' ..

description:
So I live in this hood, and eat here pretty often.  It's tough though when you call in your order and then you have to stand in a long line of college kids that all pay individually with check cards.  I mean cmon, a burrito is like $7. Plus everyone in line is stoned or on their cell, and the guy at the register is also taking the phone orders.  

This probably happens to me about 50% of the time, and I usually walk there right after I order.  After living inthe Mission, it's definitely the slowest burrito spot I've been to in SF.

Otherwise the salsa is bomb, the burrito's aren't big but they are good and you can get black refried beans.  Good menu for the veggie's and their mole is pretty good.  Sometimes they have crazy Korean breakdancer videos which can make your wait seem only half as bad, and you gotta give them a point for PBR tallboys in a can.
author: Pedro B.

description:
The salsa here is fabulous. It is 4.5 stars in and of itself. 

I usually get the nachos with grilled tofu or super rice and beans burrito (my favorite right now, the refried black beans really do it for me.) I've also gotten the breakfast burrito with soyrizo and regular chorizo, super burritos with grilled and regular veggies. The grilled tofu is outstanding and works perfectly on the nachos. I can't tell the difference between chorizo and soyrizo but that's probably because I drown everything I get in the salsa. I think the regular veggies are better than the grilled ones, the grilled ones can be a little soggy.

I give this place 4 stars because the nachos aren't quite robust enough. They just seem like they need something but I can put my finger on what it is. Maybe more pico de gallo? Not sure.
author: Mandy K.

description:
I love me some Mission burritos, and this is not a Mission burrito. But comparing the two would be apples to oranges. 

Papalote burritos are delicious in a way that doesn't make your stomach hurt so much.  The ingredients are clearly fresh, the meat high quality. And there must be crack in that special blended salsa, it's so addictive.  Put this way: I don't feel guilty when I get a Papalote burrito for dinner. I actually feel like I'm putting good food in my body.
author: Celeste S.

description:
Best Salsa! I am actually making it a tradition with my friends that I buy a Jar of it for the 49er season opener and the Superbowl as my potluck. 

I love Mexican food, especially the greasy roachcoach style ones. And with that being said, the Best way to describe Papalote's is that it is like an organic style from the regular spots. It a fresher taste to me than the greasy spots. Really good burritos!

Another plus is they bump mixtapes/GOOD hip hop/ GOOD music while you eat. That is actually a great aesthetic to the spot.

Every time I look at the menu, I would see the "Triple Threat Burrito." Never tried it before, but it sounds krazy. I think I'll man up and try that next time I go.
author: Anton A.

description: Yeah. Best burritos in SF. And that IS saying something... Soyriso burritos? Awesome!
author: Robb J.

description: My daughter and I think Papalote is amazing. I love the fish tacos---so fresh and my daughter likes everything! :-) Smile from daughter age 6!
author: Katharine A.

description:
The chicken super burrito is divine. The shrimp super burrito is divine. The steak super burrito is divine. (Always make it a super burrito! You'll love it! It includes the works sour cream, guac, etc.) The staff is friendly, the atmosphere is clean and fast-paced, but it's kind of cramped especially during lunch time and dinner time.

I got the tacos once and they were good too. But I always get a burrito now. Also, the quesadillas are good but you might as well get a burrito for the price that you would pay. Just saying. 

Papalote's salsa/ sauce is #1. F what you heard. They even sell it in a jar wit a label now haha. LEGIT! I think it's better than La Vic's (in san Jose) special orange sauce.
author: upper d.

description:
The best burrito in the city, if not anywhere.

When people come visit us and ask where to eat, we all instantaneously say "Papalote's." Everything I've ever had there is delicious. The food is fresh and a creative twist on traditional Mexican. My standards are the Carne Asada and Chile Verde super burritos. I would never ever order fish at most other relatively-fast food joints, but their Pescado Quesadillas and Burritos are to die for. The fish is sweet and buttery and delicious.

I think it's the fantastic sauces and salsas that make the food here. And everything comes with a little side of jicama (mexican potato).
author: Allison S.

description: SUPREME NACHOS! their homemade salsa by the jar is the best addition to my fridge since trader joes goat cheese medallions.
author: Lindsey H.

description: Just as good as the Mission location with a couple added advantages. Most notably it's cleaner and more organized than the Valencia location. While you can find a better burrito in SF this place takes the cake if your looking for non-meat filled options (IE shrimp, fish, soyrizo, etc.). My favorite by far are the fish and shrimp burritos, they're really flavorful and I think more enjoyable than the chicken or vegetable options available here. It goes with out saying that the salsa here is addictive like crack (is there olive oil in it or is it just me?). Try the spinach tortilla, it's delicious and nutritious!
author: Alex D.

description:
Customer service here is HORRIBBLEEEE!!...I've been here twice, and
 each time they managed to screw up my order. The wait for just ordering a burrito to go was like 20min, CMON MANNN!! All the hype is overated n overpriced!!! If im gonna pay all that extra $$$$ at least get the damn order straight!!!  You guyz did manage to get a couple stars from me for your chicken adobo but I'll never go there again....
author: D V.

description: it was everything i ever dreamed of in a burrito.  I had the carne asada and now i'm screwed - I can't stop craving it.  Damn this places is AMAAAAAZING.
author: Megan M.

description:
I have had three incredible dining experiences here. This gets 5 stars for a couple of reasons. First, they have the bottled Mexican Coke. Nobody can front on soda made with sugar instead of that corn syrup. Second, everything is prepared fresh. It kills me when people really rave about their "mission burritos" when they have all of their ingredients sitting around in a steam tray container. Fresh made is where it is at for me. Next, the carne asada is top notch. I have had the tacos and the plate, and both are equally outstanding. Last, I would like to address the salsa. I have not tasted salsa like that since eating rolled tacos at Roberto's taco shop in San Diego. This is some ass kicking salsa. Highly recommended for those looking for proper Mexican food.

UPDATE:
-1 star for you. I ate some chorizo and eggs. How can you F up chorizo? Tsk tsk. I will stick with what got me here, but please. Chorizo no no.
author: Jason S.

description:
What this!  A taqueria that's clean and its not a baja fresh.  If I had never been recommended to try it, I would just walk by.  Although the line was overbearing--considering all I wanted a a veggie quesadilla--, well worth the wait.  The veggies were quite fresh, especially with their hot salsa, which makes your tongue tingle like pop rocks.

Keep in mind, this is not an official super burrito review and will update as soon as my mexican cravings return.
author: John P.

description:
Papalote never lets me down when I'm craving a delicious burrito.  They have other things too that look quite good such as tacos, quesadillas...  

Don't pass up the salsa.  Its a gift from god to the world!
author: Jonathan G.

description:
I've been to Papalote a few times with a bunch of friends, and can say the place is okay, I guess.  The first time I went there, I had a chicken burrito, and it was okay.  I thought it was somewhat empty compared to other burrito places I have been to, and the only thing in the burrito that there was a lot of was lettece.
The next timeI went I had a cheese quesedilla.  It was only 3.00, but, I see why.  I wasn't expecting for it to be big because there was only cheese in it, but, I did expect it to be hot and the toritlla to be soft and flaky, not hard.  I would recommend it if you are hungry and want to eat anything to fill yout appetite, but if you are looking for really yummy food, find another place,
author: Lisa H.

description:
In a town with more taquerias than gas stations, it's hard to have a favorite...but damn that's some good salsa!  Really, just put that magical concoction on whatever you're eating and voila! delicious

Also, you don't feel like you need to deprive yourself of anything yummy for a week after visiting, the food is much lighter and fresher than any other taqueria I've had.  Get yo' Mexican food fix with minimal guilt!

Haven't tried the Divis location, heard it wasn't as good though

The most authentic, no---but super tasty.  The tacos de pescado are a must---the fish isn't fried, but sauteed in garlicky wine deliciousness
author: Ms J A.

description:
The best stop for vegetarian burritos in The Mission! Try the refried black beans in your favorite burrito. (I recommend the Grilled Veggie.) The prices are higher than some other places in the area but worth it. 

The salsa is some of the best I've ever tasted, and you can order it by the jar to take home. It's not mild either.

The place is crowded and hot at meal times, so try to hit on the off hours for maximum enjoyment.
author: Jen B.

description:
After reading the review of another displaced San Diegan (San Diegoan?) and feeling her pain on the lack of good mex for the socal palate, I was anxious to give this place a try.

Boy was I glad I did! Although parking was horrendous and it was raining, once I finally got a spot and got in there I ordered a carne asada burrito. It was simple: meat, beans, rice, cheese, pico de gallo... but before the guy behind the counter wrapped it up I asked him to "make it hot." He looked at me and said "Caliente?" and I nodded my head in anxious anticipation.

The salsa he dumped on the carne was orange and just looked like it would make me sweat, which for some reason is part of what makes a good burrito to me. When I finally got home and ate the burrito, the salsa wasn't too hot but it was very flavorful. The carne was a little overdone for my taste, I usually like it a little more juicy. The tortilla was grilled perfectly, and the pinto beans and rice worked well. The burrito also wasn't buried in pico de gallo, which was much appreciated.

Overall this was by far the best burrito I've had in SF since I moved up here and I'll be going back and ordering more when I need my fix.
author: Bryan Z.

description:
I can't believe I'm eating Mexican AGAIN...I just had a burrito yesterday from a Mission joint - which was a happy experience.  Too bad I can't remember the name of said burrito joint - my buddy had one waiting for me in exchange for some moving help.  

I live in the hood and was stoked when Papalote Fulton opened.  So was my veg girlfriend.  This place has great Soyrizo burritos along with the ole Carne Asada choice.  

I never wait in line either....I call my order for pick up before I leave my apartment, I have the number in my phone.  My other trick is to pull in the Lucky's/Wamu ATM driveway, dart in and pick up my piping hot food.  (Definitely NOT cool with those businesses, but hey, try to catch me!)

Also, they have the punch card, which adds up, especially if you pick up for others and bring 'em back.  The register girls have always been cool to deal with - fast service with a smile.  The other workers seem to communicate with the customers as little as possible, but they are busy serving' up the goodness.

I love the reggae music which seems to be playing constantly.  Ya Mon!  They have a spot for DJ/Band flayers too - always interesting.  Being a musician myself, they get an extra star for that.  

My first Yelp Review, this is fun!  I figured I'd start on a positive note, so I reviewed one of my favorite places first....
author: Hawk W.

description:
Why  it seems like only yesterday my friend Mumbles Lundy told me of this "hella good" taqueria within walking distance. I could never remember its name. 

Now I go to Papalote a few times a month. The carne asada super burrito is belly gratifying and their salsa is unreal. 

My only criticism is of the nachos which were very lacking. I still highly encourage you to go to Papalotes if you want an excellent burrito and if you don't stop reading this right now, I don't respect you and never will.
author: Evan O.

description:
the last couple of times i have had a burrito i have stopped halfway through, my mouth full of beans and salsa, tossed aside the stuffed tortilla and declared in a destitute tone of voice "i think i am over burritos" and proceeded with some rather melodramatic sighing. you see, burritos are the food of life, a gift from the gods, and should be enjoyed by all. as a vegetarian i was soooooooooooooooo EFFING sick of the typical mixed veggies, bean and cheese, fajitas without the meat variety offered by other taquerias.

enter papalote. there are as many vegetarian options on this menu as there are meat! at papalote i can have TWO varieties of grilled veggies, soyrizo, and tofu. you can only imagine my joy when last night i bit into my grilled tofu with achiote and vegan black refried bean burrito to discover that i do indeed still have love for this smorgasbord wrapped in a warm, grilled, whole wheat tortilla. burritos are completely pocketable, hand held, and relatively mess free (if you are careful to slurp those beans!).  next time i think i will go on with my bad self and order tofu with grilled veggies. YES. thank you, papalote, for restoring my faith in burritos!
author: Rachael S.

description:
decent portions for a decent price. this place never fails to deliver when we are in between classes and have to eat fast. 

I like how they have the normal selection and several specialty options too like prawn seafood etc. 

the salsa was delicious, just the right amount of spicy.
author: Scarlet S.

description: After hours of shopping and walking around in the rain, you can bet we built up an appetite. Starving, we were. We wanted to venture out to the Mission to inhale the burrito that beat Bobby Flay in the burrito throwdown. So we did. We waited. A while. But mission completed, we satisfied our hunger with the winning Triple Threat Burrito! Grilled chicken, carne asada and camarones wrapped in a blanket called a white flour tortilla. Goodness in every bite! Not sure I'd pay $19.95 for a burrito on a regular basis, but it hit the spot. We ordered two and split it amongst the four of us - plus we ordered other things off the menu to fill in the holes of hunger. Glad we got to try it. No doubt, it was delicious but just because the burrito beat Bobby Flay's, I don't think you needed to hike the price so high! You might scare some of your loyal patrons (and possible new ones) away!
author: Shaye G.

description:
2 Things I regret in my life:

1.) My marriage 
2.) That,  I never came to this place sooner!

Happy 10th anniversary! My friend Miguel, the owner, he ROCKS!
author: Sheila S.

description: The best burrito I've ever had!  I'm a pretty picker eater - especially when it comes to Mexican food.  I tend not to like salsa but theirs is the only one I've ever gone back for thirds.  Creamy, smooth, and a little spicy, it's so yummy!  I love how they always sear the burrito after it's been made so everything is hot and cooked to perfection.  The prices are a little outrageous but such a delicious spot that I can't resist going.
author: Maya G.

description: came here tonight and had a chorizo con queso, a super chicken mole burrito and a super chile verde burrito. the burritos were bland, super mushy, and quite possibly the worst burritos i've ever had. the chorizo con queso was a little better, but i don't think you can ever go wrong with melted cheese over greasy chorizo. i don't understand all the rave reviews about their burritos. they're bland, gross, and over priced. this is my third time here and the first two times were just as bad but i thought i'd give this place another try. big mistake and a waste of money. i will never come back again.
author: Robbie R.

description: The adobo burrito was ok. Was hoping for more of the adobo flavor to make an impression on my tastebuds...  I was a bit underwhelmed
author: Glenn M.

description: Excellent chicken burrito, and Papalote has the best salsa in the city.  I moved a block away...which is proving to be dangerous.
author: Allison S.

description: Living in San Francisco, I hold all Mexican food to a high standard. I came here with a friend and ordered a chili verde burrito. General portion but meh on the taste. Let's say I've had better. The salsa was delish though... a spicy dance on my tongue. I don't think I'll be returning.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Soyrizo, is the bomb.  Im not veggie, but If I lived next door to a Papalote it could become a reality.  Soyrizo is the real deal, and dank in any of Papa's various manners of serving.  Never really ventured outside of the Sotrizo fence, but I'm sure its all delicious.

This spot is much easier to deal w/ than the Mission location.  Finally, a burrito joint that will be there for longer than a few months.
author: Kevin Q.

description:
Hands down my favorite burrito place in the city.

Disclaimer: I'm a vegetarian and I do not go in for the SF-trope that greasy and dirty="authentic" so if you are looking meat or street cred you can move on.

I just moved back into the city after a ill-advised sojourn back in Oakland (I'm from Oakland, so I feel justified in my smack talk) and I just about fainted when I realized that Papalote, that constant source of temptation on my former walk back home from 24th St BART, had opened a second branch a mere 3 blocks from my house.

Now I go through one of their frequent-burrito-buyer cards more frequently than I care to admit.

The ingredients are always fresh and healthy.

My go-to order is Tofu Mole, regular, with black refried beans. If tofu does not scare you in a burrito, do yourself a favor a try it.

Their marinated tofu and soyrizo are great options for the vegetarian as well.

My meat-aphile friends swear by their carne asada.

Their much rhapsodized salsa is no joke.
author: Jory C.

description: Still can't get past the somewhat soggy burritos and still not as flavorful as some other places... (personal preference perhaps) But I've discovered that if you ask for the chicken adobo on a platter or in the burrito you're in for a good surprise. I don't think it is on the menu specifically, but there it is a nice pot at the end of the counter waiting for someone to eat it.... This alone (well perhaps the very small tub of sauce included in the meal for the chips) is worth the visit.
author: Dave P.

description: These burritos are awesome and huge.  Creamy, spicy dipping sauces with chips on the tables, although the tables were really wobbly.  Yummy.
author: CC P.

description:
shop reminds me of chipotle... 

7 bucks for a mid-size carne asada burrito.  a bit overpriced, no?...  8/
seasoned meat, beans, onions, guacamole.  
not bad, a bit on the saltier side, saw more beans than meat, and so little guacamole.
free chips and dipping sauce.
author: Ethan L.

description: Good burritos (I always get chicken) and I've gotten the quesadillas once and they were pretty simple but good.  The salsa is really really good (chips and salsa come complimentary with your order).  We usually grab our food to go since the place is packed and there is not much room to sit and eat.  Great burritos for a great price.
author: Natasha T.

description:
I went to lunch at Papalote on the recommendation of a friend and I was quite disappointed.  The only thing that didn't disappoint was the price.

Service - Placing Order:  I came at 1pm on a Monday and there were two people in front of me and one person taking orders.  It took 10 minutes for the counter assistant to take two orders.  The counter assistant was too busy talking to the customers who had already ate and had cute babies with them rather than focusing on assisting customers in line.

Service - Waiting for Food:  I sat down in the restaurant and waited 20 minutes for an order of tacos and an aquas frescas. The restaurant was not busy.  I didn't understand why it took 20 minutes - the meat I ordered was not one of the "cooked to order" dishes.  My frescas didn't arrive until after the food came.  A neighbor at another table had a similar experience.  While I waited, I saw staff from the kitchen come out to the dining room and eat and finish their lunch, while I sat waiting for mine.

Food:  After the 30 minutes I had been there, I was really looking forward to the tacos.  They were disappointing.  The taco was wet and had to be eaten with a fork.  The taco was loaded with salad and the meat was over salted.  I couldn't finish eating it because it was a mess.

I took notice of what other folks were eating, and while I didn't order a burrito, I was shocked how small they were for the price they were charging.  Papalote is crossed off my list.
author: Gary M.

description:
you are a minute walk away from my apartment, tempting me away from cooking more.  thank you for your tasty and convenient food.

i order one of two things:
-a chile verde burrito, with black beans (whole or refried), super style, on whole wheat tortilla if i remember, or
-two fish tacos, never super

always with an extra salsa. really, 50 cents extra?  papalote salsa, you have ruined my principles.
author: jane d.

description:
The salsa is super, but that's where the complements end from me. I'm a mexican food super snob and anyone who gives this place five stars is obviously from the east coast. Not that I don't like people from the east coast, but I find that all my friends from there have absolutely no idea what there talking about when it comes to Mexican food and none of them seem to be able to handle any spice. My LA taqueria upbringing, has made me realize that not all burritos are created equal and I've been a privlaged burrito consumer all my life.

Just feel like it's way too white bread, and will take a taco truck over the "lote" any-day, but then again I would never even consider getting a tofu burrito, not that theres anything wrong with that..

Maybe there should be a separate category for "wonder" taquerias?
author: Milo G.

description:
I am a born and bred San Diegan, so needless to say, Mexican food is my version of comfort food. Some like mashed potatoes, I like refried beans. The only concern I had about moving to San Francisco was the quality and availability of Mexican food.

So after last night, a night of one too many glasses of wine, I decided to make my way to Papalote today as recovery. 

I'll say what seems to be the cliched thing about this place; I loved the salsa. I have never, ever seen salsa made with cream. While I tend to be a bit traditional when it comes to my salsa, I thought it was awesome. I also liked how I could get refried black beans. 

It's not as good as my neighborhood taco shop back in San Diego, but I do believe it will fill the void between holiday visits back home. I'll definitely be making stops here when I need a burrito.
author: Emily M.

description:
This review is coming from someone who exclusively eats Gordos when craving for a burrito. Friends were in town and saw papalote on throw down with bobby flay so we decided to try it out. I saw the Throwdown episode and was really jones-in for the triple threat burrito (steak, prawn, chicken) but when I got there I saw it was 20 dollars. ARE YOU KIDDING ME? I might as well drive to San Jose, go to Iguanas and get the 5lb burrito for 15!!! Talk about a rip off. Does anyone even order that? I got a super carne asada burrito which came out to be an expensive 10 dollars AND bottled pop so you have to pay for more. It feels like these people got arrogant that they got on the food network so they really cheap out and make you pay more than you would at Farolito or Gordos. The burrito was okay. They grill the tortilla which Gordos doesn't do and that was a plus, but wasn't good enough to convert me. I'll stick with gordos. Speaking of that, I'm going to go get one now!

By the way-the salsa for their chips is REALLY good. It must have sour cream in it because it is thick. Put that on Gordos instead of the chile verde please!!!!
author: Patrick M.

description:
I had not visited Papalote in a very long time since moving to the Peninsula; but now that I am back in the city i figured it was a good time to visit again. 

BIG MISTAKE! How disappointing! I had never been to the location on Fulton but it is the closest one to my house. OH GOSH! the moment we walked in we were greeted by the bussing station full of dirty dishes and garbage and the strongest smell of pinesol!! ush! Strong smell of pinesol means dirty restroom in my book! Disgusting! The entire place was dirty and cramped! I was stunned!! I know the owners very well and was so suprised to find such a mess at this new location! There were 4-5 people behind the dirty counter and not one could move and go clean the tables! wow! 

I ordered a marinated tofu burrito and my boyfriend ordered a simple shrimp burrito. Disappointed again! The guacamole on my burrito was sour which means it had been sitting un-refrigerated for way too long.. ugh just the thought makes my stomach turn. And the tofu was certainly not marinated. HOW DISAPPOINTED!! I paid $20.00 for 2 burritos!!!!

One star because i love the salsa. Nothing else. Sorry to say i won't be going back.
author: Lizette P.

description:
I found out about this place through yelp and some of my friends. I read/heard great things about this place, and to be honest I'm a little disappointed, but I think it's only because I had such high expectations of this place.

The food is pretty good for the price, a little bit overrated in my opinion. The place is small but has this comfy feel to it.

I got there on tuesday around 1PM with my friend, and we ended up eating there at 2, because... what else?? we had a hard time finding PARKING SPACE. 

overall it's just okay.
author: Dee S.

description:
"Long time listener, first time caller" or so I am naming my first Yelp review. 

It was Saturday evening, circa 5 pm. I was starving. I was feeling a burrito. I live in the Richmond, so not exactly burrito heaven. The two Chipotles were too far. But then I remembered that I had read some good reviews about Papalote on Yelp. And it was a hop, skip and a jump down good ol' Fulton. So I decided to go for it. 

Reasons why I feel good about Papalote:
1. Papalote had a parking garage across the street, so I did not have to experience massive frustration mixed with starvation. 
2. I am vegetarian, and Papalote decided to show some love by serving marinated tofu, soyrizo, wheat tortillas, and all three bean choices were veggie. 
3. I thought the employees were friendly. 
4. For some reason I thought I was going to walk to into a restaurant with a bunch of hipsters eating burritos, but it was not so, and I had a lovely time eating my burrito solo at their long burrito counter. 
5. They serve chips and salsa with your food. I am usually not crazy about chips but I really liked their salsa! I ended up eating it in my burrito and then eating just enough chips afterwards to make sure I finished it off. 
6. Bottom line foodwise: I had a marinated tofu burrito with black beans, wheat tortilla and cheese and guac. Melty cheese + somewhat crispy/soft wheat tortilla = happy camper. 

The only thing I would have improved would be for Papalote to have a bigger space. They are so popular, it would be great if they had more room. But I will definitely be back!
author: Libbi K.

description: Papalote's ingredients bumped up the quality of their overall menu, but the flavor was completely lackluster. One thing that I was hoping to be the saving grace, their "acclaimed" chips and salsa, were bagged tortilla chips and a super salty, somewhat spicy tomato paste. The Mexican restaurants in the bay need to learn that fresh tortilla chips make all the difference, as does fresh salsa. When all other flavor is lacking, this might be the one saving entity. Unfortunately, there was nothing that would bring me back to Papalote.
author: Shannon F.

description: The best word for this place is Over-rated. I think they buy the veggie chorizo at the same stores I do so it bothered me that they charged so much for it. Uh and what Mexican place have you ever been to that charges for chips and  salsa? Puhlease!
author: Lucy W.

description: Always extra fresh and not entirely authentic, kind of like me. Very vegetarian friendly which is not like me.
author: patrick g.

description:
I'm always in search for good carne asada and fish tacos so I was very excited to try out Papalote per recommendation of my coworker, who I took to my Meet Me at the Taco Truck (aka El Castillito on Church) soiree.  

I was a bit miffed that tacos were not sold individually, but in twos.  You cannot get two different kinds for an order, even if they're the same price.  They are served in a white corn tortilla, with green lettuce (not iceberg) and fresh tomato salsa.  The cheapest would be rice and beans for $3 (I don't know why anyone would want that) to $5.95 for pescado... glorious fish sauteed in white wine and butter. 

You get your own bowl of freshly fried/toasted corn chips with a small bowl of spicy blended salsa.  Very good.  Their horchata was great to mute the capsaicin effects in my mouth.

I had the carne asada and pescado... so 4 tacos total (I gave away one carne asada to my coworker and just ate the fish filling of the 2nd pescado taco).  They store and get the fresh meats from these 4 small drawers underneath the grill... when they pull it out, they reminded me of those morgue drawers for da dead bodies.  I guess it's the same concept because the meats are from the dead bodies of the animals.  They even put a small scoop of salad on the side (chopped oranges with jicama, topped with a slice of radish), which was actually lovely.  I told them to hold the lettuce for my carne asada taco.. the beef chunks were a bit too big, but the meat quality was good and it was fairly seasoned, so it had some flavor.  The pescado taco they have here beats out Rubio's and El Castillito's.... which is a pretty big deal for me to say because I love the fish tacos at both locations... it's okay.. I just love Papalote's more.

My friends ordered the vegan soyrizo taco and a grilled veggie (zucchini and eggplant) quesadilla, to which she had them add some soyrizo..... that quesadilla was what secured the 4th star for this place.  I had a small bite of that fantastic and creative combination of roasted eggplant and zucchini... plus soyrizo.... plus the queso... ahhhh I wanted more but I had to finish my tacos.  =S

It's great that they have vegan and vegetarian options, the prices are very reasonable, and you can customize your orders to your taste.  They serve soda with a free refill, gringo cerveza (domestic and imported) as well as the Mexican kind.

(checkit.. it's nextdoor to a karaoke joint...but that's a whole 'nuther review)
author: Grace M.

description: No option for ZERO STARS!! I never had a chance to try the food, because I had my dog with me (carried him in).  Blondie with the bangs said they only serve customers with service dogs.  No big deal, I respect that and totally obliged.  When I asked her if I could place my order and wait for it outside, she said NO.  Papalote service sucks.  Come on Miguel.  Your front counter, lacking in customer service, most likely miserable because she hates her job, cashier sucks!  You can't even take an order for a customer who will wait outside??? Geez, McDonald's provides better customer service than blondie with the bangs.  I drove to the Mission and ordered the 15 burritos for a softball team that I would have ordered at Papalote.  You don't get a second chance, because of the poor first impression, and you have blondie with the bangs, to thank for that.
author: CynCub C.

description: This must be one of my favorite hang out spots. Healthy mexican food and of course the salsa. I'm so excited they will be featured on Food Network soon. Miguel and Victor are amazing brothers and they've always taken care of me. Their chefs and staff are very well trained and sooo efficient and hardworking. I love them.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
legit mission quality mexican. 

this is what tango 20 shouldve been. papalote is my gulity pleasure and my belly shows
author: desi d.

description: I think this place is pretty over-rated. The burritos are okay (really nothing worth raving about) and they're pretty stingy with their chips. No surprise in saying there are much better choices in the Mission. Or, if you're local to the area, Green Chile Kitchen is only a few blocks away.
author: Novi M.

description:
In passing this place and often seeing only "gringos" an no actual mexicans in this joint I knew it wouldnt be as authentic as the real mexican places. 

I didnt have any high expectations going to this place after a hard work out at the gym and was pretty hungry so I was game for anything. After hearing rave reviews about the chips and salsa I was looking forward to this. 

I ordered, carne asada tacos with all the fixins for additional .99. + Chips and salsa.

I've had many good tacos in my life and this one was a bit,well wierd.
All the ingrediants were really fresh and satisfying, but there was something about the actual tortilla that bothered me. It was neither hot nor cold, grilled nor straight soft and limp. It had this sort of tough doughy chewyness to it that I felt was wierd. The jicama in the taco was a nice touch, but can my little teeny weeny little thing of salsa get ANY and I say ANY smaller? WTF? + if you want more they charger you .50 for literally a tiny little metal cup which basically is the equivalent to a few tablespoons at the most. their salsa is not the traditional salsa, its almost creamy like. It is good, but at that rate you might as well as sell it for crack its so damn expensive. I mean come on, food cost to ratio is not even there. ridiculous! Service is good and food took a bit longer than usual and I left feeling good and full but not gross greasy full. After going home, I felt a bit like I was missing something.
The carne asada wasnt well seasoned, it could have used something else. All in all, i've had better, and would rather not come back to a faux mexican place when I have plenty of authenti places in the city to go to! DOnt waste your time finding parking and coming here!
author: Petri Y.

description: Sigh.  We walked across the street to Papalote for lunch today, and I must say the fare is unexciting.   It was nice to see Mexican soft drinks, though.  I ordered a burrito de carne asada and a non-alcoholic Sangria.  The Sangria was fun; it left a tangy aftertaste.  But I really question whether the Mexicans would buy anything non-alcoholic.  My date ordered chips & guacamole and mole chicken.  She preferred the Casa Sanchez from Albertsons!  Both of us left feeling the cooks could have done better.  It really isn't the Mission!
author: David D.

description: Parking (as with almost any SF place) is a pain in the behind.. and be careful where you park! They'll tow you in a heartbeat (speaking from experience). The salsa with chips (appetizer free with my meal) was delicious!! Pretty spicy.. but so yummy. I ordered the triple-threat burrito (4oz of chicken, 4oz of steak, and 4oz of shrimp.. I'm pretty sure those are the measurements) for $20.. I dunno.. I mean, the idea of it makes my mouth water.. but it wasn't all that and a bag of chips, if you know what I mean. The meat was all burnt (not in that crispy charred good way) and there was like NO other flavor to it.. just a bunch of burnt meat in a plain tortilla.. bummer. Thank goodness for the salsa to add at least a little flavor. Definitely NOT worth $20. Let's hope they were just having a bad day. It was packed.. seating is limited.. but the staff were extremely pleasant. I don't know that I'll go back.. but if you're in the neighborhood it might be worth checking out.. maybe they'll realize their potential by the time you stop by.
author: Cristen N.

description: Love the Adobo burrito and also the famous Papalote Salsa is like no other! I wish there was one in the East Bay. Hint Hint Mr. E! hahahah!  5 Stars!!
author: Oliver B.

description: Delicious chicken burritos (make sure you add sour cream & guac,) Chips and salsa have a kick and are addicting.  Typically a line, but goes quickly.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I've never really understood why San Franciscans get so fired up over which taqueria makes the best burrito -- yes, there are truly bad burritos, but aren't good burritos all roughly about the same? Ummm, no. Papalote changed the way I think about burritos with its perfect proportions of meat, beans and rice and its grilled tortillas. And the salsa, in all of its smooth chipotle perfection -- I wish I could put Papalote's salsa on everything I eat, which would probably involve bribing one of their workers to get the recipe until they start selling it by the pint (or half-gallon!).
author: Heather F.

description: When you have only 15 minutes between classes at USF, call for pickup and your meal will be low cost, quick and GOOD!!
author: J. K.

description:
WARNING: Please read this review before going to Papalote's. Worst restaurant experience ever.

I went last week for the first time expecting to love it. I'm a big fan of El Farolito (which I understand Papalote's is *not*), but I was prepared for something my friends described as a little "healthier" and "fresher."
