When we arrived, my boyfriend was seriously put off by the lack of carnitas, but I had heard good things about the carne asada. I had also heard that the black refried beans were fantastic, so even though I don't like beans, I ordered them on the side along with a super carne asada burrito.

My burrito arrived, poorly wrapped, dangerous close to a puddle of gooey, liquidly bean substance. I cleaned off any bean contamination and started eating. I soon found that there was no guacamole. I told the waiter, who was bring food for someone else in my party,  that I had ordered a super burrito but there was no guac (I think there was also no cheese & crema, other features of the super, but I wasn't sure). He asked for my check number to verify if I had indeed ordered a super burrito. I was part of a large party and although I remembered our check number "range" (17-22), I didn't remember my own number. I told him I'd ordered the beans on the side and he went to the kitchen to check the order. When he came back, he said they "needed to check." I thought he meant they needed *the* check, and I repeated that I didn't have it. He said no, they had to TAKE MY HALF-EATEN BURRITO BACK TO THE KITCHEN, to check if there was guacamole in it, because they DIDN'T BELIEVE ME. I was dumbfounded, as were the others in my party. We asked if he was serious; he was. But there was nothing I could do if I wanted guac, so I sent it back. 

When my burrito returned, it had been opened and poorly re-rolled, plopped down in the bean puddle, and a teaspoon of guac had been added to the side of the plate. I scraped the beans off the tortilla and finished eating because I was hungry, rationing my small bit of guac for the remaining meal. 

Needless to say, I will not be returning here. I have never had such a horrible experience in a restaurant in my entire life.

(And about the food: it was mediocre. Gordo's is even better, and El Farolito blows them all out of the water. And the beans were disgusting-- even for a bean dip, they should have been thicker, and more flavorful.)
author: Celine P.

description: A new burrito is a plump, happy thing.  An unwrapped, sent back burrito looks like a bloated, eviscerated animal.  In other words, this place is good -- if they manage to get your order right.  The achiote tofu is good, along with the mole, but every time I've been there they messed up my order, and I watched several other people bring back sad, unwrapped burritos with/without certain burrito elements. The staff seemed nice enough, but sometimes they had these confused looks of just being asked to show up and fill in for somebody else.
author: ed y.

description: I heart Papalote. Why do I love this place? The food is yummy. The price is reasonable. The service is quick AND friendly. The salsa is amazing. Plus, they care about vegetarians as shown by their very numerous veg- options, including soyrizo! The list goes on...   (Shout out to Jessica L. who happens to be my Papalote buddy!)
author: Kimi W.

description: This place is amazing.  For a vegetarian it can be heavenly.  They have a soyrizo burrito and a marinated tofu burrito.  These are not the same old beans and rice that you always find.  These burritos have SO many flavors!  The burritos are a little on the pricey side for a burrito but it is worth it!  I like to use the frequent customers card because after 10 items you get a free one.
author: Lauren B.

description: It's not too hard to please me when eating burritos or something because I am a usually a simple eater when it comes to Mexican, but this place really is the best. The food is cooked to order and they use healthy and fresh ingredients. I've never waited long and the service is great. I usually call ahead and pick up, and I have had no problems at all. The food is delicious!
author: Ian P.

description: After reading all the hype about this place, we went there on May 23rd and all I can say is that either the main cook was off that night, or the reviews are contrived, or the people doing them do not know what good tacos and borritos taste like!  Are you sure that this was the site of the Bobby Flay throwdown, the main reason we came? In all my travels around the U.S., this was the most tasteless food we have ever had without a doubt! The bean and cheese dip had hardly any cheese taste whatsoever, the chips were extremely thick and tasted like they were a few days old, the borritos were flat tasting as were the tacos. There are so many Mexican food restaurants in San Francisco that are very tasty, but this is definitely not one of them. They do not even have ice tea, as the drink selection is very limited. The only thing that was at least average was the salsa, but nothing to brag about. This is nothing but a below average neighborhood restaurant and my Mom and Dad were very, very disappointed after reading all the good reviews.
author: Finnegan M.

description: Soupy fish burrito made with sea bass.  And the famous salsa.  Mmmmmm.
author: Melanie C.

description:
as a graduate of USF, i'm no stranger to the weekly/bi-weekly/tri-weekly trips to papalotes. their food is consistently good and i SWEAR there is some kind of illicit substance in that salsa! 

i'm not a burrito gal.... in all honesty, i dont like biting into nondescript tortilla. i like to see and smell and know what im going to be eating before i taste. so there, that is my bias. 

that doesnt mean papalotes has nothing for me. it sure does. quesadilla, hand it here! i've had soyrizo-amazing, chile verde-just right, steak--consistently good, and my usual: chicken. 

as a SoCal native, i usually prefer some dirty taco truck or burrito stand to the fancy fixings of a place like papalotes, but i keep coming back for the quality and flavor!! Sure, taco trucks have their pluses like great grandma's secret spices.. but papalotes ALWAYS serves up a clean, well cooked piece of meat--and i'm pretty picky with fat/meat quality. they also have this salsa/chile sauce that is seriously craveworthy..... it's so good i bet your food will be drowning in it after first taste.
author: Sandy H.

description:
omggggg i am loving Papalote. i always respect restaurants that have a good mix of vegetarian & meat offerings (you don't have to be a super hippie all vegan zany restaurant to throw some tofu on the menu, man). Papalote definitely seems to have something for everyone. 

I sampled the marinated tofu burrito, which was super delicious.  as one who shies from dairy, i'm not normally a huge fan of burritos as it's difficult to get the flavors and textures just right without cheese and sour cream. however, papalote does a wonderful job. 

its proximity to GGP also makes it an ideal lunch destination for a sunny day. grab a burrito to go and coke in a glass bottle or even a tall can of pabst if you're into that (ok so i'm totally into that) and walk a few blocks to the park. flavorful, hearty burritos + beer + park on a nice day in the city is a combination that is near impossible to beat in its idyllic bliss.
author: Jessica C.

description: The only saving grace for this place is their grilled chicken. Had a prawn burrito earlier that was basically a veggie burrito outside of two bites. When calling in the order, I was placed on hold for 5 minutes, but could still hear chat going on that had nothing to do with taking an order. Disappointed and won't be back.
author: DJ M.

description: I love this place and it's become a staple in my weekly dinner routine. It's cheap and amazingly tasty food. The chips and salsa alone are worth the venture. I get something different every time I go there. Check it out you won't be disappointed.
author: Jessica S.

description: The salsa is awesome with the warm tortilla chips! Super Tofu Burrito is my fav! The place is small and cramped sometimes. A swarm of USF students are generally the cause of this problem. Despite that, this place is great. They do flavorful Mexican that doesn't make you feel sick and like you ate a ton of grease.
author: Sonya S.

description: Ummm yes, I ate this fantastic burrito after Bay to Breakers (see http://www.yelp.com/biz/bay-to-breakers-san-francisco if you need a point of reference), so no, I don't remember many details, but HELL YES it was delicious.  I know it was grilled, I know the salsa during our wait was amazing, and I know that I was a little skeptical because it wasn't as "hands on" with the choices as Chipotle and Qdoba (I was afraid I wasn't going to get everything I wanted!), but I also know that it exactly hit the spot.  Maybe from now on I can just ask for a Papalote's burrito when I go to one of those joints?
author: Diana K.

description: I'm truly not a huge fan of Mexican food unless I am in Mexico...where I find it to be fantastic. However because the ex loved it, I would have to eat it more often than I cared to. Now since we've split up, I find myself actually craving it far more often than I would have ever expected. Craving chilaquiles, I wandered into Papalote after picking up the dry-cleaning. It was a pleasant enough experience. While I liked the chilaquiles, and thought the service to be pleasant, I only wish they made the dish with green chiles, instead of red. Oh well. Satisfies the Mexican craving now and then....
author: Suepattra M.

description: The trick to the chicken taco at Papalote is to separate it immediately from   the conjoining taco and fold. You must eat this taco within 8 to 10 minutes of delivery. The pico de gallo is so fresh that the tomato juice will ruin your tortilla. Do not put sauce on this taco b/c this is a very delicate tortilla. You have a good four to five mouthfuls of taco on each one. Fresh lettuce, chicken and pico de gallo makes this one of the better tacos in the city. I don't stray to anything else on the menu b/c these tacos are so simple and delicious. The total for the meal is $4.91. Overall 5 stars b/c it is delicious and you don't spend a fortune.
author: John S.

description: I had a great lunch here, my bean and rice burrito was fresh and tasty. The whole toasting of the tortilla is always a nice touch.  However, it seems it gave my office pal unpleasant emissions. Currently, they are only coming out of her mouth, but it's still early...
author: Dixon T.

description: Chile Verde burrito was great, except I wanted more chile verde and wasn't that impressed with the tortilla, so next time I come I will get the chile verde plate instead.  The house salsa was awesome.  Came here on a Saturday night with a group which wasn't the best idea since there isn't much seating, but we were able to squeeze in at the counter and sit down.  A bottle of Mexican coca cola topped off the meal.  I'll be back for that chile verde.
author: kate m.

description: This is one of those baffling places that people love. Unauthentic, poorly made Mexican food with the rudest people in San Francisco working for them. I've lived in the neighborhood for six years, and stopped going here a couple years ago when green Chili moved in cuz they're nice and tastier than Papalote. But, in fairness, I tried it again today, and, a-mazing, the same rude woman is still there rudely taking orders. My quesadilla was soggy and had maybe a teaspoon of sour cream,. They get two stars cuz the salsa is good, but then again, so is Chevy's, so not mich of reason to go here. I'd avoid this place at all costs and go to Little Chihuahua or Green Chili, both of which are supreme to this severely overrated 'Mexican' food restaurant.
author: brant f.

description:
not as cheap as it should be. i realize its not in the mission, but the food is the same quality. lots of options but really not very impressive. dont like the salsa which is apparently a big part of everything. they do have breakfast all the time, but i dont like it very much. 

lackluster.
author: lissy d.

description: Papalote is one of the best Mexican restaurants in the city. Their homemade salsa is incredible (a side of it with chips comes with ever order and is also available for purchase in individual glass mason jars). I'd highly recommend the carne asada and grilled chicken quesadillas. Definitely make any item you get Super (they add guacamole, sour cream, cheese). Sometimes the line is long at busy meal times, but it's well worth the wait for a delicious, freshly made entree from Papalote!
author: Maggie C.

description:
i think their salsa deserves 5 starts on its own... i almost wanted to drink it it was so good! and then i learned that you can purchase a jar of it! and yes, i purchased the jar and pretty much put it on everything (eggs, cracker/cheese/salami, etc). 

going to come back to try the burritos. i had the pork and carne asada tacos and it was so yum (of course i doused it in salsa). i'll be coming back for the salsa refill...
author: Lucy C.

description:
Oh yeahh, the best refried black beans, ever. And the smokey RED SALSA is about the best in town. But I have to say my favorite thing about Papalote is their frequent burrito card, buy 10 and get one free. The best way to give back to your customers!  
  And did I mention the jammin Soyrizo¿!
author: Vince B.

description: Salsa is to die for, but I ordered the shrimp burrito and was disappointed.  I only got 4 small shrimp in the burrito and they were very dry.  I would stick to the carnitas or carne asada.
author: Colleen B.

description: Typically 2nd locations drop off in quality and service, but not at the Papalote on Fulton.  I actually like this location better, it's bigger, less seating, but parking is easier with the garage and lot across the street.  It's good to have decent Mexican food here in this part of San Francisco.  Don't forget to get yourself a jar of their Salsa to take home.  That stuff is good!!!  Favorite is the of-course the Triple Threat Burrito.  (Chicken, Beef,  and Shrimp)
author: Jason A.

description: Sometimes I find myself looking out my living room window (I live across the street) just to see if the neon 'OPEN' sign is lit up. Even when I'm not hungry. Maybe I just like knowing there are hot vegan burritos a stones throw away if I ever want 'em. Totally delish, cheap, and fresh tasting. And of course, their salsa is killer. Love calling them to put an order in and running across the street 10 minutes later in my jammies to pick up food. And then right after to Lucky's to get a 6-pack of Mexican beer.
author: JJ W.

description: Some friends took me here. I was a little concerned not getting a burrito in the mission. It was packed with USF kids (go to 24th st location to cure both these problems). Got a tofu burrito. Quite amazing actually. Couldn't eat the whole thing. Wouldn't be my first choice for a burrito, but worth it. Want to go back to try to soyrizo
author: Scott L.

description:
Of course, this place has been full of hype since the throw down, and I wasn't disappointed when I finally tried it. The burrito I had was fresh and tasty. And I'd be lying if I said it wasn't heavy, but the heaviness wasn't due to being over greasy. It was a satisfied and full kind of heavy. That's what a huge burrito is supposed to do. Saved half and ate it the next day for lunch. So for decent price of 1 burrito, you get 2 satisfactory meals if you are not a large portion eater. 

1 star off for the grouchy young blond at the counter who refused to smile and just pointed at the box when I asked her if I could have a piece of foil.
author: m. e.

description:
This place is seriously deadly to my diet. I love it, can't get enough of it. It's on my speed-dial for goodness sakes.

Even the basic rice and bean burrito (believe me, make it a super) can cure the deadliest of hangovers. 

The Soyrizo Burrito? I could die happy.. 

Thank you Papalote. Thank you.
author: Heather H.

description: Perhaps I have been spoiled by Mission taquerias, but this didn't quite measure up. Almost, but not quite.
author: Hunni B.

description: I was gonna give this place four stars since it's no awesomely fat-monster coma inducing Mission burrito (along the lines of El Farolito).  But then I realized that you can't really rank the two in the same category.  Papalote isn't your average taqueria.  It's surprisingly clean and fresh and the staff is always really friendly.  There are a lot of vegetarian/vegan choices, including vegan refried black beans, soyrizo, and my personal favorite--marinated tofu that's just as good as the chicken, both grilled to order.  The unique and spicy salsa here rules.  Everything costs about a dollar more than anything in the Mission, but you don't have to head all the way out there if you're near the Panhandle.  I will continue to eat here three times a week...
author: jess l.

description:
I really liked this place. Me-n-Mama were shopping at Albertson's .....oops! Lucky, and we decided to go have a snack at Papalote because my Mama heard good thangs about it!
Love referrals!!!!!!!!!!!!
So we just got some carne asada tacos and they were F*ckin Yummy which is just below F*ckin Awesome. So they were pretty good.
I can't wait to go back and have a burrito.
What I liked most about them was that they weren't your typical taqueria with buckets of mystery meat behind the window, they cook your carne or pollo or whatever the hell you order, RIGHT there nice and fresh and juicy and hoTTT. That's what I'm talking about people!
I hope they do that all the time - actually, they must because it got pretty busy and the line was out the door and our tacos were taking hella long - but, there is forgiveness in my heart for someone who is grilling me fresh meat!
So, you should try Papalote - for real - for real - I'm going back to have a burrito. 
P.S. I saw someone order the prawn taco - only two prawns per taco. The prawns were grilled. They also had a shrimp taco, so maybe they are more generous with the shrimp. The shrimp are sauteed in white wine and butter.

P.S. Again. Everything tasted so FRESH, but still flavorful - cuz you know I ain't on that healthy hype. But the food was filling and it didn't feel like 6 lbs of Mexico in your tummy :)
author: Tianna R.

description: This is a five-star americanized Mexican burrito restaurant.  It is responsible for what is quite possibly the best burrito I've had in SF.  And I've had a lot of burritos on my search for perfection.  My first taste of Papalote was the chile verde burrito.  I can't wait to try a different one.
author: Chad W.

description: Home of the $10 burrito! This is place good. Just as good as Panchos on Geary or any other burrito place in SF that isn't horrible but way too expensive. Not sure where they get off charging $10 for a burrito but luckily we live in the best city in the world and there are many other options. I'll be coming back here never. Oh I have $10 but it's still BS to charge $10 for a burrito in SF.
author: Andrew M.

description:
So, I'll just go ahead and admit it. I'm a pretty simple girl. I like pretty dresses. My favorite food is fish. I LOVE my husband, I truly believe honesty is the best policy and that we should all practice random acts of kindness. We should all believe in love above all things (and love whoever we want to love without judgment) and we should all be nice to each other. There's really no need to cut in front of people in line at the grocery store or cut people off in traffic just because you think your destination is more important than someone else's. There's no need to wash your hands in the restaurant bathroom and then throw your used paper towels on the floor instead of the garbage can and there is certainly no need to put chewing gum in someone else's plants. So let's all be nicer to each other okay? Because, before we all go out to the park and gather around our "Loving Circle", hold hands, and sing "He's Got the Whole World . . ." let me tell you of my latest experience at Papalote. 
 I was hungry. It was lunch time. Burritos are good. Somehow, burritos have gotten expensive, however. I was in line at Papalote and I was craving their prawn burrito. I wanted to make my burrito a super but as I was searching through my pockets, I realized that I might not have enough cash on me. I dug deep and found $8.25. That should be enough, right? If there was no tax, I was golden. Before ordering the burrito, I wanted to be sure I had enough so I asked the woman behind the counter what the price of the super prawn burrito would be. She told me it would be $8.61. My face fell a little but I had to giggle and mention I didn't have enough for that but I would choose something else. Then, the girl in line in front of me turns to me and says, 
 "I have some extra change if you'd like." She smiled sweetly at me and started digging through her purse. I had never seen this girl in my life and she was offering her change to me! I was touched but I felt a bit embarrassed about accepting money from a stranger for my lunch so I thanked her and assured her that while I appreciated the offer, I could totally choose an alternate burrito. Then, the woman behind the counter asks me how much money I have. Again, I'm a bit embarrassed but I confess to having only $8.25. I then try to assure her that I'm all right with modifying my order. Then she  gives me a big ol smile and says. "It's okay. For you, it's okay. $8.25 is enough."  Since, unfortunately, I find it rare that people do actually perform random acts of kindness, I was a bit surprised and even a little more embarrassed. I didn't want to be causing trouble but here I have these two total strangers offering me help with my lunch. I giggle nervously again and thank them both again but (a little weakly) try to insist that it's all right. The girl in line smiles at me again and says, "Between us, we're going to make sure you get that prawn burrito that you want!" We all share a laugh and I finally accept the offer to pay $8.25 for the burrito that should have cost $8.61. 
 Now, I do realize that it was only a $.36 difference, but to have those women offering me their help was super cool. It made me feel happy and it was such a simple gesture. They were just nice because they wanted to be nice. I like nice people. We all should be nicer people. It makes a difference. 

And that is my story. Warm and fuzzy. Rated G. Fun for the whole family.
author: Nuvia C.

description: I share my neighbors glee over the demise of Tango 20 and the rebirth of a new mexican place in it's stead. I was encouraged upon walking in for the first time last weekend by the fact that the people who work and eat there are actually hispanic. Then the prices--so much cheaper for what turned out to be so much more food than Tango 20. And breakfast--my fav meal--all day. Rock. on. The neighborhood is saved. Now for the old Fulton Street bar space...
author: Gretchen T.

description: I am sad to admit that I did not enjoy the chicken mole (it was less "mole" and more "colorado," if you ask me), but if they would bottle that salsa I'd consider bathing in it except that would be wasteful so instead I'd just have to eat it on everything.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Hungry. Exit house, walk across street, buy tasty, fresh, easy on the dirty burrito. Done and done.
author: Erica R.

description: Came here on a visit to Golden Gate Park. Sprang for the carne asada super burrito. It was just ok and on the small side for being called "super". Picked up the tab for my buddy, so two burritos and two beers was almost $30. Seems kinda high for me, but maybe that is normal for San Fran.
author: Ben R.

description: Hands down my favorite burrito in all of SF. Cheesy, chewy, perfectly grilled, warm all the way through to the last bite, clean ingredients with good internal distribution, awesomely marinated chicken, and salsa that is unbeatable. This place is a gem.
author: Ron S.

description: We recently planned a day trip to San Francisco and decided to give the less touristy restaurants a try.  I looked up vegetarian friendly restaurants and Papalote came up in the results.  The website certainly made it seem like it was delicious! We love Mexican food, especially taqueria style places, so this seemed like a good place to go.  We were really impressed that we could still eat fairly healthy here.  My friend and I ordered the Grilled Veggie burrito, "Super" style (which adds guacamole, sour cream and cheese for 99 cents).  He ordered his with the standard flour tortilla and I got mine with the whole wheat tortilla and substituted the refried beans with the whole black beans.  I hadn't had a burrito that delicious in ages! The way the flavors all meshed together was excellent! My girlfriend ordered the Pollo Burrito, Super style with the whole wheat tortilla and whole black beans as well, and it, too, was the bomb.com! Not to mention the chips and salsa were soooooo good! We definitely will be coming back again!
author: Heather G.

description: A nice, quick, and inexpensive spot for Mexican food.  The work of local artists is usually on display in the seating area.  The refried black beans are unique and delicious, and I love their salsa.  Unfortunately, the chips are stale at times. . .
author: Rajeev S.

description: This is my favorite mex place in the city. Everything is organic and pretty fresh. My only complaint  (like someone else mentioned) is the prices are high and I have to add a lot of stuff to the regular order to get everything I want!
author: Artemis R.

description: This place wholly earns its glowing Zagat rating. One pays almost nothing at this oddly located Mission institution... and gets SO MUCH. I dream of this place. I dream of their shrimp burritos and chicken mole. On my next visit I shall make a beeline from SFO directly to Papalote. Oh golly! How can everything here be so good?!?!?
author: M M.

description: Best salsa ever!! Anything else I eat here is just a means to get that salsa in to my mouth! I don't know what's in it but it's magically good.
author: Kristin S.

description: While hanging out in the NoPa area, I finally had a chance to see what Papalote was all about. Hip-hop and local indie show posters on the windows and groovy ambiance like OM Records, I knew this place was as hip as folks described it. If you know your DJs, you'll find a treat... The "Triple Threat Burrito" brought to you by Apollo, Vinroc, and Shortkut- representing prawns, beef, and chicken. It's $15, but man... it's a serious threat for stomachs and wallets. Try it one time though! Papalote has a terrific tangy salsa as well to compliment your chips and entrees. This is not your average Mexican grill- so prices are a bit up there, but the food and service are fresh to def. On my next visit, I'll just groove to something lighter.
author: Leroid D.

description: I'll pretty much eat mole sauce on anything and Papalote makes it far too easy.  It's right across the street from my house, the prices are good, the service is fast, and it's delicious.  I don't even like burritos but last night I downed an entire chicken mole burrito in one sitting.  It's a damn good thing I just started marathon training or I'd be gaining serious pounds here.
author: Katie S.

description: THIS IS MY FAVORITE RESTURANT EVER! It's sooo good highly recommended. Chicken super burrito is the BEST
author: Barbie W.

description: Vegan black refried beans + cheese + pollo may sound like a confused burrito, but it's clear to me - - - All we need is a margarita joint & i'm living in the Mission Nueva!
author: Nicole L.

description:
very. good. burritos.

[i wasn't so sold on the salsa, though, but i'll get to that in a minute]

i'll be completely honest and say that i didn't come into this place with very high expectations. i'd been used to, well, everything i'd been used to, and have never found a balance of all the essential elements of a burrito- that being beans, rice, meat, cheese, salsa, guacamole and the tortilla itself [i'm not much into sour cream].

that is, until now.

while other taquerias have certain strengths and weaknesses in the areas i mentioned, papalote delivers a very well-rounded burrito. 

first, there's the tortilla. 75% of burritos i've ever eaten in san francisco have a soft tortilla, bordering on gummy, which gets stuck behind your teeth. only papalote and taqueria reina [behind BMWSF] offer a dry, almost flaky tortilla which doesn't get in the way of the ingredients.

the ingredients, as expected, are all good and fresh like every other place, but here's where the carne asada makes a difference- it's actually grilled in front of you, sliced up, then grilled again. the difference in taste is very, very noticeable. i'll never have another run-of-the-mill ground beef burrito again.

but every place has its weaknesses

one is very obvious: they charge you an extra buck to use a credit card if you spend less than $10. what the hell for? most burritos are pretty cheap [even here] and bought as meals for an individual, meaning less than $10. 

personally, i hate carrying around cash, so instead of walking to the nearest bank of america ATM [way up the hill next to the USF bookstore] or being charged two damned dollars to use the WaMu/Wells Fargo ATM's across the street, i'll just have to absorb the dollar penalty.

[but seriously, excuse the shit out of me if i don't require myself to spend $10 or more every time i feel like a burrito. we're in san francisco where people care about their health. want the local population of cheese-chugging fatties to meet the minimum charge? move to dallas.]

last of all, there's the salsa, which is often touted as the best in san francisco. i'll admit that it's good, but i prefer the chunkier stuff from casa sanchez [ah, let the flaming begin...]. i'm just not comfortable with the salsa being a homogeneous liquid. it's deep flesh-tone doesn't help either.

in short, come here for the burritos, bring cash if you're not a fatass, stay away from the salsa, and definitely order the carne asada. it's well worth it.
author: Charles C.

description:
what a difference actually eating here makes!

my friends that live near here all rave about it.  awesome chicken mole, salsa, and on and on.  i totally agree about the salsa, is why i had originally given this place 5 stars.  but that was until i ate here...

was up in sf a couple of weeks ago.  and we finally made a trip here.  we ordered the asada tacos and chicken mole.  both terrible.  i couldnt believe it!  after all my friends' raving.  after all the positive yelp reviews.  stunned!

i stopped eating, and we walked down the street to el farolito to salvage this trip up to mission.  thank god for el farolito.
author: jing c.

description: The best burritos ever!  If you are like me and want a hint of Mexican grill flavor but not the heavy grease and starchiness of the full Mexican food experience this is were you need to go.  Anything with their grill steak is awesome as with the homemade salsa that is smokey and creamy.  The lunch hour is crazy with USF and St. Mary's hospital nearby. I took my boss there for lunch (yup cheap date!) and he had to say that it is even better than Gordo's burritos and had two entrees!   Also, parking is not validated if you park at Lucky's so be prepared to buy something there too if  you want to take advantage of that convenience.
author: Anne L.

description: A solid Taqueria, and I love the fact that it is within walking distance to my apartment.  Bonus points for that.  The burritos are just as god as in the Mission location, and the salsa and chips are the bomb as well.  A good, solid, Taqueria in the Western Addition.  Reprazent.
author: Francis K.

description:
Just as so many people who live in the City, I consider myself something of an authoritarian on burrito spots.  Papalote on Fulton has established itself in my mind as a great little spot.  The carne asada burritos are killer, as well as the pollo, and shrimp.   
   I always describe Papalote to my friends who have never been, that it's sort of "gourmet" burritos( But let's be honest, $7 for a good burritos isn't that bad). They're a bit smaller, and come on plates with a fork and a knife.  Now I'm a purist and feel that eating a burrito with a knife and fork would be too civilized, but I'm not judging those of you who prefer a little refinement in your burrito world.
   The main thing that keeps me coming back to this spot, is by far the salsa.  It's got some sun-dried, chipotle some-such that they never give you enough of, and it always leaves to wanting more. Damn you Papalote for your crack infused salsa, and the cravings for more that it gives me!  Enough said.  It's a good spot that I'll be frequenting regularly as long as I'm in the city.
author: Nathan C.

description: yummy and close to my home..love the shrimp burritos and their salsa is excellent. Also very fast and friendly. Often crowded but you can order form home and pick up and avoid the hipster rush. Thank you for quality food in a hurry.
author: Valerie S.

description:
i quit smoking about a month ago and tried to sneak a puff of a friend's cigarette after throwing back a few. (you kind of need it)...  but before i could take a decent hit, i was slapped in the face with the SCALLOP burrito that I BOUGHT my boyfriend from here (it was still bagged). now that's love... i guess.

i don't know how it tasted, but it sure was a strong burrito.
author: Renae C.

description: So glad this is here in NoPa! Fresh ingredients, staff know how to cook.
author: Dale D.

description: not bad but is not mexican food, burritos and tacos with lechuga? I saw the zagat sign at the door and i think it doesn't deserve it.
author: Gerardo P.

description:
I never really craved a burrito before. Now I do.

Well, that and their salsa.

I don't really get the concept of burrito nirvana. To me, it feels like a very functional shape and format for delivering a mix of chunky meat, beans, rice, etc.. Except when it's leaking, of course. So, if engineered correctly, I think burritos can be very good, but not like... great. 

But I admit to craving that smell of grilled chicken and prawns, although I longed for some real tastier mexican queso inside.

I also tried the huevos. So glad to have access to another good breakfast option nearby.

Papalote is also super clean, and I like their name and paper kite theme. I am just glad
author: Sherwin L.

description:
Burritos too small.  Non-descript vegetable flavor.  Far too expensive.  Significant sanitation issues.  Sanitizing liquid does not make a dirty towel clean.
The great salsa is the high point of the visit.  Shouldn't that be embarrassing?
FIX THE DOOR. Wake up to your own business' shortcomings.
author: Mark B.

description: P-lote is good, but it only gets 3 star from me. Not for the food - because the burritos are awesome - but because they can be kind of stingy, so I'm going to be stingy with the number of stars the get. One of my major pet peeves is when I order two separate burritos, they only give you chips for one if you get it to go or eat in. However, if you make two separate phone calls, you'll get chips for two. They should give enough chips for the number of people eating. The staff is also kinda of angry all the time. But its ok p-lote, I'll still keep coming.
author: Jenica M.

description: it was great but i have had better burritos in the Mission.  I am very happy that they did win the challenge with Bobby Flay as I do not think it compares.  Bobby should focus on other things not trying to compete with Papalote.  Do think that the quality of food is great and they sure have nice service.  Do wish them success.
author: Santi S.

description: Sometimes I dream about the salsa at Papalote. I dunno what they put in that stuff, but wow. If you buy a jar of it to take home, you can bring it back for cheap refills. My fave burrito is the chorizo breakfast one with eggs. Don't forget to drink plenty of water after you eat one, though, or you'll be freaking parched an hour or so later.
author: amanda a.

description:
The best burritos in town! I really can't express how good the burritos are here. The carne asada is flavorful and tender - which is a huge challenge at some mexican restaurants.  
We always get the burritos with carne asada - fully loaded!  They are just amazing! No matter how many other mexican places we try - we always come back to Papalote!
Try it - its worth it!
author: Caroline K.

description: Awesome. Two Papalote's in one city. I have to say, it's pretty good, but not as strong as it's Mission brother. I was kind of annoyed by the space when we first came in here before a Yelp Elite event. People standing in line who shouldn't be, nobody really paying attention to us, and a confusing ordering system. Thankfully the confusion didn't last long and I ordered up some fish tacos and a horchata. The fish tacos, although not the best I've ever had, still fresh and piping hot. The horchata was somewhat of a disappointment, but the chips and roasted red tomato salsa made it worth it. Oh good lord it's so delicious.
author: Michael E.

description: A good post-Albertson's stop for healthy Mexican food. The carne asada is top notch. I used to adore the Horchata drink, but the last time I had one I ended up with stomach cramps so my love of the Horchata has been deeply shattered.
author: Jen O.

description:
It's time to kiss the diet good-bye and tearfully embrace the existence of the perfect burrito, heretofore thought to be extinct. And it's two blocks from my house. I'm going to get soooo fat. 

The chili verde was wonderful. The "super" ingredients flavorful and well blended. The salsa was delcious. I can't wait to go back and try the nachos. And the carne asada. And the chilaquiles. And everything else. 

Right around the corner, that's where my new favorite taqueria stays. Yes!
author: Sage R.

description: As a transplanted San Diegan, I'm pretty picky about my mexican food (ie: I hate most of the mexican food up here). Papalote gets my seal of approval for the kick as burrito I inhaled the other day - definitely the best I've had outside San Diego.  And Papalote gets extra props for being so veggie friendly.
author: Cindy R.

description: WOW.  The carne asada super burrito with refried black beans topped with that awesome salsa was a TASTE SENSATION!  I ate it lukewarm and it was still fantastic!!!  I will try the pork in chile verde next...
author: Mitzi C.

description: Mmmmmmmm......spicy soyrizzo burrito. 'Nuf said.
author: Lisa A.

description: Oh Papalote...I want to give you five stars. You do make large cheap delicious burritos however without fail everytime I ingest one of those carbohydrateheaven burritos I end up with awful indigestion. The yummy black beans and perfectly cooked chicken make me want to say YES YES but unfortunately the following sharp pains in my stomach yield a 3 stars.
author: Tam G.

description: As a Native San Franciscan, I'd like to think of myself as a burrito connoisseur ... but I digress ... anyway, if you're looking for an authentic SF Mission-style burrito, you've come to the wrong place.  If you're looking for that guilt-less, non-greasy, healthy-tasting burrito made by Latinos, you've come to the right place.  Look, I moved in before this place popped up in the Panhan, and before that, I lived around the corner from its original location on 24th, so I know this burrito (taco, nachos, etc.) quite well.  I admit, I like it.  But as a Mexican-American, I have to admit that it is not what I am craving after an 8-hour shift.  But what has me coming back each time?  The damn pico de gallo, and the fact that I order chicken tacos or a chicken burrito and not feel the grease for 24 hours.  It is damn tasty, but like I said, not authentic.
author: Gina G.

description: Best burritos in SF my scrote.  The place is unwelcoming, the staff is rude and the food is anything but authentic.  Guess why all the taquerias in the Mission do it the same way?  Cuz it's good that way and it works!
author: Frankie D.

description:
So i know that i piss them off every time i come in with my weird order. But i dont care, and they never say anything they just look at me strange...but this is a burrito place not a 5* upscale place so who the hell cares. Here it is, dont laugh...I told my friends, they think its picky but then they tried it and at least a dozen of them always order it.
Chicken mole burrito
no rice
spinach tortilla
black beans
add Hickima( normally they give this as a garnish which is chunks of this with spices on it, PUT it in the burrito man, this is amazing)
 Also they give you salsa but i always buy it, they have jars for $7, but it isnt anything you could get at Luckys accross the street. i dont know what the hell is in it but its the best salsa i have ever had in my life. 
PLUS: meat is grilled..not greasy, healthier options, clean and nice decor inside. i dont feel as guilty eating a burrito when i eat here!
author: melissa c.

description: Great burrito, everything is super fresh and high quality.  The only knock that I have on this place is that it's hard to find parking.   Other than that, Papalote is the best burrito in town
author: Chris D.

description: I have enjoyed a good many meals at their Mission District location, but for some reason the food at the Fulton Street store has not brought me back more than the requisite couple of times. Maybe it's because it comes out cold. Don't write it off, though. Go down to 24th and Valencia where the owner (?) will greet you himself.
author: Jabe N.

description: The ONLY place I recommend to anyone. The grilled chicken burritos are beyond amazing.  The salsa is completely unique and absolutely delicious.  My favorite!  I probably eat here at least once a week.
author: Katie H.

description:
so i used to think that papalote's burritos were a little overpriced, and just so-so, but that is because i wasn't eating the GRILLED VEGGIE NACHOS or the GRILLED ZUCCHINI AND EGGPLANT BURRITO made "SUPER" for 99cents, with pickled JALAPENOS SLICED ON TOP and STRAWBERRY JUICE.

unfortunately they are very stingy with the AMAZING SALSA, which is so so good and spicy, but in their favor they have pretty pleasant service, and the bussers are always very friendly.
author: Renee L.

description: I go for the burrito.  I have to get extra meat (3.00 ) though since the portion of meat is very small.  If you get guacamole its extra(.99) as well.  So my burrito usually comes to around 12 dollars.  is it worth it?  I dont know... Great salsa though..
author: Mike V.

description:
Simply Amazing. 
Constantly Reviewed as one of the best burritos the city has to offer. 
This isnt a lie

The house salsa is oh so good. I wish they sold it separately.  

Carne Asada Super Burrito w double meat = Crack.

5stars. Nasafast
author: Cam K.

description: $20 for a burrito? Don't visit this restaurant for the Triple Threat. They are obviously not interested in clientele other than their local customers. We visited as we were finishing up a two day trip to SF.. Every eating surface was covered in crumbs and spills from previous customers. The staff was very unfriendly, as we were clearly not locals. They laughed at us and sarcastically thanked us as we left. The burrito was Ok, possibly worth $8, certainly not $20. I have had much better burritos for $5. Don't waste your time on this place. The order of chips and salsa - a bowl with 7-10 chips and a bunch of crumbs at the bottom. The bathroom was disgustingly filthy.
author: Steve O.

description: This place makes an awesome burrito, and more.  This seems to be the new neighborhood for REALLY GOOD FOOD with some of my everyday favorites including Papalote, Green Chile Kitchen, NOPA, Tortilla Heights (since crispy nick's influence) and so much more all in close proximity.  Papalote is perhaps the most economical of my favorites, but it is still of course a few pesos more than a taco truck or an average mission district taqueria. Check out Papalote soon!
author: P H I L H.

description: Went there last weekend and it was delicious.  I had a steak super burrito and it couldn't have hit the spot more.  There MAY be better burritos in SF, but I can't complain at all about Papalote.  MMMM....
author: Ben L.

description: What a rip-off!  Ordered the Triple Threat Burrito just because of  the Throwdown episode.  I was shocked to find out that it was in the $20 range.  Never seen or heard of a burrito that was so expensive.  I asked the clerk how come it's so expensive and she told me that it is quite big and they use it for a lot of the eating competitions that they have.  Thinkng it was going to be ginormous, i thought it will also provide me  for my lunch the following day.  When I got home and took it out, it is the same size as a regular burrito from the Mission.  What a RIP-OFF.  Do they feel that they need to screw the public for their 15 minutes of fame.  The filling was tasty but a bit dry.  Certain to say that I will never be back...just left a sick feeling in me and that is not what I expected when I go out to eat.  What a shame!
author: Tokyokid G.

description: The triple threat totally isn't worth $20!!!  The chicken and the carne asada were both extremely dry.  I expected alot more for $20, it's the same size as any ordinary burrito.  And you have to pay extra to make it a super!  I definitely wouldn't get it again, probably wouldn't even go back
author: Denise C.

description: meh, i've had better. certainly overpriced, have to say that the salsa may be good but it's not making $15 burrito and drink lunch worth it. burritos shouldn't try to claim gourmet. keep it fresh, simple and reasonably priced Thanks!
author: eric m.

description: OK- this is no el farolito or cancun.  this is the white man's burrito joint.  my usual test is if there are people of that ethnicity eating at an ethnic restaurant, and there are no mexicans here, except for behind the counter.  there's no carnitas, or tongue or hard core meat stuff like that.   i'm usually a stickler for authenticity, but for some reason, i love this place!  the tofu burritos are very tasty, and fish tacos are great as well.  however, i think what really keeps me coming back is the house salsa.   this location is new, and very clean.   it's easy, yummy, and i think it's fairly healthy.
author: Liz C.

description:
so i heard alot about this place and finally last night got to have the Carne Asade Burrito with there infamous salsa. It was pretty damn good. It hits the spot. You get major food coma ...that's for sure. I was so excited that they had HORCHATA!!! I always try it at every Mexican rest/joint and its always been disappointing. 
BUT this Place made it right! OMG i guzzled it down  and with every slurp i swished it around my mouth to savor the taste!
author: JK K.

description:
i could eat their salsa with a spoon.
it's that good.
they have whole wheat tortillas, if you're silly like me.

very veg friendly, as has been mentioned before, which make me oh-so-happy, but when i got a chicken burrito for my mom one time, i noticed that they grill the meat fresh for each burrito instead of it sitting on the hot-line for who knows how long. nice.
have i mentioned i could eat their salsa like gazpacho?
and thier prices are cheap.
i get a basic rice and bean burrito which keeps me happy for hours and hours, for the cool price of only 3.25.
if i want to feel really fat i'll get it super ( with cheese AND sour cream AND guacamole) for 99 cents more.
yes.
and you can call them when you're on you're way over and they will make it and have it ready for you.
mmmmm.  
all the other taquerias in the neighborhood are crap compared to papalote. believe me, i've tried them all...
author: Melody O.

description: Actually quite good food even if it seems way Americanized. They have good quality ingredients. I usually order the carne asada quesadilla, but I've had nibbles of the butter shrimp and it was pretty darn tasty! Better in a quesadilla than in a burrito though. I've never eaten inside of the restaurant because it is so small, but it's a good place to go and grab a quick bite to go if you live closeby. Parking is probably going to be an issue if you can't walk there, but if you plan on also buying some groceries, you can take advantage of the parking lot at the Lucky's supermarket across the street, and get your parking validated after buying your burrito and then groceries.
author: Jade L.

description: Erm... the taco truck near my work place tastes better than this
author: Jane H.

description: Solidly "good" burritos. I still prefer Green Chile Kitchen, though. Cool place to stop into if you're already closeby, but not a destination.
author: David R.

description:
the burrito was a 3.  not bad, not great, just a decent burrito.

the chips and salsa are excellent.  too bad they give you 17 chips, and a small gig of salsa (ie not enough to pour on your burrito).  and for more salsa its 55c a pop.

but nonetheless i'd come back for just chips and salsa at the very least.
author: Jason J.

description: OK, I was sucked in by the Throwdown, and ordered a Triple Threat burrito without looking at the price. Caveat emptor. No burrito is worth $20, and another 1$ for guac, sour cream and cheese.  I found the other items to be acceptable, but no better than other places.  After my Triple Ripoff burrito, I won't be going back.
author: Doug D.

description: Went with my wife after seeing them wine in the throwdown.   Waited in a long line to order (not surprising since soon after air date) but then took another 30 min to get served.  Burrito was ok but for $20 was expecting a lot more.   i know there are better burritos out there at half the price.
author: David G.

description:
I have a confession. I secretly kiss my burrito before taking the first bite. 

Normally, I go to Papalote in the Mission, but I was able to try the Fulton Street location and found it equally delicious and kinda fun to watch the big scoopin' kitchen action through the clear glass window. Good thing they have that glass shield. I suffer from poor impulse control so staring down the little packages of the world's most amazing salsa was tempting me something wicked. Luckily, I was able to look up at the TeeVee and watchBreakin' 2 The Electric Boogaloo while I waited. This distracted me for a short minute until the package of love was delivered to my greedy paws. Incredible veggie options. Soyrizo? I'm not a fan of that stuff but I appreciate the options. Sometimes the marinated tofu feels a little too salty for me, but I think I might just be salt sensitive. The rice n' bean burrito is a steal at $3.25. I need to add guac, cuz I'm piggy like that, (they charge an extra buck) but still, for under $5, you can't find a better eatery.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: my friend introduced me to this spot today and i loved it.  We got the chicken burrito with black beans and it was very good.  The chicken and tortilla was cooked perfectly.  This place is kinda small with not much sitting room.  I'll be back if i crave any mexican.
author: Hugh L.

description: Every taqueria does something best.  I prefer Papalote's tacos over their burrito.  All of their seafood, mole (both chicken and tofu), salsa and the black beans are the standouts for me here.  Guac is very avacado-y (not so gloopy).  The food is lighter than at a lot of taquerias.
author: Stefan A.

description: This used to be a pretty good burrito place. Fair prices, fresh food, reasonable service.  Not great, but very good.  No longer - for the THIRD TIME I did not get what I ordered.  Paid for a super- got  regular (to go of course) Paid for chicken with whole black beans got refried (to go of course) Paid for six got five (had to drive back on that one)  The prices are way toohigh 10.00 for a veggie buritto-come on- and too consistently not get one's order.  My daughter has also stopped going there.  Either they don't care as much anymore or it's race related.  In any case my advice find another place.  I want to give minus one star but am forced to give one by the program.
author: d m.

description:
i work two streets up from fulton on hayes, and papalote gets me through a power lunch when i don't have time to walk to the haight.

nachos - gigantic. the strictly veggie one can be sort of a trip if you are not accustomed to stuff like zucchini, but it's pretty cool.

dinner plates - expensive, not worth it if you want more food for your buck.

chicken mole burrito - the best of the burritos, with black beans and NOT super (which includes sour cream, and really, fucking with mole with something dairy is not kind). this is by far my favorite to get.

salsa - crack. spicy and tangy orange-colored.

tacos/quesadillas - prob cheaper at taqueria cancun, but hey.

the place toutes out its vegan/veggie slant a lot, which i suspect is a lot of where the business goes, and though i admit hating to spend money here because i know it's more expensive than most mission taq's i've been to, papalote is pretty damn tasty.

they also do "frequent burrito" cards, where every time you get a burrito you can get a stamp and your 11th burrito is free. chicken mole burrito, i'm coming to you, i swear...

plus, fun fact: "papalote" means "kite" in spanish, which makes so much sense if you have been inside and seen the crazy kites suspended from the ceiling.
author: Jenz y.

description: Pretty sure this is the best burrito in the bay area.  Vegan black refried beans.  Incredible salsa and great vegetarian options.
author: Narendra R.

description: First off, let me explain the one star rating. I have been a loyal Papalote customer since its opening during my early years of college. Along with my best friend, I would frequent Papalote on a weekly basis. We walked into the restaurant earlier this week, ordered our usual dishes, and were surprised when the employee at the register informed us that the prices had increased. Although surprised, because we had recalled a recent price increase, we didn't question the news until we realized that the increase wasn't just a minor one. I went from paying roughly $8.75 for a chicken burrito super to slightly over $10 (close to a 15% increase). Upon questioning, the employee's initial response was that the nearby lounge, one store down, was closing? OK, sad, but I never went there and didn't exactly frequent it on a regular basis. Back to the point,  I'm still not exactly sure what relevance that had to my initial question. We continued to ask the reasoning behind the sudden price increase when another employee informed us that their meat supplier had increased their prices, and that that we should keep in mind that the ingredients served are "organic." Although we understand that the cost of living, working, and maintaining a profitable business in SF is higher than most areas, paying over $10 for just a burrito is insane. (Especially since recently we have been getting about 7 chips in each bag with our orders, but thats another issue). If you add a drink to this or even pick up the tab for a friend/significant other, you're out $25 easily. To sum it up: Papalote went from being an awesome Mexican restaurant at an expensive (for mexican food), but reasonable price, to an overpriced, very recently overstaffed Mexican restaurant. Same food, same service, much higher prices (less chips too, remember). I'll miss this place, but am certainly on the hunt to find the next best Mexican place with reasonable pricing.
author: Sean S.

description: I'm biased as I live barely a block away, but I absolutely love this place!  It's already tough to find a vegan mole sauce in most of the city, but to have one paired with tofu and done so well is phenomenal!  I also love the soyrizo tacos - great if you don't have room for a burrito, but want more than a salad.
author: Matthew S.

description: This place is fair at best. Far from the best taqueria food I've ever had (Taqueria La Bamba in Mountain View) by the way. I had a carne asada burrito, it was dry and tasteless. Tried the carne asada nachos, there was hardly any meat on the tortilla chips. The pollo chicken burrito was tasteless also. Overall in the neighborhood, the Green Chile Cafe is better.
author: Greg M.

description: Best burritos I've ever had, hands down. You'd be fooling yourself not to go. Should note their veggie and vegan options are grand.
author: Rubin S.

description:
quality ingredients. 

fish tacos and the chicken burrito are my favorite.

Plus the rice and beans are purely vegetarian.
author: Scott B.

description: Had the Carne Asada burrito.  Couldn't even taste the carne asada as they put so much refried beans in it that the beans dominated the taste of the entire burrito.  Their salsa is good, but beware they charge 55 cents for extra salsa in case the little cup of salsa they give you with the chips wasn't enough.  Burrito is also way overpriced.  I prefer The Little Chihuahua a few blocks away on Divis.
author: Mike C.

description: $8.30 for a chicken burrito??? Are you serious? I didn't even get a super, just a regular chicken burrito. Also, I called the order in, the woman said it would be ten minutes. I got there in ten minutes paid my $8.30 and waited another ten minutes for it. Finally I walked up and asked if my order was done and it had been sitting behind her the entire time. If I hadn't asked it would have never come out at all. So I ate a cold, over priced burrito. This is also a gringo spot, any of the places La Taqueria, La Cumbre, Pancho Villa, all of them are hella better than this place...
author: John S.

description:
best vegan burrito ever!  really.  i can't give a great review of this place because i always get the same thing--the grilled tofu burrito with vegan refried black beans.  it is so good.  i can barely finish it but i do somehow.  plus the salsa is so delicious i've actually drank it before.  go here now if you want amazing grilled tofu.  which everyone does.

edit!  i now get the PINTO beans!  so you see, everyone can make changes.  plus i've brought a few other friends here for objective opinions and they agree that it is the best burrito in town.  unfortunately, this makes me unable to enjoy any other burritos in town.  but that's okay, as we frequent papalotes at least once every 10 days.
author: kate s.

description: Papa-LOTT'es is a great place to get a solid vegan burrito for a bank load of money. I'll hand it to them. They make a killer soyrizo and tofu mole. Until I found papalote, I had no idea such dreams were possible, But now since I took out a bank loan, I can afford to get the $10 nachos with soyrizo added. They covet that salsa like its going to cure cancer. Probably because its fucking good and shit. In a nutshell: good eats, long wait and empty pockets. And yes, another restaurant that offers vegan options and then asks you if you want it "Super" which adds cheese, sour cream and probably beef, who knows. Come on folks, its not a hard concept. Fucking burrito bastards. See you again next week.
author: Go Cat Go G.

description: Food is great but parking is sometimes hard to find near the restaurant. Pretty inexpensive but not to much of a seating area for parties of 3 or more. Persons working the register are not friendly at all and seem to hate life but other than that great!
author: Edward M.

description: the time hath come for me. I too, am officially smitten with their trademark salsa. I only have one word at this point. DELIVERY.
author: Miss W.

description: OMG I love this place. Yeah, the prices are a just a little higher than your average taqueria, but the quality rocks. One of the only places in SF to get chilaquiles......mmmmmmmmmmmm. And the salsa? OMG. The new crack!
author: Cake M.

description:
Oh here go hell come...


GUACALA!!! No, not guacamole but "guacala," more like the Spanish (maybe just Mexican) way to express dissatisfaction with taste or appearance, or selection, or any dissatisfaction. In this case, FOR IT ALL. 

Being a USF alum I  am no stranger to Papalote, It had just been a really long time I had stopped by and my tastebuds had no recollection of what fu(k£r¥ was yet to come my way disguised as a burrito. 

Let's go ahead and start off with first impressions: SUCIO! Sue-C-OH. This place was dirtier than my old freshman dorm room in Phelan building at USF. My lover and I walked in to this carbon monoxide haven and found  Two "gueras" (blonde haired women) burrito order takers  gossiping and seemed to care less about who over heard. One did stop while we placed the order, the other continued. 
 
On to the food...

The famous salsa they were once known for is no longer. It is now the tomato soup concoction they sell in jars as Salsa. The jar stuff NEVER tasted like the real thing so I guess they now just serve their jar stuff. Hot mess in a jar, and not in a good way, but a bad way like a "hot tranny mess". No self respecting Mexicano would consider this an alternative for anything. 

Papalote (kite), I want to cut your string and let the wind take you faaaaaar away to Chard-Dry Land! Your burritos are flavor-less. What did I end up eating!? A char burrito? The chicken was dryer than a cup of sand from the Sahara desert in drought season and burnt that all i tasted was the taste of burnt chicken. No flavor, no seasoning, nothing. Just charbroiled nothingness in my burrito. Could of well been a charbroiled piece of carboard!!!  Your pinche tortilla was more like a tostada, crunchy and toasted, learn from other places an steam them!. The beans, well the beans were pinto and unappetizing, they needed some salt. Y la salsa bandera? (pico de gallo) was soggy and once again, with no flavor. It was more like chopped up old tomato and wilted cilantro. The guacamole? well I'd rather not go there but GUACALA, I have to!!! Was the guacamole in my burrito from a 5 pound tub being sold at costco? Because it sured as hell tasted like it! I was truly repulsed  that this place exists. Pictures look yummy, but your taste buds and tummy will think your a dummy for eating here.
 I was truly repulsed by my lack of motivation to seek other dining options that night.  
That's all.
author: Dre X.

description: This is one of my favourite burrito joints ever - they have this amazing vegan mole with tofu burrito - it's heavenly.  I also love their fish tacos and their horchata is so refreshing.  While it's a little pricy for a burrito, it's more than worth it because you can tell they run a clean kitchen, use fine ingredients and care about the atmosphere.
author: Mahogany G.

description: My week has just been made. As said above my guy and I normally trekk across town to grub on some Soyrizo Burrito's in the Mission. I cannot believe that heaven is now just a few blocks away from my place. The Western Addition is seriously becoming the best place in the city.
author: K B.

description: My boyfriend and I ate there last week and he was raving about his combination (everything) burrito...I got the prawns taco which I thought was great but a little skimpy on the prawns (2 prawns per taco and a lot of lettuce)...the flavors were great though and they brought a second bowl of chips and salsa for us when we asked...the staff there is really friendly and we had a great dinner for a great price...
author: Kira B.

description: Yummmmmmm......yummalicious....this place is stoner approved. Too bad I live so far from this place otherwise I would be up in this mug everyday makin myself a health heiffer.  Chicken burrito from papalote: I'll make that a hell yeah!!!!!
author: Marie B.

description:
Delicious burritos. Forget about chipotle(mcdonalds). Papalote has good quality ingredients and fast service.
If you're looking for greasy authentic mexican food, this is not the place. 
Burritos come with free chips and special orange salsa. Very Addicting spot...
author: John c.

description: I'm so biased, but it's still my favorite salsa in the city!!!  Organic, so well priced, and the owners are awesome.  The music is made by one of the brothers that owns the joint and happens to also be an awesome DJ in the city.  Try the fish tacos with a little of the special salsa!  You will thank me later
author: Sasha S.

description: I wish I could give this place a F*** Yeah for moving in!  I used to travel across town to the mission for the best fish tacos and mole in town.  Last week when i got the fortune cookie that read "something wonderful is about to happen to you" I didn't know it was being rewarded with a Papalote walkable from my house.  Oh yeah, I'm dancing!
author: Chard M.

description: Man!  What is that special sauce made out of??  Definitely recommend this place.
author: JC R.

description: I like their prawn burrito. I'll get it to go, walk over to George's Market on Central and Hayes and buy a giant Tecate for two bucks, then go home, sit in front of the tv with some lime and salt, eat, drink, then nap. The salsa they give with the chips is good but the girl with the sharpie-drawn on eyebrows and lips scares me.
author: Hunter G.

description:
it is gravely unclear to me why in this college neighborhood (where i reside) there are, like, 2 places to eat.

what. the. f.

where i went to school, there were at least 3 places to get pizza, two sammy joints, random ethnic spots, and mo'. in the vicinity of this school, there is papalote.

so yah, i guess its good. whatever. 

the salsa is not salsa, but it is tasty. the burritos are strange, but they are tasty. and soy-rizo, your name makes me giggle.

in a take what you can get neighborhood, papalote is king!!
author: shaine h.

description: Yum.  I think I like Papalote better than Gordo.  Refried vegan black beans.  Cheese.  Guacamole.  Grilled tortilla (as opposed to steamed; I like grilled better).  Good chips and unique salsa.  Yum.
author: Laura B.

description: I had to be different and ordered from the breakfast menu - lo and behold i wasn't impressed. When I received the dish, huevos con chorizo kind of looks like vomit on a plate. Evenly divided up in fourths there's refried beans, rice, huevos/chorizo and bright green lettuce all accompanied by a side of tortillas. The entire dish was taste-less. NO amount of hot sauce could revive this dish. One thing i did like was the salsa, you must try it. The consistency is much different than the normal pico de gallo type salsas. Next time, if there's a next time, i'll try the burritos like everyone raves about. Boy did i order the wrong thing.
author: BrYan W.

description: I've NEVER had a bad burrito here!! The ingredients are always fresh and so yummy! The soyrizo burrito is EVERYTHING to me! Plus... the hot sauce!!! I buy it by the jar now.
author: Angel P.

description:
My main problem with Papalote is that the veggie burritos just aren't gooey enough.  I prefer La Taqueria and Taqueria Cancun.  But there are some nice things about this place: 1) seating -- makes it feel like more of a restaurant than other places in the Mission; 2) cleanliness; 3) nice chips and salsa; and 4) the menu options are more creative than some other taco shops.

It is not the kind of place that I crave after I've had too much to drink, but is often perfect for that late afternoon weekend meal when you know you'll be going out and don't want to be crazy full.  I don't care for the fish tacos -- to me they can't compare to what you get in Hawaii.

Bottom Line: Not the best, but you can do far worse for Mexican.
author: L G.

description: For the past 2 years, or however long this location's been open, I've been telling my wife after finishing a burrito that, "I should really post a review on Yelp about how they never mess up our order whether we phone it in or eat it there. Even when we add and/or substitute 2-3 different things on 2 different burritos.  Or how the hot sauce they serve with the chips is awesome.  Or how all of their meat is made to order (except for the chile verde) and not sitting in a tub.  Or how they have the best refried black beans ever. Or how they show cool old cartoons and movies like the Pink Panther or Breakin'. Or if I'm not in the mood for a burrito then a I get fish tacos, where the fish is sauteed in a wine-butter sauce and not deep fried.  Ok, I think I'll write that reivew today."
author: Sean M.

description: I love this place. It's down the street from me and I call in my order and then I pick it up and then I sit down and then I turn on the t.v. and then I eat my burrito and it is good but it is filling.  That salsa melts my brain. I majored in Spanish in college so I easily know more about burritos than anyone and I put this place on the top of my list. SoCal has better burritos though. I mean why can't I find a California burrito anywhere in the city? We are still in California aren't we? (I didn't major in geography). I would recommend the chorizo and egg burrito for  breakfast and the chicken quesadilla for dinner or the mole or chili verde burritos. And you have to get everything Super or you are an r tard.
author: John C.

description: All I can say is that Paplote is one of my most favorite places to eat in SF. I love the food, friendly employees, bright decor-- I wish we had one in the 707! So many good things about this place keep me coming back for more. One, the salsa is BOMB. Best salsa, hands down! Two, if you're health conscious at all, it's one of the healthiest places to go for Mexican food--the tofu burrito satisfies your burrito craving without making you feel like you're gonna have a heart attack right after eating it. I love all the burritos, period! And three, the owner, Miguel aka DJ. MR.E is one of the most hospitable & humble business owners you'll meet (plus, he's Hip Hop). I'm sure you know him if you're a regular and if not--you will meet him cause he's always there.  If you haven't tried it yet, gooooo!! And if you live in SF and are a regular, I envy you!!
author: Cel C.

description:
Adequate, unremarkable food. This place only gets business because of its brilliant location and the number of customers it gets who aren't quite sure what really amazing Mexican food tastes like. The cooks are friendly but the front staff are rude and brusque even after a year of occasionally eating here. 

I say walk to two extra blocks to Baker and eat at the much superior Green Chile Kitchen.
author: C R.

description:
You're way off base if you act all righteous about the authenticity of a burrito at Papalote. Look, it's NOT El Farolito. It's not even trying to be El Farolito. Is that not obvious by the snappy sign outside, the fact that it has a color scheme inside, and the availability of vegetarian soyrizo on the menu? Take a hint or three. It's a California-healthy take on Mexican fast food. And for that, I think it's really good. 

What's more, I love the mole burrito. I guess I'm just not a mole elitist like some of the mole aficionados who've left scathing mole reviews.  And yeah, you can slap a whole wheat tortilla on that, shove in some black beans, brown rice, and leave out the cheese, because that's what I was expecting here. For Cal-Mexican fast food that tastes good and is near my house, I like Papalote. I'm not ashamed.
author: Mich L.

description: The veggie burrito has mushrooms, carrots and potatoes. Smother that with their salsa and I'm good to go for the rest of the day.
author: Jake G.

description: Good burritos but the staff could use some customer service training.
author: Stewart D.

description: The only reason I give this place 2 stars and not just one is because their salsa is probably the best in san francisco.  Salsa is absolutely key in a good mexican restaurant and papalotes is the best.  Having said that they are the most overpriced mexican restaurant ever I think I spent like 9 dollars on a steak burrito.  And notice I said steak burrito not carnitas.  This because they DONT SERVE CARNITAS. Isnt that unbelievable what mexican restaurant doesnt offer carnitas I mean really though.  I walked in there and was beside myself when I saw that I almost walked out but I was too starving and was with a group of people.  I mean really no carnitas and the steak was average at best and for the price no way Dont go there unless you want to buy their salsa by the gallon.
author: christian l.

description: My bro took me here claiming it was amazing... it seems like he eats at the Mission location daily.  Maybe I'm spoiled living in the Mexican-food-friendly state of Arizona, but surely there must be much better and more authentic in San Francisco.  The nachos w/ chicken were uninteresting to say the least.  I tried his veggie burrito --- healthy but nothing special.  The salsa was anything but spectacular.  Is Papalote an acquired taste or is there something I'm missing?  Maybe I'll give it another try next time I'm up but for now 3 stars is pretty darn generous.
author: Josh D.

description:
Ah, Papalote II, at last we meet...

During my last jaunt to SFO (cool kids call cities by their airport code), I, of course, had a burrito at Papalote. BUT! Instead of going there a second time, we instead ventured to....Papalote _II_!!!!

This review is mainly a comparison to the original Papalote. So consider this as almost an addendum to my review of the original location.

We stopped by P2 (as I will hereby refer to it as) on the way to the Kabuki. Partly because it was closer than P1, but also to find out how the two places stack up. Well, fret not, because P2's food is just as good! For the sake of science, I ordered the same meal that i consumed less than 24 hours earlier. Chicken mole super burrito and a Coke. Well the burrito was spot-on, in typical Papalote fashion, even if they were a little stingier than normal with the jicama side-garnish-stuff. My dining compatriots were no less satisfied than I was with P2's relative quality. The one area I feel that P2 falls short of P1 is in the size & layout of the restaurant. There are maybe three tall tables crowded together in the front, and the only other seating is a long counter opposite the the kitchen/ordering area. So the place is definitely more suited for take-out or solo dining, rather than eating with friends. I do feel however, that it is located in a nicer area than P1, so we'll call it a wash.

Fret not, fans, Papalote's second location stays on par with the original.
author: Matt C.

description: Conveniently located down the street from the University of San Francisco. The chips and their salsa are hella good. Burritos are good but not spectacular. One thing I don't like is that if you want guacamole, it comes with fresh diced tomatoes. I'm not really a fan of fresh tomatoes. So if I don't want tomatoes, I can't have guacamole. Papalote should offer plain guacamole as an option. They also have a TRIPLE THREAT BURRITO which is ~$13. I have yet to try it but one day will but for now thats quite expensive.
author: MIKE D.

description: I just don't get the love.  I've tried several burritos here and they were all just okay.  3 stars because it's 'round the corner from my house.
author: Rachel N.

description: That smokey salsa is what keeps me coming back.  I'm a big fan of the shrimp burrito.  Kudos to Papalote to investing in this neighborhood.  It was a good move.  The eating arrangement is a bit awkward, but that may be because it's always seemingly packed.  Nevertheless, the staff is efficient and friendly.  Bonus that they seem to regularly (and quietly) play breakdancing movies/videos on the overhead TV.
author: Ben C.

description: 2 words: SALSA NAZI's!!!!!! No salsa for u!!..  My only complaint bout this place.. Why must u tease us with your narcotic like salsa and only give us a medicine cup's worth..
author: Carlo M.

description: I am a picky eater, so I have only eaten one thing off of their menu, which is the chicken quesadilla, but it is the bomb! I also love the spiciness (sp?) of their salsa that you get with the pre-meal chips, which are yummy as well. I live just a block away, so I frequent this place a lot, and I'm glad that I do. The staff is great, friendly, and always having a good time, and the food has yet to disappoint.
author: Danielle S.

description: Carne Asada Burritos as big as your head, well not quite. But certainly bigger and better than the oh so often mispronounced Chipotle. The brown salsa was really good as well, but tastes strangely familar to Rubio's.
author: Rob H.

description: Good selection and I liked the fish burrito. During busy times you don't really get to relax with your meal, they politely insisted we should move along barely after we finished our last bites. Kind of a rushed experience. It gets 4 stars instead of 3 because of the guac and the creamy salsa. Maybe takeout is a better way to go when there's a line out the door.
author: Arun C.

description:
i could eat a burrito every day for the rest of my life and be happy.  i seriously could. and i'm well on my way. 

***** 5 stars for their guacamole.
***** 5 stars for their salsa.
***** 5 stars for having not just one kind of yummy black beans, but two (whole and refried).
***** 5 stars for making their refried black beans vegan.

you know it's good when something as simple as a black bean, rice and guacamole burrito is mmm-mmm-good.

umm, yeah - i give it 5 stars.
author: cynthia q.

description:
first off, i'm glad to have a couple burrito options in north panhandle. 

here's what i like about papalote: they use great meat (and chicken breasts, not misc chicken parts), the salsa is good, the line can be long but it moves pretty quickly, and the jar of jalapenos in the back by the water. oh, and they've got a diverse menu too.

here's what i don't like: it feels like a chain. they nickel and dime you (who charges for extra salsa?!). 

but on the whole, it's a good place, and considering i live a block from it, i'm happy!
author: Sidney B.

description:
restaurant 3 out of 50

this place is hella good.  the chicken is grilled nicely and they chop it up right before putting it into your burrito.  the outsdide of the burrito is nicely toasted.  and best of all, the salsa is hella good.  oh, and they have refried black beans... aww yeah!!
author: vlad k.

description: Many of my close friends love this place.  It's definitely fresh mexican food which isn't always easy to find.  And people love the salsa, which i think is okay.  But it's the best Mexican food in the area by far.  It's definitely a popular place for people in the neighborhood and clean, colorful and bright.  To sum it up it's good Mexican but not the best.
author: Jessica C.

description: fresh,fresh,fresh and yummy. So far I have tried their chicken mole quesadilia, their carne asada burrito and their chile verde pork tacos and all three were delicious!!! best burritos I have had and the mole sauce was great. They have different kinds of tortillas as well, such as tomato or spinach tortilla. The meats there are superb and very clean. Highly recommended.
author: Chris D.

description:
Great bang for the buck: $3.25 for a rice and bean burrito. Hearty and perhaps even mildly healthy Mexican food; at least, it's not as greasy as the other burrito joints in the neighborhood.

The highlight of every meal for me is the fire-roasted salsa, rich and smoky--truly exceptional. Smother everything with it, and it will make everything better.

The shrimp here are also very tasty, marinated in lime juice and very slightly charred. Highly recommended.
author: Tim B.

description: All I'm going to say is vegan tofu mole.  mmmm.....
author: Liz B.
